Though these two lines conclude the discussion of the three men’s skills, their meaning is vast, for the three men’s skills serve as metaphors for the disputes over right and wrong in the world—they are not merely about the three men. *Huayi* means "indistinct and unclear." Confusion that breeds doubt appears bright but is not truly illuminating. *Yao* means "brightness." The sage’s mind does not cling to traces, so what it perceives is as if present, as if absent. To refrain from use and lodge it in the ordinary—this is called "illumination."

The term *tu* means "desire," indicating that what the sage desires is precisely this. Thus, to set aside "this" without employing it and lodge it in the ordinary—this is called "illumination."

From *"Since things are never without their opposites"* down to *"not one, not inexhaustible,"* the meaning of "illumination" is explained. From *"Using a finger to illustrate a finger"* down to *"one attains it and nearly grasps it,"* the meaning of *"relying on this"* is further clarified. Then, returning directly to this point, the text concludes with *"this is called 'illumination,'"* its structure rising and falling, shifting and transforming, yet its guiding principles remain distinct. I have often said that the *Qi Wu Lun* is but a single continuous text—examining its phrasing closely reveals its vital pulse.

Now, suppose I make a statement here: I do not know whether it belongs to the same category as "this" or not. Whether it belongs or does not belong, if both are considered as belonging to the same category, then it differs in no way from that. This passage arises from the phrase *"not employing this,"* hence the question: *"Does it belong to the same category as this, or not?"* This is the vital pulse of its phrasing. Earlier, it said, *"Words are not the blowing of the wind,"* and now, shifting its opening, it exclaims, *"Now, suppose I make a statement here"*—this, too, is the vital pulse connecting its beginning and end.

When the similar and the dissimilar are viewed from each other’s perspective, one sees that similarity and dissimilarity are themselves alike. The meaning is this: if you regard it as me and me as it, you will see that I and it are the same. Thus, it says, *"it differs in no way from that"*—this is the meaning of *"using a finger to illustrate a finger"* and *"using a horse to illustrate a horse."*

Yet, let me try to speak of it. There is a beginning; there is that which precedes the beginning; there is that which precedes even that which precedes the beginning. There is being; there is non-being; there is that which precedes non-being; there is that which precedes even that which precedes non-being. Suddenly, there is being and non-being, yet I do not know which of the two—being or non-being—is truly being or non-being. Now, I have already made a statement, yet I do not know whether what I have called it is truly a statement or not.

Just as Zhuangzi’s prose takes a turn at *"Yet,"* his words are marvelous. His meaning is this: though there is neither right nor wrong, let us still speak of it—hence, *"let me try to speak of it."* *"Beginning"* refers to the Supreme Ultimate; *"that which precedes the beginning"* refers to the Limitless; *"that which precedes even that which precedes the beginning"* is yet another layer beyond the Limitless. *"There is being"* refers to the arising of things, which must begin from non-being. Thus, *"there is non-being"*—and above *"non-being"* is *"that which precedes non-being,"* another layer beyond the Limitless. The *Liezi* speaks of the Great Simplicity, the Great Pristine, and the Great Beginning—this is the same idea. Originally, there was no being; not only was there no being, there was not even non-being. Suddenly, there was non-being, and from it arose being. Tracing this back reveals the meaning: in the beginning, there was originally nothing. Only with the emergence of the self did things and the self arise; only with things and the self did right and wrong appear. The general idea is no more than this, yet its exposition is truly lofty and wondrous.

Here, it should say, *"Suddenly, there is being,"* but instead, it says, *"Suddenly, there is being and non-being"*—this is where the brushwork attains its subtlety. Though this *"non-being"* has arisen, can it truly be called non-being? Thus, it says, *"I do not know which of the two—being or non-being—is truly being or non-being."* Though this *"non-being"* remains unknowable, once it is called *"non-being,"* it has already acquired the name of being and non-being. Thus, it says, *"Now, I have already made a statement."* Yet, though I have spoken these words—*"statement"* here meaning *"words"*—I do not know whether these words can truly be called being or non-being. This is akin to the passage on the fledgling’s cry.

The sage judges but does not debate. The *Spring and Autumn Annals* records the intentions of the former kings who ordered the world—the sage debates but does not argue. Thus, where there is division, there is also non-division; where there is argument, there is also non-argument. One asks: Why? The sage cherishes it within, while the multitude debates it to display to one another. Thus, it says: *"Where there is argument, there is also non-perception."*

Having already spoken of self and other, right and wrong, these few lines introduce yet another layer of meaning, revealing the boundless subtlety and freedom within this elder’s mind. Beyond the six directions lies the realm beyond heaven and earth—this is what is meant by *"preserving without discussing,"* akin to the Buddhist notion of the four directions and above and below being beyond conception. Within the six directions lies the realm of the cosmos, where countless principles exist. The sage does not refrain from speaking of them, yet he does not establish rigid debates to impose understanding upon the world. The *Spring and Autumn Annals* is the name of a historical record—this line refers to the fact that wherever there is ruler and subject, high and low, all that appears in the annals reflects the intentions of the former kings in ordering the world. How could the sage fail to establish such debates? Yet when has he ever contended with the world over right and wrong? For the principles of the world, silence is the highest speech; the moment one engages in division and debate, it reveals that one’s own understanding is not yet thorough. Thus, it says: *"Where there is division, there is also non-division; where there is argument, there is also non-argument."*

Here, it once more raises the question: *"Why?"* *"Cherishing it within"* means *"withdrawing and concealing in secrecy."* The sage, in this regard, rolls it up and cherishes it within, while the multitude, in this regard, must debate and clarify it to boast and display to one another. The moment there is division and debate, it is a sign of lacking insight—thus, it says, *"there is also non-perception."*

The great Dao is not named; great debate does not speak; great benevolence is not benevolent; great integrity is not modest; great courage is not aggressive. When the Dao is made manifest, it is no longer the Dao; when words are debated, they fall short; when benevolence is constant, it does not achieve; when integrity is pure, it is not trustworthy; when courage is aggressive, it does not succeed. These five, though round, nearly tend toward the square.

Thus, to know where to halt in what one does not know—this is perfection. Who understands the debate of no-words, the Dao of no-Dao? If one can grasp this, it is called the Celestial Treasury. Pour into it without filling, draw from it without exhausting, yet know not whence it comes—this is called "preserving the light."

That which has an opposite is called a name, but the great Dao has no opposite. Within wordlessness lies the most profound speech, hence it is said, "great debate does not speak." Only when no trace of benevolence remains does it become great benevolence.

"Modesty" (嗛) means fullness; monkeys hide things by stuffing their cheeks. If one takes contentment as integrity, there arises the intent of self-satisfaction. The *Guoyu* states: "The virtue of self-restraint is insufficient to achieve greatness," for it remains small. Thus, whether one is modest for fear of others knowing or for fear of others not knowing, neither attains great integrity.

"Not aggressive" (不忮) means no trace of courage is seen in its use. Having expounded these five phrases, the text further elucidates them in turn.

"Manifest" (昭) means clarity; the Dao cannot be designated by name. If it is made manifest and named, it is no longer the Dao—hence it is said, "to give form to the Dao through debate is to reveal where one’s insight falls short." "Constant" (常) refers to visible progress; if there are visible traces, it is not the full realization of benevolence. Integrity that reaches the point of self-purification lacks sincerity, for "purity" (清) implies the intent of self-cleansing. "Trustworthiness" (信) means authenticity. Courage that manifests in aggression must lose its true courage.

The term "round" (圆) signifies wholeness, indicating that the five qualities above are all complete and perfect, for their essence is undifferentiated and whole. If the slightest trace appears, they verge upon the angularity of square things—meaning they acquire edges and corners.

"Approaching" (几) means drawing near. The word "toward" (向) shares the same sense as "in" (於). The true knowledge of all under heaven must culminate in knowing as not-knowing, and there it finds its ultimate limit. This "not-knowing knowledge" is the debate that transcends words, the Way that transcends the Dao. If one can grasp this, one may perceive where the principles of heaven converge. Thus it is said: "This is called the Heavenly Treasury." The Heavenly Treasury is the convergence of heavenly principle. Where heavenly principle converges, one may seek to augment it yet cannot add to it—hence it is said, "Pour into it and it is not filled." One may seek to diminish it yet cannot take from it—hence it is said, "Draw from it and it is not depleted." The subtlety of the supreme principle knows no end and no beginning, thus it is said, "One knows not whence it comes."

"Preserved radiance" (葆光) is the glow of elusive doubt. "Preserved" (葆) means concealed. Concealing one’s light without revealing it is called "preserved radiance." Thus, in ancient times, Yao asked Shun: "I wish to attack Zong, Kuai, and Xu’ao, yet when I sit facing south, I feel unsettled. What is the reason?" Shun replied: "Those three rulers still dwell among the brambles and mugwort. Why should you feel unsettled?" The word "thus" (故) at the beginning of the next passage serves to connect it to the foregoing as supporting evidence. The matter of Zong, Kuai, and Xu’ao is not recorded in the classics—it is merely an allegory. "Unsettled" means displeased. "Among the brambles and mugwort" is a metaphor for being obscured by worldly desires and unaware of heaven and earth. It means that those three states, self-obscured by desire, have not yet turned toward transformation, and if I feel displeasure at this, then self and other are set in opposition. The tale of the ten suns appearing together is also found in the *Huainanzi*. This is likely a parable of Zhuangzi’s, which the *Huainanzi* later embellished. It says that the sun illuminates all things without exception—how much more should my virtue, surpassing the sun, be able to embrace these three rulers? This meaning alludes to the opposition of self and other, right and wrong, and why the sage truly does not debate: he illuminates all with heaven. The parable of the ten suns is thus akin to the analogy of "illuminating with clarity."

Nie Que asked Wang Ni: "Do you know what things share in common as right?" Wang Ni replied: "How would I know?" "Do you know what you do not know?" "How would I know?" "Then do things lack knowledge?" "How would I know?" "Nevertheless, let me try to speak of it. How do I know that what I call knowing is not not-knowing? How do I know that what I call not-knowing is not knowing?" This passage arises from the earlier theme of "knowing to halt at what one does not know," and is drawn from the preceding discussion of "right." Thus the entire essay is but a single continuous text. Nie Que’s question about "what is shared as right" and Wang Ni’s response of "not knowing" both exemplify knowing to halt at what one does not know. Yet the invention of such names and the spirited elaboration are what make this the work of Zhuangzi. Though he says, "How would I know?" he then adds, "Nevertheless, let me try to speak of it"—these are the subtle turns of his art. "What I call knowing is not not-knowing; what I call not-knowing is not knowing"—these two lines brilliantly develop the idea of knowing to halt at what one does not know. His meaning is that not-knowing is true knowledge. "Now, let me put this question to you."

People who sleep in dampness suffer from lower back pain and partial paralysis—are eels any different? Those who dwell in trees are filled with dread and trembling—are gibbons any different? Which of these three knows the proper dwelling? People eat the flesh of livestock, deer feed on grass, centipedes relish snakes, and owls and crows delight in mice—of these four, which knows the true flavor? Gibbons mate with *bianju* apes, elk couple with deer, and loaches swim with fish. Mao Qiang and Lady Li are considered beauties by humans, yet fish plunge deep at the sight of them, birds take flight, and deer bolt away—of these four, which knows the true countenance of the world?

From my perspective, the distinctions of benevolence and righteousness, the paths of right and wrong, are but a tangled, chaotic snarl. How could I discern their distinctions?

Now, the question I once posed to you was but an opening remark. Loaches are at ease in water, gibbons in trees—how could humans dwell there? Each is content in what it finds contentment, yet none can bear what it finds unbearable. Thus, none of the three truly knows the proper dwelling. How, then, can humans claim superiority over gibbons or loaches?

*Chu* refers to the food of plants and trees; *huan*, to the taste of meat. *Jian* is grass; *dai*, snakes. Deer feed on grass, centipedes on snakes, owls and crows on mice, while humans eat the flesh of livestock. Their preferences for what is sweet and savory all differ—so which of the four knows the true flavor? *Bianju* is a kind of ape. Gibbons mate with apes, elk with deer (both being of the same kind), and loaches with fish (not two separate creatures). Following this analogy of male and female, the text turns to Mao Qiang and Lady Li, saying: those who take pleasure in beauty—how do they differ from birds and fish? My view of apes and deer is no different from theirs of me. Yet of these four, which knows the true countenance of the world?

*Jue* means fierce; *zhou*, swift. These three sections all serve as metaphors for the distinctions between right and wrong, self and other. Thus, the passage concludes: from my perspective, the divisions of benevolence and righteousness, the debates over right and wrong, are but a confused and muddled tangle—just like the differing perceptions of dwelling, flavor, and beauty. How, then, could one possibly distinguish them?

Nie Que said: "If you do not know benefit and harm, does the Perfected Person likewise not know benefit and harm?"
Wang Ni replied: "The Perfected Person is divine. Though great marshes burn, they cannot be made hot; though the Milky Way freezes, they cannot be made cold; though thunder splits mountains and winds shake the seas, they cannot be startled. Such a one rides the clouds and qi, mounts the sun and moon, and roams beyond the four seas. Life and death bring no change to them—how much less the distinctions of benefit and harm?"

Wang Ni is the Perfected Person. "Divine" describes one who subtly permeates the myriad things without leaving a trace. Unaffected by heat, cold, or shock, their mind wanders in the beginning of the formless. Even the great matter of life and death does not move their heart—how much less benefit, harm, right, or wrong? This line serves as a plain and solid conclusion.

Ju Quezi asked Chang Wuzi: "I have heard from the Master that the sage does not engage in worldly affairs, does not pursue profit, does not avoid harm, does not delight in seeking, does not follow the Dao, speaks without speaking, and speaks as though not speaking—and thus roams beyond the dust and grime. The Master deemed these reckless words, but I consider them the conduct of the wondrous Dao. What do you think?"

Chang Wuzi replied: "These are words that even the Yellow Emperor would strain to comprehend—how could Confucius possibly understand them?"

This passage, following the discussion of the Perfected Person, introduces the question of the sage, further critiquing the scholars of the Confucian school. "Worldly affairs" refers to matters one does not take to heart. To approach or avoid is to acknowledge benefit and harm—if one does not know benefit and harm, how could there be approach or avoidance? If things seek me or I am drawn to them, I do not take it as delight. "Does not follow the Dao" means leaving no trace of conduct. "Speaks without speaking" is speech that is not speech; "speaks as though not speaking" is speech that is no speech.

"Reckless" means insubstantial. "The Master" refers to Confucius. Ju Quezi says: I spoke of the sage’s conduct to the Master, who deemed it insubstantial, but I consider it the wondrous Dao—what do you think? "You" here refers to Chang Wuzi.

"Strain to comprehend" means to make clear. It is said that only the Yellow Emperor could understand such words after careful listening. "You are far too hasty in your judgment—seeing an egg and demanding a rooster’s crow at dawn, seeing a slingshot and craving roasted owl. I have spoken to you idly—why not listen idly in return? To ride beside the sun and moon, to embrace the cosmos, to let one’s lips meet, to set aside confusion and resentment, and to serve as companions in mutual reverence—this is the way.

The common people toil endlessly, while the sage appears foolish and dull. They harmonize the myriad ages into a single purity, for all things are thus, and this is how they are enfolded within one another.

"You are far too hasty in your judgment" means that your words are as they are, yet you prematurely deem them the conduct of the wondrous Dao—this is seeing little and thinking much of oneself. It is like seeking a rooster’s crow at dawn before the hour of *mao*, or craving roasted owl before the bird is even struck by the slingshot—this is the metaphor of hasty judgment.

*Shiye* refers to a rooster’s crow at the proper hour. I have idly spoken to you—listen idly in return, and see how it is. The word "how" here is striking.

"To ride beside the sun and moon" means to be in their company; "to embrace the cosmos" means to hold it within one’s arms.

"Seam," meaning "to join," speaks of a state of perfect fusion without gap or fissure—this is how the ultimate principle merges into oneness.

"Slippery" describes a rushing, turbid flow; "muddled" means benighted and confused. The rushing, muddled world of men, with its hierarchies of deference, is set aside and left unspoken. Scholars defer to grand officers, grand officers treat scholars as underlings; grand officers defer to ministers, and ministers treat grand officers as underlings. Extend this upward, and all are underlings to one another, yet they still fabricate distinctions of high and low. The multitude, deluded by the world, toil endlessly in their labors. The sage, knowing through unknowing, remains in a state of undifferentiated simplicity—like one foolish and dull. "Foolish and dull" describes the appearance of utter ignorance.

"To unite" means to converge; when one surveys the convergence of ten thousand ages, only this single principle remains, with no admixture or interruption—thus it is called "a single, pure accomplishment." "All things are thus" means that each thing is as it is in its own way. Every person harbors private intentions, so that between heaven and earth, from ancient times to the present, countless instances of "this is so" accumulate—hence the saying: "they enfold one another through 'this is so.'" "To enfold one another" is like saying "to pile up and press upon one another."

How do I know that delight in life is not a delusion? How do I know that aversion to death is not like one who has lost his way in weakness and does not know the way home?

Lady Li was the daughter of the border warden of Ai. When the state of Jin first obtained her, she wept until her tears soaked her collar. Yet once she arrived at the king’s palace, sharing his royal couch and feasting on fine meats, she came to regret her earlier tears.

How do I know that those who die do not regret their initial longing for life? One who dreams of drinking wine may wake weeping, while one who dreams of weeping may wake to go hunting. In the midst of a dream, one does not know it is a dream—even within the dream, one may interpret it, only to awaken and realize it was all a dream. And only after the great awakening does one know that this was the great dream. Yet fools believe themselves awake, priding themselves on their discernment: "This one is a lord, that one a herdsman!" How rigid is Confucius! You and I are both dreaming. When I say you are dreaming, I too am dreaming—such words are called "perverse consolation."

Were a great sage to arise ten thousand generations hence and grasp this understanding, it would be as if we had met in a single morning or evening. The preceding discussion arose from the principle of "enfolding one another through 'this is so,'" which further clarifies the earlier statement that "life and death undergo no change."

"To lose one’s way" means to depart from one’s homeland; "weakness and loss" refers to one who leaves home in youth. To linger long in a foreign land and forget one’s native country—this is akin to delighting in life and dreading death. Lady Li was a consort of Duke Xian of Jin, captured from the state of Lirong, hence called "Lady Li of Li." Ai was a Rong territory, and the "warden" was its border guardian. When she first left the Rong lands for Jin, she grieved, but once she attained nobility, sharing the king’s couch and feasting, she regretted her initial tears—this serves as an analogy for life and death.

The saying, "One who dreams of drinking wine may wake weeping; one who dreams of weeping may wake to go hunting," appears in many dream-interpretation texts. Such transformations between dream and waking are so fluid that, within the dream, one does not recognize it as a dream—even attempting to interpret it—only to awaken and realize both the dream and its interpretation were illusions. These passages subtly capture the nuances of human nature. If one grasps this, one sees that the exchanges between Wei Jie and Yue Guang, though insightful, do not reach such depth—this is a matter of great significance in learning. For instance, in Yue Guang’s lament, how does it compare to King Gaozong’s dream of Fu Yue or Confucius’ dream of the Duke of Zhou?

The "great awakening" refers to one who has perceived the Dao—what Chan Buddhists call "great enlightenment." "Lord" signifies nobility, "herdsman" lowliness; yet fools, still dreaming, cling to distinctions of rank—how deluded they are! "Pride in small discernment" describes their narrow vision. What I say to you is also part of the dream; when I call you a dreamer, that too is a dreamer’s words. The meaning here is that the world is but an empty dream, though the phrasing is artfully strange. "Perverse consolation" means utterly bizarre. My words may seem utterly strange, yet within that strangeness lies profound truth. If, ten thousand generations hence, a great sage were to arise and comprehend these insights, it would be as if we had met in a single day. This is akin to Yang Xiong of later ages, who would surely understand my intent.

"Understanding" here means insight. Suppose you and I were to debate: if you defeat me, does that mean I am wrong and you are right? If I defeat you, does that mean I am right and you are wrong? Or might one of us be right and the other wrong? Or could both be right, or both be wrong? You and I cannot know for certain. People are inherently shrouded in darkness—whom could we appoint to judge? If we chose someone who agrees with you, they would already share your view—how could they judge fairly? If we chose someone who agrees with me, they would already share my view—how could they judge fairly? If we chose someone who differs from both of us, they would be at odds with us—how could they judge fairly? If we chose someone who agrees with both of us, they would already share our views—how could they judge fairly? Thus, you, I, and others cannot know the truth—must we await another?

This passage emerges from the principle of "enfolding one another through 'this is so,'" echoing the earlier notion of "the ends of benefit and harm." Victory and defeat cannot determine right and wrong, for in our debate, neither of us can truly know the other. "Darkness" refers to the obscurity of perception. If both parties’ views are clouded, whom can we appoint to judge? Agreement with your position is no solution, nor is agreement with mine, nor is disagreement with both, nor agreement with both. I am one perspective, you are another, and another person is yet another—three perspectives, none of which can know the others. Must we await yet another? This "another" is the workings of creation, the "Heavenly Boundary" (tianni), which is the "Heavenly Equality" (tianjun) mentioned earlier.

What does it mean to harmonize with the Heavenly Boundary? It means: "Is it so? Is it not so? If it is truly so, then the distinction between 'so' and 'not so' need not be debated. Is it truly so? Then the distinction between 'so' and 'not so' need not be debated." The interplay of opposing voices depends on their mutual opposition. If they do not oppose one another, harmonize them with the Heavenly Boundary, follow their natural unfolding, and thus exhaust the years. Forget the years, forget righteousness, roam beyond all limits, and so lodge in the boundless.

The "Boundary" (ni) means division. What harmonizes the Heavenly Boundary is simply "this is so." "This is so" and "this is not so," "so" and "not so"—both are preserved, as in the earlier principle of "walking two paths." The moment one asserts "this is so" or "this is right," a counterclaim of "not so" or "not right" arises, giving rise to disputes over right and wrong.

Voices are speech; "transformative voices" refers to using words to convert and subdue. "Mutual opposition" means mutual confrontation and resistance. If, in disputes over right and wrong, one forcefully employs speech to set oneself in opposition and seeks to convert and subdue, why not instead follow what the other affirms and avoid mutual resistance? Thus it is said, "if they do not oppose one another." These two characters are most extraordinary. "If they" may be read as "how could it resemble?" If they do not oppose but still harmonize, then one may harmonize them with the Heavenly Boundary and roam freely, exhausting the years. Thus it is said, "follow their natural unfolding," "so exhaust the years." "Follow" means to comply; "unfolding" means to roam freely; "exhaust the years" is like Du Fu’s "carefree passage of days and months." If one can do this, not only may one exhaust the years, but one may even forget the years, and not only forget the years, but even forget principles of righteousness. Once years and righteousness are forgotten, one may stir and dance in the realm of nothingness—this "stir" conveys the meaning of "carefree wandering." Having wandered carefree in the realm of nothingness, one may lodge there for a lifetime.

The dim shadow beside the reflection asked the reflection: "Just now you were walking, now you have stopped; just now you were sitting, now you have risen. Why are you so lacking in constancy?" The reflection replied: "Do I depend on something to be thus? Does what I depend on also depend on something to be thus? Do I depend on the snake’s molted skin or the cicada’s wings? How could I know why it is so, or why it is not so?" This passage arises from the notion of "dependence." The dim shadow refers to the faint outline beside the reflection. "Lacking in constancy" means having no fixed measure. "I depend on something to be thus" means the reflection’s movement depends on the form. Though I depend on the form, the form itself depends on something else—it depends on the Creator. The form as form is no more than the snake’s molted skin or the cicada’s wings. Do I merely depend on that? The cicada has transformed, yet its molted skin and wings remain—this is its shedding. How could they move on their own? Since I depend on the form, and the form depends on something else, how could I know why it is so or not so? This is the analogy for right and wrong depending on one another.

Once, Zhuang Zhou dreamed he was a butterfly, fluttering about as a butterfly, self-content and at ease, unaware that he was Zhou. Suddenly he awoke, and there he was, solidly Zhou. But he did not know whether Zhou had dreamed he was a butterfly, or the butterfly had dreamed it was Zhou. Between Zhou and the butterfly, there must be a distinction—this is called the transformation of things. This passage arises from the earlier discussion of dreams. "Fluttering" describes the butterfly in flight. "Self-content" means self-delight; "at ease" means carefree. In the dream, as a butterfly, he was utterly carefree, forgetting his own existence, hence "unaware that he was Zhou." "Solidly" describes the stiffness of waking in bed. Such passages are like brushstrokes in a painting. For Zhuang Zhou, the night’s dream of being a butterfly might make the butterfly, in turn, take his present waking state as a dream. Thus he said, "he did not know whether Zhou had dreamed he was a butterfly, or the butterfly had dreamed it was Zhou." Between dream and waking, there must be a point of distinction, hence "between Zhou and the butterfly, there must be a distinction." This sentence seems to conclude yet does not, leaving it unspoken, precisely to prompt inquiry—much like a Chan "critical phrase." "This is called the transformation of things" means this is the principle of the myriad things’ transformation.

This chapter, titled "Discourse on Leveling All Things," concludes with two analogies. The writing is extraordinarily ingenious, and the meaning profoundly subtle. One who awakens to this will see that there is no right or wrong to dispute—just as it is said, "life and death do not alter the self," let alone the concerns of profit and harm. The beginning and end resonate, now severed, now connected, now arising from one another yet not continuous, forming a single piece of writing. The brushwork rises and falls thus; read it thoroughly, and it yields boundless flavor.

*Southern Florescence Scripture Oral Exegesis, Scroll 3 (End)*
