*Southern Florescence Scripture Oral Exegesis, Scroll 4*
*By Lin Xiang of Yuanzhai*

The "Nurturing the Lord of Life" in the Inner Chapters—this "Lord" is akin to what the Chan school calls the "true master." To nurture the master of this life is what Daoists refer to as the "foundation of the elixir." First speaking of the joy of free wandering, then of the absence of right and wrong, we arrive here at the work of cultivating oneself. These three chapters seem to follow a sequence, though what follows does not entirely adhere to it.

"My life has its limits, yet knowledge is without bounds. To pursue the boundless with the bounded is perilous." And yet those who claim to know are but courting peril. *Ya* means "limit" or "boundary." Human life has its limits, its finite span. *Zhi* means "thought," and the mind’s reflections are endless. To chase infinite thought with a finite body is to be swept into ceaseless turmoil—when will it end? *Dai yi* expresses the gravity of this danger. *Yi* is a grammatical particle. The following *yi* echoes the preceding one, as in the "Equalizing Things" chapter.

Amidst such peril, to still employ calculation and cunning, priding oneself on knowledge and ability—such a one, I see, will meet only peril in the end. Reiterating *dai* reinforces the warning for later generations. This *dai* is the same as the *wei wei* ("only peril") in the *Book of Documents*. As for "those who claim to know," it is like saying "the enlightened." Enlightened, they act with purpose.

"In doing good, avoid proximity to fame; in doing evil, avoid proximity to punishment. Follow the *du* as your constant path—thus can you preserve your body, fulfill your life, nourish your kin, and live out your years." These lines precisely encapsulate the art of nurturing life, the self-cultivation to which Zhuangzi devoted himself.

"In doing good, avoid proximity to fame" means that even in virtuous acts, one should not seek renown. "In doing evil, avoid proximity to punishment" means that even in wrongdoing, one should not invite condemnation. This aligns with the "Webbed Toes" chapter’s admonition: "Above, one dares not cling to the conduct of benevolence and righteousness; below, one dares not engage in licentious or deviant acts." *Du* means "urgency"—that is, to respond only when pressed, to act only when unavoidable.

To roam the world with the mind, leaving no trace of good or evil to be named, and simply follow the natural patterns of Heaven—responding only when compelled, and doing so without contrivance—this is the constant way. *Yuan* means "to follow"; *jing* means "constant." To make a habit of rising only when pressed is the essence. Thus can one preserve the body, fulfill the principle of life, honor one’s parents, and live out one’s natural span—just as Mencius said, "Whether long-lived or short-lived, one remains unwavering, cultivating oneself to await its end."

Mencius speaks from the standpoint of mind and nature, and thus his tone is so upright; Zhuangzi, from the standpoint of spontaneity, and thus his words flow so freely. Though their language differs, their intent in teaching others is the same.

Huian, interpreting *du* as "center," found the thread of the passage incomplete when considering the lines about avoiding fame and punishment. He remarked: "If one fears the entanglements of fame and does not fully exert oneself in learning, one inclines toward evil. 'In doing evil, avoid proximity to punishment' suggests choosing transgressions that do not incur legal penalties, cunningly navigating to evade consequences—leading one to conclude that Zhuangzi advocates reckless abandon." Yet if one examines the flow of Zhuangzi’s words alongside the "Webbed Toes" chapter, this interpretation does not hold. Though *du* can mean "center," it is better rendered as "urgency," as the text itself confirms—this is the most precise reading.

Cook Ding carved an ox for Lord Wenhui. Where his hand touched, his shoulder leaned, his foot pressed, his knee braced—*xu* and *xiang* sounded in unison, the blade *huo*-ed through, all in perfect rhythm, harmonizing with the dance of *Sanglin* and matching the cadence of *Jingshou*.

Lord Wenhui exclaimed: "Ah! Excellent! How has your skill reached such heights?"

"Where his hand touched"—the motion of contact. "Where his shoulder leaned"—when the hand exerts force, the shoulder tilts. "Where his foot pressed"—as he applies strength, his stance naturally adjusts. "Where his knee braced"—*yi* means a slight bend; as he leans into the ox, his knee flexes. These four lines depict the butcher at work. *Xue* is the sound of entry; *huo*, the sound of severing.

The sounds *xu*, *xiang*, and *huo*—all are the noises of his blade in use—yet the phrase "wielding the knife" is placed between them: such is the structure of the text. As in the *Seventh Month* poem: "In the eighth month, it is in the wilds; in the ninth month, it is beneath the eaves; in the tenth month, the cricket is under my bed." Here, too, the word "cricket" is positioned in the middle. "Wielding the knife" means advancing the blade; to advance with the knife is called *zou*. "None failed to strike the note" means that the sounds *xu*, *xiang*, and *huo* all accorded with the pitch-pipes. *Sanglin* and *Jingshou* are both names of musical compositions; dance is accompanied by music, and *hui* refers to the gathering of dancers. "Harmonizing with *Sanglin*" and "matching the cadence of *Jingshou*" also describe how his movements aligned with the rhythms of the pitch-pipes. Lord Wenhui was King Hui of Liang. *Xi* expresses admiration. "How has your skill reached such heights?" means "How wondrous it is!" Cook Ding set down his blade and replied: "What your servant delights in is the Dao, which surpasses mere skill. When I first began to carve oxen, all I saw was the ox. After three years, I no longer saw the whole ox. To set down the blade and respond thus is to say that my skill was attained through the study of the Dao, and only afterward did I reach this level of technique—it is not mere technique. That after three years I no longer saw the whole ox means that the parts of the ox’s body where it could be carved were all apparent at a glance, without need for force.

Now, I encounter it with my spirit rather than with my eyes, and my senses cease while my spirit moves. I follow the natural patterns, cleaving the great seams, guiding the blade through the great cavities, proceeding according to what is inherently so. I have never touched the *kenqing* or the *qing*—how much less the great bones! To encounter with the spirit rather than with the eyes means that the mind unites with it; *yu* means to unite. The *guan* are the ears, eyes, nose, and mouth. That the senses cease means that when one stands in stillness, the ears and eyes perceive nothing; the knowledge of the senses halts, while the spirit moves of itself—this is the natural course. The *tianli* are the ox’s natural grain; to *yi* is to follow that natural grain in carving. The *da xi* are the junctions of bone and flesh; *pi* means to strike, and *kuan* means hollow—the spaces between the joints are naturally large and empty. To *dao* is to follow and carve along them. The junctions of bone and flesh, the hollows of the joints—all are inherently so, and I simply proceed accordingly. In my technique, the use of the blade has never once touched the *kenrong* or the *qing*. *Qing* is pronounced *qing*; the *kenqing* are the points where bone and flesh adhere. If even the *kenqing* are untouched by the blade, how much more the great bones! A good cook changes his knife every year, for he cuts. An ordinary cook changes his knife every month, for he hacks. My blade has now been in use for nineteen years, having carved several thousand oxen, yet its edge is as if newly whetted. A good cook is one who excels at his craft; an ordinary cook is one of the common sort, inferior. The inferior cook must change his knife every month, for he chops at the great bones and damages or breaks his blade. The good cook changes his knife every year, for even when he works between the *kenrong*, he may still cut, and so his blade wears out. But my knife has been in use for nineteen years, and though I have carved many oxen, its edge remains as if freshly sharpened—it has suffered no damage. The *xing* is a whetstone.

Where the joints have spaces and the blade has no thickness, to insert what has no thickness into what has space is to find ample room for the blade to move freely. Thus, after nineteen years, the edge of my knife is as if newly whetted. Where the joints have spaces—the ox’s joints naturally have gaps—and my blade is exceedingly thin, to follow those gaps with such a thin blade is to allow the edge to advance within them. "Ample room" means there is no obstruction. This passage speaks of how the difficulty or ease of worldly affairs all follow natural principles; if I simply proceed in accordance with them, without resisting or disturbing my mind, I remain at ease, and nothing can harm my life—this is the method of nurturing life.

Yet whenever I come to a cluster, I see the difficulty, and I am alert, my gaze fixed, my movements slow, my blade moving with utmost care. Then, with a *che*-sound, it is parted, like earth crumbling to the ground. I raise my knife and look around, filled with satisfaction, then wipe the blade and put it away. Lord Wenhui said: "Excellent! From Cook Ding’s words, I have learned how to nurture life." Though this is but a turn of phrase, it carries great meaning. For in navigating the world, how can one always meet with favorable circumstances? There are also times of adversity. When such moments arise, one must adapt and proceed with flexibility. It is easy to move through favorable circumstances, but when faced with adversity, one often becomes flustered, even to the point of ruin—how can one’s mind remain undisturbed? This is why this turn is added. *Zu* means a gathering, referring to the places where the ox’s sinews and bones converge. Though I say I no longer see the whole ox with my eyes, and though I use my blade only in the great seams and cavities, when I come to the tangled clusters of sinew and bone, I still recognize the difficulty and treat it as a challenge.

*Chu* means to be stirred; *jie* means to be vigilant. "My gaze fixed" means that when I look, my eyes pause, and then my movements with the blade become slow. This merely expresses the care I take. Having taken such care, my blade moves with great subtlety, lightly and without force. *Che* is pronounced *te*; *jie* is pronounced *xie*...

*Huo* means suddenness; *jie* means to disperse—this describes how, with such light effort, the bones and flesh suddenly separate of their own accord, like earth crumbling to the ground, speaking to its abundance and ease. Once the ox is fully dismembered, I lift my blade and stand, gazing leisurely about. *Chouchu* means unhurried, the self-contentment of one at ease; *manzhi* means fulfillment, not that one’s ambitions are self-satisfied, but that this fulfills my intent. Why is it fulfilling? Because I dismember the ox without force, and though I dismember, the blade remains unharmed—this is why it is fulfilling. *Shandao* means to carefully tend to the blade and put it away.

This meaning is meant to illustrate how, when one encounters adversity, one can respond with natural compliance, keeping the mind undisturbed. Once the matter passes, one transforms with the situation, resting in non-action as if nothing had ever occurred. The passage beginning *"To do good without seeking fame"* directly expounds the method of nurturing life, while the story of Pao Ding serves as its metaphor. Here, at the very end, it lightly concludes with four characters: *"one attains the nurturing of life"*—this is where the momentum of the text is effortlessly guided, and it must be examined closely.

Gongwen Xuan saw the Right Master and exclaimed in shock: "What sort of person is this? Why is he one-legged? Did Heaven do this to him, or was it man?" He replied: "It was Heaven, not man."

Heaven’s creation of this one-legged being was to make him solitary, while man’s appearance is naturally paired. From this we know it was Heaven, not man.

Gongwen is the surname, Xuan the given name. The Right Master was a man who had undergone foot-amputation and held the office of Right Master. *Jie* means solitary—having lost one foot and retaining only one. *Was it Heaven or man?* asks whether his condition arose from Heaven’s design at birth or from human amputation. Though the amputation was clearly man’s doing, he says it was Heaven, not man. *Heaven’s creation of this being was to make him solitary* means that when Heaven made him, it intended him to have only one foot. How do we know this? Because the form and appearance of all people include two feet that walk side by side; among the multitude, he alone is different—this is Heaven’s doing, not man’s. *Paired* means walking side by side. This suggests that in the human world, excess and deficiency are all the work of Creation. Even when it appears to be man’s doing, it is ultimately Creation’s design. The intent is that when one encounters adversity, one should accept it with compliance.

The marsh pheasant takes ten steps for a single peck, a hundred steps for a single drink—it does not wish to be kept in a cage. Though its spirit may flourish, it is not well. The earlier discussion of accepting adversity with compliance aligns with the idea in the Pao Ding story that "whenever he reached a complex joint, I saw where the difficulty lay." Here, in these few lines, the marsh pheasant is used as a metaphor, illustrating that in human life, adversity is common—like treading on a tiger’s tail or wandering within Archer Yi’s range. The marsh pheasant takes ten steps for a single peck, a hundred steps for a single drink, emphasizing the difficulty of its sustenance. If kept in a cage, it would have ample food and drink, yet the pheasant does not desire this, hence *it does not wish to be kept in a cage*. *Qi* means to desire; *fan* means cage. Why does it not wish this? Though the caged pheasant’s food and drink may be plentiful, and its spirit may seem to flourish, it is ultimately not content. Thus it is said: *though its spirit may flourish, it is not well*. *Wang* is pronounced as "flourishing"; *not well* means not content. The intent is that one who cherishes their own life should not be submerged in worldly entanglements but should instead preserve their integrity.

When Lao Dan died, Qin Shi went to mourn him. He wailed three times and departed. A disciple asked: "Was he not your friend?" He replied: "He was." "Then is such mourning appropriate?" He said: "It is. At first, I thought him an extraordinary man, but now I see he was not. Earlier, when I entered to mourn, I saw the elders weeping for him as if for their own children, and the young weeping as if for their own mothers. The reason they gathered like this must be that they spoke words they did not intend to speak and wept tears they did not intend to shed—this is fleeing from Heaven and betraying true feeling, forgetting what they had received. The ancients called this *the punishment of fleeing from Heaven*." Zhuangzi’s teachings originate from Laozi, and here he first criticizes Laozi, which serves as a prelude to his criticism of Yao and Shun. I, the Master, take the Dao as my foundation; I have no partiality even toward Laozi, let alone others. *He wailed three times and departed* means he did not indulge in emotion. The disciple’s question suggests that Laozi was Qin Shi’s friend, so why did he mourn without emotion? The Master refers to Qin Shi. *At first, I thought him an extraordinary man* means I initially took Laozi to be an exceptional person, but upon mourning him, I realized he was not. Why? When Laozi died, his disciples—young and old alike—wept with such sorrow. This indicates that Laozi had not transcended his physical form and had moved his disciples’ hearts, so their words and tears of grief and longing arose spontaneously, without premeditation. What Heaven bestows is fundamentally formless, yet if one is moved by emotion, it means forgetting the original endowment and fleeing from Heaven’s principle, betraying true feeling. Such actions offend Heaven, hence *the punishment of fleeing from Heaven*. *Bei* is synonymous with *betray*.

*Coming at the right time, Master, is timing; departing at the right time, Master, is compliance.* Resting in the right time and abiding in compliance, no single moment of joy can enter. The ancients called this *the release from Heaven’s bonds*. Having discussed the Qin Shi passage above, this now elucidates the principle of fully understanding life and death, concluding the chapter. The intent is for people to recognize that what occurs naturally should not disturb their minds in matters of life and death—only then can one nurture life. *Master* is a term of respect for one who embodies the Dao. It means that among those with the Dao in the world, their coming is at the right time, and their going is at the right time—one should simply follow the timing and comply. Once one understands the naturalness of coming and going, arrival is not a cause for joy, nor is departure a cause for sorrow. *Cannot enter* means it cannot disturb the mind. *Xuan* means the mind is bound. *Di* means Heaven. Knowing the naturalness of Heaven’s principle, even Heaven cannot bind one with life and death. It means that even Heaven has no power over me. Thus it is called *the release from Heaven’s bonds*.

*The flame is limited by the fuel, yet the fire is transmitted—its end is unknown.* This is a metaphor for life and death. It is like using firewood to kindle a flame: if you focus on the firewood, it will eventually be exhausted, yet the fire in the world has been passed down from ancient times to the present, never ceasing, and its end has never been seen. These three lines are extraordinary prose. The principle of life and death cannot be fully expressed in words, yet earlier the text discusses the principle, and here it concludes with a metaphor—is this not the most exquisite part of the writing? *The Oral Exegesis of the True Scripture of Southern Florescence, Volume Four* ends here.

**The Oral Exegesis of the True Scripture of Southern Florescence, Volume Five**
*By Lin Xiang of Yongzhai*

**Inner Chapters: "The Human World" (Part One)**

The preceding section spoke of nurturing life; this one speaks of engaging with the world. It means that since we possess this body and dwell in this world, how can we completely sever ourselves from human affairs? The key is to navigate them well.

Seeing this intent, how could Zhuangzi be impractical? How could he fail to grasp worldly matters? This aligns with the meaning in the Outer Chapters: *"Nothing should be done, yet nothing can be left undone."*

---

Yan Hui sought an audience with Confucius, requesting permission to depart.
Confucius asked, *"Where are you going?"*
Yan Hui replied, *"I intend to go to Wei."*
*"What will you do there?"*
Yan Hui said, *"I have heard that the lord of Wei is young in years, acts willfully, treats his state lightly without recognizing his faults, and squanders the lives of his people. The dead in his realm are as numerous as reeds in a marsh—so much so that the people have nowhere to turn.*

*"His youth and willfulness"* refer to his being young and self-reliant, unmoved by others’ opinions. *"Treating his state lightly without recognizing his faults"* means he governs carelessly, unaware of his errors. *"Squandering the lives of his people"* describes his reckless disregard for their survival, as if they were mere fodder. *"The dead in his realm are as reeds in a marsh"* compares the slaughtered to the abundance of reeds in a wetland, implying he treats his people as worthless as grass. The *Fu Guo* chapter of the *Xunzi* contains a similar phrase, *"measured by the marsh"*—here, the word order is inverted to *"marsh-like reeds,"* a striking literary flourish.

For example:
*"Cloud"* is a marsh; *"Dream"* is also a marsh. In ancient times, the Yunmeng region was entirely water, but now it has land for cultivation. Yet we do not say *"Yunmeng’s soil is tilled"* (*yun meng tu zuo yao yi*), but rather *"Yun’s soil, Meng’s tilled"* (*yun tu meng zuo*).
Similarly, *"dark"* is fine, *"white"* is fine—yet we do not say *"dark-white fine"* (*xuan gao xian*), but *"dark-fine-white"* (*xuan xian gao*).
This is a rhetorical device.

*"Where"* means *"to go."* *"The people have nowhere to turn"* means they have no refuge.

Yan Hui had once heard the Master say: *"Leave well-governed states; go to disordered ones. A physician’s gate is crowded with the sick."* He wished to apply what he had learned, hoping the state might yet be healed.

Confucius sighed and said, *"Alas! You will likely go only to be punished."*

The Dao does not tolerate杂乱.杂乱 leads to excess, excess to disturbance, disturbance to anxiety, and anxiety cannot be remedied.

The utmost person of old first established it within themselves before establishing it in others. If what is established within oneself is not yet settled, how can one attend to the conduct of violent men?

Moreover, do you understand how virtue is swayed and from where knowledge arises? Virtue is swayed by fame; knowledge arises from contention. Fame is a tool for mutual suppression; knowledge is an instrument of strife. Both are inauspicious tools—not to be employed without restraint.

If your virtue is profound and your trustworthiness evident, yet you have not aligned with the other’s qi; if your reputation is illustrious and your conduct uncontentious, yet you have not reached their heart—then to forcibly present them with the language of benevolence, righteousness, standards, and methods is to display your own excellence before a violent man. People will resent your possession of such beauty, calling you a *"calamitous man."* One who brings calamity to others will surely face retaliation. You will likely become a target of their harm.

The saying goes: *"In a state with the Dao, appear; in a state without the Dao, withdraw."* This is the teaching of sages and worthies. Yet Zhuangzi reverses it, saying: *"Leave well-governed states; go to disordered ones."* It is like a physician: only when many are sick can one practice their art. If a state is already well-ordered, what need is there for you?

*"Wishing to apply what I have heard"* means Yan Hui wanted to convey to the lord of Wei what he had learned from Confucius, urging him to reflect on proper principles and reform, hoping the state might be stabilized.

*"You will likely go only to be punished"*: *"You"* refers to Yan Hui; *"likely"* means *"will."* If you go in this manner, you will only be executed by him—meaning it is inadvisable to go.

*"The Dao does not tolerate杂乱"* means that when the mind is uncluttered, it is pure, empty, and luminous. If one harbors intentions—thinking, *"Since he acts thus, how should I save him?"*—this is already杂乱 within oneself. If one is not pure, how can one save others?

*"杂乱 leads to excess"* means becoming entangled in many concerns. *"Disturbance"* means chaos; *"anxiety"* means self-torment. You would only torment yourself—how could you save others?

The ancients first cultivated what was within themselves before admonishing others. If what is within oneself is not yet settled, how can one attend to others? Even if their conduct is violent, you are already tormented—how can you attend to their virtue?

*"Virtue"* refers to naturalness; *"knowledge"* refers to private cunning. The moment one seeks fame, one’s natural virtue is already lost. The moment one employs private knowledge, contention arises. Thus it is said: *"Virtue is swayed by fame; knowledge arises from contention."*

*"Mutual suppression"* means mutual undermining. *"Instrument of strife"* means that if I use private knowledge, they will too, and the more we contend, the worse it becomes. *"Instrument"* here means *"tool."*

Fame and knowledge are both inauspicious matters in the world—one cannot act upon them without consequence, for doing so will surely invite disaster.

*"Profound"* means deep; *"profound virtue"* is true virtue. *"Profound"* implies sincerity and trustworthy conduct. Even if one possesses virtue and trustworthiness, if one has not aligned with the other’s nature and qi; even if one has a fine reputation and uncontentious conduct, if one has not reached their heart—then to forcibly present the language of benevolence, righteousness, standards, and methods before a violent man is to make them resent you, believing you are boasting of your own excellence.

*"Standards"* refers to regulations; *"methods"* is synonymous with *"techniques."*

*"Calamitous man"* means a harmful person. They will surely call you a *"calamitous man,"* and once branded as such, the harm will rebound upon you. If you go now, you will likely only bring calamity upon yourself—how could you transform the lord of Wei and save his state?

Moreover, if one merely delights in the worthy and detests the unworthy, what use is there in seeking to be different? If you do not await summons, the king and nobles will surely seize upon your words to contend for victory, and your eyes will grow dazed, your countenance will flatten in submission, your mouth will stammer in defense, your bearing will betray fear, and your heart will yield to compliance. This is like quenching fire with fire or flooding water with water—it only adds to the excess. Following such a course will lead to endless peril. If you speak earnestly without first establishing trust, you will surely die before a violent man.

If he already knows the worthy and delights in them, and knows the unworthy and detests them, what need has he for you? He would seek elsewhere. Thus it is said: *What use is there in seeking to be different?* It is precisely because he does not distinguish between the worthy and the unworthy that he acts as he does. If he does not recognize worthiness, how could he know you are worthy and trust your words?

*"Summons"* means to call. *"You"* refers to yourself. The lord of Wei has never summoned you, hence it is said: *If you do not await summons.* Since you go uninvited, he, in his noble rank, will surely seize upon your words to vie for victory. *"Contend"* means to struggle; *"victory"* means to prevail. Once cornered by him, your eyes will grow dim, *"dazed"* meaning bewildered. *"Your countenance will flatten in submission"* means you will alter your expression to appease him, bowing in deference to extricate yourself. *"Your mouth will stammer in defense"* means you will stammer to explain and justify yourself. *"Your bearing will betray fear"* means your posture will reveal terror, trembling and prostration. *"Your heart will yield to compliance"* means you will submit in your heart. Emperor Wu of Liang’s debate with He Chen perfectly mirrors this hexagram’s omen—it speaks of contention ending in self-submission.

If the other party is already violent and then defeats you, his arrogance will only grow. This is truly like quenching fire with fire or flooding water with water. *"Excess"* means increase; *"adds to the excess"* means his malice will only multiply. Proceeding thus, his wickedness will know no end, and his brutality will only worsen. *"Earnest words"* means profound speech. You have not yet earned his trust, yet you, untrusted, speak profoundly before a violent man—you will surely be killed by him.

In ancient times, Jie killed Guan Longfeng, and Zhou killed Prince Bigan—both had cultivated themselves to humbly serve the people, thus defying their superiors. Their rulers, resenting their virtue, cast them out. They were lovers of reputation. In former times, Yao attacked Congzhi and Xu’ao, and Yu attacked Youhu, leaving their lands desolate and their bodies mutilated. Their ceaseless warfare and insatiable pursuit of fame and gain were all for the sake of reputation and profit. Have you not heard of this? Reputation and profit are things even the sages cannot overcome—how much less can you?

Guan Longfeng and Bigan cultivated themselves to love the people, not realizing the people belonged to others. You, in turn, humbly serve them—*"humbly serve"* means to cherish and nurture. Jie and Zhou did not love the people, yet you love *their* people, thus defying your superior. This is why they were killed. *"Cultivated"* means to refine; resenting their refinement, their rulers turned against them—this was the fault of their love of reputation.

Congzhi, Xu’ao, and Youhu are all allegories. Their lands became ruins, their deaths left them as vengeful spirits—*"vengeful"* meaning ghosts without descendants or refuge. Their downfall to such ruin came from ceaseless warfare in pursuit of fame and profit. *"Profit"* means material gain. *"Cannot overcome"* means cannot endure. Those who seek reputation and self-interest—even Yao and Yu could not endure them, leading to the destruction of their states—how much less can you?

Though this is so, if you must have some purpose, come and tell me of it. Yan Hui said: *"Be upright yet empty, diligent yet single-minded—would that suffice?"* The reply: *"How could it?"* For one who exults in yang energy, whose countenance shifts unpredictably, is what ordinary men dare not oppose. If you rely on what moves others to seek favor with their hearts, this is called *"daily gradual virtue"*—and even this cannot be achieved, let alone great virtue. Stubborn and unyielding, outwardly compliant yet inwardly unrepentant—how could this ever suffice?

Another turn is taken: if you insist on going, you must have some purpose—come, try and tell me. *"Try"* means to attempt; *"come"* is an auxiliary particle. *"Upright yet empty"* means to straighten your bearing and empty your heart; *"diligent yet single-minded"* means to strive earnestly and remain steadfast to the end. Could this work?

*"How could it?"* means it is utterly impossible. *"Exults in yang energy"* means one who has attained power, his qi swelling and his demeanor triumphant. *"His countenance shifts unpredictably"* means his haughty expression is ever-changing. Ordinary men dare not defy him, submitting in fear. Seeing that all fear him, if you seek to move him with words, he will demand you submit to his will to satisfy his desires—hence it is said: *seek favor with their hearts.* *"Favor"* means self-satisfaction. *"Daily gradual"* refers to minor virtue; it is said that even such small virtue cannot be achieved by people like you—how could you achieve great virtue?

*"Stubborn and unyielding"* means obstinate and unchanging. If so, you will outwardly seek compliance through upright emptiness while inwardly clinging to your diligence and single-mindedness, believing yourself free of fault. But with such limited skill, how could you ever deem this sufficient?

Thus, I am inwardly upright yet outwardly yielding, achieving alignment with the highest standards.

To be *"inwardly upright"* is to follow Heaven as one’s companion. Those who follow Heaven know that the Son of Heaven and oneself are both children of Heaven, so how could one alone seek praise for one’s words when others do good, or seek blame when others do ill? Such a person is called *"childlike"*—this is what it means to follow Heaven as one’s companion.

To be *"outwardly yielding"* is to follow others as one’s companion. Kneeling with hands clasped and bowing low—these are the rites of a minister. If all others perform them, how dare I not do the same? To do what others do is to incur no fault from them—this is what it means to follow others as one’s companion.

To *"achieve alignment with the highest"* is to follow the ancients as one’s companion. Though one’s words may resemble instruction, they are in truth admonitions—what the ancients possessed, not what I possess. In this way, though one speaks directly, it is not deemed a fault—this is what it means to follow the ancients as one’s companion.

If this is so, is it acceptable?
Then, further below, a response in the voice of Yanzi is set forth, divided into three parts.

*"Inwardly upright"* means inwardly preserving this principle to guard one’s true reality—here, *"upright"* is akin to *"true."* From the nobility of the Son of Heaven down to myself, all are born of Heaven, and thus all emerge from the natural. How could one dare to act selfishly in one’s words, seeking praise for what one deems right and blame for what one deems wrong? Without such selfish intent, one remains as unblemished as a child—thus in harmony with Heaven. Hence it is said: *to follow Heaven as one’s companion.*

*"Outwardly yielding"* means outwardly fulfilling the rites of kneeling with hands clasped and bowing low. If all others perform them, then I too perform them, and others find no fault in me. This refers to the rites of submission. Though it may go against the crowd, I follow the lower path, generating such discourse to mock the sagely gate in this manner—thus in harmony with others. Hence it is said: *to follow others as one’s companion.*

*"Achieving"* refers to one’s own established doctrines. *"Alignment"* means accord—taking one’s established doctrines and aligning them with the ancients above, citing the ancients as evidence. Though one borrows the ancients’ instructive words, these are in fact direct admonitions of right and wrong, all bearing the weight of reproach. For one’s words do not originate from oneself but are what the ancients have already spoken. In this way, though one speaks bluntly to expose another’s conduct, others do not deem it a fault. Hence it is said: *though direct, it is not a fault.* To *"follow the ancients as one’s companion"* means one’s doctrines accord with the ancients.

If this is so, is it acceptable?
Confucius said: *"No, it will not do. There are far too many administrative measures and methods, yet they remain unsettled. Though steadfast, one is still without fault—but this is all one achieves. How can such an approach transform others? It is still the way of one who follows their own mind."*

*"Administrative"* refers to affairs; *"methods"* to procedures. It means the matters and methods you speak of are too numerous and ultimately unstable. *Die* (谍) is pronounced *dié* and means *"settled."* Though one may fulfill these three, one is still without fault—yet this merely allows one to avoid blame. How can it transform others? Hence it is said: *"How can such an approach transform?"*

Where, then, lies the flaw in this? The trouble is that your three doctrines all stem from following the mind of deliberate action—this is to harbor intention, to leave traces, and thus to depart from the natural Dao.

Yan Hui said: *"I have no further progress to make. May I ask the method?"*
Confucius replied: *"Fast! I will tell you. To act upon what you possess—is this easy? Those who find it easy are not fit for the luminous heavens."*
Yan Hui said: *"My family is poor. For months I have drunk no wine and eaten no meat. Is this fasting?"*
*"That is the fasting of sacrificial rites,"* he said, *"not the fasting of the mind."*
*"May I ask what the fasting of the mind is?"*
Confucius said: *"Unify your will. Do not listen with the ears but listen with the mind. Do not listen with the mind but listen with qi. Listening stops at the ears; the mind stops at signs. Qi is that which is empty and awaits things. Only the Dao gathers in emptiness—emptiness is the fasting of the mind."*

*"No further progress"* means there is nothing higher to aspire to. *"To act upon what you possess—is this easy?"* means: *"You claim to have these skills and think it easy to put them into practice."* But the moment such a facile attitude arises, the intent of the luminous heavens is no longer pleased. Hence it is said: *"Those who find it easy are not fit for the luminous heavens."* These two lines are among the most practical and vital in life.

The fasting of sacrificial rites is external; the fasting of the mind is internal. *"Unify your will"* means to focus the mind without distraction. To listen with the ears is still external; to listen with the mind is still within the self; to listen with qi is to be without thing. Listening with the ears stops at the ears and does not enter the mind; listening with the mind requires external things to correspond with the self, creating a division between self and other. Qi follows the natural and awaits things with emptiness—emptiness is the Dao. Emptiness is where the Dao resides, hence: *"Only the Dao gathers in emptiness."* This very emptiness is the fasting of the mind.

Yan Hui said: *"Before I received your instruction, I was simply myself. Now that I have received it, there is no longer any 'me.' Can this be called emptiness?"*
The Master said: *"It is complete. 'Received instruction'* means having been taught. This is Yanzi’s sudden awakening: before receiving instruction, there was still a self; after receiving it, there is no longer a self. To forget the self is to be empty. *"It is complete"* means your words have fully expressed the principle.

*"I will tell you: if you can enter and wander within its cage without being moved by its names—*
*If they enter, then sing; if they do not enter, then stop.*
*Without gate, without poison,*
*Dwell in the one and lodge in necessity—then you are nearly there."*

*"You"* refers to Yan Hui. The world is like a cage—if you can enter and wander within it without being swayed by empty names (for wherever there are traces, there are names; and wherever there is advancement, the mind is stirred), then to be without intention is to leave no traces, and to be without advancement is to keep the mind unstirred. Hence: *"wander within its cage without being moved by its names."* What follows is the method for navigating the world.

*"If they enter, then sing"* means: if they are receptive to words, then speak to them. *"If they do not enter, then stop"* means: if they are not receptive, do not speak to them. The meaning is the same as in the *Analects*, though the phrasing is striking. Where there is a fixed direction, there is a gate; where there is no fixed direction, there is no gate. Where there is scent or flavor, there is poison; where there is none, there is no poison. *"Poison"* refers to the taste of medicine. These are all metaphors for being without intention or traces.

*"Dwell"* means to reside. To take the undifferentiated one as your dwelling and lodge this mind in necessity is to master the way of living in the human world. *"Nearly"* means complete.

*"To leave no traces is easy; to walk without treading is difficult."*
*"Traces"* are the marks of advancing feet. To stop and not move is to leave no footprints—this is easy. But how can one not walk? To walk upon the earth without leaving traces of treading is difficult. The idea is that to do nothing at all is easy, but what is human life if not action? To act without acting and yet accomplish everything—that is difficult.

*"To be employed by man is easy to falsify; to be employed by Heaven is difficult to falsify."*
*"To be employed by man is easy to falsify"* means that when one is driven by human desires, it is easy to resort to deception. Only by emptying the mind and following the workings of creation can one be without falsity. *"Employed by man"* refers to human desires; *"employed by Heaven"* refers to the daily workings of heavenly principle. The words *"easy"* and *"difficult"* carry meaning: *"easy"* means prone to straying; *"difficult"* means admitting no falsity.

*"I have heard of flying with wings, but never of flying without wings.*
*I have heard of knowing with knowledge, but never of knowing without knowledge."*

*"I have heard of flying with wings"* refers to birds, which must fly with wings. To fly without wings is to be swift without haste, to arrive without traveling—this is what is called the numinous. This line serves as a metaphor for the next: for humans, knowing with knowledge is the norm. Only by knowing what one does not know does one attain the knowing of non-knowing—this is the subtlety of attaining the Dao.

*"Look upon that empty chamber: an empty room generates brightness.*
*Auspiciousness rests where it rests. If one does not rest, this is called sitting in motion."*

*"Look"* means to gaze. This uses the empty room as a metaphor for the mind. Gazing upon that secluded chamber, wherever there is an opening, light enters—light emerges from emptiness. Taking that emptiness as a metaphor for the self, one sees that emptiness naturally generates clarity. *"Generates brightness"* means generates illumination. It does not say *"generates illumination"* but *"generates whiteness"*—this is Zhuangzi’s striking phrasing. This very place of empty clarity is where the myriad things gather. *"Auspiciousness"* is fortune; *"rests where it rests"*—the second *"rests"* refers to emptiness.

Only in stillness is there emptiness; only in emptiness is there clarity—this is the meaning of "from precepts arises concentration, from concentration arises wisdom." If I allow the mind to take hold yet cannot still it, though the body sits here, the mind races outward—how then can one achieve "sitting in forgetfulness"? This uses the phrase *"sitting in motion"* to contrast with *"sitting in forgetfulness."*

When the ears and eyes turn inward to communicate while the heart’s knowing turns outward, even spirits and gods will come to dwell—how much more so for men? This is the transformation of the myriad things, the pivot upon which Yu and Shun turned, the path Fuxi and Jiqu followed to their end—how much more so for those of lesser station?

The ears and eyes’ perceptions all inwardly connect to the heart. If I harbor no thoughts, then I follow the ears and eyes’ perceptions: though they communicate inwardly, they are truly external to the heart’s knowing. What does it mean to be *"external to the heart’s knowing"*? It means the heart remains unmoved, and external things cannot enter. Though one hears what is heard and sees what is seen, there is no heart in hearing or seeing. Thus, the heart’s emptiness communes with spirits and gods—how much more so for men? This is how one can transform others. *"Spirits and gods come to dwell"* means perfect sincerity is spirit-like; within this heart, spirits and gods commune with the Creator, hence *"come to dwell."*

Having spoken thus, the text concludes with a single phrase: *"This is the transformation of the myriad things."* This is the principle of creation, the source from which all things arise. The great pivot Yu and Shun beheld was no more than this; Fuxi and Jiqu followed this path to their life’s end—how much more so for those beneath them? *"Jiqu"* may refer to an ancient sage-king, though no record confirms this; it is likely a parable. *"Those of lesser station"* refers to ordinary people.

The following passage breaks off to elaborate further, not to be read as continuous with the above:

When Duke Zigao of She was about to be sent as an envoy to Qi, he asked Confucius: *"The king’s charge to Zhuliang is most weighty. Qi’s treatment of envoys is respectful yet unhurried. Even a common man cannot be swayed—how much less a feudal lord? I tremble with fear. You once told Zhuliang: ‘In matters great or small, few succeed without harmonious words to bring them to completion. If a matter fails, one faces the calamity of human laws; if it succeeds, one faces the calamity of yin and yang. Only those of virtue can ensure that, whether success or failure follows, no calamity arises.’*

*I eat coarse food without discerning its quality; my hearth has no desire for coolness. Now, having received my charge this morning, by evening I drink ice—is this not inner heat? I have not yet grasped the true nature of the task, yet I already suffer the calamity of yin and yang. If the matter fails, I face the calamity of human laws—two calamities indeed. As a minister, I am unworthy of this burden. Pray, instruct me further."*

*Zhuliang* was the Duke of She’s personal name; *Zigao* was his courtesy name. *"The charge to Zhuliang is most weighty"* means the mission to Qi is fraught with difficulty. *"Respectful yet unhurried"* means Qi treats envoys with courtesy, but their responses to matters are always slow. Even common men, when their requests go unanswered, are at a loss—how much more so for feudal lords? Hence his trembling fear.

*"You"* refers to Confucius, who had once taught him: *"In affairs great or small, few succeed without harmonious words to bring them to completion."* *"Few"* means rare; *"without harmonious words"* means without proper discourse. If a state’s affairs fail, one faces punishment—hence *"the calamity of human laws."* If one labors over plans and calculations, even success brings illness from worry—hence *"the calamity of yin and yang."* To ensure that, whether success or failure follows, no calamity arises—only those of virtue can achieve this.

All the above is Confucius’ teaching. *"Now, since receiving my charge, I no longer taste my food—coarse or fine, I know not the difference."* *"Fine"* means refined. He says even coarse food seems fine, for in ordinary times, frequent feasting keeps the kitchen hearths perpetually warm, so the cooks desire coolness but cannot attain it. Now, consumed by worry, his appetite is scant, and the hearths remain cold. *"Having received my charge this morning, by evening I drink ice—my breast burns with anxiety."* *"True nature"* means reality. He has barely received his charge and not yet grasped the task’s reality, yet he already suffers illness. If the mission fails, he faces punishment—two calamities indeed. As a minister, he cannot bear this burden. *"Bear"* means endure. *"Pray, instruct me"* means *"What further teaching can you offer?"* *"Further"* is a grammatical particle.

Confucius replied: *"Under heaven, there are two great precepts: one is fate, the other is duty. A child’s love for parents is fate—it cannot be untied from the heart. A minister’s service to his lord is duty—there is no place where the lord is not present, no escape within heaven and earth. These are called the great precepts.*

*Thus, in serving one’s parents, one finds peace without choosing the place—this is the height of filial piety. In serving one’s lord, one finds peace without choosing the task—this is the height of loyalty. In serving one’s own heart, sorrow and joy do not alter what lies before it; knowing the inevitable and finding peace in it as fate—this is the height of virtue. As a minister and child, one is bound by what cannot be avoided. In acting according to the true nature of affairs, one forgets the self—how then can one find leisure to delight in life and dread death? You may proceed with your mission."*

This passage is entirely sound and proper. Such words on *"the human world"* show that Zhuangzi cannot be dismissed as one who speaks in grandiose, impractical terms.

*"Great precepts"* means great laws. *"Fate"* is what one receives from heaven. A child’s service to parents is born with life—this heart cannot depart for a single day, hence *"it cannot be untied."*

Virtue is what one ought to do in the human world. A minister’s service to his lord is the foremost duty in the world—by the name "lord and minister," every shore within the realm belongs to the king’s subjects. Thus it is said: wherever one goes, there is no lord who is not one’s lord, no place where one is not a subject. Where in heaven and earth could one escape? Therefore, there is no escape within the bounds of heaven and earth.

In serving one’s parents and fulfilling filial piety, one follows their commands east or west, north or south, without choosing a place of comfort to act. Once this heart is fixed on loyalty, though sorrow and joy may arise before it, they cannot alter it. For affairs may be easy or difficult, fortune or misfortune may come, but once the lord’s command is given, it becomes one’s own duty to fulfill. This is the mandate of heaven—what can one do but accept and follow it? To follow fate is to submit to it. One who can do so is a person of utmost virtue.

As a minister or child, one must consider the circumstances one encounters. If misfortune befalls and one faces difficulty, it is unavoidable—one can only act according to the truth of the matter. *Truth* means reality. One must proceed with plain sincerity; how can one then turn to consider oneself? Even if calamity comes and death or life hangs in the balance, there is nothing to be done. "You may proceed with your mission" means you have no choice but to go. "Master" here refers to Duke Ye.

I, Qiu, would now add what I have heard: in close relationships, trust must be mutual; in distant ones, loyalty must be expressed through words. Yet words must be conveyed by someone. Conveying words of mutual joy or mutual anger is the most difficult task in the world. For when both are pleased, there is often excessive praise; when both are angry, there is often excessive blame. All such excess is falsehood. Falsehood breeds distrust, and distrust brings misfortune to the messenger. Thus the *Fa Yan* says: "Convey the constant truth, do not convey excess words, and you will be nearly safe."

What follows shifts again, describing the ways of the human world. *Trust* means having something as proof, like a tally or token. *Mutual compliance* means harmony—this is how close relationships are conducted. But when relationships are distant, one must express one’s feelings through words, and *loyalty* means fully expressing those feelings. Yet how do words reach their destination? They must be transmitted by someone. In transmission, the most difficult are words of mutual joy or mutual anger. When one comes with joy and the other responds in kind, their praise often exceeds what is proper—this is called *excessive praise*. *Excess* means going beyond what is fitting. If both are angry, their blame likewise exceeds what is proper—this is called *excessive blame*. Such overstated speech is necessarily untrue, hence "all excess is falsehood." Since it is untrue, those who hear it will inevitably doubt and not fully believe. *Doubt* is the appearance of suspicion. Once suspicion arises, the ill will of both sides falls upon the messenger, who is then blamed—hence "distrust brings misfortune to the messenger." This is a warning given in light of the mission.

*Fa Yan* refers to an ancient text, cited here as evidence. "Convey the constant truth" means the messenger should only transmit plain, ordinary words, not those that go beyond what is proper. Thus: "do not convey excess words." If one transmits words in this way, one may nearly preserve oneself.

Those who contend with skill and strength begin in openness but often end in deceit. When excess prevails, there is much cunning. Those who drink wine with ritual begin in order but often end in disorder. When excess prevails, there is much strange revelry. All things are like this: they begin in sincerity but often end in pettiness. Their beginnings are simple, but by the end they become great. Words are like wind and waves; actions are like gain and loss. Wind and waves are easily stirred, gain and loss easily endangered. Thus anger arises without cause, and clever speech leads to partiality.

When beasts die, they do not choose their cries; their breath is labored, and in that moment, vicious thoughts arise together. If scrutiny is too severe, unworthy intentions will inevitably respond, though one does not realize it. If one does not realize it, who knows how it will end?

After discussing the transmission of words, this passage turns to analogies of such matters in the world—every sentence reflects human nature, which is the marvel of Zhuangzi. "Contending with skill and strength" refers to those who playfully wrestle today. *Yang* means joy, *yin* means malice. At first, they casually grapple, but in the end, they often come to real blows, for when play becomes excessive, there is much overreaching and cunning. *Strange* means unusual; *excess* means going beyond what is proper.

When people gather to drink, they begin with ritual—this is the orderly arrangement of the initial feast. *Disorder* refers to the clamor and uproar that follow. For when drinking becomes excessive, the revelry often turns strange, sometimes even leading to conflict. "All things are like this" means that other affairs in the human world are often the same. *Sincerity* means trust. When people first come together for a common purpose, they are always honest and trusting, but later, pettiness and deceit arise—this is another matter. What begins as a simple plan may, in the end, become a great affair.

The above speaks generally of the world, then turns to words and actions. For in human dealings, words are the source of wind and waves. *Wind on waves* suggests emptiness and chaos. Once the word *action* is spoken, there is name and trace; with a name, reality is lost. "Wind and waves are easily stirred" means they easily become tumultuous and unceasing. "Gain and loss are easily endangered" means that when reality does not match the name, harm may follow. *Without cause* means without reason—words of anger are often fabricated, arising without justification, hence "anger arises without cause."

Partial speech reflects a one-sided view—florid words are but a skewed account, hence "clever speech, partial words." "In death from joy, no sound is chosen": when one dies in silence, what sound would they select? This metaphor illustrates those who, in anger, craft clever words. Once contention arises, their speech pours forth without pause for selection—just as the common saying goes, "no kind words in a quarrel."

"Qi and breath become tangled": this is anger. "Harshness" means cruelty and ruthlessness. Once anger arises, a cruel heart is born alongside it. If I act thus, those who respond to me, pressed by my severity, will surely harbor unfilial thoughts. At times, it may even lead to mutual harm and destruction, all driven by anger without awareness. If one is moved by anger without self-knowledge, how could they pause to consider the end?

All the above speaks of worldly affairs, where good may turn to evil, thus drawing the discussion to this point.

*End of the Fifth Scroll of the Oral Exegesis of the True Scripture of the Southern Florescence*

*Sixth Scroll of the Oral Exegesis of the True Scripture of the Southern Florescence*
*By Lin Xiang of Yuanzhai*

Thus concludes the "Among the Human World" chapter of the Inner Scrolls. The *Fayan* states: "Do not alter decrees; do not urge completion—excess is but a craving for more. To alter decrees or urge completion courts peril; beauty is perfected in time, while ugliness forms too swiftly to amend. How could one not be cautious?

Moreover, riding the spontaneity of things to roam the mind, entrusting oneself to necessity to nurture the center—this is perfection. What need is there for contrivance in repayment? Better to deliver the mandate in full. This is the difficulty.

Here, the text once more invokes ancient words, concluding the matter of the envoy’s mission. *Ling* refers to the lord’s command: not to alter it is to transmit its unchanging essence. If, upon receiving the command, one privately schemes for success—even to the point of revising its intent—then the affair cannot be served. Whether it succeeds or not must be left to nature; one must not force its completion, hence the admonition: *do not urge completion*. *Yi* means seeking excess. To entertain thoughts beyond the ordinary mind is to harbor a craving for more—this is impermissible. *Guodu* (excess) is to transgress the usual measure, that is, to go beyond what is proper. Altering decrees or urging completion are both excesses of thought, and such schemes in affairs are bound to endanger them—hence *perilous matters*.

Human bonds of harmony are exceedingly difficult to forge; they cannot be achieved in a day but require enduring time to settle—hence *beauty is perfected in time*. Yet a single discordant word or a single unaccommodating act may instantly turn to enmity, leaving no room for amendment—hence *ugliness forms too swiftly to amend*. The meaning here is that turning to enmity is easy, while forging harmony is hard—thus one must be all the more cautious.

If I ride the natural course of things to let my mind wander in spontaneity, entrusting myself to necessity in response, nurturing the center with this intent—this is the utmost. Why then contrive repayment? *Bao* means returning the mandate. Contrivance is excess, a craving for more. *Zhiming* means delivering the lord’s command to Wei with sincerity. Your mission is best served by faithfully executing the lord’s mandate without overthinking success or failure. Even this—delivering the mandate in full sincerity—is a difficult feat. You must strive to fulfill it. Here, the text underscores the word *difficulty*, for navigating this is indeed hard."

Herein lies the meaning of "wandering within the drawn bow’s range, at its center"—the center being the central ground. This chapter is titled "The Human World" precisely to speak of the difficulty of navigating life. This passage exhaustively captures the nuances of worldly affairs; without Zhuangzi’s innate mastery of the Dao, how could one so thoroughly trace these intricate turns?

Some critics claim that Zhuangzi and Laozi saw only the subtlety of the Dao-mind while neglecting the peril of the human heart—such judgments are misguided, born merely of careless reading.

When Yan He was about to become tutor to the crown prince of Duke Ling of Wei, he sought counsel from Qu Boyu, saying: "There is a man here whose virtue is as if Heaven itself has undone him. If I indulge him without restraint, he will endanger our state; if I guide him with restraint, he will endanger me. His wisdom suffices only to recognize others’ faults but not his own—what am I to do with such a one?"

Qu Boyu replied: "Excellent question! Be vigilant, be cautious—first rectify yourself. In form, do not surpass closeness; in heart, do not surpass harmony. Yet even these two carry perils: closeness must not become intrusion, harmony must not become exposure. If in form you draw too close and intrude, you will meet ruin, destruction, collapse, or downfall. If in heart you harmonize too openly, you will invite fame, reputation, calamity, or disaster.

He may act like an infant—then act like an infant with him. He may cast aside all boundaries—then cast aside all boundaries with him. He may know no limits—then know no limits with him. Guide him thus into flawlessness."

Yan He sought instruction from Boyu because he was to serve as the prince’s tutor. "There is a man here" refers to the prince. "His virtue is as if Heaven has undone him" means Heaven has stripped him of discernment. *Undone* here suggests erosion, like frost withering grass—his nature has been worn away by creation. *Without restraint* means without principle; if he is left to his own devices, he will surely endanger the state, but if one attempts to correct him, the harm will first befall oneself. The prince’s cunning is just enough to see others’ faults but not his own—what can be done?

"Rectify yourself" means to begin by ordering your own conduct. *Closeness* means following and yielding; *harmony* means blending and guiding. Outwardly, adopt a respectful and yielding demeanor, while inwardly, maintain a heart of harmony and guidance—thus, "in form, do not surpass closeness; in heart, do not surpass harmony." *Do not surpass* means no method surpasses this.

Yet the text then takes a marvelous turn. *These two*—harmony and closeness—if you yield and become one with him, you overstep into intrusion; if your guiding heart reveals even slight sharpness, you overstep into exposure. To intrude is to lose oneself entirely, hence "ruin, destruction, collapse, or downfall." To expose oneself through fame or reputation invites his envy and harm, hence "fame, reputation, calamity, or disaster."

The phrasing here is most extraordinary. *Infant* describes one like an unknowing child; *without boundaries* describes one without restraint, reckless and unprincipled; *without limits* describes one who acts without considering consequences. Infant, without boundaries, without limits—all depict a person of reckless ignorance. If he is so unknowing and reckless, then follow his lead—thus, "act like an infant with him," "cast aside all boundaries with him," "know no limits with him." When he shows signs of awakening, enlighten him so that he may suddenly awaken, perhaps then entering a state of flawlessness. *Guide him* means to awaken him; *flawlessness* means without fault.

Once, Master Aixuan spoke of this: In Putian of old, there was a man who left his father unburied, squandered his fields and estate to indulge his desires. As his land neared exhaustion, his kinsmen pitied him and collected money to fund the burial. He feigned acceptance, then spent the sum as before. All his relatives grew indignant, until one clansman stepped forth to befriend him. He indulged the man’s every whim, drinking with him through the night until they reached the height of merriment. Then, patting his back, he said: *"Others may be overwhelmed by sorrow, but Yan Hui never alters his joy."* The man suddenly awoke, wept bitterly, returned home, buried his father, and ultimately became a good man. This is precisely the principle at work here.

Do you not know the mantis? It brandishes its arms to block the wheel-ruts of a chariot, unaware of its own incapacity—yet this is the very beauty of its talent. Beware, take heed: one who repeatedly boasts of his fine talents and provokes the world’s taboos courts peril. Do you not know the keeper of tigers? He dares not feed it living prey, lest its killing fury be aroused; nor whole carcasses, lest its tearing fury be provoked. He times its hunger and satiety, appeases its rage—thus the tiger, though of a different kind from man, fawns upon its keeper, for he follows its nature. To defy it is to invite death. Hence: *"Its killing comes from defiance."*

The lover of horses uses a bamboo basket for dung and a clay vessel for urine—this is true devotion. Yet when gnats and horseflies swarm upon the beast, and the groom fails to swat them away in time, the horse will snap its bit, shatter its bridle, and break the trappings of its head and chest. Love may run deep, but a single moment of anger can erase it all. Can one not be cautious?

Below are further parables. The mantis, trusting in the beauty of its talent, seeks to block the chariot’s ruts with its arms—this illustrates how petty talent, puffed with pride, meets great affairs and seldom avoids ruin. *Accumulated* means repeated; *boasting* means vaunting; *peril* means danger. One who repeatedly vaunts his fine talents and provokes the world’s taboos will surely endanger himself. Hence: *"One who accumulates boasts of his beauty courts peril."*

The tiger’s nature is quick to anger, so its keeper must soothe and dispel its rage. Even a tiger, though of a different kind, will fawn upon its keeper—this is nothing more than following its nature. To defy it is to be torn apart. Hence: *"Its killing comes from defiance."*

A *basket* is a bamboo vessel; a *clay pot* is a vessel of plaster. To use these for dung and urine is indeed devotion. But when gnats and horseflies gather on the horse’s body, and the groom fails to swat them away at once, the horse will snap its bit, shatter its bridle, and break the trappings of its head and chest. Its sudden fury obliterates all prior affection. *Groom* here means one who busily tends to the horse; *erase* is akin to *forget*. This shows how long-cultivated goodness can be undone in an instant, while evil takes root before one can correct it. Men may spend a lifetime in companionship, yet a single word can turn them into enemies—such is the difficulty of navigating the world.

Observe the passages on Lord Ye of Gao and Yan He, and you will see how this chapter, *"The Human World,"* clarifies these matters.

When Carpenter Shi traveled to Qi and reached Quyuan, he saw an oak tree used as a village shrine. Its girth could shade an ox, its trunk measured a hundred spans; its height rivaled the mountains, its branches only appearing after ten *ren*. A dozen or more of its side limbs could serve as boats. Spectators thronged like a marketplace, yet the master carpenter did not glance at it, walking past without pause. His disciple, having feasted his eyes, caught up to Carpenter Shi and said: *"Since I took up the axe to follow you, Master, I have never seen timber so magnificent. Why did you refuse to look, walking past without stopping?"*

*"Enough,"* he replied. *"Say no more."*

The tree is but a worthless timber—fashion it into a boat, and it sinks; make it into a coffin or outer casket, and it rots swiftly; shape it into vessels, and they shatter soon; set it as a door or gate, and sap oozes forth; raise it as a pillar, and worms bore through. It is a tree of no use, fit for nothing, and thus it attains such longevity.

Carpenter Shi returned home, and in his dream the oak of the village shrine appeared, saying: *"With what would you compare me? Would you liken me to those so-called 'fine woods'? Think of the crabapple, pear, orange, pomelo, and other fruit-bearing trees—once their fruits ripen, they are plucked and humiliated; their great branches break, their small branches are stripped bare. This is how their very usefulness brings suffering upon their lives. Thus they do not fulfill their natural span but perish midway. All things that strike and clash with the common world are no different. As for me, I have long sought to be of no use, and only now, on the verge of death, have I attained it—this is my great usefulness. Had I been of use, could I have grown so vast? Moreover, you and I are both things—how can one thing pass judgment upon another? And you, a worthless man on the brink of death—what could you know of a worthless tree?"*

Quyuan is the name of a mountain; *li* (oak) is the name of a tree. The shrine stood amid this oak. As the *Analects* says: *"The Xia dynasty used the pine, the men of Zhou used the chestnut"*—in ancient times, every village shrine was centered upon a great tree. *Xu* means to measure with the hands; two hands clasped together make one span. A hundred spans denote great girth; ten *ren* denote great height. If its branches could serve as boats, its trunk’s size may be imagined. *Yan guan* means to gaze until one is sated. *San mu* refers to a useless, discarded tree. *Ye gou* describes sap flowing copiously. *Shu* (pillar) means to erect a post as a column. *Wen mu* refers to trees that are pleasing to the eye and useful. The oak of the shrine appeared in Carpenter Shi’s dream, saying: *"You take me for a worthless tree—is this not comparing me to fine woods?"* The crabapple, pear, orange, pomelo, and other fruit-bearing trees are all fine woods fit for consumption, and thus they are broken and felled by men—this is how their usefulness harms their lives. *Neng* (usefulness) refers to usable talent. *"I have long sought to be of no use, and only now do you recognize it."*

The phrase *"nearly died"* refers to Carpenter Shi’s words—like calling someone a *"half-dead man"* today. *"That which makes me of great use"* means my uselessness is my greatest usefulness, the very reason I preserve my life. Had I been useful, men would have felled me long ago; how then could I have grown so vast? The particle *"且也"* simply emphasizes the preceding *"且"* with an added *"也."*

*"You and I are both things"*—though Carpenter Shi is human and I am an oak, we are both but one thing among all under heaven. Why then do you mock me as a mere thing? Thus it is said: *"You and I are both things—why then do you treat me as a thing?"* In a single sentence, four *"也"* and one *"哉"*—this is one of Zhuangzi’s most striking rhetorical flourishes.

*"You are a useless man yourself—why mock my useless wood?"* Hence the words: *"A nearly dead, useless man—how could he understand a useless tree?"* Carpenter Shi awoke and interpreted his dream.

His disciples asked: *"If you sought uselessness, why did it become a shrine tree? Why?"*

He replied: *"Silent as though speechless, it merely lodged there, enduring scorn as one misunderstood. Had it not become a shrine tree, would it not have been felled long ago? Moreover, what it preserves differs from the common—yet to praise it for its virtue is still far from the truth."*

The term *"诊"* means to divine. Upon hearing the words from his master’s dream, the disciples said: *"This tree’s aspiration—if it sought uselessness, why then must it be used as a shrine tree?"* *"密"* means *"you, keep silent."* *"彼"* refers to the oak. Its becoming a shrine tree was merely a lodging, never expecting that today it would be scorned and reviled by those who do not understand it. *"诟"* means to curse, *"厉"* to humiliate. Had it not become a shrine tree, would it not still have faced the axe? What it preserves differs from the common—yet to judge it by moral praise or blame is far indeed from the truth. *"所保"* means *"what it guards."*

*"且几有翦乎"*—here *"几"* carries the same sense as *"殆."* Nanbo Ziqi roamed the hills of Shang and saw an extraordinary tree. A thousand chariots could shelter beneath it, its shade so dense it concealed the rustling of the wind. Ziqi said: *"What tree is this? It must possess rare qualities!"* Looking up at its slender branches, he saw them gnarled and unfit for beams; looking down at its massive roots, he saw them split and unfit for coffins. Tasting its leaves burned his mouth; smelling it induced a three-day frenzy. Ziqi said: *"This is truly a useless tree—yet it has grown so vast! Alas, the spirit-like person preserves himself through such uselessness."*

In Song there was a place called Xingshi, where oak, cypress, and mulberry thrived. Those with trunks the span of a hand were felled for monkey perches; those three or four spans wide were felled for grand mansions; those seven or eight spans wide were felled for the coffins of the wealthy. Thus they never lived out their natural years but were cut down midway by axes—this is the calamity of being useful. Hence the *Jie* states: *"An ox with a white forehead, a pig with an upturned snout, or a man with hemorrhoids—none may be offered to the river."* The shamans knew this well, deeming them inauspicious. Yet to the spirit-like person, this inauspiciousness is the greatest auspice.

This passage echoes the previous one, though it further elaborates several points. *"见大木焉有异"* means *"a tree so vast it surpasses the ordinary."* Though a thousand chariots could shelter beneath it, its shade was so dense it concealed even the rustling of the wind—hence *"隐将芘其所藾."* *"饱"* refers to the tree’s self-sufficiency, *"藾"* to others seeking its shade. *"轴解"* means *"hollow,"* like the stem of a taro. *"咶"* (pronounced *shì*)—licking its leaves burns the mouth; smelling it intoxicates like wine, so foul is its odor. Yet precisely because it is useless, the tree preserves its life and grows so immense. The spirit-like person of old preserved his life likewise—through uselessness. Hence: *"the spirit-like person through this uselessness."*

*"嗟乎"* is an exclamation of admiration. *"荆氏"* is a place name. Oak, cypress, and mulberry are all useful trees. The previous passage spoke of edible trees; this one speaks of usable ones. *"宜"* means *"suited to the land."* *"杙"* means *"stakes,"* *"丽"* means *"roof beams."* *"高名"* refers to grand households—*"high and bright,"* where ghosts peer into the rooms. The two characters are synonymous, though *"明"* is pronounced differently. *"禅傍"* refers to coffin wood. Thus, in this land of useful trees, some were felled when their trunks were but a hand’s span, others at three or four spans, still others at seven or eight—none could escape. Only by being useful did they bring such disaster upon themselves.

*"解"* refers to an ancient divination text. It states: *"An ox with a white forehead, a pig with a high snout—neither may be used to sacrifice to the river."* In ancient times, humans were sometimes offered to the river, as in the case of Ximen Bao, hence the addition of *"a man with hemorrhoids."* Zhuangzi delighted in such peculiar details. *"适"* means *"to go"*—none of these could be taken to the river for sacrifice. Though the shamans deemed them inauspicious, they did not realize that this very inauspiciousness spared them from slaughter. To the spirit-like person, this inauspiciousness is the greatest auspice.

Both passages speak of the difficulty of navigating the world: those who seek to distinguish themselves inevitably court disaster—hence these parables.

There was a man named Zhili Shu, whose chin rested on his navel, shoulders towered above his head, his topknot pointed skyward, his five viscera’s ducts protruded upward, and his thighs pressed against his ribs. By mending clothes and washing laundry, he earned enough to feed himself; by winnowing grain, he could provide for ten. When the ruler conscripted soldiers, Zhili waved his arms among them; when great labor was demanded, Zhili, citing his chronic illness, was exempted; when grain was distributed to the sick, he received three bushels and ten bundles of firewood. Though his body was deformed, he could still nourish himself and live out his natural years—how much more so one whose virtue is deformed?

*"支离"* describes a body in disarray, *"疏"* is his name. His chin touched his navel, his back was hunched, his shoulders jutted above his head. *"会撮"* refers to his topknot; the ducts of his five viscera all pointed upward due to his curvature. *"两髀"* means his thighs, which pressed against his ribs as his body bent downward. This depicts a man utterly disabled. *"挫针"* means sewing, *"治繲"* washing clothes—his means of survival. *"鼓荚"* means winnowing with a basket, sifting out the coarse to keep the fine grain, hence *"播精足以食十人,"* emphasizing his efficiency.

When the court summoned warriors and selected fighters, he thrust his arms among them, showing that none were chosen over him. Great labor refers to public works, yet he received no credit, for such tasks did not honor him. His merit was like that of the men of Jin in *Zuozhuan*, who built the altar at Si—though they assigned the work to the feudal lords, he was exempt from both military service and corvée, and further received grain and firewood due to his infirmity. This too was a way of preserving oneself through uselessness.

*"Zhīlí"* describes his virtue: the perfected person’s virtue is likewise deformed, for in uselessness lies its greatest use. This aligns with the meaning of the useless tree.

When Confucius traveled to Chu, Jie Yu, the madman of Chu, wandered past his gate and sang:
*"Phoenix! Phoenix! How your virtue has declined!*
*The age to come cannot be awaited, the age past cannot be recalled.*
*When the world follows the Dao, the sage achieves completion;*
*when the world loses the Dao, the sage merely survives.*
*In this present time, one barely escapes punishment.*
*Fortune is lighter than a feather, yet none know how to bear it;*
*disaster is heavier than the earth, yet none know how to avoid it.*
*Enough! Enough! To stand above others with virtue—*
*perilous! Perilous! To tread within marked lines.*
*Tangled brambles! Tangled brambles! Harm not my path;*
*my path winds crookedly—harm not my feet!"*

The mountain tree brings ruin upon itself; the fat of the lamp consumes itself in flame. Cinnamon is edible, so it is felled; lacquer is useful, so it is slashed. All know the use of what is useful, but none know the use of what is useless.

This passage, drawn from the *Analects*, is borrowed to mock the Confucian school. Since the age to come cannot be awaited and the age past cannot be recalled, having been born in this time as this person, one should remain obscure when the times are unworkable—those who stubbornly cling to the idea of saving the world are ignorant of the times. Thus it is said: *"Virtue has declined."* When the world follows the Dao, the sage may accomplish his work; when the world loses the Dao, the sage merely preserves his life. In this present time, an age of chaos, one counts it fortunate merely to escape punishment—how dare one seek anything more? Thus it is said: *"In this present time, one barely escapes punishment."*

To survive in an age of chaos by barely escaping punishment is a fortune as light as a feather, yet you fail to recognize it. *"Bear"* means to accept and possess. In a chaotic age, disaster that befalls the body often leads to execution—heavier than the earth—yet you fail to avoid it. The *Han Poems* says: *"Glory fades before the eye, while calamity looms large as a house."* This expresses the same idea.

*"Enough! Enough!"* is like saying *"Let it be!"*—to exalt oneself with virtue and stand above others is the path to disaster. *"Perilous! Perilous!"* means danger. *"To tread within marked lines"* describes self-imposed restraint, suffering as if walking within drawn boundaries. *"Yáng"* means brightness. Human nature is originally luminous, but if you lose your way and become confused, you will proceed in the world and suffer harm. *"Crooked retreat"* refers to evasion and compromise—unable to follow the true and straight path, you must twist and turn to avoid harm, which will inevitably injure your feet. *"Injure your feet"* means you cannot proceed.

The mountain tree, being useful, invites the axe’s ruin—it brings destruction upon itself. The fat of the lamp, being bright and useful, consumes itself in flame. Cinnamon is felled because it is edible; lacquer is slashed because it is useful. These are all parables of those who cannot conceal themselves, who seek worldly recognition and thus invite disaster. Thus it is said: *"All know the use of what is useful, but none know the use of what is useless."*

*Southern Florescence True Classic Oral Exegesis*, Scroll Six, concludes.
