**Inner Chapters: The Token of Fullness of Virtue/Power**

*Jiang* means "to respond." What one possesses within can respond to what lies without. *Chong* means "full." When one’s virtue/power is full within, one responds naturally to whatever arises.

In Lu there was a limbless man named Wang Tai, whose followers were as numerous as Confucius’s. Chang Ji asked Confucius, “Wang Tai is a limbless man, yet those who follow him divide Lu equally with you. He stands without teaching, sits without discoursing—yet those who go to him empty return full. Is there truly a teaching without words, a shaping of the heart without form? What manner of man is he?”

Confucius said, “He is a sage. I merely came after him and have not yet gone to study with him. I intend to take him as my teacher—how much more should those inferior to me! Why limit it to Lu? I would lead all under Heaven to follow him.”

Chang Ji said, “Though he is limbless, he surpasses even you, Master—how much farther is he above the common man! If so, how does he employ his mind?”

Chang Ji was a disciple of Confucius. “Dividing Lu equally” means that half the people of Lu followed Confucius, and half followed Wang Tai. “Stands without teaching”: he stood with his disciples yet taught nothing. “Sits without discoursing”: he sat with his disciples yet said nothing. Those who went to him arrived empty, with nothing to perceive, but upon seeing him, they returned full of attainment. “Without form”: nothing to be seen. “Shaping of the heart”: the heart is moved and transforms of itself.

Chang Ji, seeing this, questioned Confucius in doubt. “He” refers to Wang Tai. “I merely came after and have not yet gone”: I wish to go see him but have delayed. “Even one such as I would take him as teacher—how much more others!” *Xi jia* means “why only.” “Lead all under Heaven”: I would guide all people to take him as teacher.

“Though he is limbless, he surpasses even the Master—how much farther is he above the common man!” Here, *wang* means “to surpass.” If he surpasses even the Master, he is far above ordinary people. “The Master” refers to Confucius; *yong* means “the common man.”

Confucius said, “Life and death are indeed great matters, yet they cannot make him change.” These five words—“Life and death are indeed great matters”—are a central thread in the *Zhuangzi*. The entire vast canon of Buddhism arises from these five words. This is what is meant by “Life and death are great matters—like saving one’s own head.”

“Cannot make him change” means that though the change of life and death is great, his heart remains unmoved and cannot be altered by it. *Cannot* means “is unable.” “Make him change” means to change along with it. This statement is attributed to Confucius, but it is Zhuangzi’s parable.

Those who criticize it as heterodox say that while other matters are not expounded, this one thing is studied all one’s life—this view is quite correct. Yet in Buddhism, it is precisely because the dull and deluded cling to torpor and cannot be transformed that they are frightened with this, so that they may do good. Though its teaching is flawed, its zeal for saving the world is earnest.

For us Confucians, we cannot but refute its doctrine, yet we should also understand its intent. It holds that for people, regardless of nobility or baseness, what they fear is death. Thus it uses this to coerce them onto the Way. Some say Buddhism fears death and thus pursues this teaching, but this misjudges its heart.

“Though Heaven and Earth collapse, he would not be lost with them.” He is certain of what is real and does not shift with things, commanding the transformations of things while guarding their origin.

“Heaven and Earth collapse” is an exaggerated expression for the destruction of the cosmos. *Lost* means “to fall.” Though Heaven and Earth collapse, he would not fall with them—just as in the earlier saying: “Entering water, he is not drenched; entering fire, he is not burned.”

Reading the *Zhuangzi* differs from the *Analects* and *Mencius*; its language often goes to extremes. This is its stylistic flourish—it does not truly claim that Heaven and Earth can collapse. *Certain* means “clear,” “thoroughly seen.” *Without pretense* means “real.” Such phrases display Zhuangzi’s mastery of diction and phrasing. To say “clear about what is real” would be clumsy.

“Does not shift with things” is the same as “cannot make him change” and “would not be lost with them.” “Commanding the transformations of things” means that the changes of the myriad things all receive their mandate from him—akin to the Chan saying, “When the mind is deluded, the *Lotus Sutra* turns it; when the mind is awakened, it turns the *Lotus Sutra*.”

*Origin* refers to the beginning of the myriad things. “Guarding their origin” means that what this person guards lies in the beginning of things—echoing the earlier idea of “that which has a beginning” and “that which has never had a beginning.” In the *Zhuangzi*, though *origin* is glossed as “beginning,” its meaning goes beyond mere beginning. Only by reading it thus does one grasp its subtlety. “Guarding their origin” is the whole substance; “roaming in their harmony” is its great function.

Chang Ji said, “What does this mean?”

Confucius said, “Viewed from what is different, liver and gallbladder are as distant as Chu and Yue. Viewed from what is the same, the myriad things are all one.”

Ordinary people do not know that the myriad things share a single origin. Even liver and gallbladder seem as distant as Chu and Yue. But knowing that they share a single origin, the myriad things are all one with me.

Observe how these two phrases deploy their language—opening and closing with such skill. Many later masters of prose have employed this mechanism, for the *Zhuangzi* not only expounds subtle principles but also excels in literary refinement, surpassing all other philosophers.

“If so, he no longer knows what is fitting for ears and eyes but roams his heart in the harmony of virtue/power.” Ears are fitting for hearing, eyes for seeing. Yet one who attains this no longer merely listens with the ears or sees with the eyes.

This is what Chan Buddhists call "the six senses originating from a single source." How can sound be observed? Yet we speak of "Observing the Sounds of the World"—though this is heterodox teaching, it carries profound meaning. The harmony of virtue/power is one with Heaven and Earth and the four seasons. This "harmony" is not the moderation of the *Doctrine of the Mean*. To read this text, one must possess a distinct perspective.

Things see their unity but not their loss—seeing the loss of a foot as one would discard dirt. "Things see their unity but not their loss" means perceiving the myriad things as complete, without excess or deficiency. The passage on Kui and the centipede embodies this very idea. This further inverts the dialogue between Gongwen Xuan and Jie Yu.

"Discarding dirt" means being like earth that falls away unnoticed. Changji said: "He cultivates himself through his knowledge. Attaining his mind through his mind, he attains his constant mind—how could things rank him highest?" "Cultivating himself" is self-cultivation. "Through his knowledge" means that with this discernment, one can cultivate the self. "Attaining his mind through his mind" means that with this conscious mind, one attains the original mind. The original mind and the conscious mind are not two things—this is merely how the phrasing unfolds. The intent is that all people possess knowledge and all possess minds; if one fully realizes them, one can cultivate the self and attain the mind—nothing extraordinary. Thus, it is called "attaining the constant mind." "Ranking highest" means esteeming. It does not say "esteem" but "rank highest"—this is why Zhuangzi’s prose is so extraordinary.

"Things" refers to people. Confucius said: "People do not mirror themselves in flowing water but in still water—only stillness can still the many." Flowing water and still water both serve as metaphors for the mind. The flowing cannot be stilled; only one who can still the mind is uniquely worthy among people. The multitude seek stillness through desire, but only this person truly attains it. Thus, it is said: "Only stillness can still the many." This line suggests that those who cannot settle their minds seek instruction from him, and he can teach them to find stillness. Yet how extraordinary are these six words!

This echoes the Chan saying: "Bring me your mind, and I will settle it for you." A student said: "I have sought my mind, but it cannot be found." The master replied: "I have settled your mind for you." This is precisely the meaning of this passage.

Endowed by earth, only the pine and cypress remain verdant through winter and summer; endowed by heaven, only Shun stands upright—how fortunate to rectify his own life, thereby rectifying the lives of all. Comparing the planted pine to Shun, and Shun to Wang Tai, it speaks only of what they received from heaven as uniquely distinct from the multitude, thus able to align their own nature and align the nature of others. Here, "life" is simply "nature."

Some may ask: How can Shun be compared to Wang Tai? To read *Zhuangzi* thus is to speak dreams before a fool. The proof of preserving one’s beginning lies in the substance of fearlessness. A single brave warrior charges into nine armies, seeking fame and trusting in himself—yet even he is thus. "Proof" means evidence, verification. "Preserve" means to guard, to hold fast to the initial word and find therein both evidence and verification. This single word "trust" unfolds into the next line. The word "substance" follows "fearlessness"—without this substance, one cannot but fear.

The "nine armies" refer to a multitude of soldiers. Perhaps in the Warring States period, there were formations of nine ranks—this is not necessarily bound by the conventions of the Son of Heaven’s six armies or the feudal lords’ three. "Trusting in himself" means self-assurance. Men like Jing Ke and Nie Zheng sought fame through self-trust. They held fast to this single trust, unwavering even in life and death—how much more so for one who embodies the Way?

This passage brings to mind those in Buddhist texts who sit upon coiled pythons or guard tiger dens—it is nothing but this substance of fearlessness. *Zhuangzi* saw such things firsthand; these are not mere allegories. How much more so for one who governs heaven and earth, gathers the ten thousand things, lodges in the six bones, models the ears and eyes, unifies the knowing of knowledge, yet whose heart never dies?

To "govern heaven and earth" is for heaven to cover and earth to bear, for heaven to generate and earth to complete—each fulfilling its office. "Gather" means to assemble. The ten thousand things assemble as they are gathered, embodying the idea that "heaven and earth are born with me, and the ten thousand things are one with me." Mencius said, "The ten thousand things are all complete within me"—this too is the meaning of gathering the ten thousand things, though the phrasing differs.

"Lodging in the six bones" means the six bones are but a dwelling for the self. "Modeling the ears and eyes" aligns with the idea of not knowing the proper use of ears and eyes. The eye models the eye yet does not stop at seeing; the ear models the ear yet does not stop at hearing—hence "modeling the ears and eyes." "The knowing of knowledge": the first "knowing" is pronounced *zhi* (wisdom), the second as *zhi* (knowledge). Wisdom is received from nature; knowledge is the function of wisdom. Because it is received from heaven, there is nothing it does not know—hence "the knowing of knowledge." The heart that perceives nothing is called dead.

He will choose a day to ascend and reach the farthest. People follow accordingly. How would he deign to treat things as affairs? "Ascend" means to rise; "reach" means to arrive. The annotations reading *jia* as *gu* or *xia* as *ha* are both incorrect.

He would not choose a day to reach the Way—this means he does not wait for a chosen day to ascend and arrive at the Way, for there is no time when he is not in the Way, which is to say the Way cannot be departed from for even a moment.

The reason people follow and study under Wang Tai is simply this—this "this" is emphatic. "To treat things as affairs": "things" refers to people. He would not deign to treat people as affairs. For people seek to study under him; he never seeks to teach them.

Shentu Jia, a man without feet, studied together with Zheng Zichan under Bohun Wuren. Zichan said to Shentu Jia: "If I leave first, you stay; if you leave first, I stay." The next day, they again sat together in the same hall on the same mat. Zichan said to Shentu Jia: "If I leave first, you stay; if you leave first, I stay. Now I am about to leave—can you not stay? Or is it that you have not yet [understood]?" Moreover, when you see one in office, you do not avoid him—do you consider yourself equal to one in office? Shentu Jia replied: "In the Master’s gate, are there truly those in office who act thus? Do you delight in your office and put others after yourself? I have heard it said: If a mirror is bright, dust does not settle; if it settles, it is not bright. To dwell long with the worthy is to be without fault. Now, what you seek most is the Master. Yet you still speak thus—is this not a fault?"

Zichan said: "Since you are already as you are, you still contend with Yao in goodness. By your virtue, are you not capable of self-reflection?" "If I leave, you stay; if you leave, I stay"—this was to avoid each other. Yet Shentu Jia did not keep to the agreement. "Not avoiding" means not yielding. "Equal" means the same. "One in office" refers to himself. He meant: If you and I go out together, you would be equal to one in office. "Putting others after" means putting oneself first. To put oneself first and others after is to value oneself and belittle others. With learning, one’s vision becomes broad. "Seek" means to pursue. You study under the Master to broaden your vision, yet you remain so narrow—is this not so? The phrase "seek most" is excellent. The four words "contend with Yao in goodness" are most striking—since you are already maimed, even if you could do good, could you be like Yao? "Self-reflection" means he does not measure himself.

Shentu Jia said: "Those who describe their faults and claim they ought not to have lost [their feet] are many; those who do not describe their faults and yet ought not to have kept [their feet] are few. To know there is nothing to be done and yet accept it as fate—only one of virtue can do this. Wandering within Yi’s drawn bow, the center is the target, yet to miss it is fate. Many are those with whole feet who laugh at my lack of feet. I would flare up in anger, but when I came to the Master’s place, I would return to calm, not knowing whether the Master had washed me with goodness. I have wandered with you for nineteen years, yet you have never known I was maimed. Now you wander with me within the form, yet you seek me outside the form—is this not a fault?"

Zichan, startled, changed his expression and said: "You need not speak further." "Describe" means to recount. Many recount their faults and claim their feet ought not to have been lost. Few do not speak of their faults yet ought not to have kept their feet. Only one of virtue knows that all things have their fate—how could man do anything about it? These three sentences describe three kinds of people. "Accept it as fate" means to follow fate. The passage about wandering within the drawn bow is most extraordinary—this is what the *Yi* means by "treading on a tiger’s tail." Laozi said: "My greatest trouble is that I have a body." In this life, every movement is a perilous moment. The *Yi*’s metaphor of the tiger’s tail is already striking, yet Zhuangzi speaks of Yi’s drawn bow. "Within the drawn bow" refers to the place where the arrow is aimed when the bow is drawn. None was a better archer than Yi, and the center of the drawn bow was where he could not miss—this is a metaphor for the world’s dangers. How much more so in the Warring States era was this saying apt? That one’s heart is fortunate not to be struck is a matter of fate.

The phrase "废然乃自失" expresses the sense of losing oneself entirely in such anger. "反" means to return—upon seeing the master, one returns, having lost all cause for anger. The word "洗" is particularly fine, suggesting that being taught the good Dao is like being cleansed without one’s awareness. The line "形骸内外" is most excellent, all of which is absent in previous texts. Those who praise it say it captures eloquence, much like the *Zuozhuan*’s remark about the people of Lu being quick-witted.

In Lu, there was a crippled man named Shushan Wuzhi, who came to see Confucius by hobbling after him. Confucius said: "You were not careful. Having already suffered such misfortune, what good does coming now do?" Wuzhi replied: "I was ignorant of what truly mattered and recklessly used my body, which is why I lost my foot. Now that I come, I still possess what is noble about the foot—my nature—and so I strive to preserve it. Heaven covers all without exception, and Earth bears all without limit. I took you, Master, to be like Heaven and Earth, yet how could I have known you would be like this?" Confucius said: "I am indeed narrow-minded. Why not come in? Let me share what I have heard." Wuzhi departed, and Confucius said to his disciples: "Take heed! Though Wuzhi is crippled, he still strives to study and make amends for his past misdeeds. How much more should those of complete virtue do so?"

Wuzhi later said to Lao Dan: "Is Confucius not yet a perfected person? Why does he persist in treating learning as a guest, seeking to be known for strange and marvelous feats? Does he not realize that the perfected person sees such things as shackles?" Lao Dan replied: "Why not simply let him see life and death as a single thread, the permissible and impermissible as one continuum? If he could cast off those shackles, would that not suffice?" Wuzhi said: "Heaven has shaped him thus—how could he undo it?"

"踵见" means to follow and meet. "不知务" means not understanding what truly matters. "尊足者" refers to one’s nature. The phrase "尊足" is strikingly apt—what is noble lies not outside the body. "宾宾" refers to a reverent demeanor, as Sima explains. "諔诡幻怪" simply means a love of fame. "己桎梏" means fame is a burden to oneself. "天刑之" means Heaven punishes him by withholding the Dao.

Zhuangzi uses Confucius as a mouthpiece, sometimes humbling him, sometimes exalting him—all is allegory. Yet in this passage, he says: "Though Wuzhi is crippled, he still strives to study and make amends for his past misdeeds. How much more should those of complete virtue do so?" This teaching is also beneficial to the world’s instruction. "Life and death as a single thread, the permissible and impermissible as one continuum" echoes the *Qi Wu* chapter’s idea of affirming what is affirmable and negating what is negatable.

Duke Ai of Lu asked Confucius: "In Wei, there is an ugly man named Aitai Ta. Men who live with him grow attached and cannot leave. Women who see him beg their parents, saying, 'I would rather be this man’s concubine than another’s wife'—and there are more than ten such cases. He never initiates, only harmonizes. He holds no lordly position to save people from death, no wealth to fill their bellies, and his ugliness shocks the world. Yet he harmonizes without leading, his knowledge does not extend beyond the four bounds, and both men and women gather before him. There must be something extraordinary about him. I summoned him to observe, and indeed, his ugliness shocked the world. Yet after less than a month in my company, I took notice of his character. Before a year had passed, I trusted him, and the state had no minister. I offered him the governance of the state. He responded listlessly, as if declining, yet when I pressed him, he accepted. I felt ashamed, but in the end, I entrusted him with the state. Soon after, he left me and departed. I grieved as if I had lost something, as if there were no one left to share joy in ruling the state. What manner of man is he?"

"恶人" refers to one whose appearance is ugly. "不倡常和" means he does nothing but harmonize. "无君人之位" means he holds no noble authority. "聚禄" means wealth. "望人之腹" means to fill their bellies—"望" means fullness, as in the full moon. Observe such phrasing: how could Zhuangzi’s brush ever be matched? "知不出乎四域" means his knowledge does not transcend the world. "雌雄合其前" means he is intimate with all things, like birds that do not startle. "闷然" means responding without intent. "泛" means without attachment. "寡人丑乎" means "I am ashamed." "授之国" means entrusting him with state governance. "恤焉若有亡" echoes the Han king’s lament of losing his right and left hands.

Confucius said: "I once traveled to Chu and saw piglets nursing from their dead mother. After a moment, they looked around in alarm and fled, for they no longer saw their mother in her and no longer recognized her. What they loved in their mother was not her form but what animated her form. Warriors who die in battle are buried without funeral ornaments, and those who lose their feet no longer cherish their shoes—both have lost their root. The palace women of the Son of Heaven do not cut their nails or pierce their ears. Those who marry remain outside the palace and are no longer employed. Even one whose form is whole is sufficient for this—how much more one of complete virtue? Now, Aitai Ta has not spoken yet is trusted, has no merit yet is beloved, and is offered governance with the fear he might refuse. He must be one whose talent is complete and whose virtue is unmanifest."

The piglet analogy shows that love and aversion do not depend on the beauty or ugliness of form. "眴若" means a startled appearance. "不得类" means no longer resembling what came before. "已" means oneself. It says they no longer see their mother in her former likeness, hence the two-part phrasing.

These are all instances where Zhuangzi wields his brush playfully. The theory that love depends on form—if judged by the standards of *mingjiao* (Confucian moral governance)—would be gravely culpable. How could this align with the ancient principle of "serving the dead as one serves the living," or the reluctance to let one’s kin perish in spirit? Such passages in his descriptions may overreach, yet one must not use them as strict measures, nor remain ignorant of their impropriety.

To be slain in battle without a funeral fan is not a proper observance of mourning rites. *Zi* means "to employ." The amputee feels no attachment to shoes, for external adornments have no place. This, too, illustrates that virtue resides within, not without. The palace attendants of the Son of Heaven do not trim their nails or pierce their ears, embodying the idea of preserving wholeness in form. Those newly wed are exempt from service, as recorded in the *Rites*—they "cannot be employed again," meaning they are not to be conscripted within the palace. This analogy of bodily wholeness serves to depict the meaning of complete virtue.

Duke Ai asked, "What is meant by *cai quan* (complete talent)?"

Confucius replied: "Life and death, survival and ruin, poverty and wealth, worthiness and unworthiness, slander and praise, hunger and thirst, cold and heat—these are the vicissitudes of affairs, the workings of fate. They alternate before us day and night, yet even knowledge cannot trace their beginnings. Thus, they are insufficient to disturb harmony or enter the numinous storehouse. One who maintains ease, flow, and unobstructed joy—who allows day and night to renew without cessation, bringing springtime to all things—is one who meets each moment and gives rise to timeliness in the heart. This is called *cai quan*."

This passage culminates in the phrase *"cai quan de bu xing"* (complete talent and unmanifest virtue). Earlier, it was said that even life and death—so vast—cannot alter one’s constancy; here, it enumerates life and death, survival and ruin, poverty and wealth, slander and praise, hunger and thirst, cold and heat to exhaust the point. This is where the text unfolds its full meaning. *Gui* means "to seek." These vicissitudes of affairs, these workings of fate, succeed one another day and night before our eyes, yet even the wise cannot trace their origins—one can only say they arise of themselves. "Insufficient to disturb harmony" means they cannot disrupt the harmony within the breast, echoing the earlier line "not to be altered by them." "Not entering the numinous storehouse" means they do not move the heart. *He yu tong* (harmony, ease, flow) form a single idea: *yu* means joy, *tong* means unobstructed. With the heart unmoved, one naturally attains harmony, ease, joy, and flow without losing *dui* (joy). This sentence is quintessential Zhuangzi. *He yu tong* may also be rendered as "all-pervading completeness," as seen in later chapters. "Day and night without cessation" means constant renewal without halt. *Que* means "to stop." "Bringing springtime to all things" means adapting to circumstances with joy. *Wu* refers to affairs. The word *chun* (spring) here aligns with *dui* (joy). "Meeting each moment and giving rise to timeliness in the heart" echoes the Buddhist sutra’s "abiding nowhere yet giving rise to the heart." *Jie* means "to respond," *shi* means "timeliness." Responding to affairs without bias or stagnation is called "giving rise to timeliness in the heart." *Cai* means "essence," as in Mencius’ "Heaven’s bestowed essence." *Cai quan* thus means "preserving one’s essential nature."

Duke Ai asked, "What is meant by *de bu xing* (unmanifest virtue)?"

Confucius replied: "Stillness is the fullness of water; it can serve as a model. Within, it is preserved, and without, it does not sway. Virtue is the cultivation of perfected harmony. *De bu xing* means nothing can depart from it."

Another day, Duke Ai told Minzi: "At first, I believed that by facing south as ruler of the world, holding the people’s guiding principles and grieving over their deaths, I had attained the utmost understanding. Now, having heard the words of the perfected one, I fear I lack substance, have treated my person lightly, and nearly lost my state. I and Kong Qiu are not lord and subject—we are friends in virtue."

*De bu xing* means virtue is nowhere visible. When water is still, it is level and can serve as a model. *Fa* means "standard." *Nei bao* means "preserved within," *wai bu dang* means "not swaying without"—this rephrases the earlier "mirroring still water." *He* is the harmony of the center. *Cheng* means "complete." To complete the harmony within one’s nature is the cultivation of virtue. *De bu xing* manifests through all things, meaning virtue is present everywhere, not confined to a single aspect—hence "nothing can depart from it." The phrase "holding the people’s guiding principles" is excellent, signifying the reins of governance. "Grieving over their deaths" means loving the people. How could Duke Ai "face south as ruler of the world"? These are all instances where Zhuangzi’s brush overreaches without restraint.

"Not lord and subject, but friends in virtue" shares the same intent as Mencius’ "befriending," both being allegorical and not to be taken literally.

Yinqi, Zhili, and Wu Shen advised Duke Ling of Wei. The duke delighted in them, yet when he looked upon whole men, their necks seemed frail. The man with a great goiter like a jar advised Duke Huan of Qi. The duke delighted in him, yet when he looked upon whole men, their necks seemed frail. Thus, virtue may excel while form is forgotten. People forget what should be forgotten yet remember what should not—this is called *cheng wang* (true forgetting).

*Yinqi* means a hunched back. *Zhili* describes a stooped figure. *Wu Shen* means lipless. Hunchbacked, stooped, and lipless—these are extreme deformities. *Jianjian* describes a slender, elongated appearance. *Weng āng da ying* refers to a large neck tumor. These two examples illustrate that human likes and dislikes do not lie in outward form. The deformed and tumorous men found favor with their lords, while whole men seemed inferior—hence "virtue may excel while form is forgotten," meaning one loves virtue and forgets form. "People forget what should be forgotten yet remember what should not" is an excellent couplet, echoing Mencius’ analogy of "one finger not matching others."

What may be forgotten is form; what must not be forgotten is virtue. *Cheng wang* (true forgetting) is genuine forgetting. To know form yet not know virtue—this is true forgetting.

Thus, the sage wanders freely, yet knowledge becomes a blight, restraint becomes glue, virtue becomes an attachment, and skill becomes trade. The sage does not scheme—why then employ knowledge? He does not carve—why then employ glue? He suffers no loss—why then employ virtue? He does not barter—why then employ trade? These four are the nourishment of Heaven. That which Heaven nourishes is Heaven’s sustenance. Having received the Mandate from Heaven, why then rely on man?

The sage’s wandering is what is meant by "the mind roaming in Heaven." *Zhi* (knowledge) is the use of wisdom in affairs. *Yue* (restraint) is self-discipline through ritual. *Gong* (skill) is technical ability. *Nie* (blight) is calamity. *Jiao* (glue) is mud, or fixation. *Jie* (attachment) is clinging to externals while forgetting the internal. *Shang* (trade) is commerce, like buying fame under Heaven. When the mind roams in Heaven, one realizes these four are all burdens.

The sage does not scheme in the world, so he has no use for knowledge. Without carving, he naturally aligns with principle, so he has no use for restraint. Guarding the internal and having no concern for the external, he has no use for virtue. Not seeking to sell himself, he has no use for skill. These four—no scheming, no carving, no loss, no bartering—are the nourishment of Heaven. Heaven’s nourishment is Heaven’s emolument, akin to Heaven’s nobility. Having received sustenance from Heaven, why rely on man? It is like possessing Heaven’s nobility yet not seeking man’s rank.

To generate circumstances in the heart through attachment—talent remains whole while virtue does not manifest. The knowledge of a single wisdom: in earlier passages, the three characters *jie*, *de*, and *zhi* were laudable, yet here they become pejorative. This shift in brushwork, unmoored from consistency, marks the text as heterodox.

One has the form of a man yet lacks the passions of a man. Having the form of a man, one mingles with others; lacking the passions of a man, right and wrong do not adhere to the self. How small and petty—thus belonging to man! How vast and great—thus completing one’s Heaven!

Hui Shi asked Zhuangzi: "Do men truly have no passions?"
Zhuangzi replied: "Yes."
Hui Shi said: "If a man has no passions, how can he be called a man?"
Zhuangzi said: "The Dao gives him his appearance; Heaven gives him his form. How can he not be called a man?"
Hui Shi said: "If he is called a man, how can he have no passions?"
Zhuangzi said: "This is not what I mean by passions. What I call having no passions is that a man does not allow likes and dislikes to internally harm his person, but constantly follows nature without augmenting life."
Hui Shi said: "If one does not augment life, how can one preserve the self?"
Zhuangzi said: "The Dao gives him his appearance; Heaven gives him his form. He does not allow likes and dislikes to internally harm his person. Now you expend your spirit externally, exhaust your essence, lean against a tree to chant, and recline on a withered catalpa to doze. Heaven bestowed your form upon you, yet you clamor about ‘hard and white.’"

This passage records the debate between Zhuangzi and Hui Shi. The lines beginning "One has the form of a man" are Zhuangzi’s usual words, which Hui Shi then questioned.

"Mingling with others" means belonging to the same kind as men. "Right and wrong do not adhere to the self" means being unperturbed in all circumstances, transcending right and wrong. "Completing one’s Heaven" means following Heaven as one’s companion. If a man can rise above right and wrong, unperturbed in all circumstances, then he follows Heaven as his companion, and his achievements are vast.

"Heaven gives him his form" means having physical existence. "The Dao gives him his appearance" means all things must have their principles. What I call having no passions is that a man does not allow the passions of likes and dislikes to internally harm his person. Where there is gain, there is loss; by constantly following nature, there is neither gain nor loss. To speak of excess and deficiency is to speak of illness. Augmenting life is the illness of excess. When likes and dislikes arise from nature without attachment, there is neither loss nor gain.

Hui Shi said, "If one does not augment life, how can one preserve the self?"—taking augmentation of life as the means to sustain life, which was not Zhuangzi’s intent. Zhuangzi and Hui Shi were the closest of friends. Hui Shi was broadly learned and fond of debate, so Zhuangzi mocked him for expending his spirit externally and exhausting his essence.

"Expending spirit externally" means the spirit is used outside, like failing to keep it settled. *Gaowu* (withered catalpa) refers to using a dried tree as a desk. *Min* means weariness. *Jianbai* (hard and white) is the name of a debate. *Xuan* means bestowed. Heaven bestowed your form upon you, yet you torment yourself thus—why? The single word "clamor" inspired Han Yu to compose an entire preface. With such marvels, how could Zhuangzi not be a master of prose?

*Oral Exegesis of the Southern Florescence True Scripture*, Scroll Seven concludes.
*Oral Exegesis of the Southern Florescence True Scripture*, Scroll Eight
By Lin Xiang of Yuanzhai

**The Great and Venerable Master, Part One**

The Great and Venerable Master is the Dao. It is like saying the sage models Heaven, Heaven models the Dao, and the Dao models spontaneity. To know what Heaven does and to know what man does—this is perfection. To know what Heaven does is to know that it gives life. To know what man does is to use what his knowledge knows to nourish what his knowledge does not know, so that he completes his Heaven-appointed years without dying prematurely—this is the fullness of knowledge.

Yet there is a danger: knowledge depends on something else to be fitting, but what it depends on is not yet fixed. How do we know that what I call Heaven is not man, or that what I call man is not Heaven? Only when there is a true person is there true knowledge.

Man’s life arises entirely from Heaven, and so it is called what Heaven does. Yet living in the world, there are human affairs that must be fulfilled, and so it is called what man does. When human affairs are complete, Heavenly principle appears, and thus one uses what his wisdom knows to nourish what his wisdom does not know. Not exhausting oneself to harm life, one thus completes his Heaven-appointed years. Having known both Heaven and man, this is called the fullness of knowledge. These several lines are quite correct.

Yet from "there is a danger" onward, this turn is especially fine. Knowledge depends on something else to be fitting, but what it depends on lies outside. Sometimes one attains without seeking, sometimes one must seek to attain—neither can be fixed. "Fitting" means settled. Only after a matter is settled does one see whether it is fitting or not. This single word "fitting" is most skillfully placed.

If one thinks it comes from Heaven, one must still seek to attain it; if one thinks it comes from man, there are things one seeks yet does not attain. This is what is meant by "how do we know that Heaven is not man, or that man is not Heaven?" For example, whether one lives long or dies young is all a matter of fate, yet it is also said, "One who knows fate does not stand beneath a crumbling wall." This shows that what Heaven does and what man does are not fixed. Zhuangzi’s insight into worldly affairs is most keen—such passages deserve careful reflection.

Only when there is a true person is there true knowledge. This refers to one who embodies the Dao. What is a true person? The true persons of old were not averse to scarcity, did not boast of success, and did not scheme for affairs. In this way, when they erred, they did not regret; when they succeeded, they did not feel self-satisfied. In this way, they climbed high without trembling, entered water without getting wet, and entered fire without feeling heat. Such was their knowledge’s ability to ascend to the Dao.

"Scarcity" means insufficiency. "Not averse" means compliance. When facing insufficiency, they simply accepted it. Though their achievements were great, they did not take pride in them. "Boast" means to brag. *Shi* (士) and *shi* (事) were interchangeable in ancient script. As in the *Odes of Dongshan*: "Do not *shi* the marching ranks." *Mo* means to scheme. They acted without intention, and so it is said they did not scheme for affairs.

"When they erred, they did not regret"—"erred" means to fail, like what is now called "making a mistake." "When they succeeded, they did not feel self-satisfied"—"succeeded" means to hit the mark, like what is now called "just right." When things succeeded, they did not feel self-satisfied or overly pleased. In all matters, whether failing or succeeding, they entrusted it all to spontaneity, not regretting failure or rejoicing in success.

"Climbed high without trembling, entered water without getting wet, entered fire without feeling heat"—this is to say there was nowhere they did not feel at ease. "Their knowledge’s ability to ascend to the Dao" means their insight deeply penetrated the Dao.

The two "in this way" phrases show Zhuangzi’s stylistic force. *Zhi* (知) and *zhi* (智) are the same. *Jia* means to reach. The true persons of old slept without dreaming, woke without worry, ate without relishing, and breathed deeply. The true person’s breath reached his heels, while ordinary people’s breath reached only their throats. Those who are cringing in speech sound as if they are retching. The deeper their desires, the shallower their Heavenly mechanism.

"Slept without dreaming"—their spirit was settled, which is what is meant by "the perfected person does not dream." "Woke without worry"—they engaged with things without contending in their minds. "Ate without relishing"—they had no desire to be full, which is what the Chan school calls "filling the hunger storehouse." "Breathed deeply"—the true person’s breath reached his heels, while ordinary people’s breath reached only their throats. This is the origin of the Daoist discourse on cultivation and nourishment.

When the spirit is settled, the breath that enters and exits is deep, rising from the heels to the mouth and nose, which is why there is the method of counting breaths. When the spirit is not nourished, the breath that enters and exits stops only at the throat. The difference between stillness and agitation is manifest in the body.

*Wa* means to spit. *Ai* means the throat. Without true insight, speech remains on the surface, and so one is easily cringing before others. This line, when examined alongside Chan inquiry, reveals the savor of Zhuangzi’s words. For example, what is called "frog Chan" only leaps once—this is the ease of cringing like retching.

"Desires" are human desires; "Heavenly mechanism" is Heavenly principle. "Deep and shallow" refers to what the elders called the waxing and waning of Heavenly principle and human desire in proportion. This passage, with each sentence forming a coherent thread, is the origin of both Daoist and Buddhist texts. It shows that this old master’s self-realization cannot be read carelessly. It is a pity that we do not see Dahui, Zhang Pingshu, and others discuss this with him.

The true persons of old did not delight in life or hate death. Their going forth was not joyful, their returning was not resistant. They came and went with ease, nothing more. They did not forget their beginning, nor did they seek their end. They received and rejoiced in it, forgot and returned to it—this is called not using the mind to harm the Dao, not using man to assist Heaven. This is called the true person.

This passage speaks only of life and death. "Going forth" is birth; "returning" is death. "Came and went with ease," "did not forget their beginning," "did not seek their end," "received and rejoiced," "forgot and returned"—all this is summed up in the two words "life" and "death."

Those who "do not resist" do not go against; it is the meaning of following with ease. "Not forgetting their beginning, not seeking their end"—this is what is called "tracing the origin and grasping the end," and thus they know the discourse on life and death.

Someone asked Master Zhaozhou, "Where will the Master go after a hundred years?" Zhaozhou replied, "After the fire burns, it becomes a single blade of thatch." This is not seeking their end. "Receiving" means receiving their form, which is bestowed by Heaven—how could they not rejoice in it? "Returning" means going back; they return whole and without attachment, hence it is said, "forgot and returned."

"Not using the mind to harm the Dao"—the mind is the Dao, and outside the mind there is no Dao. "Not using man to assist Heaven"—longevity and early death are fated, and human effort cannot add to it. These ten characters deserve careful reading. "Not harming" means not departing from it even for a moment.

If this is so, their will is steadfast, their countenance serene, their forehead broad and upright. They are chill like autumn, warm like spring; their joy and anger flow with the four seasons, harmonizing with things as they should, yet none know their limit.

"Will" means having a firm resolve. The meaning of the words in this text cannot be sought through the methods of the *Analects* or *Mencius*. The ancients said that the Buddhists, in speaking of nature, only speak of the mind—since they are already heterodox, how can one seek the meaning of our texts through theirs?

"Serene" means still. Facing the wall for nineteen years is where his countenance is serene. "Broad" means large; "forehead" is the brow. Because his head is held upright, his forehead appears broad. "Chill" is anger; "warm" is joy. Joy and anger without intent are like the four seasons of spring and autumn.

"Limit" is the point of cessation. "Things" are affairs. Responding to affairs, each finds its proper place, yet there is no fixed point of cessation—this is what is meant by "their mind moving with the times as they encounter them."

Thus, when the sage uses troops, he may destroy a state yet not lose the people’s hearts; his beneficence extends to ten thousand generations yet he is not partial to men. Using troops poisons the world; bestowing beneficence loves the world. Both are done without intent, so those whose states are destroyed do not resent it, and those who receive his virtue say, "What has the Emperor’s power to do with me?"

Our texts also contain this meaning. However, Zhuangzi’s brush, in its depictions, often goes too far. For instance, when he says, "His beneficence extends to ten thousand generations yet he is not benevolent," or "He kills the myriad things yet he is not righteous"—these are of the same kind.

Thus, one who delights in harmonizing with things is not a sage; one who has partiality is not benevolent. One who follows the seasons is not worthy; one who does not comprehend gain and loss is not a gentleman. One who pursues fame loses himself and is not a scholar; one who destroys himself without authenticity is not a servant of others.

Take Hu Bujie, Wu Guang, Boyi, Shuqi, Jizi, Xuyu, Ji Ta, and Shentu Di—they are servants of others’ servitude, following others’ paths, yet not following their own. These lines are mocking the sages and worthies to illustrate how the true person is beyond reach. The underlying meaning is that there are no true persons in the world, that none know the utmost Dao, and that from the sages downward, none—great or small—are genuine.

One who "delights in harmonizing with things" finds joy in the sage’s mind when not a single thing fails to find its place—"harmonizing" means finding its place. If one takes delight in this without bearing the vicissitudes of things, one is not a sage. Without intent, there is no near or far; to have near and far is to have intent, and having intent is not benevolence.

One who moves with the seasons knows the seasons of Heaven. To take this as ability is also not worthy. The gentleman can pursue gain and avoid harm, but if he cannot unite gain and harm as one, he is still not a gentleman. The scholar must seek fame, yet fame is the guest of reality—pursuing the guest, he loses himself, hence he is not a scholar.

"Authentic" means natural. One who does not know the natural and labors to the point of losing himself is a servant of others, not one who employs others. These are all excessive arguments.

Thus, from Hu Bujie onward—such as Boyi, Shuqi, and Jizi—they are all ridiculed as servants of others who have lost themselves, hence it is said they "do not follow their own path." Though the language is extreme, the writing is also marvelous.

Hu Bujie, Wu Guang, Xuyu, Ji Ta, and Shentu Di were all worthies of old. "Not following their own path" means not attaining their own fulfillment.

The true persons of old had a bearing upright yet not aloof, appearing insufficient yet not submissive. They were yielding yet not weak, expansive yet not ostentatious. They seemed joyful yet solemn, as if compelled. Their demeanor was imposing, their virtue restraining. They were stern as if worldly, yet untamable. They seemed fond of seclusion, yet their words were forgotten.

They took punishment as their body, ritual as their wings, wisdom as their timing, and virtue as their guide. "Taking punishment as their body" means they were lenient in their severity. "Taking ritual as their wings" means it was how they moved through the world. "Taking wisdom as their timing" means they acted only when unavoidable. "Taking virtue as their guide" means that, like one with feet reaching the hills, others truly saw them as diligent in conduct.

This passage of depiction has its refined and gentle aspects, but it is described too starkly. Buddhist texts contain many such examples.

Appearance is form, demeanor is bearing—righteous yet not partisan, standing centered without leaning. They seemed lacking yet did not humble themselves. "Bearing" implies submission and self-abasement, as in the *Zuozhuan*, where the deputy is called "the bearer." "In harmony" describes a relaxed bearing. "Flesh" refers to the corners of virtue. "Fleshy yet not firm" means possessing the corners of virtue without sharp edges. "Expansive" describes a state of ease and openness. "Vacuous" means being as if empty. "Unadorned" signifies substance. "Joyful" describes a pleased appearance, seeming glad yet not truly so. "Humbled" means lowered, suggesting that in engaging with the world and responding to things, there is an unavoidable reluctance, much like responding only after hesitation. "Clear" means gathered, a look of fullness and contentment—its vitality manifesting in the face, hence "advancing my countenance." "Restrained by my virtue" refers to what is called "the auspiciousness of an empty chamber." "Restrained" means to halt. "In harmony" describes a self-contented bearing. "Stern" conveys severity; though they appeared stern like worldly people, their inner truth held a humbled reluctance, hence "seeming worldly." "Vigilant" means great, unyielding to the world, hence "untamable." "Fond of seclusion" means unwilling to speak. "Joined" means united, dense—before speaking, they seemed reluctant to speak, and after speaking, as if they had not spoken, hence "forgetting their words with delight." These two phrases express the same idea. "Delighted" describes a lowered bearing.

"Body" means foundation. "Wings" means attachment. The sages say, "Illuminating the five punishments to assist the five teachings," whereas here it is said that punishment is the foundation and ritual the attachment—both are expressed in reverse. "Lenient in their severity" means that though they executed punishments, they did so with ease, without distressing their hearts. "Moving through the world" means following customs with ritual. "Timing" means employing wisdom only when unavoidable to respond to affairs. "Following virtue" means following the virtue of Heaven naturally, proceeding without effort, like one climbing a small hill—all who have feet reach the top, yet others assume they arrived through diligence. This is a metaphor for acting without contrivance. "Hill" refers to a small mountain.

Thus, their liking is one, their disliking is one. Their oneness is one, their not-oneness is one. Those who are one follow Heaven as their companion; those who are not one follow man as their companion. Heaven and man do not overcome one another—this is called the true person. "One" means naturalness, the workings of creation. "Liking and disliking" refer to preferences. Their oneness is sameness, their not-oneness is difference. The sameness and difference of preferences do not extend beyond creation, hence "their oneness is one, their not-oneness is one." If one can regard preferences as the same, they know Heaven. Thus, "those who are one follow Heaven as their companion." If one regards preferences as different, they know man but not Heaven. Thus, "those who are not one follow man as their companion." Man cannot overcome Heaven, nor can Heaven overcome man. The true person has no preferences, no differences, no sameness, no division between Heaven and man—only following nature.

This is what the Buddhists call "abandoning both existence and nonexistence," what Laozi calls "both returning to the mysterious." Thus, "Heaven and man do not overcome one another"—this means that both oneness and not-oneness are one. "One" is the great master.

Life and death are fate, possessing the constancy of night and day—this is Heaven. What man cannot intervene in is the nature of things. They regard Heaven as their father and cherish it, yet how much more should they cherish what is loftier? They regard having a lord as better than themselves and die for it, yet how much more should they cherish what is true? Life and death are like day and night, as the *Yijing* says: "Understanding the Dao of day and night." "Nature" means reality. What human effort cannot influence is the true principle of Heaven and Earth, of the myriad things—this is called fate, called Heaven. These lines elucidate the meaning of life and death as Heaven’s mandate, clarifying the idea of oneness and not-oneness.

Father and lord are the most revered and beloved in the human world, yet the greatness of the Dao surpasses even lord and father, hence it is said to be "the father of all fathers." Thus, "there is a true lord within." "Lofty" means high, unattainable. "True" means natural. These words imply that people know lords and fathers but do not know the Dao as the great master.

When springs dry up, fish find themselves on land, moistening one another with breath, wetting one another with foam—better to forget one another in rivers and lakes. Rather than praising Yao and condemning Jie, it is better to forget both and be transformed by the Dao. The great clod burdens me with form, labors me with life, eases me with old age, and rests me with death. Thus, those who are good to my life are also good to my death.

"Moistening one another with breath, wetting one another with foam" means facing one another and sharing moisture. Being on land and wetting one another is not as good as forgetting one another in rivers and lakes—this metaphor means that acting in the world is not as good as embodying the Dao and practicing non-action. The line praising Yao and condemning Jie may seem absurd, but it reveals a unique insight. Without Jie, there is no Yao; without decline, no rise; without good, no evil; without slander, no praise. Praise and slander, rise and decline, good and evil all arise in mutual dependence. Rather than distinguishing between them, it is better to forget both and entrust them to nature—entrusting to nature is being transformed by the Dao.

The Buddhists say: "All dharmas are equal, without high or low." They also say: "Abandon both existence and nonexistence." And: "The great Dao is not difficult, only disliking discrimination." All these express the same idea.

Two clay oxen fight and plunge into the sea—no news of them to this day. This line is most excellent.

The great clod is heaven and earth. Only after form arises does life come to be; once born, one cannot be without toil. When old age comes and sinews and strength wane, one naturally finds repose. "Repose" means cessation. To "cherish our life" is to preserve our body whole. This is what is meant by "Hear the Dao in the morning, and in the evening death may come."

Hiding a boat in a ravine, concealing a mountain in a marsh—this is called secure. Yet in the dead of night, a strong man may carry them away, and the deluded do not know it. Even when concealing the small within the great is done fittingly, there is still escape. But to hide the world within the world is to leave no room for escape—this is the great truth of all things.

People delight in possessing human form, yet if one has human form, the myriad transformations have no end. How can their joy be measured? Thus the sage wanders where things cannot be pursued yet all abide.

To master early death, to master old age, to master beginnings, to master endings—even men emulate this, let alone that on which the myriad things depend and by which all transformations are sustained.

The boat in the ravine, the mountain in the marsh—these may be called securely hidden, yet at times they are lost. "In the dead of night, a strong man" refers to the workings of creation. "Carrying them away" is loss. It means that even when human plans are most deeply laid, there are times when one cannot act freely—this is like "forging iron to make a doorstep, where even ghosts clap their hands in laughter." The "deluded" are those who do not know.

"Small and great" refer to the boat and ravine, the mountain and marsh. A ravine large enough can hide a boat; a marsh large enough can hide a mountain—concealing the small within the great is fitting. Yet "escape" means loss. To hide the world within the world is to entrust it to nature. All that lies beneath heaven is entrusted to heaven, leaving no room for escape. This is the true and constant nature of all things.

People rejoice in having form, yet do not know that the human body undergoes a thousand changes and ten thousand transformations—how can one know where it will end? If one could know this, then the myriad things would all be complete within me, heaven and earth would be one with me, and how could their joy be measured?

The sage’s mind wanders in the natural, so there is no gain, no loss. Thus it is said: "He wanders where things cannot be pursued yet all abide."

To master early death, to master old age, to master beginnings, to master endings—this is the work of creation. "Master" means "to be able." If even creation can do this, men emulate it—how much more so the Dao, on which the myriad things depend and by which all transformations are sustained. This is what is meant by the "Great Master."

Each passage rises higher than the last—this is the style of Zhuangzi’s brush. The words of sages and worthies, by contrast, are plain and unadorned.

The Dao has essence and trustworthiness, is without action and without form. It can be transmitted but not received, attained but not seen. It is self-originating, self-rooted; before heaven and earth existed, it was already firmly established. It spiritually animates ghosts and gods, gives birth to heaven and earth. It stands before the Supreme Ultimate yet is not high; it lies beneath the six directions yet is not deep. It preceded the birth of heaven and earth yet is not ancient; it is older than high antiquity yet is not aged.

The earlier passage did not mention the word "Dao," but here it is finally introduced to speak of the Great Master.

"Essence" means reality; "trustworthiness" also means reality. "Without action" means there is no place to begin. "Without form" means it has no shape or bounds. "Can be transmitted but not received, attained but not seen"—these two lines are known only to those who understand the Dao. Guan Yinzi has a chapter that elucidates the meaning of "transmission" most aptly.

"Self-originating, self-rooted" means tracing back to its origin. Tracing the origin of this Dao, we find that before heaven and earth existed, the Dao was already present—this is what is meant by "the Supreme Ultimate without yet being the Ultimate."

"Ghosts" are the traces of creation; "Emperor" is like the "Emperor" in the *Yi* who emerges from the east. That ghosts and emperors can be spiritually potent is due to this Dao. Even heaven and earth exist only because of the Dao—thus it is said to "give birth to heaven and earth." The *Yi* says: "The Supreme Ultimate gives birth to the Two Modes"—this is the same idea.

The four lines—"not high," "not deep," "not ancient," "not aged"—are expressed with utmost clarity.

The "six directions" are the six directions of space.

When Fu Xi obtained it, he harnessed the mother of qi. The Northern Dipper obtained it and has never erred since time immemorial; the sun and moon obtained it and have never ceased since time immemorial. Kan Pei obtained it and thereby possessed Kunlun. Feng Yi obtained it and thereby roamed the great rivers. Jian Wu obtained it and thereby dwelt in the great mountains. The Yellow Emperor obtained it and thereby ascended to the cloudy heavens. Zhuan Xu obtained it and thereby dwelt in the Dark Palace. Yu Qiang obtained it and stood at the North Pole. The Queen Mother of the West obtained it and sat in the Lesser Expanse—none knew her beginning, none knew her end. Peng Zu obtained it and lived from the time of Youyu down to the Five Hegemons. Fu Yue obtained it and thereby assisted Wu Ding, ruling over all under heaven. He rode the eastern cord and mounted the tail of the Winnowing Basket, becoming equal to the ranks of the stars.

From Fu Xi onward, there are thirteen instances of "obtained"—all speak of obtaining this Dao and thereby achieving such things.

Fu Xi was an ancient emperor-king. "Harnessing the mother of qi" means harmonizing yin and yang within oneself—this is the origin of the practices of those who cultivate refinement. Kan Pei is a mountain spirit. "Possessing Kunlun" means having Kunlun. Feng Yi is a water spirit. Jian Wu is the spirit of Mount Tai. The Yellow Emperor’s ascent to the cloudy heavens refers to the affair at Mount Dinghu. The Dark Palace is like the present-day Pure True Realm. Yu Qiang is the spirit of the north. The Lesser Expanse is the dwelling of immortals.

The phrase "entering without knowing beginning or end" shares the same meaning despite variations in sentence length—this is a matter of literary technique. Among these thirteen sentences, the sun, moon, and Dipper are interspersed, and Peng Zu and Fu Yue are cited as later evidence. Such stylistic liberties transcend conventional rules; one cannot judge this by the standards of the sages’ writings but must regard it with a different perspective.

Nanbo Zikui asked Nü’ou, “You are advanced in years, yet your complexion is like that of a child—how is this so?”
“I have heard the Dao,” she replied.
Nanbo Zikui said, “May I study it?”
“Alas, how could that be? You are not the right person. Now, Bu Liangyi possesses the talent of a sage but not the Dao of a sage, while I possess the Dao of a sage but not the talent of a sage. I wished to teach him, hoping he might truly become a sage. Otherwise, conveying the Dao of a sage to one with the talent of a sage would be easy. I still guarded and instructed him: after three days, he was able to put the world outside himself. Once he had put the world outside, I guarded him again, and after seven days, he was able to put things outside himself. Once he had put things outside, I guarded him again, and after nine days, he was able to put life outside himself. Once he had put life outside, he could then attain morning clarity. With morning clarity, he could then perceive the solitary. Perceiving the solitary, he could then transcend past and present. Transcending past and present, he could then enter the state of neither death nor life. That which kills life does not die; that which gives life does not live. As a thing, it sends off all without exception, welcomes all without exception, destroys all without exception, and completes all without exception—its name is *yingning*. *Yingning* is that which is completed only after disturbance.

Nanbo Zikui said, “From whom did you alone hear this?”
She replied, “I heard it from the son of *Fumo*; the son of *Fumo* heard it from the grandson of *Luosong*; the grandson of *Luosong* heard it from *Zhanming*; *Zhanming* heard it from *Niexu*; *Niexu* heard it from *Xuyi*; *Xuyi* heard it from *Wou*; *Wou* heard it from *Xuanming*; *Xuanming* heard it from *Canliao*; *Canliao* heard it from *Yishi*.”

Zikui and Ziqi are both allegorical figures. To be advanced in years yet possess the complexion of a child—this is the teaching of present-day refinement cultivators. The distinction between “the talent of a sage” and “the Dao of a sage” is exceptionally well put; none but Zhuangzi could have said it, for no one before him had. Only those who possess both Dao and talent—aside from the Five Emperors and Three Kings—are Yi Yin, the Duke of Zhou, and Confucius. The three, seven, and nine days need not be rigidly parsed; they merely signify one stage surpassing the next. “Putting life outside” means forgetting one’s own body. “Morning clarity” is the luminous state of the mind, like the sky at dawn, suffused with limpid qi. “Perceiving the solitary” means seeing for oneself what others cannot. Transcending past and present means transcending life and death. Here, “killing life” is said to be “not dying,” and “giving life” is said to be “not living”—this is a common flourish in Zhuangzi’s writing. It means that though one may kill, it is not death; though one may give life, it is not life. “Sending off” means escorting; without welcoming or sending off, without completion or destruction, it is simply the natural course. *Ying* means disturbance; though buffeted by turmoil and chaos, that which is constant remains undisturbed. *Ning* means stillness. Only after disturbance does one perceive this stillness—hence *yingning*. *Yingning* is the name that arises from disturbance.

The nine instances of “heard” are truly extraordinary. *Fumo* refers to writing. Words are first spoken, then recorded on bamboo and silk—hence *fumo* (supplementary ink). Speech is the rectification of form; writing is the ink’s supplement. *Luosong* means reciting by heart. One reads with the text before them and recites from memory, like a son begetting a grandson—hence the use of “son” and “grandson” below. *Zhan* means to see; seeing clearly is called *Zhanming*. *Nie* is the same as *nie* (to whisper); to affirm oneself in speech is called *Niexu*. *Yi* means to employ; *xu* means to await. One may await the right moment to act—hence *Xuyi*. *Wou* means to chant when words are insufficient; *yu* expresses admiration, signifying the joy of self-attainment. All these phrases suggest that the Dao is attained through reading, inventing many names along the way—an astonishing feat, yet ultimately ascribed to the workings of creation. *Xuanming* is the beginning of qi; *Canliao* is the beginning of the nameless; *Yishi* is the beginning before the beginning—what is called “having a beginning” is also “having a beginning before the beginning,” and “having a beginning before the beginning before the beginning.” This implies that though the Dao may be obtained through writing, it is in truth inherent in our nature.

*Southern Florescence True Scripture: Oral Exegesis*, Scroll Eight (concluded)
