Close off the outer—do not let external things disturb your heart. Excessive knowledge becomes a burden; only when one knows nothing does virtue remain whole. Hence, it is said that excessive knowledge leads to ruin. The beginning of supreme yang is the great brightness; the beginning of supreme yin is profound obscurity. *Yuan* (原) means 'beginning.' The realm above the great brightness is the domain beyond the Great Void; the gate of profound obscurity is the inception of the Infinite. The *Yijing* speaks of 'the Dao as the alternation of yin and yang'—this is of the same import. Yet its expression is reserved, whereas Zhuangzi speaks with unbridled directness, hence his words are as they are. *Wei ru* (为汝, "for you") means "to teach you." *Sui* (遂) means "to follow" or "to proceed"; *ru* (入, "to enter") means "to delve deeply," indicating the desire to instruct you to the utmost. *Guan* (官) means "office"; *cang* (藏) means "repository." This speaks of the human body as containing Heaven and Earth, yin and yang. My Heaven and Earth each fulfill their offices; my yin and yang each reside in their proper places. Thus, this body may be carefully guarded, and all things will naturally become firm. *Wu* (物, "things") refers to all that constitutes the self; hence, it is said that things will naturally flourish. What is guarded is the One, undivided; what is abided in is harmony without discord. This is why, though my form has endured for one thousand two hundred years, it has not declined. *Chu* (处, "to abide") means to engage with affairs and things, responding to stimuli. Heaven and Earth here refer to the vigor and compliance within the self.

The Yellow Emperor bowed twice and prostrated himself, saying: "Guangchengzi is truly Heaven!" Guangchengzi said: "Come, let me tell you more. Those things are boundless, yet people all regard them as finite; those things are unfathomable, yet people all regard them as limited. Those who attain my Dao may ascend as sovereigns or descend as kings. Those who lose my Dao may see light above but become earth below. Now, the myriad beings all arise from the earth and return to the earth. Thus, I shall leave you and enter the gate of the boundless, to wander the wilds of the Infinite. I shall share radiance with the sun and moon, and endure with Heaven and Earth. Shall I be near? Shall I be distant? All others will perish, yet I alone shall endure."

When Guangchengzi is said to be "Heaven," it means he may unite with Heaven as one. How can things be boundless when people insist on seeking their end? How can things be unfathomable when people insist on seeking their limit? Thus, they pursue the finite while following the infinite. These two lines are deeply resonant. To speak crudely, it is like forging iron into a threshold—ghosts clap their hands and laugh, for this is the same idea. The *Yijing* does not conclude with *Jiji* (既济) but with *Weiji* (未济), for it recognizes that things are boundless and unfathomable. When Confucius stood by a river and said, "What passes is like this," he too referred to the boundless and unfathomable. Above, one may become a sovereign; below, one may become a king—these terms *huang* (皇) and *wang* (王) refer to the sage who fulfills all human relationships and the king who perfects all systems, as in the *Tianxia* chapter’s "inner sageliness and outer kingliness." *Huang* is non-action; *wang* is action—not the Three Sovereigns or the kings of the Three Dynasties. "Seeing light above" refers to the sun and moon; "becoming earth below" refers to the ground. It speaks of dwelling between Heaven and Earth in ignorance, seeing only the sun and moon when one looks up and only the earth when one looks down. *Baichang* (百昌) means "the hundred beings." They arise from the earth and return to the earth—like leaves falling to their roots, the putrid transforming into the wondrous, the wondrous transforming into the putrid. *Qu ru* (去汝, "leaving you") means departing from the human world."

The Gate of the Boundless, the Wilderness of the Limitless—this speaks of what lies beyond Heaven and Earth. One may endure as long as the sun, moon, Heaven, and Earth, thus "sharing their light with the sun and moon, standing constant with Heaven and Earth." *Min* (缗) is akin to *ming* (冥), meaning dim and obscure. "That which meets me" comes toward me; "that which distances itself from me" turns away from me. The coming and going of things—I remain oblivious, unmoved, and thus say: "What meets me is dim; what distances itself is obscure."

Cloud General was traveling east when he passed the branch of the Whirlwind Tree and chanced upon Vast Vagueness. Vast Vagueness was just then slapping his thighs and leaping about in play. Seeing him, Cloud General halted in astonishment, standing rigid, and asked: "Old sir, who are you? Why are you doing this?" Vast Vagueness, still slapping his thighs and leaping, replied: "Wandering." Cloud General said: "I wish to ask you something." Vast Vagueness looked up at him and sighed: "Ah!" Cloud General said: "Heaven’s qi is disharmonious; Earth’s qi is pent up. The six qi are out of balance; the four seasons are disordered. Now I wish to blend the essence of the six qi to nurture the myriad beings—how should I proceed?" Vast Vagueness slapped his sides, leapt, and shook his head: "I do not know! I do not know!" Cloud General could not press his question.

Three years later, Cloud General traveled east again, passing through the wilds of Song, where he once more encountered Vast Vagueness. Overjoyed, he hastened forward and said: "Has Heaven forgotten me? Has Heaven forgotten me?" He bowed twice, prostrating himself, and begged to ask Vast Vagueness a question. Vast Vagueness said: "Aimless wandering, knowing not what you seek; reckless roaming, knowing not where you go. The wanderer is restless, observing only the unfeigned. What do I know?" Cloud General said: "I too thought myself reckless, yet the people follow wherever I go. I cannot escape them—now they imitate me. I wish to hear a single word." Vast Vagueness said: "To disrupt Heaven’s warp, to defy the nature of things—this cannot fulfill the mysterious workings of Heaven. Scatter the herds of beasts, and birds will cry out at night; calamity will strike the grasses and trees, disaster will befall the insects. Alas! This is the fault of governing men."

The branch of the Whirlwind Tree is where the Fusang Tree rises with the sun. *Slapping his thighs and leaping* describes his joyful, carefree bounding. *Tangran* (傥然) conveys a look of self-forgetfulness; *zhanran* (贽然) suggests standing tall and motionless. *Old sir* refers to Vast Vagueness. When Zhaozhou met Touzi returning from buying oil, he remarked: "I have long heard of Touzi—today I see only an oil-buying old man." Touzi replied: "Oil, oil." Observe how this Chan matter unfolds. When Cloud General says *wandering*, Zhuangzi depicts him in a state of exultation. The character for *oil* differs from *wandering*—this is not to equate the two. *Unceasingly* replying while leaping, *looking up* and sighing—such subtleties are wondrous in themselves. The phrase *nurturing the myriad beings* echoes the earlier dialogue with the Yellow Emperor. *Shaking his head* means to refuse. *Has Heaven forgotten me?*—*Zhen* (朕) means "I." Calling Vast Vagueness "Heaven," he asks: "We met once before—do you still remember? Or have you forgotten me?" *Aimless wandering* means roaming without purpose; *reckless* means unrestrained. *Knowing not what you seek* means having no goal; *knowing not where you go* means having no destination. *Restless* describes a state of turmoil. *The unfeigned* is the real. To wander amid the world’s turmoil while observing one’s own reality. *I cannot escape them* means he wishes to withdraw but cannot. *Imitate* means to follow as a model—the people take me as their standard.

*Heaven’s warp* refers to the natural order of things, which is simply spontaneity itself. Now, acting with intention disrupts and defies this spontaneity—how can one fulfill the transformations of the mysterious Heaven? Thus it is said: "This cannot fulfill the mysterious workings of Heaven." *Mysterious* means empty, akin to "prior to Heaven." When herds do not contend, there is no distinction between same and different. Now, scattering them creates division—self and other, same and different. Birds cry at night in alarm. Failing to assist things in following their nature causes grasses, trees, and insects to suffer disaster. All this begins with the intention to govern men—just as before, the fault lies in disturbing the human heart.

Cloud General asked: "Then what should I do?" Vast Vagueness said: "Alas! How poisonous! Return, return, in light steps." Cloud General said: "I have met with Heaven’s difficulty—grant me a single word." Vast Vagueness said: "Ah! Cultivate the heart. You need only abide in non-action, and things will transform of themselves. Cast off your form, expel your cleverness, forget both self and things, and merge with the vast primordial. Release the heart, free the spirit, and become as though soulless. The ten thousand things, teeming and swarming, each return to their root—each return to their root without knowing it. Remain in undifferentiated chaos, never departing from it your whole life. If you claim to know it, you have already departed from it. Do not inquire into names; do not pry into natures—things arise of themselves."

Cloud General said: "Heaven has bestowed virtue upon me and shown me silence. Seeking it in myself, I have now attained it." He bowed twice, prostrated himself, rose, and took his leave.

"What should I do now?" means: "Given this, how should I proceed?"

Alas! This is like the "Alas! Alas!" spoken of by the stone. Soaring, soaring—such is the urgency of departure. It means: you have already poisoned and tormented yourself; hasten back, there is no need to question me further. This passage of fabricated dialogue resembles the exchanges in the *Transmission of the Lamp*.

"Nurturing the heart" means: simply let this heart nurture itself—this is sufficient. It does not say "nurture the heart" but "heart-nurturing"; one must discern this carefully. "Merely" means "only": you need only abide in non-action, and things will transform of themselves. "Self-transforming" means ceaseless coming and going, self-arising and self-transforming. Cast off all your former cleverness and leave none of it behind. "倫" is interchangeable with "沦," meaning to sink and disappear. When you dissolve and forget both self and things, you merge with the vast primordial. "涬溟" refers to the formless, traceless beginning before qi arose.

"Release the heart" means to dissolve the heart that clings to having a heart; "free the spirit" means to release the spirit that clings to knowing. "莫然" means settled, at rest; "soulless" means without knowing. Essence is called *po*, spirit is called *hun*; "soulless" echoes the earlier phrase "lump-like, standing by virtue of form alone." The "heart" in "release the heart" differs from the "heart" in "heart-nurturing," just as the "spirit" in "free the spirit" differs from the "spirit" in "embracing the spirit in stillness." These terms demand careful reflection.

"Cloud-cloud" means teeming and swarming. All that is born must perish, yet though it perishes, it does not truly perish—for what perishes gives rise to new birth. Thus it is said: "each returns to their root without knowing it." "Undifferentiated chaos" describes the state of being without knowledge or awareness. Remain in this chaos, and you will never depart from the Dao your whole life. But if you claim to know it, you have already separated from it. This line is profoundly subtle; fix your gaze upon it.

"Names" refer to all distinctions; "natures" refer to likes and dislikes. "窥" means "to see." Without inquiring into names or prying into natures, you will be free of distinctions, free of preferences—this is non-action and spontaneity. When I embody non-action and spontaneity, the ten thousand things each follow their own nature, for this is their inherent way. Thus it is said: "things arise of themselves." "固" means "inherent."

"降" means "bestowed upon me"; "默" means "silence." Heaven has bestowed upon me the virtue of spontaneity and shown me the principle of wordlessness. Seeking it within myself, I have now attained it. "躬" means "personally" or "oneself": it is by seeking within my own being that I have obtained what I sought. Thereupon, I bowed in gratitude and departed.

The common run of people delight in those who agree with them and despise those who differ. Those who desire agreement and reject difference do so out of a desire to stand above the crowd. Yet those who seek to stand above the crowd—have they ever truly done so? Relying on the crowd to affirm what they have heard, they are no different from the crowd in skill. And yet they aspire to govern others' states—this is grasping at the benefits of the Three Kings while blind to the perils. To govern another's state with such an attitude is to gamble on luck. How many times can one gamble on luck without losing the state? The chance of preserving another's state is less than one in ten thousand, while the risk of losing it is more than ten thousand to one. How tragic that those who hold land do not understand this!

From this point to the end of the chapter, Zhuangzi expounds at length. To desire others to be like oneself and to resent their differences is to seek to place oneself above the crowd. Yet if one insists that others conform to what one has heard before feeling at ease, how is one any different from the crowd? Even if one wishes to stand out, how can one do so? If one claims unique insight, it must be that no one else understands—yet if one desires everyone to agree, then one's skills are no greater than the crowd's. Laozi said: "When few know me, then I am esteemed." Zhuangzi here turns the idea over again. This is akin to Han Tuizhi's remark about writing: "There is still the influence of others' words in it"—the meaning is the same.

Those who harbor such thoughts and yet seek to govern others' states are grasping for the advantages of the Three Kings while ignoring the inevitable harm. To scheme for another's state with such a mindset is to rely on luck. When luck is one's guiding principle, one sees only ruin—how can there be success? Yet those who hold land remain unaware, seduced by such people.

"有土者" refers to those who possess states, meaning the feudal lords of the time. This passage clearly satirizes the itinerant persuaders and strategists of the day.

Now, those who possess land possess great things. But great things cannot be treated as mere things. Only by not being treated as a thing can one govern things. To recognize that the governor of things is not a thing—how could this apply only to ruling the world and its people? Moving in and out of the six directions, roaming the nine provinces, coming and going alone—this is called "possessing alone." Those who possess alone are called "most noble."

Those who "govern things" have intentions and traces; those who "do not treat as things" act through non-action, spontaneously and naturally. Through non-action, nothing is left undone—thus it is said: "Not treating as a thing, one can govern things." If one recognizes that the governor of things is itself a thing, how could this apply merely to ruling the world? Thus it is said: "Moving in and out of the six directions, roaming the nine provinces." This speaks of the Dao transcending all things. Operating freely within creation, opening and closing with the transformations of nature, one becomes one with Heaven—no person can divide this unity. Hence it is said: "Coming and going alone."

"Heart-nurturing" means: simply let this heart nurture itself—this is sufficient. It does not say "nurture the heart" but "heart-nurturing"; one must discern this carefully. "Merely" means "only": you need only abide in non-action, and things will transform of themselves. "Self-transforming" means ceaseless coming and going, self-arising and self-transforming. Cast off all your former cleverness and leave none of it behind.

"Lun" is identical with "lun," meaning to sink and vanish. When one vanishes utterly and forgets all things, one becomes one with the primordial vastness. This "primordial vastness" is the formless, traceless beginning before qi arose.

"Dissolving the heart" means dissolving the heart that clings to having a heart; "releasing the spirit" means releasing the spirit that clings to knowing. "Mo Ran" means stillness—"without hun" means without knowing. The *po* is the essence, the *hun* is the spirit; "without hun" echoes the earlier phrase "a mere clod, standing by virtue of its form." The heart dissolved in "dissolving the heart" differs from the heart in "heart-nurturing," just as the spirit released in "releasing the spirit" differs from the spirit in "embracing the spirit in stillness." These terms demand careful discernment.

"Cloud-cloud" signifies multiplicity. "Each returns to its root": what is born must perish, yet though it perishes, it does not perish—what perishes gives rise to new birth. Thus it is said: "Each returns to its root, yet knows it not." "Hunhun dundun" describes the state of knowing nothing, sensing nothing. In this state, one never departs from the Dao; the moment knowing and sensing arise, one divides from the Dao. Thus it is said: "If one knew it, this would be to depart from it." This line is profoundly subtle—one must fix one’s gaze upon it.

All discrimination is called "name"; all likes and dislikes are called "emotion." "Peering" means seeing. Without questioning, without peering, there is no discrimination, no likes or dislikes—this is non-action and spontaneity. If I can be non-active and spontaneous, then all things fulfill their own lives, for this is their inherent nature. Thus it is said: "Things inherently live of themselves." "Inherent" means "innate."

"Jiang" means "bestowed upon me"; "mo" means "silent." The Way bestows upon me the virtue of spontaneity, reveals to me the principle of wordlessness. Turning inward to seek it, I have already attained this Dao. "Gong" means "personally," "oneself"—only by seeking within myself do I obtain what is to be obtained. Then, bowing in gratitude, he departed.

Ordinary people all delight in those who agree with them and resent those who differ. Those who desire agreement and reject difference do so with the aim of standing out from the crowd. Yet how can one who aims to stand out ever truly stand out? Relying on the crowd to secure what one has heard is no better than the crowd’s many skills. Yet those who would rule others’ states grasp at the advantages of the Three Kings while blind to the dangers. This is gambling with others’ states—how often can one gamble and not lose another’s state? The chance of preserving another’s state is less than one in ten thousand, while the risk of losing it is more than ten thousand to one. How tragic that those who possess lands do not understand this!

From this point to the end of the chapter, Zhuangzi unfolds his argument in full. To desire others to agree with oneself and resent their difference is to seek to place oneself above the crowd. Yet if one insists that all conform to what one has heard before feeling at ease, how is one different from the crowd? Though one may wish to stand out, how can one do so? If one claims unique insight, it must be that no one else understands—yet if one desires everyone to agree with oneself, then one’s skills are no greater than the crowd’s. Laozi said: "When few know me, then I am valued." Zhuangzi here turns the point another way. Han Tuizhi’s remark on writing—that it still contains others’ ideas—expresses the same meaning.

With such a mindset, to rule another’s state is to seize the Three Kings’ advantages while ignoring the inevitable harm. To scheme for another’s state is to rely on luck. When luck is one’s aim, one sees only ruin—how can there be success? Yet those who possess lands do not recognize such people and are deceived by them. "Those who possess lands" refers to the feudal lords of the time. This passage clearly satirizes the itinerant persuaders of the age.

Those who possess lands possess great things. Yet great things cannot be treated as things. Only by not being a thing can one master all things. To recognize that the master of things is not a thing—how could this apply merely to ruling the world and its people? Thus it is said: "Moving in and out of the six directions, roaming the nine provinces." This speaks of the Dao transcending all things. Operating freely within creation, opening and closing with the transformations of nature, one becomes one with Heaven—no person can divide this unity. Thus it is said: "Coming and going alone—this is called 'possessing alone.'" One who possesses alone is called "most noble."

Those who master things have intentions and traces. Those who are not things act without acting, spontaneously and naturally. Without acting, there is nothing they do not do. Thus it is said: "Not being a thing, they can master all things." If one knows the master of all things, how could this apply merely to ruling the world? Thus it is said: "Moving in and out of the six directions, roaming the nine provinces." This speaks of the Dao transcending all things. Operating freely within creation, opening and closing with the transformations of nature, one becomes one with Heaven—no person can divide this unity. Thus it is said: "Coming and going alone—this is called 'possessing alone.'" Such is the most noble.

The teaching of the great person is like a shadow following form, an echo answering sound. When questioned, they respond, exhausting what is in their heart to match the world. They dwell in no-sound, move in no-direction. Leading you, they guide you to the bustling throng, roaming without end. Entering and exiting without side, with the sun having no beginning, they praise and discuss the form and body uniting with the great unity. In great unity, there is no self—how could there be anything possessed by the self?

Those who see being are the gentlemen of old; those who see non-being are the friends of Heaven and Earth. The "great person" is the perfected person—the one who "possesses alone." Form must have shadow, sound must have echo—this is spontaneous and natural. When questioned, they exhaust what is in their heart to respond, matching the world with their single body. They are the host; the world is the guest. Without sound, without mark, without direction, without trace. "Naonao" describes the ceaseless movement of the multitude. "Shi" means "to go"; "qie" means "to lead."

You point to all the people of the world. "Return" means to go back; you lead all the people of the world to return into the midst of the ceaseless movement, for though one emerges from the world, one does not stand apart from it—emerging from the world and dwelling in the world are not two separate ways. "Without end" means without beginning; "without side" means boundless in all four directions. Entering and exiting, you wander within it, day after day in this manner, seeing no end—how could you know its beginning? Thus it is said: "with the sun having no beginning."

When we discuss and praise in terms of bodily form, all within Heaven and Earth share this same body, and so it is said: "they unite with the great unity." "Praise" means to extol. Since my body is the same as the myriad things, I cannot act for myself alone—this is "no self." If there is no self, then what could be possessed? This is what Master Pang meant by "emptying all that exists, not filling what does not."

The gentlemen of old saw only being; those who are friends with Heaven and Earth see non-being. When it says "the gentlemen of old," it includes all from Yao and Shun downward. That which is base yet cannot be neglected is *things*. That which is lowly yet cannot be forsaken is *the people*. That which is hidden yet cannot be left undone is *affairs*. That which is coarse yet cannot be abandoned is *laws*. That which is distant yet cannot be departed from is *righteousness*. That which is intimate yet cannot be left unexpanded is *benevolence*. That which is regulated yet cannot be left unaccumulated is *ritual*. That which is centered yet cannot be left unexalted is *virtue*. That which is unified yet cannot be left unchanged is the *Dao*. That which is numinous yet cannot be left undone is *Heaven*.

Observing this passage, one sees that Master Zhuang still concerns himself with worldly affairs—he does not merely discourse on emptiness and nothingness. Master Yichuan said that the Buddhists have "upward attainment" but no "downward study," and this is an excellent remark. Yet even in these few lines, there are places that approach "downward study," and an understanding that the refined and the coarse cannot be separated.

If the Dao is esteemed, then things are deemed base—but how can one abandon things? Thus it is said: "that which is base yet cannot be neglected is *things*." "Neglect" means to disregard. If the Dao is honored, then what pertains to people is lowly—yet how can one stand apart from people? Thus it is said: "that which is lowly yet cannot be forsaken is *the people*." "Forsake" means to depend upon. "Hidden" means concealed; "obscure" means dim. That which is clear is the Dao. When affairs are contrasted with the Dao, affairs are obscure—yet how can one entirely abandon worldly affairs? Thus it is said: "that which is hidden yet cannot be left undone is *affairs*."

The Dao is refined; laws are coarse. How can laws be entirely discarded? Thus it is said: "that which is coarse yet cannot be abandoned is *laws*." Righteousness is distant from the Dao—yet how can righteousness be abandoned? Thus it is said: "that which is distant yet cannot be departed from is *righteousness*." The Dao has no intimacy or estrangement; benevolence involves love. Though it is not the ultimate Dao, how can one abandon benevolence? One must extend it. Thus it is said: "that which is intimate yet cannot be left unexpanded is *benevolence*."

Ritual has regulations and forms, seeming forced upon the world, yet it cannot be left undone. Thus it is said: "that which is regulated yet cannot be left unaccumulated is *ritual*." The rituals number three hundred, the rules of deportment three thousand—how could these be accomplished by the effort of one person in a single day? Thus it is said: "accumulating virtue is what all people share." Though one harmonizes with the world, there are places where one must stand alone—how could one be the same as others? Thus it is said: "that which is centered yet cannot be left unexalted is *virtue*." "Centered" means harmonizing with others.

That which is unified with the natural is the Dao. Yet there are places where change is necessary—how could one cling to oneness without change? Thus it is said: "that which is unified yet cannot be left unchanged is the *Dao*." That which is unknowable is called numinous; what Heaven does is all unknowable. Human affairs cannot be left undone—how could one entirely entrust them to the unknowable? Thus it is said: "that which is numinous yet cannot be left undone is *Heaven*."

Thus the sage observes Heaven yet does not assist, completes virtue yet is not burdened, emerges from the Dao yet does not scheme, unites with benevolence yet does not rely on it, approaches righteousness yet does not accumulate it, responds to ritual yet does not conceal, engages with affairs yet does not yield, equalizes through laws yet is not disordered, depends on the people yet does not belittle them, and follows things yet does not abandon them.

Things are not worth doing, yet they cannot be left undone. Those who do not understand Heaven are not pure in virtue; those who do not comprehend the Dao have no means to proceed. Those who do not understand the Dao—how lamentable! "Not assisting" means not applying force. What pertains to people cannot be left undone, yet when viewed with the eye of the Dao, though one acts, one does not apply force. Thus it is said: "observes Heaven yet does not assist." This "assist" is the same as in "assisting growth."

"Not burdened" means not piling up to become lofty. Piling up to become lofty is to harbor intentions that are not natural. "Burdened" is pronounced like *lěi*. "Not scheming" means having no mind for calculation. "Not relying" means not considering it a personal favor. "Unites" means to gather. "Accumulating" means not transforming; if one does not accumulate, one transforms. "Approaches" means to press near. Though one’s conduct is near to righteousness, one does not consider oneself to possess it—if one accumulates righteousness, one does not transform.

"Not concealing" means not being constrained by taboos. "Responds" means to engage. If one is bound by the forms of ritual, there are things one conceals and avoids. What can be done is done; one engages with things as they come. Thus it is said: "responds to ritual yet does not conceal." "Yielding" means shrinking back. In engaging with affairs, one acts directly and straightforwardly, without shrinking back. Thus it is said: "engages with affairs yet does not yield."

Using laws to equalize things, even amid complexity there is a sense of simplicity and directness. Thus it is said: "is not disordered." Though the people can be depended upon, one does not belittle them. Though things can be relied upon, one does not abandon the root to pursue the branches.

From the preceding lines to this point, the discussion has fully turned—yet once more the character "thing" (物) is raised: "Nothing is worth doing, yet nothing can be left undone." This "thing" encompasses both the refined (精), which is the Dao, and the coarse (粗), which is the material world; all affairs and all things reside within it. Viewed through the mind of Dao, nothing is worth doing. Yet there are things that cannot be left undone—this is where the human mind comes into play. From this single line, can we not see that Zhuangzi understood the principle of the refined and the coarse as one?

It is further said: "One who does not understand Heaven cannot perfect virtue." Though worldly affairs cannot be left undone, one must grasp the principle of spontaneity. Without understanding the spontaneity of Heaven’s principle, one’s own virtue remains impure. To be unpervaded by the Dao is to be unenlightened about Heaven. "There is nowhere one can go without obstruction"—this means that without progress, one encounters only blockages.

Earlier, it was said that one who does not understand Heaven is unpervaded by the Dao; here, at the conclusion, it is again stated that one does not understand the Dao. Thus, the two phrases—"not understanding Heaven" and "not pervaded by the Dao"—express the same idea.

What is the Dao? There is the Dao of Heaven and the Dao of humanity. The honored is that which is without action: this is the Dao of Heaven. The encumbered is that which acts: this is the Dao of humanity. The ruler follows the Dao of Heaven; the minister follows the Dao of humanity. The Dao of Heaven and the Dao of humanity are vastly different—this cannot be left unexamined. These two lines are most subtle and most intimately connected to learning, yet readers often overlook them without deep inquiry.

That which is without action yet honored is the spontaneity of Heaven’s Dao; that which acts and is encumbered is the inescapable doing of humanity’s Dao. The former pertains to the mind of Dao; the latter, to the human mind. This word "encumbered" (累) is akin to "perilous" (危). The ruler embodies the Dao of Heaven—this means taking the mind of Dao as the master. The minister embodies the Dao of humanity—this means making the human mind obey. These terms "ruler" and "minister" do not refer to courtly sovereigns and subjects; readers have long mistaken them as such. They refer to the sovereign and subject within the self. As the *Qi Wu Lun* says: "Do they alternate as ruler and subject? Is there a true ruler abiding within?" This is how they should be understood.

Zhuangzi’s writings generally esteem non-action and disdain action. Having already explained that there are things one cannot leave undone, he feared that readers might conflate action and non-action. Thus, he reiterates here: "The Dao of Heaven and the Dao of humanity are vastly different—this cannot be left unexamined." The text opens and closes, rises and falls, with mutual resonance throughout. If one sees this clearly, it becomes lively and dynamic. Yet his language is intricate, shifting and transforming like drumbeats—hence, some fail to fully grasp it.

Take, for instance, the phrases: "That which is distant yet cannot be left uninhabited" (referring to righteousness) and "That which is near yet cannot be left unexpanded" (referring to benevolence). Such expressions do not align with the coherent principles of the sages and worthies, and thus drift toward heterodoxy. One must not read them as one would the *Analects* or *Mencius*.

From "That which is lowly yet cannot be left unassigned" to "this cannot be left unexamined," this is one of the great guiding principles in Zhuangzi’s thought, akin to the *Tian Xia* chapter. Su Dongpo observed that Zhuangzi never criticized Confucius, a point discerned from the *Tian Xia* chapter. Here, we see that Zhuangzi never failed to understand the principle of the refined and the coarse, the fundamental and the incidental, as one.

There is another perspective: the words of sages and worthies endure for all ages without flaw, yet the various masters of the Hundred Schools also have their incisive insights. Consider the *Yi Jing*: "That which is above form is called the Dao; that which is below form is called the vessel. To transform and regulate it is called change; to extend and enact it is called penetration. To lift and apply it to the people of the world is called the enterprise of the sage." And again: "What is perceived is called the image; what takes form is called the vessel. To fashion and employ it is called the law. When its utility is employed in egress and ingress, and the people all use it, it is called the numinous." Did it not speak of the refined? Did it not speak of the coarse? Expressed with such seamless integrity, it naturally avoids flaw.

Lèxuān remarked: "When Confucians awaken to the Dao, their minds become ever more refined; when Chan Buddhists awaken to the Dao, their minds become ever coarser." This penetrates to the marrow of the distinction between Confucianism and Buddhism—something unseen before. In passages like this, Zhuangzi belittles worldly affairs, dismissing them as base and coarse, yet interjects the phrase "cannot be left undone." Such maneuvers are even coarser, lacking the spirit of "only refinement, only unity" and the equilibrium of "holding fast to the center." Only by discerning this distinction in refinement and coarseness can one recognize that Lèxuān truly awakened to the Dao—he was a man of great vision. Others who refute Buddhism merely scratch the surface; since Buddhism claims to be a "dharma beyond the world" and attacks human relationships and ethical norms, how could they ever convince its adherents?

*Collected Oral Exegeses on the True Classic of Southern Florescence*, Scroll Thirteen—concluded.

**Collected Oral Exegeses on the True Classic of Southern Florescence, Scroll Fourteen**
*By Yùzhāi Lín Xīyì*

**Outer Chapters: "Heaven and Earth"**

Though heaven and earth are vast, their transformations are uniform.
Though the myriad things are numerous, their governance is one.
Though the masses of people are many, their lord is the ruler.
The ruler originates in virtue and is perfected by Heaven. Thus it is said: the rulers of remote antiquity governed all under heaven through non-action, embodying nothing but the virtue of Heaven.

That their transformations are uniform means all are of primordial *qi*. "Governance" means mastery. Though the myriad things are numerous, what masters them is but the singular work of creation. Though the masses of people are many, their lord is the ruler—just as heaven has no second sun, nor the people a second king.

What Heaven bestows upon me is virtue. If I can trace the origin of this virtue, seeing that all is perfected by Heaven, then human effort adds nothing. Should one who is a ruler comprehend this, he would govern through non-action, following nature—non-action and naturalness being the virtue of Heaven.

"Remote" (*xuán*) means distant; "remote antiquity" (*xuángǔ*) is akin to "deep antiquity." Viewing all under heaven through the Dao, the ruler is rectified. Viewing distinctions through the Dao, the principles of ruler and minister become clear. Viewing abilities through the Dao, the offices of all under heaven are well-ordered. Viewing all things broadly through the Dao, the responses of the myriad things are complete.

Thus, what pervades heaven and earth is virtue. What courses through the myriad things is the Dao. What governs the people above is affairs. What enables skillful execution is technique. Technique is encompassed by affairs, affairs by righteousness, righteousness by virtue, virtue by the Dao, and the Dao by Heaven.

Between heaven and earth, where there is *qi*, there is sound; where there is sound, there are names. When names designate the ruler, the divisions of all under heaven are settled. This was determined from the very beginning, when sound first arose—it is natural. Thus it is said: viewing all through the Dao, the ruler of all under heaven is established. "Speech" (*yán*) is sound; the Dao is nature.

Once these divisions exist, the principles of ruler and minister naturally follow, as high and low are arrayed, and noble and base assume their stations. Thus it is said: viewing distinctions through the Dao, the principles of ruler and minister become clear.

The affairs of all under heaven cannot be managed by one person alone; rather, each fulfills their duties according to their abilities. What enables these abilities is bestowed by Heaven. For Heaven brings forth many people to accomplish many tasks. Thus it is said: viewing abilities through the Dao, the offices of all under heaven are well-ordered.

Among the myriad things, nothing exists without its counterpart: where there is cold, there is heat; where there is female, there is male; where there is above, there is below; where there is front, there is back; where there is left, there is right. Each responds to the other, all arising naturally. Thus it is said: viewing all things broadly through the Dao, the responses of the myriad things are complete.

These four phrases are most exquisite, their language pure and unadulterated.

Heaven covers and engenders; earth bears and completes—both share this virtue. "Pervades" (*tōng*) means "unites." Among the myriad things, each follows its natural principle. Thus it is said: what courses through the myriad things is the Dao.

What those above use to govern—rites, music, punishments, and policies—are the affairs of governance. Within each affair lies its respective craft, and what enables these is human technique.

The Dao and virtue are refined; affairs and technique are coarse. Yet both refined and coarse arise from nature. Thus technique is affairs, affairs are righteousness, righteousness is virtue, virtue is the Dao, and the Dao is Heaven. "Encompassed" (*jiān*) means "uniting two as one." "Righteousness" (*yì*) was originally written as "art" (*yì*), a scribal error due to their similar pronunciation.

Thus it is said: those of antiquity who nurtured all under heaven desired nothing, and all under heaven was sufficient; they acted not, and the myriad things were transformed; they were profound and still, and the hundred clans were settled.

The Record states: "Grasp the One, and the myriad affairs are complete; attain effortless attainment, and even spirits submit." To "nurture all under heaven" is what Mencius called "nourishing all under heaven with goodness." If I desire nothing, all under heaven is naturally sufficient; if I act not, all under heaven is naturally transformed; if I am still, the hundred clans are naturally settled. "Profound stillness" (*yuānjìng*) is clarity and tranquility.

The myriad affairs are but one principle. Thus it is said: grasp the One, and the myriad affairs are complete. If what is attained within me is free of contrivance, not only will people submit, but even spirits will yield. "The Record states" means "as the tradition has it." These words were handed down from high antiquity, and Zhuangzi cites them as corroboration. These five phrases are exceedingly pure, with the first three resembling the thought of Laozi.

The Master said: "The Dao is that which covers and bears the myriad things. Vast and boundless, how great it is! The noble person cannot but hollow out his heart." Non-action in doing is called Heaven; non-action in speaking is called virtue; loving others and benefiting things is called benevolence; uniting what is different is called great conduct; being unbound by distinctions is called magnanimity; possessing myriad differences is called abundance.

Thus, holding fast to virtue is called discipline; the completion of virtue is called establishment; following the Dao is called fulfillment; not allowing things to thwart one’s resolve is called wholeness. Should the noble person comprehend these ten principles, his mind would be vast in its engagement with affairs, and he would flow with the myriad things in boundless abundance.

"The Master" refers to his teacher. "Hollowing out the heart" means excising the heart of discriminating awareness. Only by removing this heart of awareness can one study the Dao.

"Others" (*rén*) means nature. Acting in accordance with nature is called Heaven. What is attained within oneself is self-evident without speech. Thus it is said: non-action in speaking is called virtue. "Non-action in speech" means having nothing to say.

What is different is also the same. Thus it is said: uniting what is different is great. "Distinctions with traces" (*yáyì*) means having form; "magnanimity" (*kuān*) means expansiveness.

The myriad things are all different, yet I possess them all—thus it is said: to contain ten thousand differences is called abundance. This means all things are complete within me.

*Ji* (紀) means order. The virtue one holds, whether great or small, follows a sequence and has its own order—thus it is said: holding to virtue is called *ji*. Standing towering as if established marks the completion of virtue. Following the Dao in action, nothing is lacking—*bei* (備) means the Dao is whole and perfect, complete. When external things cannot disturb the mind, what lies within remains whole—thus it is said: not allowing things to thwart one’s resolve is called perfection.

These ten are: the heavenly virtue, benevolence, greatness, magnanimity, abundance, order, establishment, completeness, and perfection. *Tao* (韜) means concealment, encompassing all affairs without omission, all returning to the mind. This mind is so vast it has no bounds—thus it is said: vast in its engagement with affairs. *Shi* (逝) means to go, flowing like this passing away. The myriad things come and go without end, yet I move with them in boundless abundance—thus it is said: flowing with the myriad things in boundless abundance.

One who is thus conceals gold in the mountains and pearls in the depths, neither valuing wealth nor seeking nobility and riches. They do not rejoice in long life nor grieve over early death, feel no pride in success nor shame in poverty. They do not confine the world’s benefits for private gain, nor regard ruling all under Heaven as a mark of distinction—distinction lies in clarity. All things are stored in a single repository; death and life share the same form.

Concealing gold in the mountains and pearls in the depths means wealth is stored throughout the world. "Not seeking" means keeping distance. They do not take longevity or early death as causes for joy or sorrow, nor success or failure as grounds for honor or disgrace—*chǒu* (丑) here surpasses *rǔ* (辱) in meaning. The benefits of an age are shared with all, not hoarded as one’s private portion—this is the idea that when one loses a bow, another gains it. Though ruling all under Heaven, they do not consider themselves exalted; the imperial yellow canopy was not Yao’s desire. The clarity within their breast illuminates Heaven and Earth—this is true distinction, so they do not regard ruling all under Heaven as distinction.

Gathering the myriad things into one principle is called a single repository. Death and life are great indeed, yet they bring no change to the self—viewing them as one is called sharing the same form.

The Master said: The Dao dwells in profound stillness, its clarity like flowing water. Metal and stone cannot remain silent—thus they have sound, yet without striking, they do not ring. Who can determine the myriad things?

"Dwelling in profound stillness" means tranquility, stillness, and stability. "Clarity like flowing water" means purity without mixture or confusion. The resonance of metal and stone is also the natural work of Heaven—thus it is said: metal and stone cannot remain silent. This resonance is itself the Dao. Yet though metal and stone have sound, without human striking, they do not ring—human striking is also the work of Heaven’s mechanism. These two lines express the same principle as the earlier saying: how do we know what I call Heaven is not human, and what I call human is not Heaven? Thus it is said: who can determine the myriad things? Heaven relies on humanity to act, and humanity relies on Heaven to complete—this is the same idea, though the wording here is extraordinary.

One who embodies royal virtue moves with simplicity and feels shame in becoming entangled in affairs. They establish the root and understand the divine in its manifestations. Thus their virtue is vast, and their mind’s responses are shaped by things. Therefore, form does not arise without the Dao, and life is not illuminated without virtue. Preserving form and exhausting life, establishing virtue and illuminating the Dao—is this not the mark of one with royal virtue?

Vast and boundless, they suddenly emerge, stirring dynamically, and the myriad things follow them—this describes one with royal virtue. *Wangde* (王德) means possessing the virtue to rule all under Heaven. *Su shi* (素逝) means moving with unadorned simplicity, like the *Yi*’s "plainly treading the path." They act without doing, yet nothing is left undone, and they do not seek recognition—thus it is said: feeling shame in becoming entangled in affairs. The root is the origin of the myriad things. "Understanding the divine in its manifestations" means perfect sincerity like the divine. *Cai* (采) means to take. Things take from me, and only then does the mind respond—thus it is said: the mind’s responses are shaped by things. *Cai* means to be moved; *chu* (出) means to respond.

All things are born of creation; all that have form share this Dao. Yet without self-realization, the Dao remains unilluminated—meaning it is not understood. The next *sheng* (生) refers to my receiving the center of Heaven and Earth to live. Preserving my form to exhaust the principle of life’s origin, establishing my virtue to illuminate the natural Dao—this is beyond the capacity of ordinary people. *Dangdang* (荡荡) describes greatness. "Suddenly emerging" means rising above the multitude. "Stirring dynamically" expresses the inevitability of action. "The myriad things follow" means that when the sage acts, all things behold it.

Gazing into darkness, listening to silence: within obscurity, they alone perceive clarity; within silence, they alone hear harmony. Thus, delving ever deeper, they can engage with things; refining ever further, they can attain subtlety. Therefore, in their interaction with the myriad things, they provide for all needs from nothingness. Timely and swift, they grasp the essence of all, whether great or small, long or short, near or far.

*Mingming* (冥冥) is the realm of formlessness. Gazing into formlessness yet perceiving clarity is like the *huanghu* (恍惚) where images emerge. Others consider it silent, yet they alone hear, as in the harmony of the eight sounds—this is not seeing others but seeing oneself, not hearing others but hearing oneself. "Delving ever deeper" means entering the profound and wondrous. Yet they can also respond to things, adapting to the refined and the coarse. *Shen* (神) is formless; *jing* (精) is qi. With formlessness, they perceive the presence of qi—this is the interplay of the formless and the formed. What resides within me is emptiness, yet it responds to things.

To attain the ultimate nothingness is to fulfill the needs of all things. Timely and swift, they emerge and are put to use.

To grasp their ultimate destination is not to fix upon one, for they may be small or great, long or short, near or far—this is the meaning of timeliness. "Far-reaching" should be paired with "near" to complete the sense; here, "far-reaching" implies "long," yet its meaning clearly aligns with "near." Perhaps since the above mentions "small and great, long and short," this reference to "far-reaching" includes "near" as well. Otherwise, it would be a lapse in careful phrasing. Yet these scattered passages are exquisitely precise—how could others wield such a brush?

The Yellow Emperor roamed north of the Red Water, ascended the heights of Mount Kunlun, and gazed southward. Upon returning, he lost his Dark Pearl. He sent Knowledge to seek it, but it was not found; he sent Li Zhu to seek it, but it was not found; he sent Chi Gou to seek it, but it was not found. Then he sent Indistinct, and Indistinct found it.

The Yellow Emperor said: "How extraordinary! Could only Indistinct obtain it?"

This passage speaks of seeking the Dao: it does not lie in cleverness, nor in eloquence—just as the Buddhist sutras say, "To seek the Great Perfect Enlightenment with a thinking mind is like trying to burn Mount Sumeru with a firefly’s glow." Yet it unfolds such a discourse.

The Dark Pearl is the Dao. *Knowledge* is perception. *Li Zhu* is clarity. *Chi Gou* is eloquence. *Indistinct* is absence of mind. Perception, clarity, and eloquence cannot attain the Dao; only with absence of mind is it obtained. Such metaphors are truly extraordinary.

Yao’s teacher was Xu You; Xu You’s teacher was Nie Que; Nie Que’s teacher was Wang Ni; Wang Ni’s teacher was Pi Yi.

Yao asked Xu You: "Could Nie Que be fit to rule as Heaven?" "I would summon Wang Ni to inquire."

Xu You said: "How perilous it would be for the world! Nie Que’s nature is keenly perceptive, quick-witted, and sharp—his abilities surpass others, yet he still relies on human effort to align with Heaven. He is meticulous in restraining faults but does not understand their source. How could he be fit to rule as Heaven? He rides upon human affairs yet knows not the Heavenly; he takes himself as the root yet differs from other forms. He exalts his intellect and races like fire; he is driven by trivial matters and ensnared by things. He looks all around as things respond, adapts to every circumstance, and merges with things—yet has never known constancy. How could he be fit to rule as Heaven?

"Nevertheless, he has lineage and ancestry; he may serve as a father to the multitude but not as the father of fathers. He may lead order or chaos, yet bring calamity whether facing north or south."

Passage after passage unfolds, growing ever more wondrous—could one say the outer chapters are coarser than the inner?

*To rule as Heaven* is like the saying in the *Book of Documents*, "The rites of Yin ascend to match Heaven," meaning to govern the world. *Summon* means to invite. *Perilous* and *danger* both signify risk. *Keen perception and wisdom* are his nature. *Quick* means nimble; *sharp* means swift in response. His nature is agile, so he responds with alacrity—this is how he surpasses others. He cultivates human affairs to accord with Heavenly principle, hence "relies on human effort to align with Heaven." *Meticulous* means clear. *Restraining faults* is like holding the mind without transformation. If one understood the source of faults, there would be no need for restraint.

*Riding upon human affairs yet knowing not the Heavenly* means exhausting one’s efforts in action without understanding non-action. *Riding* means to act, to engage in human affairs. *Self* refers to me; opposing things, it is called "taking oneself as the root yet differing from other forms." *Racing like fire* describes haste. Exalting one’s intellect and using it urgently is called "exalting intellect and racing like fire." *Trivial matters* are the ends. Being enslaved by ends without knowing the root is called "driven by trivial matters," implying fragmentation. *Ensnared by things* means being constrained by affairs and objects. Things come from all four directions, and he looks around to respond—hence "looks all around as things respond." Adapting to each situation and measuring its fitness is called "adapting to every circumstance." Losing one’s natural constancy by being swept away by things is not true responsiveness—hence "merging with things yet never knowing constancy." *Merging* means being altered by affairs and objects. *Constancy* means unity. *Never knowing constancy* means having no stability.

Seven "he is" and seven "just then" in succession—where in ancient or modern times has such prose been seen?

Yet it turns again: though he may not be fit to rule as Heaven, there is still something worthy of reverence. A clan gathers and honors its ancestors—hence "has lineage and ancestry." These four casual words are also extraordinary. *A father to the multitude* means rising above others to guide them. The *father of fathers* is even higher—the father of fathers is Heaven, the natural. *Lead* means to command; this person’s role in the world may bring order or chaos. *Facing north* is the minister; *facing south* is the ruler. To make this the way of minister or ruler invites disaster—hence "calamity whether facing north or south."

Yao observed Hua, and the border guard of Hua said: "Ah! Sage!"

The border guard offered blessings to the sage, wishing him long life. Yao declined. He wished him wealth. Yao declined. He wished him many sons. Yao declined.

The border guard said: "Long life, wealth, and many sons—these are what all men desire. Why do you alone not desire them?"

Yao replied: "Many sons bring many fears; wealth brings many troubles; long life brings many humiliations. These three are not what nurture virtue—hence I decline."

The border guard said: "At first, I took you for a sage, but now you are merely a gentleman. Heaven gives life to the people and must assign them their duties. If you have many sons and assign them duties, what fear is there? If you are wealthy and distribute it among others, what trouble is there? Long life, wealth, and many sons are what all men desire, yet those who study the Way regard them as unworthy of concern. Zhuangzi turns this on its head, revealing his loftiness. 'Heaven gives life to the people and must assign them their duties'—this is like a child falling to the earth and already having clothing and food, the natural allotment of mountains and valleys, as in the saying 'a hundred grasses grieve in the spring rain.' 'Wealthy and distributing it among others' means entrusting it to each person.

The sage dwells like a quail and eats like a fledgling, moving like a bird without leaving a trace. When the world follows the Way, all things flourish together; when the world loses the Way, he cultivates virtue and retreats to leisure. After a thousand years, weary of the world, he departs and ascends as an immortal, riding the white clouds to the realm of the Emperor. The three afflictions never reach him, and his body remains free from harm—what humiliation can there be?

'Dwelling like a quail' means having no fixed abode. 'Eating like a fledgling'—the young bird is fed by its mother, though it eats, it does not seek food itself, meaning it is without concern for sustenance. 'Moving like a bird' means flying. 'Without leaving a trace' means having no attachments, dwelling wherever one finds oneself. 'All things flourish together' means each thing and I attain our respective lives. 'Cultivating virtue and retreating to leisure' means withdrawing when the state lacks the Way. 'Weary of the world and ascending as an immortal' expresses the idea of liberation. 'White clouds and the realm of the Emperor' refer to the heights of emptiness. The 'three afflictions' are youth, adulthood, and old age—the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra*'s metaphor of the Ganges' waters. 'The body remains free from harm' means self-contentment.

Above, he spoke of long life, wealth, and many sons; below, he reverses the order, placing long life last, and the rhetoric grows more expansive—this is the pivot of the text’s artistry.

The border guard departed, and Yao followed, saying: 'May I ask a question?' The border guard replied: 'Withdraw.' Yao still wished to ask, but the border guard did not answer, merely saying 'withdraw,' as if to say, 'Go away.' Jie Yu hurriedly avoided him; the old man with the staff left upon arrival. Master Cheng could not share a boat with such a one—all these are instances of this mechanism.

Yao governed the world, and Bo Cheng Zi Gao was established as a feudal lord. When Yao passed the throne to Shun, and Shun to Yu, Bo Cheng Zi Gao resigned his lordship to plow the fields. Yu went to see him and found him plowing in the wilds. Yu hastened to stand downwind and asked, standing: 'In the past, when Yao governed the world, you, sir, were established as a feudal lord. When Yao passed the throne to Shun, and Shun to me, you resigned your lordship to plow. May I ask the reason?'

Bo Cheng Zi Gao said: 'In the past, when Yao governed the world, he did not reward, yet the people were encouraged; he did not rage, yet the people were awed. Now you employ punishments, and the people grow unkind. Virtue has declined from this point, and penal law has been established from this point—from here, the disorders of later ages begin. Sir, why do you linger? Do not interfere with my work.'

He bent low to his plowing and did not look back. This passage speaks again of the world’s decline, each era worse than the last—even in Yu’s time, it was not as in Yao and Shun’s. 'Do not interfere with my work'—*luò* means 'to neglect'; he said he had no time to speak with Yu, lest he neglect his plowing. *Yìyì* describes the posture of bending low to plow.

Yao did not reward or punish, yet now you reward and punish, and the people grow unkind. His meaning is that rewards and punishments are not as good as their absence—like the idea that litigation should ideally not exist. Yet he uses the names of Yao, Shun, and Yu to make his point.

In the Great Beginning, there was nonbeing; there was no being, no name. The One arose from this—there was the One, yet no form. Things obtained it and were born—this is called *power*. Before form, there were divisions, yet they were seamless—this is called *fate*. Movement abided and gave birth to things; things formed and possessed the principle of life—this is called *form*. Form and spirit preserved each other, each with its own pattern—this is called *nature*. When nature is cultivated, it returns to power; when power reaches its fullness, it is one with the beginning. Being one is emptiness; emptiness is vastness. Harmonizing with the cries of the world, the cries of the world harmonize with it, joining with Heaven and Earth. This joining is profound, appearing foolish and dull—this is called *mysterious power*, one with the Great Compliance.

'The Great Beginning' is the inception of creation. What existed was only nothingness—there was not yet even the word 'being.' If being were like nonbeing, how could there be a name? This is the origin of the One. This 'One' is the word 'nothingness,' hence 'there was the One, yet no form.' Things obtained it and were born—then there was being. All things possess their own being—this is *power*. 'Before form' refers to the moment when the One arose. Though there were divisions, they could not be separated, hence 'seamless.' *Qiěrán* means 'just so,' and the word *qiě* is often followed by another character. 'Seamless' means undifferentiated; 'having divisions' means distinct—this 'fate' is the mandate of Heaven that gives rise to nature.

'Movement abided and gave birth to things'—the primordial *qi* moved ceaselessly, and when its movement abided in a place, it gave birth to things. Hence 'movement abided and gave birth to things.' The phrase 'movement abided' is profoundly subtle—do not read it carelessly. 'Movement' is yang; 'abided' is stillness, and stillness is yin. This line already contains the idea of yang generating and yin completing. Things obtain it and are born; once formed, they possess the principle of life. The movement of primordial *qi* becomes my life—this is called *form.*"

Observe how the character *xing* (形, "form") is explained here—this is found nowhere else in other texts. "Form and body preserve the spirit, each possessing its own norms and patterns, which is called *xing* (性, nature)." This single phrase corresponds to the *Book of Poetry*'s "There are things, there are norms," and to the *Zuozhuan*'s statement that "the people receive the mean of Heaven and Earth, thereby possessing the norms of movement, action, dignity, and propriety." "Form and body" are *qi*; within *qi* resides the spirit, and the so-called norms and patterns are all brought forth by this spirit—this is the idea that within *xing* naturally reside benevolence, righteousness, propriety, and wisdom.

If we discuss this in terms of my own work, the first of these four phrases should replace the character *ban* (搬) with *xing* (性), and this *xing* refers to the functioning of nature. Thus, one must regard the meanings of the characters in this text as a single, unified vision. "*Xing* cultivated returns to *de* (德, virtue/power)" means that by cultivating this *xing*, one restores its natural *de*. When *de* reaches its utmost perfection, one becomes identical to the state before the existence of things. "Returning to *de*" is akin to "returning to *li* (禮, ritual)." "Utmost" means "to reach." To be identical to the state before the existence of things is to be empty; emptiness is vastness, and vastness is speech without words.

"Closing the beak" is silence; "chirping" is speech. The three characters following "speech without words" mark the text’s extraordinary flourish. Below, however, the phrasing turns again, stating, "the beak’s chirping closes"—here, the character *he* (合, "close/unite") differs from the earlier *he*. This means that when the beak’s chirping speaks through silence, it unites with the natural. Through this natural union, it unites with Heaven and Earth. Hence, it is said, "the beak’s chirping closes, uniting with Heaven and Earth." *Minmin* (缗缗) is like *minmin* (泯泯), describing a state of seeming foolishness or dullness—this depicts the character *he* (合). This is what is called the wondrous and subtle *de*, which is identical to the Great Compliance. The Great Compliance is the principle of the Great Beginning’s spontaneity.

Confucius asked Lao Dan: "There is a man who governs the Dao as if imitating others—affirming the unconfirmable, agreeing with the disagreeable. A debater once said, 'Separate hardness and whiteness, as if suspended in midair.' Could such a one be called a sage?" Lao Dan replied: "This is like a clerk or artisan bound by skill, laboring the body and startling the mind. A dog kept to catch raccoons becomes anxious; a monkey’s agility brings it from the mountains. Qiu, I tell you what you cannot hear and speak of what you cannot utter. All those with heads and feet but no heart or ears are many; those with form and those without form or shape who all exist are entirely absent. Their movement and stillness, their life and death, their decline and rise—these are not their true causes.

There is governance in man: forget things, forget Heaven, and it is called forgetting the self. One who forgets the self is said to enter into Heaven. 'As if imitating' refers to the idea that emperors and kings share the same lineage and tribute. By my affirmation, I clarify their negation; by my agreement, I clarify their disagreement. Though the debater’s words—hardness and whiteness, sameness and difference—are tangled and multifarious, I can distinguish them as if suspended in the sky, clearly revealing them to others. *Li* (離) means analysis. *Xuyi jixi* (胥易技系) has been explained in a previous section. *Chengsi* (成思) means being bound by others and thus becoming anxious. 'Coming from the mountains' means being captured and brought here. Earlier it said 'grasping the *zhi* (斄),' but here it says 'grasping the *li* (狸)'—*zhi* is a mistake.

'What cannot be heard, what cannot be spoken' refers to the idea that the *xing* and the Dao of Heaven cannot be heard. 'Having heads and feet' means that people share the same crown and heels. 'Without heart or ears' means they are without knowledge or perception. 'Without form or shape' refers to the spontaneous; from the realm of form, one sees the formless—this is 'those with form and those without form or shape who all exist.' This phrase is also remarkably crafted. 'Entirely absent' means no such person exists in the world. 'Movement and stillness' refer to daily life; 'decline and rise' refer to success and failure. Life and death, success and failure—all have their spontaneous causes. People know the movements and stillnesses, lives and deaths, declines and rises as such, but do not know their true causes.

Han Yu’s *Preface to Sending Wen Chang* says: 'The reason rivers flow, the reason beings flourish.' This too is an insightful remark, but people today read it carelessly. *Zhi* (治) refers to governance; *ren* (人) refers to human affairs. Governing through human affairs leaves no room for personal intent—hence, 'there is governance in man.' Not only does one forget things, but one also forgets Heaven—this is called forgetting the self. One who forgets the self has no self. 'Entering into Heaven' means entering into spontaneity, akin to the earlier 'entering into the non-human.' Above it says 'forget Heaven,' and here it says 'enter into Heaven'—entering means uniting with Heaven, and only through forgetting can one achieve unity.

However, in *Responding to Emperors and Kings*, it says, 'Never yet has it emerged from the non-human'—this means one has not yet forgotten Heaven. 'Never yet has it entered into the non-human'—this means rising above creation. This differs from the phrase 'entering into Heaven.' These are all instances of the text’s dynamic flourishes; one must not cling rigidly to them, for clinging makes *Zhuangzi* difficult to read.

Jiang Lü Meng visited Ji Che and said: "The Lord of Lu told me, 'I request your instruction,' and I could not decline. Having already spoken, I do not know if it was appropriate—allow me to try presenting it. I told the Lord of Lu: 'You must practice reverence and frugality, promote those who are publicly loyal and free from partiality—then which of the people would dare not be harmonious?'" Ji Che laughed heartily and said: "If these are your words on the virtue of emperors and kings, it is like a mantis raising its arms to block a chariot wheel—it will surely fail. Moreover, if this is how you conduct yourself, you endanger your viewing platform, and many will come, treading in your footsteps."

Jiang Lü Meng, startled, said: "I am at a loss regarding your words."

Though so, I wish to hear the drift of your words.

To "present" means to set forth—allow me to set forth what I have said. "Promoting those who are publicly loyal" means to elevate the worthy. "Free from partiality" means to be without favoritism or cliques. "Harmonious" means at peace.

"Chuckling" describes the manner of laughter. The mantis raising its arms to block a chariot wheel speaks of strength too small to bear so great a task. We say "flaring into flight," we say "plants flaring into growth"—here, it speaks of "flaring its arms," for Master Zhuang delights in placing the word "flare" below.

"His self-made place" means the position he has made for himself. If he conducts himself thus, it is as if he endangers his viewing platform to display it to others—people will come and turn to him, and those who tread in his footsteps will grow ever more numerous.

"Many things" refers to the multitude of people. The implication is that the more his reputation flourishes, the more the world will flock to him, and thus he will burden himself.

"Startled" describes the manner of surprise. Hearing these words yet understanding nothing, he said he was utterly lost in what you had spoken.

The term "wind" here refers to the wind of legacy, much like saying "in brief." Ji Che said: When the great sage governs the world, he sways and stirs the people’s hearts, shaping their teachings and transforming their customs. The multitude abandons their predatory minds and advances their solitary aspirations—just as if it were their nature’s own doing, and the people know not how it came to be.

If this is so, how could he merely rank alongside Yao and Shun, humbly submitting to their teachings? He desires that all align with virtue, and thus his heart finds repose.

"Sways and stirs" means to shift and transform. "Predatory mind" refers to the mind of deliberate action. "Solitary aspiration" is the aspiration of solitary attainment—the "solitary" seen in "dawn clarity." Once the people have been shaped by teaching and their customs transformed, they all cast aside their private minds and advance toward the Dao, as if by the nature of innate knowledge, unaware of the ruler’s transformative influence. Thus it is said, "they know not how it came to be."

To regard Yao and Shun as superior and oneself as inferior is to call their teachings elder and one’s own younger. The implication is: How could Yao and Shun surpass me? I am not beneath them—yet the following phrase takes such a stance, which is rather striking. "Humbly submitting" carries the sense of bowing one’s head in deference. The word "people" here is synonymous with "person." If ordinary people could attain this, how could they willingly rank Yao and Shun’s teachings above their own and place themselves below?

When one aligns with the virtue of spontaneity, the heart finds peace. "Reposes" means to settle. "Desires" refers to the sage’s wish for the people to be thus.

Zigong traveled south to Chu and, on his return to Jin, encountered an old man in Hanyin who was tending his garden plots. He had dug a tunnel to enter the well, then hoisted a jar to draw water for irrigation, exerting great effort yet achieving little. Zigong said: "There is a device that can irrigate a hundred plots in a day, requiring little effort yet yielding great results. Would you not wish to use it?"

The gardener looked up and asked: "How does it work?"

Zigong replied: "Carve wood into a mechanism—heavy at the rear, light at the front. It draws water as if pulling, gushing forth like boiling water. It is called a well-sweep."

The gardener flushed with anger, his expression darkening as he laughed: "I have heard from my teacher that those who rely on machinery inevitably engage in mechanical affairs, and those who engage in mechanical affairs inevitably harbor a mechanical mind. When a mechanical mind resides in the breast, purity and whiteness are incomplete. When purity and whiteness are incomplete, the spirit is unsettled. One whose spirit is unsettled cannot bear the Dao. I am not ignorant of this—I am ashamed to do such a thing."

Zigong hung his head in shame and made no reply. After a pause, the gardener asked: "What are you doing here?"

Zigong said: "I am a disciple of Confucius."

The gardener replied: "Are you not that man of vast learning who emulates the sages, boasting to overshadow the crowd, strumming a lone zither and chanting mournful songs to peddle your reputation across the world? You should first forget your spirit and qi, cast aside your bodily form, and only then might you approach this. If you cannot even govern yourself, how can you presume to govern the world? Be on your way—do not hinder my work."

"Digging tunnels between plots" refers to creating water channels. "Pulling" means to draw up. "Gushing forth like boiling water" describes the ease of drawing water. These lines vividly depict the well-sweep’s efficiency.

"Machinery" refers to devices. Using them constitutes "mechanical affairs," and the mind that employs them is the "mechanical mind." A mechanical mind renders purity and whiteness incomplete, meaning it lacks undivided clarity. When the spirit is unsettled, one cannot embrace stillness and unity. "Cannot bear the Dao" means one cannot carry the Dao.

Such matters of learning and effort demand careful reflection.

"Who are you?" is akin to the *Analects*’ "Where are you from?" "Emulates the sages" means to admire the sages. "Boasting" describes an air of self-importance. "Strumming a lone zither and chanting mournful songs" refers to reciting and expounding when others do not understand—akin to striking a chime in Wei, though not quite the same. "Peddling reputation" means to seek fame.

"Forget your spirit and qi" is like saying "dismiss your cleverness." "Cast aside your bodily form" means to forget oneself. If you can do this, you may yet approach it. Otherwise, if you cannot even govern yourself, how can you govern others? These words mock our sage.

"Do not hinder" means "do not delay." Zigong, abashed and crestfallen, walked thirty *li* before recovering his composure.

His disciples asked: "Who was that man just now? Why did you change countenance and lose composure, unable to regain yourself for the rest of the day?"

Zigong replied: "At first, I thought there was only one man in the world—yet I did not know there was another like him. I have heard from the Master that in affairs, one seeks what is feasible; in achievements, one seeks completion; in effort, one seeks minimal labor for maximal results—this is the Way of the sage. But now, it is not so. One who holds to the Dao attains wholeness of virtue; one with wholeness of virtue attains wholeness of form; one with wholeness of form attains wholeness of spirit. Wholeness of spirit is the Way of the sage.

Entrusted with life, he moves among the people yet knows not where he goes—vast and perfectly whole! One must forget the mind of utility, skill, and craft.

"Crestfallen" describes a look of shame. "Abashed" conveys a sense of self-loss. "Unable to regain himself" means he did not return to his usual state. "One man in the world" refers to Confucius.

"In affairs, one seeks what is feasible" means to act only when it is proper. "Minimal labor for maximal results" is like the well-sweep. "Now, it is not so" refers to the uniqueness of the old man from Hanyin.

"Entrusted with life" means living in the world, moving among people yet unaware of his destination—like drifting without aim, reckless and unknowing. Thus it is said, "entrusted with life, he moves among the people yet knows not where he goes." "Perfectly whole" means pure and undivided. "Vast" describes a lack of form or trace.

"One must forget the mind of utility, skill, and craft" means this man’s heart surely holds no such things. Here, "forget" is synonymous with "absence." Such a man does not go where his aspirations do not lead, nor does he act where his heart does not incline.

Though the whole world praise him for attaining what he deems right, he remains aloof and unmoved; though the whole world blame him for losing what he deems right, he remains unperturbed and unshaken. Neither praise nor blame from the world can add to or take away from him—such is the man of perfect virtue. I, however, am but one tossed by the winds and waves of the world.

This man refers to the old man from Hanyin. He does not regard slander or praise as gain or loss; if even praise fails to sway him, how much less would blame? What he speaks and acts upon in the world is called "attaining what he deems right"; what he speaks and does not act upon is called "losing what he deems right."

Returning to Lu, he reported this to Confucius. Confucius said: "That man practices the great arts of the Primal Chaos. He grasps the one but knows not the two; he cultivates his inner self but neglects the outer. Now, one who embodies clarity to enter simplicity, who practices non-action to return to uncarved simplicity, who preserves his nature and embraces the spirit to wander among the common world—would you not be right to marvel at him? Moreover, the arts of Primal Chaos—how could you or I truly comprehend them?"

"Great" here means vast cultivation. "Primal Chaos" refers to the beginning of Heaven and Earth. "Arts" means the Dao. "Grasping the one" means holding to undivided purity; "knowing not the two" means the heart remains undivided. "Inner" refers to the original heart; "outer" refers to external things. "Clarity" allows one to enter simplicity—simplicity being uncarved simplicity. "Non-action" returns one to the natural state of uncarved simplicity. "Preserving nature" means keeping one’s nature whole; "embracing the spirit" means unity. "Would you not be right to marvel?"—"right" here means fitting, for you have not yet understood this Dao and thus fittingly find it strange.

When Zhun Mang journeyed east to the Great Abyss, he encountered Yuan Feng on the shores of the Eastern Sea. Yuan Feng asked: "Where are you going?" "To the Great Abyss," he replied. "What will you do there?" "The Great Abyss," said Zhun Mang, "is such that no matter how much flows into it, it never fills; no matter how much is drawn from it, it never empties. I shall wander there." Yuan Feng said: "Have you no concern for the people of the horizontal-eyed world? I wish to hear of sagely governance."

Zhun Mang said: "Sagely governance? It appoints officials without error, promotes the capable without oversight, fully perceives the true state of affairs, and acts accordingly. Words and deeds arise from self-interest, and the world is transformed. With a wave of the hand or a glance, the people of the four directions all come—this is sagely governance."

The "Great Abyss" is the great sea. "The people of the horizontal-eyed world" is a phrase coined to describe the common folk. "Wandering in the Great Abyss" means that the world is not worth observing, and one instead turns to the sea. "Appointing officials without error" means each fulfills their duty fittingly. "Promoting the capable without oversight" means no talent is overlooked. "True state of affairs" refers to concrete matters. Perceiving all that can be done and acting accordingly is called "fully perceiving the true state of affairs and acting accordingly." Words and deeds arise from self-interest, not for others, and the world naturally transforms. "Self-interest" means acting for oneself, not for others. "A wave of the hand" means stirring movement.
