With a gesture or glance, none fail to respond—this is recorded in the *Book of Documents*: "Only when moved does great response follow, fulfilling the will." "A wave of the hand or a glance" conveys the ease of command. Such is the governance of the sage over the world—referring to the ancient emperors and kings.

"I wish to hear of the virtuous man."

Zhun Mang said: "The virtuous man dwells without thought, moves without calculation, harbors no judgments of right or wrong, beauty or ugliness. Within the four seas, all share in his benefit and delight in his presence; all are provided for and find peace in his care. He is forlorn as an infant parted from its mother, disoriented as a traveler who has lost his way. Wealth and resources abound, yet he knows not their source; food and drink suffice, yet he knows not their origin. This is the bearing of the virtuous man."

"Dwelling and moving" refer to activity and stillness. Without concern for either, it is said he "dwells without thought, moves without calculation." "Harboring no judgments of right or wrong, beauty or ugliness" echoes the Buddhist teaching of "neither thinking of good nor thinking of evil." "Sharing benefit and provision" conveys the joy of mutual delight. "Forlorn" describes a desolate appearance. Like an infant parted from its mother or a traveler who has lost his way, he is detached from the world yet not without constraint. Wealth, resources, food, and drink all come to him unbidden—this is the mark of a heart without attachment. The virtuous man stands a level above sagely governance.

"I wish to hear of the spirit man."

The spirit man rides the light, vanishing with form—this is called "illuminating vastness." He fulfills destiny and exhausts feeling, so heaven and earth rejoice and the ten thousand affairs dissolve; the ten thousand things return to their true nature—this is called "primordial chaos."

"Spirit man" speaks of one whose spirit soars upward, transcending heaven and earth, so that even the light of sun and moon lies beneath him—thus he "rides the light." "Vanishing with form" means that though he has a body, it is as if he has none. "Illuminating vastness" describes his great clarity. "Fulfilling destiny" means attaining the utmost of heaven’s mandate. "Exhausting feeling" means fully realizing the feelings inherent in his nature—this "feeling" aligns with Mencius’ "if one follows one’s true feelings, one may do good." Delighting in the Way of heaven and earth, with no affairs to burden him, it is said that "heaven and earth rejoice and the ten thousand affairs dissolve." "Returning to true nature" means reverting to reality, so that when the ten thousand things all return to reality, they become one with him. "Primordial chaos" is the undifferentiated state, the so-called "Hundun."

The spirit man stands yet another level above the virtuous man. Such distinctions suggest that above the ancient sage-kings, there are those who remain beyond reach.

Menwugui and Chizhang Manji observed King Wu’s army. Chizhang Manji said, "Is he not inferior to the Lord of Yu? That is why he incurs this disaster." Menwugui replied, "Was the world well-governed before the Lord of Yu governed it? Or did he bring order only after chaos?" Chizhang Manji said, "A well-governed world is the universal wish—why calculate whether it was the Lord of Yu? The Lord of Yu was like a physician treating sores: applying a wig to a bald head, seeking a doctor for illness. A filial son prepares medicine to cure his compassionate father, yet his countenance remains distressed. The sage feels shame at this." Manji’s words imply that military conquest falls short of yielding and deference. In response to Menwugui’s question, he further criticizes the Lord of Yu, saying that while all desire a well-governed world, relying on the Lord of Yu’s governance only becomes a burden. "Without sores, what need is there for medicine? Without baldness, what use for a wig? Without illness, what need for a doctor?"—this suggests that calling governance "governance" is itself an affliction. Governing through non-action means no affliction exists. A filial son preparing medicine for his father still appears uneasy—how much better if the father were never ill? Thus, the sage deems those who act with intent to govern as bringing shame upon the world. Though his words are not orthodox, their metaphors are striking.

Cultivation signifies advancement, synonymous with shame—these characters were interchangeable in ancient script. "Deems them shameful" means deems them disgraceful. In the age of utmost virtue, worthies were not exalted, nor were the capable employed. Rulers were like bare branches, the people like wild deer: upright yet unaware of righteousness, affectionate yet unaware of benevolence, sincere yet unaware of loyalty, fitting yet unaware of trustworthiness, instinctively aiding one another without perceiving it as favor. Thus, their conduct left no traces, their affairs no records. The entire world, pure and undivided, bore no names of worthies or the capable—hence, "worthies were not exalted, nor were the capable employed." Bare branches refer to withered limbs, visible only in their boughs, devoid of leaves—an analogy for the absence of emotion and desire. Uprightness denotes self-cultivation; affection, mutual kinship. Sincerity in interaction is integrity, the heart’s expression is loyalty. Fitting action means affairs are aptly managed. The four "unawares" following uprightness indicate that in that era, there were no names for benevolence, righteousness, loyalty, or trustworthiness. "Instinctive movement" refers to all living people; "aiding one another" means mutual friendship and assistance. "Without perceiving it as favor" means without regarding it as grace. "Conduct left no traces, affairs no records" signifies that in that time, there were no matters of right or wrong, praise or blame. All this depicts the age of great antiquity.

A filial son does not flatter his parents; a loyal minister does not fawn upon his lord—this is the height of ministerial and filial devotion. Yet when a parent’s words are affirmed and their conduct deemed good, the world calls such a son unworthy. When a lord’s words are affirmed and their conduct deemed good, the world calls such a minister unworthy. But how can this be certain? When the world’s so-called "right" is affirmed as right, and its so-called "good" is deemed good, one is not called a sycophant. Is it then that worldly custom reveres parents and lords more strictly? To be called a flatterer provokes indignation; to be called a fawner elicits displeasure—yet one spends a lifetime flattering and fawning. One who neither flatters nor fawns can admonish their lord or father. To affirm whatever they say as right and whatever they do as good is to fail in admonition. In the case of lords and parents, admonition is deemed correct, and its absence incorrect. Yet in the world, one follows what is deemed good and affirms what is deemed right—does this not mean worldly custom reveres lords and parents less strictly?

This suggests that what people today call the Way is merely what the world collectively deems right, not something uniquely attained by the self, nor something that aligns with the Creator. "Guiding" means compliance; "flattery," obsequiousness. If what I call the Way merely aligns with worldly custom, then my conduct is nothing more than guiding and flattering the world. If others brand me a flatterer, I will surely resent it—yet my lifelong conduct cannot escape such a charge, for it cannot differ from worldly custom. The sage takes what is universally practiced as the Way, but Zhuangzi holds that the Way transcends the age, thus ranking the emperors and sages of antiquity a grade below. This passage unfolds with such force, its brushwork surging and irresistible—truly unmatched. Yet his words may err on the side of excess.

Gathering analogies and adorning words is to assemble the masses—yet beginning and end, root and branch, do not correspond. Donning robes and skirts, displaying colors, altering countenance to ingratiate an age, yet never calling oneself a guide or flatterer; aligning with others in right and wrong, yet never deeming oneself one of the common folk—this is the height of folly.

"Gathering analogies" means assembling the world’s metaphors to establish a doctrine. "Adorning words" means refining one’s rhetoric. "Assembling the masses" means drawing all scholars of the world to oneself. At the outset, the heart aspires to rise above the age, yet in the end, it cannot depart from the people of its time. Thus, beginning and end, root and branch, do not align—hence "do not correspond," meaning they do not match.

"Donning robes and skirts, displaying colors, altering countenance" refers to the Confucians’ attire and demeanor. "Colors" signify patterns. They methodically guide and instruct scholars, thus ingratiating themselves to the age. This is all a veiled critique of our sage. What one deems right, one’s disciples also deem right; what one deems wrong, one’s disciples also deem wrong. Those who study under one are all mediocre folk of the vulgar world. If one’s judgments align with theirs, then one is also a mediocre person. Yet to consort with mediocrity and not call oneself mediocre—this is the utmost stupidity, utterly lacking in discernment.

Zhuangzi’s intent is that what he alone has grasped, others do not know, and thus he differs from them. This gives rise to such resentful words, which are not sound argument. To know one’s own folly is not great folly; to know one’s own confusion is not great confusion. The greatly confused never awaken in their lifetime; the greatly foolish never gain insight. If one in three is confused, the path one seeks may still be reached, for confusion is slight. If two in three are confused, one labors in vain and does not arrive, for confusion prevails. But now the whole world is confused—though I have my own aspirations, how can they be realized? Is this not lamentable?

Grand music does not enter the ears of the village; the tunes *Zhe Yang* and *Huang Hua* make them burst into laughter. Thus, lofty words do not lodge in the hearts of the common folk; profound speech remains unspoken, for vulgar words prevail. If two jars and bells confuse, the path one seeks cannot be found. Now the whole world is confused—though I have my aspirations, how can they be attained? To know they cannot be attained and yet force the matter is yet another confusion.

Thus, it is better to let go and not press the point. If one does not press, who then shares the sorrow? To never awaken or gain insight is merely to lack self-knowledge.

"Aspirations" means direction. If two of three companions are confused, one still toils in vain and does not arrive. Now the whole world is confused by such doctrines—though I alone have a direction, how can I turn the age? This "I" is Zhuangzi speaking of himself. *Zhe Yang* and *Huang Hua* are names of rustic tunes. "Grand music" refers to ancient melodies, an analogy for his most profound teachings. That they "do not lodge in the hearts of the common folk" means his words do not penetrate. *Zhe Yang* and *Huang Hua* stand for vulgar speech. When vulgar speech prevails, profound words remain hidden.

"Dangling the heels" means sitting with feet hanging, unwilling to proceed. "Two dangling heels confused" refers to the earlier "two confused." "The path one seeks cannot be found" echoes the earlier "labor in vain and do not arrive." Scribal errors have rendered "dangling" as "jars" and "heels" as "bells," both unintelligible. Comparing the preceding and following phrases, "dangling heels" is clearly correct.

To know it cannot be attained and yet force the matter is yet another confusion—this is self-deception. Knowing it cannot be conveyed and yet insisting on conveying it adds another layer of confusion. "Let go" means to abandon it. "Not press" means not to insist on explaining. "Near" means close. To entrust it to silence is to avoid drawing near to sorrow—this is self-consolation.

A leper gives birth in the dead of night, hastily seizing a torch to examine the child, anxious lest it resemble himself. A "leper" is an evil person. The inserted "之" is like the earlier "骊之姬"—this is his stylistic pattern. An evil person fears his child will resemble him, for he knows his own wickedness. Yet those who are confused in the world do not know themselves and thus fall short even of the leper.

From the earlier "great confusion never awakens in a lifetime" and "great folly never gains insight," to these two analogies, the argument remains unresolved—this is mere literary play.

A century-old tree, split into sacrificial vessels, painted with green and yellow patterns—its offcut lies discarded in a ditch. Compared to the sacrificial vessel, the offcut in the ditch is one of beauty and ugliness, yet both have lost their original nature. Robber Zhi and the virtuous Zeng and Shi differ in conduct, yet all alike have lost their original nature.

Moreover, there are five ways to lose one’s nature: first, the five colors confuse the eyes, making them unclear; second, the five sounds confuse the ears, making them dull; third, the five odors choke the nose, congesting the sinuses; fourth, the five flavors cloy the mouth, making it numb; fifth, preferences and aversions agitate the heart, scattering the nature. These five are all harms to life, yet Yang Zhu and Mo Di strain to stand apart, claiming to have attained something—this is not what I call attainment.

If what is confined can be called attainment, then the owl in a cage may also be called attainment. The offcut in the ditch is the remnant of the tree split into sacrificial vessels. Though the same wood may be fashioned into a vessel or discarded in a ditch, its honor or disgrace differs, yet both are but withered wood—this is akin to the parable of the hidden grain and the lost sheep.

The five colors, five sounds, five odors, and five flavors are all products of human effort, thus they disrupt the nature. These four, along with preferences, are all denigrated.

"To be confined is to be obstructed and opposed by others. The central glabellum connects from the nose to the forehead. Alone, the mouth defiles its... Alas! *Lishuang* means deviation and loss. *Quhe* refers to judgments of right and wrong, preferences and aversions. When *quhe* muddles the heart, the natural nature is lost—thus it is said that *quhe* disturbs the heart, causing the nature to scatter and soar. The teachings of Yang Zhu and Mo Di are those that disturb the heart with *quhe*, yet they claim ability. They confine themselves with their doctrines and call it attainment. If this is called attainment, then beasts in cages may also be called attainment. This is a severe rebuke. (The variant *zhuokou* is incorrect.)

Moreover, preferences and aversions toward sounds and colors clutter the inner self, while *pibian*, *yuguan*, *jin hu*, and *shenxiu* constrain the outer. Internally, one is propped up by a wooden fence; externally, one is weighed down by snares. Bright-eyed within the snares, one yet claims attainment—this is like a criminal with bound arms and crossed fingers, or tigers and leopards trapped in sacks and cages, which may also be called attainment.

For their preferences and aversions manifest in speech and countenance, contending with others over right and wrong, their hearts become obstructed—thus it is said that preferences and aversions toward sounds and colors clutter the inner self. *Pibian*, *yuguan*, *jin hu*, and *shenxiu* are all the attire of the Confucians; clothing and conduct must be forcibly restrained by ritual—thus it is said to constrain the outer. *Jin* means to hold a *hu*; *shenxiu* refers to the long sash."

Within, one is crammed and congested as though by a wooden fence—this speaks of the lack of ease in the breast. Without, one is bound and constrained by ritual and decorum as though a criminal under restraint; *jijiao* refers to being tied with rope. *Huǎn huǎn* describes the appearance of gazing. Though others see one tormenting oneself as though in bondage, one yet claims attainment—would this be like a prisoner or a tiger in a sack and cage also claiming self-attainment?

To condemn Yang Zhu and Mo Di with such vehemence is excessive indeed. *Jiaobi* means to bind the arms; *lizhi* refers to the fingers being so tightly bound by rope that they may be counted. *Nang* and *kan* are spoken of together, much like the common saying of "a macaque in a sack."

*Oral Exegesis of the True Scripture of the Southern Florescence, Fifteenth Scroll*
By Lin Xiyi of Yuanzhai

**Outer Chapters: The Dao of Heaven**

The Dao of Heaven revolves without accumulation, thus all things are brought to completion. The Dao of the Thearch revolves without accumulation, thus the world submits. The Dao of the Sage revolves without accumulation, thus all within the seas obeys. One who is enlightened by Heaven and attuned to the Sage, whose six penetrations and four openings align with the virtue of thearchs and kings—such a one acts in profound obscurity, yet nothing is not at rest.

The stillness of the sage is not stillness for its own sake; it is good, and thus still. No thing suffices to disturb the heart, and so it is still. When water is still, it clearly reflects beard and brows, its level serves as a standard, and the great craftsman takes it as a model. If still water is so luminous, how much more so the spirit! The heart of the sage is still—it is the mirror of Heaven and Earth, the mirror of the ten thousand things.

The Dao of the Thearch and the Dao of the Sage are fundamentally difficult to distinguish. Zhuangzi’s intent is likely to regard the Thearch as the Three Sovereigns and the Sage as the Five Emperors. To revolve without accumulation is to be pure and unceasing. The phrase “without accumulation” makes this clearer. The central meaning of this passage, however, lies in the word *stillness*.

Within utmost stillness, revolving without accumulation—how could this be like withered wood or dead ashes? It is only that readers fail to perceive it. “Six penetrations and four openings” means unobstructed in all directions—east, west, south, north, above, and below. *Obscure* here carries the sense of *profoundly dark*. The sage’s stillness is not stillness for its own sake; it is good, and thus still—this line is most vital. It means the sage does not prize stillness as a virtue and thus seek it. No thing suffices to agitate the heart, so stillness is not pursued but arises naturally. *Disturb* is interchangeable with *agitate*.

The analogy of water and mirror for stillness is drawn from everyday speech, yet the phrasing is exquisitely precise. Now, emptiness, stillness, tranquility, quiescence, and non-action—these are the equilibrium of Heaven and Earth and the perfection of virtue and power. Thus thearchs, kings, and sages rest in them. To rest is to be empty; to be empty is to be full. What is full is ordered. To be empty is to be still; to be still is to move; to move is to attain. Stillness is non-action; in non-action, those who handle affairs bear responsibility. In non-action, one is at ease; at ease, one cannot be beset by care or calamity, and thus enjoys long life.

Emptiness, stillness, tranquility, quiescence, and non-action—these are the root of the ten thousand things. Understanding this and facing south, one becomes a ruler like Yao. Understanding this and facing north, one becomes a minister like Shun. Practicing this in a high position, one embodies the virtue of thearchs, kings, and Son of Heaven. Practicing this in a low position, one follows the Way of the dark sage and unadorned king. Retiring to leisurely wander rivers and seas, recluses of mountains and forests submit to this. Advancing to govern the world, one achieves great merit, renowned fame, and unifies all under Heaven.

Expanding the single word *stillness* into eight—emptiness, stillness, tranquility, quiescence, and non-action—clarifies its meaning. *Equilibrium* means *fixed*; *perfection* means *utmost*. This is the unchanging principle of Heaven and Earth, the ultimate in virtue and power. *Rest* means *to halt*. The hearts of thearchs, kings, and sages halt at this—akin to the saying “halt at utmost goodness.” To rest is to be empty, just as “only the Dao gathers in emptiness” and “auspiciousness halts where it halts.”

Yet what follows—“to be empty is to be full; what is full is ordered”—is even more incisive. “To be empty is to be full” is like the Chan saying that true emptiness gives rise to real existence. *Ordered* means *principle*; within true fullness, there is inherent pattern—this is radiance within undifferentiated wholeness. The previous line expounds “to be empty is to be full,” while the next speaks of “to be empty is to be still; to be still is to move.” This is the mutual rooting of movement and stillness. To move without failing to accord with what is fitting is called “to move is to attain.” “Those who handle affairs bear responsibility” means each fulfills their duty, achieving non-action yet nothing left undone.

*At ease* describes a state of bliss. “Cannot be beset by care or calamity” means not falling into distress; *beset* implies *sinking into*. Not entering into care or calamity is like the saying “the humane are without anxiety.” Long life is the reward of stillness. These four lines develop the idea of emptiness, stillness, and non-action—this is Zhuangzi’s literary method.

Here, the eight characters—emptiness, stillness, tranquility, quiescence, and non-action—are reiterated, concluding with “the root of the ten thousand things.” *Root* means *beginning*. This principle arises before the existence of the ten thousand things. Practicing this in a high position, one faces south as a ruler; in a low position, one does not serve. The *dark sage and unadorned king* refers to one who possesses the virtue of a sage but not the position. Retiring to leisurely wander is the path of the recluse; advancing to govern the world is the path of one who serves the times. Observe this line—how could its intent not be to engage with the world? How could it not regard movement and stillness as one?

Stillness makes one a sage; movement makes one a king. In non-action, one is revered; in simplicity, none under Heaven can rival its beauty. One who comprehends the virtue of Heaven and Earth—this is called the great root and great origin, harmonizing with Heaven. Thus one harmonizes and regulates all under Heaven, harmonizing with others. To harmonize with others is called human joy; to harmonize with Heaven is called Heavenly joy.

Stillness makes one a sage; movement makes one a king—this is the four characters *inner sage, outer king*. “In non-action, one is revered”: *revered* means *noble*, for no Dao under Heaven is more noble than non-action. *Simplicity* means *without adornment*. Though it may seem plain, none under Heaven surpasses its beauty, hence “in simplicity, none under Heaven can rival its beauty.” *Comprehends* means *clearly understands*. Knowing this virtue of Heaven and Earth, one may become Heaven’s companion, hence “harmonizing with Heaven.” *Harmonize* means *to unite*. *Great root and great origin* is praise for the virtue of spontaneity, akin to the idea of “self-rooted, self-so.” To harmonize and regulate all under Heaven is to unite with others—just as Yao said, “You are Heaven’s match.”

“For I am humanity’s match.” Having spoken of harmony with Heaven and harmony with humanity, the text now turns to *humanity delighting in Heaven’s delight*, its brushwork soaring and exultant—such is its general tenor.

Zhuangzi says: “My master! My master!”—who crushes nothing yet leaves no thing unblest, whose grace spans ten thousand ages yet claims no benevolence, who outlasts high antiquity yet boasts no longevity, who roofs and bears the cosmos, who carves and shapes the myriad forms yet lays no claim to artistry. This is called *Heaven’s delight*. These lines recur in the *Great and Venerable Master* chapter, though here they are prefaced with “Zhuangzi says.” Earlier they were the words of Xu You; now they are spoken as if by Zhuangzi himself. Clearly, every utterance is a parable—how could one take them as literal speech?

Thus it is said: One who knows *Heaven’s delight* moves in life as the heavens move, dies as things transform; in stillness shares the power of yin, in motion rides the wave of yang. Therefore, one who knows *Heaven’s delight* bears no resentment from Heaven, no blame from humanity, no burden from things, no reproach from spirits. Hence it is said: In action, one is Heaven; in stillness, one is Earth. With a single mind settled, one rules all under Heaven; no ghost brings misfortune, no soul grows weary. With a single mind settled, the myriad things submit. This speaks of extending the principle of emptiness and stillness to Heaven and Earth, penetrating the myriad things—this is called *Heaven’s delight*.

*Heaven’s delight* is the heart of the sage nurturing all under Heaven. *Heaven’s movement* means following the spontaneous pattern of Heaven’s principle. *Transformation of things* means changing with the myriad things. In stillness, one is yin; in motion, one is yang. *Riding the wave* means flowing together. The Confucian school speaks only of “not resenting Heaven, not blaming others,” but here two more phrases are added—*no burden from things, no reproach from spirits*—rendering the passage even more spirited. When ghosts manifest to humans, it is called *misfortune*; *no ghost brings misfortune* means the spirit is concealed and does not reveal itself. *No soul grows weary* means the spirit is not exhausted. *Ghosts* and *souls* refer to the spirit itself. When the mind is settled, the spirit is naturally settled, and the myriad things submit of themselves.

Extending the principle of emptiness and stillness to move among Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things—this is called *extending to Heaven and Earth and penetrating the myriad things*. *Nurturing all under Heaven* means governing the world by skillfully nourishing its people.

The virtue of emperors and kings takes Heaven and Earth as its model, the Dao and its power as its foundation, and non-action as its constant. In non-action, one employs all under Heaven with abundance; in action, one is employed by all under Heaven with insufficiency. Thus the ancients prized non-action.

When the ruler practices non-action, the subjects also practice non-action—this means the subjects share the ruler’s power, and when subjects share the ruler’s power, they do not serve as ministers. When the subjects act, the ruler also acts—this means the ruler shares the subjects’ path, and when the ruler shares the subjects’ path, he does not serve as lord. The ruler must practice non-action to employ all under Heaven; the subjects must act to be employed by all under Heaven—this is an unchanging principle.

The Dao of Heaven and Earth and the power of virtue are nothing but the principle of non-action. This passage contrasts non-action with action, taking non-action as the ruler’s path and action as the minister’s path. *When subjects share the ruler’s power, they do not serve as ministers* means ministers should labor. *When the ruler shares the subjects’ path, he does not serve as lord* means the lord should be at ease. *Employing all under Heaven* is the role of the ruler; *being employed by all under Heaven* is the role of the minister. This discussion of lord and minister presents yet another perspective, distinct from the *Heaven’s Dao, Humanity’s Dao* passage in *Preserving and Nurturing*. If one clings rigidly to such distinctions, one cannot read Zhuangzi.

Moreover, though this chapter states that the ruler should practice non-action while the minister should act, an earlier passage says, “Understanding this and facing north, as Shun did when serving as minister,” and “Using this to advance and govern the age, one achieves great merit and renowned fame”—thus even the minister’s path is one of non-action. How could these teachings contradict one another? Therefore, if one reads Zhuangzi with such rigid adherence, one will fail to grasp his meaning.

Thus the ancient rulers of all under Heaven, though their knowledge encompassed Heaven and Earth, did not scheme for themselves; though their eloquence adorned the myriad things, they did not delight in themselves; though their abilities exhausted the realm, they did not act for themselves. Heaven does not produce, yet the myriad things transform; Earth does not grow, yet the myriad things are nurtured; emperors and kings practice non-action, yet all under Heaven achieves success. Hence it is said: Nothing is more divine than Heaven, nothing richer than Earth, nothing greater than emperors and kings. Thus it is said: The virtue of emperors and kings matches Heaven and Earth. This is the Dao of riding Heaven and Earth, driving the myriad things, and employing the human realm.

*Encompassing Heaven and Earth* means embracing them—*embracing* and *encompassing* share the same meaning. *Adorning the myriad things* refers to their artistry. The myriad things generate themselves, not by Heaven’s production; they grow themselves, not by Earth’s growth. Thus it is said: Heaven does not produce, Earth does not grow. Emperors and kings achieve the world’s success through non-action, aligning with Heaven and Earth. *Riding Heaven and Earth* is like saying “riding the six dragons to govern Heaven”; *driving the myriad things* means commanding the moving multitude.

This passage simply praises the ruler’s path of non-action. Its essence lies in the ruler; its details lie in the minister. What matters is the lord; what is elaborated is the minister. The deployment of the three armies and five weapons is the outermost expression of virtue; rewards and punishments, benefits and harms, the five punishments—these are the outermost expression of teaching. Rituals, laws, measures, punishments, names, and detailed comparisons—these are the outermost expression of governance. The sounds of bells and drums, the forms of feathered banners—these are the outermost expression of music. Wailing and mourning, the gradations of mourning attire—these are the outermost expression of grief. These five outer expressions require the movement of spirit and the activation of the mind’s art before they can be followed.

Such outer expressions were practiced by the ancients, but they are not what should come first. From this point onward, the text again discusses action, for non-action is the root, while action is the branch. What matters is the ruler’s path of non-action; what is elaborated is the minister’s path of action. The assistance of martial and civil virtue—hence it is said: *The deployment of the three armies and five weapons is the outermost expression of virtue*. The *five weapons* are the bow, shield, spear, dagger-axe, and halberd.

The clarification of punishments assists instruction, hence it is said: rewards and penalties, advantages and harms, the five punishments and their applications—these are the outermost expression of teaching. Measurements and gradations are matters of rank and distinction; penal codes and names are matters of nomenclature. *Bi* means classification by analogy; *xiang* means meticulous detail. Ritual laws, measurements, bells, drums, plumes, and banners—none of these are the root of ritual and music. It is like saying: "Are jade tablets and silk, bells and drums the essence of ritual and music?" The outermost expression of grief likewise embodies the meaning of "rather sorrow than ease."

These several lines are most balanced. The movement of spirit and the activation of the mind’s art must come first, for all proceed from the inner heart and are not imposed from without. That the ancients practiced these outer expressions does not mean they should come first—this line is particularly fine, for it shows that Zhuangzi never intended to entirely abandon weapons, punishments, ritual, or music.

The ruler leads and the minister follows; the father leads and the child follows; the elder brother leads and the younger follows; the elder leads and the younger follows; the man leads and the woman follows. This hierarchy of honor and precedence is the course of Heaven and Earth, and thus the sage takes it as his model. Heaven is honored and Earth is lowly—such is the positioning of the numinous. Spring and summer come first, autumn and winter follow—such is the sequence of the four seasons. The transformations and creations of the myriad things, their sprouting forms and distinct shapes, their waxing and waning, their flowing changes—all these too are the course of Heaven and Earth. If even Heaven and Earth, most numinous of all, possess this order of honor and precedence, how much more should the human Dao?

In ancestral temples, kinship is honored; in court, honor is given to rank; in village communities, age is honored; in affairs of state, worth is honored—this is the sequence of the Great Dao. To speak of the Dao while violating its sequence is not the Dao. To speak of the Dao while misrepresenting the Dao—how can one claim to grasp the Dao?

Following the contrast of "leading" and "following," the text offers many analogies. It means that what should lead must lead, and what should follow must follow—all is the natural principle of Heaven and Earth. Thus the sage takes it as his model, saying: "The hierarchy of honor and precedence is the course of Heaven and Earth, and the sage takes it as his model." The analogies of Heaven, Earth, and the four seasons serve to illustrate this. *Huazuo* means transformation and generation—like the line in the *Book of Songs*: "The fern also sprouts." *Meng* means sprouting; *qu* means differentiation. It speaks of things being born with different forms. Changing with the seasons, first flourishing then declining, this too is an analogy. The sequence of precedence and the gradations of decline are matters of degree. What flourishes does not flourish all at once, nor does what declines decline all at once—all follows an order, hence it is called "the gradations of flourishing and decline."

From the sequence of precedence, the text moves to honor and lowliness, for honor and lowliness are also matters of precedence. "In affairs of state, worth is honored" means that in assigning duties, the worthy take precedence. Age, rank, kinship, and worth—these too are the natural principles of the world, hence they are called "the sequence of the Great Dao." "How can one claim to grasp the Dao?" means that if one does not know this sequence, how can one possess the Dao?

Thus those in antiquity who illuminated the Great Dao first illuminated Heaven, then virtue/power followed; once virtue/power was illuminated, benevolence and righteousness followed; once benevolence and righteousness were illuminated, the division of duties followed; once the division of duties was illuminated, forms and names followed; once forms and names were illuminated, the assignment of tasks followed; once the assignment of tasks was illuminated, investigation and reduction followed; once investigation and reduction were illuminated, right and wrong followed; once right and wrong were illuminated, rewards and punishments followed. Once rewards and punishments were illuminated, the foolish and the wise were placed appropriately, the noble and the base occupied their proper positions, the benevolent and the worthless each settled into their true natures. Abilities were distinguished, names were adhered to, and with these one served superiors, nurtured inferiors, governed things, and cultivated the self. Scheming and planning were set aside, and all necessarily returned to their Heavenly nature. This is called the ultimate state of Great Peace and governance.

This passage describes the sequence of governance, comprising nine levels. Heaven is first, virtue/power second, the seven virtues (benevolence and righteousness) third, the division of duties fourth, forms and names fifth, the assignment of tasks sixth, investigation and reduction seventh, right and wrong eighth, and rewards and punishments ninth. *Fenshou* means official duties; *xingming* refers to external designations (the character *xing* is interchangeable with *xing*, meaning "form"). *Yinren* means assigning great tasks based on one’s duties. *Yuan* means exemption; *sheng* means reduction—if one is not suited to a task, they are exempted or removed. *Shifei* means distinguishing the good from the bad. *Shangfa* refers to punishments like flogging or rewards like chariots and robes to make them known.

Zhuangzi’s account of the sequence of governance is thus, yet how can it be said that Heaven’s punishment of the guilty and Heaven’s mandate to the virtuous—how can rewards and punishments not be of Heaven? Why must one go through nine transformations before reaching them? Such reasoning strays far from the sages. Yet to say "first illuminate Heaven, then virtue/power," and then proceed through these several stages is not a matter of abandoning the coarse to seek the refined.

"The foolish and the wise are placed appropriately" means being suited to their tasks. *Lüwei* likewise means being in one’s proper position. *Xi* means to settle—settling into one’s true nature means the noble and the base each have their place. "Names are adhered to" means demanding reality in accordance with names. "Scheming and planning are set aside, and all necessarily return to their Heavenly nature" means that though each matter has its place, there is no room for contrivance—all returns to spontaneity. This is the age of Great Peace.

Thus the *Book* says: "There are forms and names." Forms and names were practiced by the ancients, but they are not what should come first. Those in antiquity who spoke of the Great Dao underwent five transformations before forms and names could be established, and nine transformations before rewards and punishments could be discussed. To abruptly speak of forms and names is to ignore their root. To abruptly speak of rewards and punishments is to ignore their beginning. To speak of the Dao in reverse or to expound it perversely is what others may govern, but how can one govern others?

To abruptly speak of penal codes, names, rewards, and punishments is to possess the tools of governance but not the Dao of governance. Such a one may be employed by the world but cannot employ the world—this is called a disputatious scholar, a man of partial understanding. Ritual laws, measurements, penal codes, classifications, and meticulous details were practiced by the ancients, but these are what inferiors use to serve superiors, not what superiors use to nurture inferiors.

The texts are ancient writings. Though they contain discussions of forms and names, they never abandon the root to pursue the branches—thus they are not what should come first. If one does not know the proper sequence and speaks of them abruptly, one loses their fundamental origin. "Inverted" means to place things upside down; "perverse" means to go against the natural order. If one reverses this natural Dao or inverts its teachings, one becomes governed by others—used by the world rather than using the world. To regard penal codes, names, rewards, and punishments as the tools of governance, and to divide and uphold benevolence and righteousness as the Dao of governance—where is the error in this? Only that the exposition becomes convoluted. "Partial" means one-sided. What superiors use to nurture inferiors is the way of the ruler; what inferiors use to serve superiors is the way of the minister.

Formerly, Shun asked Yao, "How does the Son of Heaven employ his heart-mind?" Yao replied, "I do not slight the destitute, nor abandon the impoverished. I grieve for the dead and commend the young, pitying widows—this is how I employ my heart-mind." Shun said, "Admirable as this is, it is not yet great." Yao asked, "Then what should it be?" Shun said, "Let virtue emerge in tranquility, like the sun and moon shining and the four seasons proceeding. As day and night follow their constant course, clouds move and rain falls." Yao said, "Then I am but restless and troubled! You are in accord with Heaven; I am in accord with man." Now, Heaven and Earth are what the ancients deemed greatest, what the Yellow Emperor, Yao, and Shun all esteemed. Thus, those who ruled all under Heaven in ancient times—what did they do? They simply followed Heaven and Earth.

"Slight" means to treat with contempt; "grieve" means to feel compassion. "Commend" means to approve. "Widows" refers to women without husbands. Though the term "widow" is not used, it is implied by the pairing with "the young." "Heavenly virtue" is the virtue of nature. "Emerging in tranquility" means to rise above all things so that the myriad states are at peace. As the sun sets, the moon rises; as cold departs, heat arrives—this is the sun and moon shining and the four seasons proceeding. Day follows night, and night follows day, ever constant—this is the meaning of "course." Clouds move and rain falls, following the seasons naturally—all this illustrates the idea of acting without contrivance. "Restless and troubled" describes disorder. Yao said his actions fell short of Shun’s, for he could not avoid self-generated disorder, and thus he was in accord only with man, not with Heaven. The next three sentences are Yao’s self-deprecating words.

"Heaven and Earth are what the ancients deemed greatest"—this means the principle of Heaven and Earth, from ancient times to the present, has been the greatest of all. "All esteemed" means all cherished it. Those who ruled all under Heaven did nothing else but model themselves on Heaven and Earth. The earlier praise and criticism of Yao and Shun, followed by their equal mention alongside the Yellow Emperor, show no distinction in weight. If one clings to their names and words, one will be obstructed and unable to proceed.

Confucius traveled west to deposit his writings in the Zhou archives. Zilu counseled, "I have heard that in Zhou there is a keeper of the archives named Lao Dan, who has retired and now lives in seclusion. If you wish to deposit your writings, you might visit him and seek his aid." Confucius said, "Very well." He went to see Lao Dan, but Lao Dan refused his request. Thereupon, Confucius expounded the Twelve Classics to persuade him. Midway through, Lao Dan interrupted, saying, "This is too prolix—pray tell me the essentials." Confucius replied, "The essentials lie in benevolence and righteousness." Lao Dan asked, "Are benevolence and righteousness part of human nature?" Confucius said, "Indeed. The noble person who lacks benevolence cannot achieve completion, and without righteousness, cannot live. Benevolence and righteousness are the true nature of humanity—what more could one do?" Lao Dan said, "I ask what you mean by benevolence and righteousness." Confucius replied, "To delight in all things with a harmonious heart-mind, to love universally without partiality—this is the essence of benevolence and righteousness." Lao Dan said, "Alas! These are but shallow words. Is not universal love impractical? To claim impartiality is itself partiality. If you wish to ensure that all under Heaven do not lose their proper nurture, know that Heaven and Earth have their constancy, the sun and moon their brightness, the stars and constellations their order, birds and beasts their flocks, and trees their uprightness. You too should emulate virtue and act, follow the Dao and proceed—you have already arrived. Why then do you laboriously brandish benevolence and righteousness, as if beating a drum to seek a lost child? Alas! You confuse human nature."

"Traveled west to deposit his writings in the Zhou archives" means he went west to Zhou to examine its archival texts. "Expounded" means to explain repeatedly. "Midway through" means Laozi found the discourse too verbose when only half complete. "Too prolix" means too diffuse. "Delight in all things" means to find joy in things and become one with them. "Shallow words" means superficial remarks. "Alas!" expresses concern. "Things are unequal"—how can one love them universally? This is an impractical and convoluted doctrine. To claim impartiality is to harbor partiality in one’s heart—this "impartiality" itself becomes a preoccupation, revealing an intentional mind. Thus, "to claim impartiality is itself partiality."

"Nurture" means to care for. If you wish to ensure that all under Heaven do not lose their proper care, know that all things between Heaven and Earth have their natural transformations—how can human effort intervene? One should only emulate natural virtue and follow the natural Dao—this is already perfection. Thus, "you have already arrived." "Lost child" refers to a runaway; beating a drum to seek one is to labor and disturb the world—this is to confuse human nature. Thus, Lao Dan spoke deceptively, saying, "Alas!" as if in reproach. "You" is a respectful term, like "my lord." "Laboriously" describes the appearance of exertion.

Shi Chengqi visited Laozi and said, "I have heard that you are a sage, so I did not hesitate to travel a great distance to seek an audience. For a hundred days, with calloused feet, I dared not rest. Now I observe you and find you are not a sage. You have surplus grain in your rat holes yet abandon your younger sister—this is not benevolence."

The feast before him was not fully consumed, yet he hoarded without end. Laozi remained silent, offering no response.

The next day, Shi Chengqi visited again and said, "Yesterday, I reproached you, but now my heart has wholly receded—why is this?" Laozi replied, "The man of cunning knowledge and divine sagacity—I have long since transcended such. Formerly, when you called me an ox, I accepted it as an ox; when you called me a horse, I accepted it as a horse. If one truly possesses the reality, yet refuses the name others give, one invites double misfortune. My conduct is ever thus, not because I deem it right to act so. 'A hundred lodgings, calloused feet without rest'—this describes your toil. *Jun* refers to the thickened skin on the soles of the feet. To discard surplus food in the dark recesses of rat burrows, where light does not reach—*mei* shares the meaning of *mei* (obscurity), and this is to lack care for things, hence deemed unbenevolent. 'The feast before him was not fully consumed, yet he hoarded without end'—this speaks of his boundless accumulation. *Shengshu* refers to raw and cooked foods. What lies before one is not exhausted, yet he still gathers and stores without cease—thus, 'hoarding without end.' Laozi’s silence was his refusal to answer. *Ci* means reproach. *Que* means retreat. Formerly, there was reproach; now, his heart has wholly receded, as if, upon meeting, he suddenly awakened. *Qiaozhi* refers to the learning of divine sagacity through artificial means. *Tuo* means departure—transcending such. Since I am without fixed intent, whether you call me horse or ox, I merely listen. 'If one truly possesses the reality, yet refuses the name others give, one invites double misfortune'—this line is most pure. If I truly possessed such faults, and you reproached me, yet I resisted, this would be a twofold transgression—first the fault, then the denial. *Fu* means conduct. My actions are ever thus, not because I deem them right to act so—this is to act without self-awareness. Thus, 'My conduct is ever thus; I do not act because I deem it right to act.' This is akin to 'not saying stillness is good, yet stillness arises naturally.' The four *fu* characters below are all masterful strokes.

Shi Chengqi walked sideways, avoiding his shadow, treading step by step, gradually advancing, and asked how to cultivate the self. Laozi said, "Your countenance is haughty, your gaze piercing, your forehead prominent, your mouth agape, your demeanor rigid—like a horse tethered yet straining to bolt. In movement, you are restrained; in action, you are mechanical; in scrutiny, you are exacting; in knowledge, you are cunning, yet your bearing is overbearing. All this stems from a lack of sincerity. At the borderlands, such a man would be called a thief." *Yanxing biying* describes his sidling posture. *Lüxing* means stepping cautiously, one foot after the other; *lüxing suijin* depicts his gradual, hesitant advance. *Yairan* suggests an aloof, exceptional bearing. *Chongran* suggests a piercing, fixed stare. *Kanran* describes a gaping mouth. *Yiran* suggests rigidity. A horse’s nature is to run; though tethered, it still strains to bolt—this is the meaning of "sitting in restless motion," a most apt description. *Dong er chi* depicts restraint in movement. *Fa ye ji* refers to the trigger of a crossbow—his judgments are as swift and mechanical. *Cha er shen* means he is overly discerning and precise, lacking any concealment. *Zhi qiao er du yu Tai* means he relies on his cleverness, and his arrogance is plainly visible. These ten traits all arise from insincerity, hence "all stem from a lack of trustworthiness." *Buxin* means insincerity. If one perceived the true principle, these faults would vanish. At the borderlands, such a man would surely be branded a thief—his overactive scheming, his failure to follow the natural Way in life, invites disaster.

The Master said, "The Dao is not exhausted in the great, nor does it neglect the small—thus, the ten thousand things are complete. Vast and boundless, it embraces all; deep and unfathomable, it cannot be measured. Manifest virtue, benevolence, and righteousness are but the remnants of the spirit. Who but the perfected person can rightly discern this?" The Master is Laozi. "Not exhausted in the great" means it has no limit; "not neglecting the small" means it leaves nothing out—this echoes the saying, "In speaking of the great, nothing can contain it; in speaking of the small, nothing can break it." No thing lies beyond the Dao, hence "the ten thousand things are complete." *Guangguanghu* means vastness. *Yuanhu* means depth. When the spirit takes form as virtue, benevolence, and righteousness, these are but its secondary manifestations. *Xing* means manifestation; *shen* means the wondrous function. *Ding* means to discern rightly. Who but the perfected person can distinguish its root from its branches?

"The perfected person possesses the world—is this not grand? Yet it does not burden him. Though the world seizes power, he does not join in its pursuits. He discerns the unreal and does not shift with profit. He exhausts the truth of things and guards their root—thus, he puts heaven and earth aside, leaves the ten thousand things behind, and his spirit is never constrained. In harmony with the Dao, aligned with virtue, he sets aside benevolence and righteousness, treats ritual and music as guests—such is the settled mind of the perfected person." *You shi* means possessing the world. Though he holds the world’s vastness, it does not burden his heart. *Bing* means power. Though the world seizes power, his heart does not follow—this means his mind is unmoved. *Bu wei li qian* means he does not calculate profit and loss. He exhausts the true principle of things, thus guarding their inherent stillness. *Wai tiandi, yi wanwu*—he is unmoved by externals. With his mind unmoved, how can his spirit be constrained? *Tong* means unity. *Daode* means naturalness. *Tui renyi* means treating benevolence and righteousness as secondary, not primary. *Bin liyue* means regarding emotions and nature as primary, with ritual and music as secondary.

Stillness is stability. This is how the mind of the perfected person attains stillness and stability. What the world values in the Dao is the written word. Yet writing is but speech, and speech has its value. What is valued in speech is meaning. Meaning has its source, but what meaning follows cannot be transmitted through words. The world, however, prizes the transmission of words through writing. Though the world values it, it is still not truly worthy of value—for what it values is not what should be valued.

Thus, what can be seen are forms and colors; what can be heard are names and sounds. How lamentable that the world believes forms, colors, names, and sounds suffice to grasp the true nature of things. If forms, colors, names, and sounds indeed cannot grasp that nature, then the wise do not speak, and those who speak are not wise—how could the world recognize this?

Writing can convey the Dao, which is why the world values it. Yet what is truly valued is the Dao, not the writing. When words express the Dao, they become valuable; but what is valuable is the meaning, not the words. *Sui* means direction. Where meaning directs itself, words cannot transmit it—thus neither words nor writing are truly worthy of value. To prize these is to prize what is not truly prized, hence it is said: "what it values is not what should be valued."

*Ming* refers to verbal expressions. Forms and colors can be seen, names and sounds can be heard—but does the Dao have form, color, name, or sound? That the world seeks to grasp its reality through seeing and hearing is truly lamentable. *Qing* means reality. *Guo* means certainty. Since seeing and hearing are certainly insufficient to grasp it, those who know the Dao do not speak, and those who speak do not know it. How could the world’s understanding reach this? This is why it is lamentable.

Duke Huan was reading in the hall while Wheelwright Bian carved a wheel below. Setting down his mallet and chisel, Bian went up and asked, "May I ask what Your Lordship is reading?" The Duke replied, "The words of the sages." Bian asked, "Are the sages still alive?" The Duke said, "They are already dead." Bian said, "Then what you are reading is but the dregs of the ancients."

The Duke said, "I am reading—how dare a wheelwright comment? If you have an explanation, fine; if not, you die." Wheelwright Bian said, "Your servant observes this from his own work. If the carving is too slow, it is smooth but not firm; if too fast, it is rough and does not penetrate. Neither too slow nor too fast—it is grasped by the hand and responds to the heart, yet the mouth cannot express it. There is a measure within, but I cannot explain it to my son, nor can my son receive it from me. That is why I am still carving wheels at seventy. The ancients and what they could not transmit are gone. Then what you are reading is but the dregs of the ancients."

This passage illustrates the earlier point—that the Dao cannot be transmitted through words—with an analogy so precise it is marvelous. *Gan* means smooth. *Ku* means rough. *Xu* means loose. *Ji* means tight. If too loose, it is smooth and easy to enter but not firm; if too tight, it is rough and hard to penetrate. The key is neither too loose nor too tight, for there is a proper measure within—yet it cannot be put into words. Even from father to son, it cannot be transmitted. Writing records the words of the ancients, but if the person is gone, how can what cannot be transmitted be obtained? Feeding on the dregs, how can one know the taste of wine?

If the Dao could be offered to others, none would fail to offer it to their lord; if it could be transmitted, none would fail to pass it to their children—this is the same idea. Generally, what is written in books does not pertain to a single matter. This text repeatedly expounds on the principle of naturalness, unfolding many words, growing ever more extraordinary, yet never departing from its single theme. Read in this way, the unmatched brilliance of Zhuangzi becomes ever clearer. The same holds for those who read Buddhist scriptures.

*End of the Fifteenth Scroll of the Oral Exegesis of the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*
*Beginning of the Sixteenth Scroll of the Oral Exegesis of the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*

The *Yanzhai* commentary by Lin Xi-yi on the "Outer Chapters: Heaven’s Motion":

Does Heaven move in its course? Does Earth abide in its place? Do the sun and moon contend for their positions? Who directs and sustains this? Who governs and orders this? Who, dwelling in non-action, yet propels and enacts this? Is it that some mechanism is at work, compelled by necessity? Or does it revolve ceaselessly, unable to halt itself?

Do clouds give rise to rain, or does rain give rise to clouds? Who causes them to swell and descend? Who, dwelling in non-action, indulges in excess and urges them on? Winds arise from the north, now west, now east, drifting upward in restless motion. Who breathes and draws them forth? Who, dwelling in non-action, yet scatters and stirs them?

These several lines are exquisite in every phrase—five instances of *hu* (乎), unmatched by any before or since. Heaven’s motion completes a circuit each day—is this its own self-motion? Earth has four directions and above and below—how could it remain fixed in place? To speak of the sun’s departure and the moon’s arrival as "contention" is to liken it to men vying for possession—who else could have coined these three words?

"Directing and sustaining" and "governing and ordering" both imply exertion. "A mechanism compelled by necessity" and "revolving ceaselessly, unable to halt itself" suggest that it is not subject to external control. Heaven’s *qi* descends, Earth’s *qi* ascends—thus clouds and rain are formed. But which gives rise to which: do clouds become rain, or does rain become clouds? Such a question is truly extraordinary.

"Swelling and descending" (*longshi*): *long* means to rise, *shi* means to cease. Like the alternation of tension and release, sometimes active, sometimes still—who brings this about? "Excessive indulgence" (*yinle*): *yin* means wantonness, *le* means play or amusement. "Urges" (*quan*) means to assist. Who engages in such unrestrained play and aids in the formation of clouds and rain?

Winds blow from all directions, but here it speaks of arising from the north—this follows the shape of Heaven, which leans toward the north, so winds naturally come from there. Sometimes west, sometimes east, sometimes above, sometimes below. "Restless motion" (*panghuang*) describes their coming and going; that it speaks only of "above" and not "below" is a matter of literary structure. "Scattering and stirring" (*pifu*) means to sway and agitate. One dares to ask: for what reason?

Wu Xian Shao replied: "Come, let me tell you."

The heavens possess the Six Ultimates and Five Constants; when rulers align with them, there is order, but when they defy them, there is calamity. In the affairs of the Nine Luo, governance is perfected and virtue is complete, illuminating the lands below, so that all under heaven revere them—this is called the Supreme Sovereign. The question is posed without naming the interlocutor, yet another shift in stylistic approach.

The Six Ultimates are the six qi; the Five Constants are the five phases. Both six qi and five phases are the principles of nature. The Nine Luo refer to the nine provinces. *Luo* means to gather or converge; *luo* and *luò* are interchangeable in ancient script. "Governance is perfected and virtue is complete" means that when rulers align with these natural principles to govern, the nine provinces achieve success and their virtue is fulfilled, shining upon all under heaven so that the people universally revere them. These are the men above even the Three Sovereigns, hence it is said: this is called the Supreme Sovereign.

The Grand Steward Dang of Shang asked Zhuangzi about benevolence. Zhuangzi replied: "Tigers and wolves—they are benevolent." Dang said: "What do you mean?" Zhuangzi said: "Father and son are affectionate toward one another—how is this not benevolence?" Dang said: "May I ask about perfect benevolence?" Zhuangzi said: "Perfect benevolence has no partiality." The Grand Steward said: "I have heard that without partiality there is no love, and without love there is no filial piety. Can it be said that perfect benevolence is unfilial?" Zhuangzi said: "It is not so. Perfect benevolence is lofty indeed; filial piety is simply insufficient to describe it. This is not a matter of surpassing filial piety, but of falling short of it. Comparing tigers and wolves to benevolence is akin to the idea that even bandits have their own Way. These are all arguments that reject and diminish the Confucian school, yet though their words may be biased, they still possess their own logic. As the saying goes, 'Even fierce tigers do not devour their young'—is this not the benevolence of tigers and wolves? 'Perfect benevolence has no partiality' means that benevolence is rooted in mutual affection, yet one does not recognize the source of that affection—this is called the perfection of benevolence. 'Filial piety is insufficient to describe it' does not mean it is unfilial, but rather that when it comes to perfect benevolence, filial piety need not even be mentioned. At its perfection, it transcends filial piety, surpassing it. As for the Grand Steward’s question, it merely falls short of filial piety. It is like saying, 'If you cannot fully exhaust the seven [virtues], then you fall short of filial piety; but if I can exhaust them, then I have surpassed it.' One who travels south to Ying, facing north yet unable to see Mount Ming—why is this? It is because the distance is too great. Thus it is said: Reverent filial piety is easy; loving filial pity is difficult. Loving filial piety is easy; forgetting one’s parents is difficult. Forgetting one’s parents is easy; making one’s parents forget you is difficult. Making one’s parents forget you is easy; forgetting all under heaven is difficult. Forgetting all under heaven is easy; making all under heaven forget you is difficult. The virtue of Yao and Shun was left behind, yet they did not act for its sake; their beneficence flowed through ten thousand generations, yet all under heaven remained unaware. How could one merely sigh and speak of benevolence and filial piety?

Filial piety, brotherly respect, benevolence, righteousness, loyalty, trustworthiness, integrity, and incorruptibility—these are all self-exhortations that serve to constrain one’s virtue; they are not worthy of praise. Thus it is said: The most noble—state rank is equaled by it. The most wealthy—state wealth is equaled by it. The greatest aspiration—fame is equaled by it. Therefore, the Way does not change.

Dark Mountain lies to the north; traveling south from the north to Ying, one no longer sees the northern mountains—this is because they have receded too far, not because they are out of sight. Such a trivial analogy, yet it serves to illustrate the idea that falling short of filial piety is not the same as surpassing it. Reverent filial piety still leaves traces, while loving filial piety leads to mutual forgetting. Beyond this lie "intent upon one’s parents," "forgetting all under heaven," and "all under heaven intent upon me." Each step must rise above the last—such is the stylistic method of this text. All things with traces are inferior to those without; all things with intent are inferior to those without.

To *leave behind* (遺) is to abandon, to disdain—disdaining even Yao and Shun as insufficient for virtue. Beneficence flowing through ten thousand generations is insufficient for benevolence; how then could one sigh and boast of mere filial piety and benevolence? Such sighs are but self-deception and vainglory.

Filial piety, brotherly respect, benevolence, righteousness, loyalty, trustworthiness, integrity, and incorruptibility—these eight are what the world deems fine virtues, yet in truth, they are but self-exhortations that weary one’s virtue. Thus it is said: "self-exhortations that constrain one’s virtue are not worthy of praise." *To constrain* (役) is to labor; *not worthy of praise* means not worthy of esteem. What need has my utmost nobility for state rank? What need has my utmost wealth for state riches? What need has my greatest aspiration for fame? *To equal* (并) is to cast aside—all are cast aside. Utmost nobility, utmost wealth, and greatest aspiration belong to the Dao of non-action. *State riches* refer to the wealth of the entire state. *Unchanging* means constant, that which is ever thus. The eight are acts of self-constraint through effort, while I remain ever in non-action.

Beigong Cheng asked the Yellow Emperor: "When you performed the *Xianchi* music in the wilds of Dongting, at first I heard it and was afraid; then I heard it again and grew weary; finally, I heard it and was bewildered. Adrift and silent, I could no longer find myself." This passage uses music to craft another striking discourse. First fear, then weariness, then confusion—such were the three transformations I underwent upon hearing this music. *Adrift* (荡荡) means the spirit scattered; *silent* (默默) means the mouth sealed. *Not finding oneself* means not feeling at ease, overwhelmed by the music’s awe.

The Emperor said: "You were nearly right. I performed it with human affairs, harmonized it with Heaven, conducted it with ritual and righteousness, and conveyed it through the Great Purity. The supreme music first responds to human matters, aligns with the principles of Heaven, proceeds through the five virtues, and accords with the natural—only then does it regulate the four seasons and harmonize the myriad things. The four seasons arise in succession, and the myriad things follow their growth. One flourishes, one declines; civil and martial follow their order. One clears, one muddies; yin and yang attain harmony. Its sound flows luminously, and hibernating creatures stir as I startle them with thunder. In the end, it has no tail; in the beginning, no head. One dies, one lives; one collapses, one rises. Its constancy is inexhaustible, yet its unity cannot be awaited. Thus, you were afraid.

You were nearly right—when you heard my music, these three transformations were fitting. *Performed* (奏) means to initiate; *harmonized* (徽) is like the markers on a zither. *Conducted* (行) means to establish and set in motion. *Human affairs* refer to worldly matters; *Heaven* to the principles of Heaven. *Ritual and righteousness* mean the music follows order. *Great Purity* means it aligns with the workings of creation. The initial sounds were thus balanced and just.

From 'the four seasons arise in succession' onward, it speaks of the music’s workings—its transformations startling and wondrous, now playing, now ceasing, yet without revealing its ultimate destination. Generation is civil, decline is martial—they follow their sequence. The four seasons’ growth and decay, the myriad things’ orderly flourishing, their eventual decline—like the music’s civil and martial rhythms. The zither’s civil and martial strings are of this kind, hence 'civil and martial follow their order.' *Flowing light* means the sound flows luminously. Tuning the music’s yin and yang, its clear and muddy tones, it flows thus radiantly, like hibernating creatures roused by thunder.

One cannot see its beginning when approaching, nor its end when following—thus 'in the end, no tail; in the beginning, no head.' Head and tail are but beginning and end. Death and life, collapse and rise—its constancy is inexhaustible, yet its transformations are ceaseless. Seeking its unifying ground, one finds it unattainable—hence 'its unity cannot be awaited.' This is why you were afraid at first.

Then I performed it with the harmony of yin and yang, illuminated it with the brightness of sun and moon. Its sounds could be short or long, soft or hard, transforming uniformly without clinging to old forms. It filled valleys, filled ravines, blocked the senses to guard the spirit, taking things as its measure. Its sounds soared freely, its name lofty and bright—thus ghosts and spirits guarded their depths, while the sun, moon, and stars followed their courses. I halted it at the finite, flowed it into the infinite. You wished to ponder it but could not know it, to gaze upon it but could not see it, to pursue it but could not reach it. Suddenly standing on the path of the fourfold void, leaning against a withered catalpa and chanting, your eyes exhausted in seeking what they desired to see, your strength spent in chasing what you wished to pursue. I had already surpassed you, my form filled with emptiness until it became supple and yielding—thus you grew weary.

The harmony of yin and yang, the light of sun and moon—these too signify harmony and radiance. Long and short, hard and soft—all are transformations, indistinguishable, hence 'transforming uniformly without clinging to old forms.' *Uniform* (齐一) means the same; *old* (故) means former. *Without clinging to old forms* means ever renewing. Filling ravines and valleys means pervading all between Heaven and Earth. *Blocking the senses* (涂却) means sealing one’s clarity—*blocking* (却) is akin to *crevice* (隙), referring to the seven apertures."

Dismiss your cleverness and guard it with spirit, following the myriad things as their measure—this means my music arises not from cunning but from following nature. Its sound unfurls with spacious ease, naturally bearing the name of loftiness. Ghosts and spirits guard their depths, so that no specters haunt nor souls grow weary. Sun, moon, and stars move in their courses, their comings and goings natural. As if halting yet not halting, it is said: "Halting at the finite, flowing without cease." Desires and thoughts know nothing; desires and longings see nothing; desires and pursuits reach nothing—all describe how it seems to have form yet has no form. The four voids are the Great Void.

At such a time, I stand amid the Great Void, leaning on my armrest and chanting. Though I long to see, it cannot be exhausted; though I long to pursue, it cannot be reached. My form, though full, forgets itself, as if empty—thus yielding and at ease. How much more so for you? It is precisely this ease that makes you weary.

*Tangran* describes a state without intent. I then play with tireless sound, tuning it to the command of nature. Thus, it mingles and chases in profusion, like music in the forest yet without form, spreading and waving without drag, dark and dim yet without sound. Moving without direction, dwelling in the profound and obscure—some call it death, some call it life; some call it substance, some call it glory. Flowing, scattering, shifting, it does not adhere to fixed sounds. The world doubts it, so they consult the sage. The sage is one who penetrates reality and fulfills destiny. The celestial mechanism does not unfold, yet the five senses are all complete—this is called celestial music. Without words, the heart rejoices. Thus, the Lord of Yan sang its praise: *"Hearing it, you do not hear its sound; seeing it, you do not see its form. It fills Heaven and Earth, enveloping the six directions."* You wish to hear it yet find no point of contact—hence your confusion.

*Tireless* means unceasing. *The command of nature* is the principle of nature. *"Mingling and chasing in profusion"* describes how the myriad things grow thickly, chasing one another in undifferentiated unity. *Music in the forest* means music so abundant it fills the forest, yet no form is seen. It spreads and waves without force to pull or drag, dark and dim without sound. Changing and moving without fixed direction, its dwelling is in the profound and obscure, beyond exhaustion or fathoming. Neither life nor death, neither glory nor substance. Flowing, scattering, shifting—it does not abide in fixed sounds, that is, it does not cling to old forms. The world, perplexed by this, questions the sage. *Consult* means to inquire. *Penetrating reality* means grasping the true principle. *Fulfilling destiny* means attaining the natural. The five senses are all complete, yet the celestial mechanism does not stir—eyes, ears, hands, and feet are present, yet seeing, hearing, and movement are not self-aware. This is attaining the joy of nature, hence "celestial music." As the *Śūraṅgama Sūtra* says: *"Returning the flow to perfect unity, the six senses do not function"*—this is the meaning of the celestial mechanism not unfolding while the five senses are complete. *Without words, the heart rejoices* means its joy transcends speech. Though you wish to hear it, there is nothing to grasp—hence your confusion.

At this point, another verse is composed, showcasing the artistry of literary elaboration. *"Filling Heaven and Earth, enveloping the six directions"* is the same as *"pervading all between Heaven and Earth."* These four lines carry no separate meaning; their rhythmic turn creates cadence—this is the method of composition.

As for music: at first, there is fear; fear gives rise to haunting. Next comes rest; rest gives rise to escape. Finally, there is confusion; confusion gives rise to foolishness, and foolishness gives rise to the Way. The Way can be borne and journeyed with. Earlier, fear, weariness, and confusion seemed without purpose, but in the conclusion, foolishness leads to entering the Way—this turn is especially artful. For those who seek the Way must pass through such states before making progress.

*Haunting* means eerie clarity. *Weary and escaping* describes the moment of being unable to stop. *Confused and foolish* describes when consciousness vanishes and the six senses cease. These three stages resemble the Chan school’s approach to discussing music. Though divided into three parts, there is no great distinction—merely rhetorical flourish.

When Confucius traveled west to Wei, Yan Yuan asked Shi Jin: *"What of the Master’s conduct?"* Shi Jin replied: *"Alas! Your Master is doomed to hardship."* Yan Yuan asked: *"Why?"* Shi Jin said: *"Before the straw dogs are presented, they are adorned with baskets and mats, wrapped in embroidered cloth, and the invocator fasts to prepare them. Once presented, passersby trample their heads and spines, and gatherers take them to burn. If one were to gather them again, adorn them with baskets and mats, wrap them in embroidered cloth, and wander or rest beneath them, they would not dream—yet surely they would blink in irritation. Now your Master has taken the straw dogs of the former kings, already presented, and wanders with his disciples, resting in their shadow. Thus, he was assaulted while felling a tree in Song, had his borders pared in Wei, and was impoverished in Shang and Zhou—was this not his dream? Besieged between Chen and Cai, seven days without fire or food, death and life as neighbors—was this not his irritation?"*

This passage critiques our sage. Even in Confucius’ time, there were figures like the Old Man with the Staff, Jie Yu of Chu, and the recluses Chang Ju and Jie Ni—all of this kind. *Straw dogs* are dogs made of grass for exorcism, used in sacrifices and then discarded. *Basket* refers to a container; *mat* to a bamboo tray. *Gatherers* collect grass. *Blinking* means dust in the eyes—implying that the learning of the Confucians consists of ancient, outdated words, useless in the present age.

Just as traveling on water is best done by boat, and traveling on land is best done by cart, so too is it with all things. To take a boat’s fitness for water and seek to push it on land is to spend a lifetime going nowhere. How could the difference between past and present be any less than that between water and land? How could the difference between Zhou and Lu be any less than that between boat and cart? Now to insist on practicing Zhou’s ways in Lu is like pushing a boat on land—laborious and fruitless, bringing only misfortune upon oneself. They do not understand the transmission of the boundless Way, which responds to things without exhaustion.

The analogy of rivers and land, boats and carts, speaks to the difference of times. The "transmission of the boundless Way" means not clinging to a single path. Since ancient times, the transmitted Way has always been one that adapts to the times without fixation, thus responding to the world without exhaustion.

Have you alone not seen the well-sweep? Pulled, it descends; released, it rises. What moves it is not the pull of man, yet it bows and lifts without offending anyone. Bowing and lifting, it follows others without attachment—this is the analogy of responding to things without fixed method.

Thus, the rites, righteousness, laws, and measures of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors were not prized for their uniformity but for their efficacy in governance. The rites, righteousness, laws, and measures of the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors may be likened to hawthorns, pears, oranges, and pomelos—their flavors differ, yet all are pleasing to the mouth. Thus, rites, righteousness, laws, and measures are things that change with the times.

Hawthorns, pears, oranges, and pomelos are all prized by people, though their flavors differ—this illustrates the idea that the Three Kings had different rites and the Five Emperors had different music. The hawthorn is a type of fruit, resembling a pear but sour.

Now take a gibbon and dress it in the robes of the Duke of Zhou, and it will surely gnaw and tear at them, casting them off entirely before it is satisfied. To observe the difference between past and present is like seeing the difference between a gibbon and the Duke of Zhou. To force the rites and music of the ancients upon people today is like forcing a gibbon to wear human clothes. It is not merely "human clothes" but "the robes of the Duke of Zhou"—the phrasing is meant to mock the sages, hence the pointed wording. The Duke of Zhou established rites, including the system of caps, crowns, robes, and garments, hence "the robes of the Duke of Zhou."

When Xi Shi suffered from heartache, she knit her brows in her village, and the ugly women of her village, seeing this, thought it beautiful. Returning home, they too clutched their chests and knit their brows. The rich of the village, seeing this, firmly shut their doors and refused to come out, while the poor, seeing it, took their wives and children and fled. They knew the beauty of the knitted brow but did not know why it was beautiful. Alas, how your Master will come to ruin!

"Knit her brows" means to furrow the forehead. For people of today to imitate the ancients is like the village women imitating Xi Shi’s knitted brow. The beauty of the knitted brow can only be spoken of in the presence of Xi Shi herself. The way to practice can only be seen in the presence of the ancients. "Your Master" refers to your Master.

This passage contains six analogies, each one excellent—nothing is more difficult in writing than analogy. Wang Quxuan once said: "All my life, I have wanted to create an analogy of my own, but whenever I think of one, it turns out to be something the ancients have already used." In the *Zhuangzi*, every analogy is extraordinary.

Confucius, at the age of fifty-one, had still not heard the Way, so he went south to Pei to see Lao Dan. Lao Dan said: "Have you come? I have heard of you, a worthy man of the north. Have you attained the Way?" Confucius said: "Not yet." Laozi said: "How have you sought it?" Confucius said: "I sought it in measures and numbers, but after five years I had not attained it." Laozi said: "How else have you sought it?" Confucius said: "I sought it in yin and yang, but after twelve years I had not attained it."
