Ran Xiangshi grasped the center of the ring, following completion—with things, he had no end, no beginning, no moment, no time. One who daily transforms with things is one who does not transform—when did he ever abandon it?

After long travel, returning to one’s old state and capital, there must be a joyful resonance, a stirring of feeling. Even if, within that old state, people and things have changed, the hills overgrown with weeds, nine-tenths lost compared to the past—yet if even a fraction remains familiar, there is still joy. How much more for one seeking the Dao who suddenly awakens, seeing what they have always seen, hearing what they have always heard—all things originally possessed—could they not rejoice? This is what the Buddhists call "original face" and "native scenery."

A ten-*ren* terrace is the highest place. "Hanging" means displaying music; "crowds" means many displays; "amidst" refers to the alternating sounds of *sheng* and *yong* instruments. To stand in so high a place and hear the interwoven music can stir the ears and eyes of the world—how much more for the ancient sages, who with the principle of emptiness, non-action, and nature, delighted in following all things. Their self-abiding was as lofty as the empty center of a ring.

No end, no beginning—end and beginning are as one. No moment, no time—no past, no present. "Moment" refers to the changes of seasons. "Daily transforming with things" means moving with things, ever renewing—yet what I have attained is one unchanging thing, thus put into use. "Abandon" means to leave; "why" is *he*. Why do worldly people not abandon old habits and return to the ultimate Dao?

Ran Xiangshi is an ancient sage. To take Heaven as teacher yet not take Heaven as teacher, to be enslaved with things in their pursuits—how could this be their affair?

The sage never began with Heaven, never began with man, never began with beginning, never began with things. He moves with the world without ceasing, his actions complete yet not stagnant—how could he be said to unite with it?

Tang found his gatekeeper, Yin Deng, and made him his tutor, following the teacher without constraint. Grasping what follows completion, he oversaw its name.

"Taking Heaven as teacher yet not taking Heaven as teacher" means taking nature as model yet having no name for modeling nature—merely following things in accord. Hence "enslaved with things in their pursuits." If there is intent in affairs, then how could it be thus? The slightest intent in affairs is already not natural.

"Man" is having intent; "Heaven" is without intent. Not only are there no traces of action, but even the absence of action is absent—hence "never began with Heaven, never began with man." "Things" are traces; "beginning of no things" is no trace. Not only are there no traces of things, but even the absence of traces is absent—hence "never began with beginning, never began with things."

In traversing this world, one has never not been the same as others, yet in the human realm nothing is ever neglected—hence "moving with the world without ceasing." "Without ceasing" means without neglect. All actions are complete yet none is clung to, hence "what is done is complete yet not sunk." "Equalizing things" speaks of its aged sinking; "sunk" means mired and drowned in attachment. United with the Dao, one does not seek yet naturally accords—if one seeks accord with the Dao, accord cannot be attained, hence "how could it be accorded?"

Tang’s relation to Yi Yin was that he studied under him before making him minister. Zhuangzi, however, alters the names and words, changing his office to "Director of Chariots" and calling him "Gatekeeper Deng Heng"—all such strange and uncanny speech. "Attendant" means assistant, speaking of Yin assisting Tang. Though Tang took Yin as teacher, he was not confined by him, hence "following the teacher without constraint." Tang’s non-action was self-attained from the completed patterns of the myriad things, and he naturally dwelled in the realm of non-action, allowing his assistant to act. Yin, however, took charge of names, hence "attaining what follows completion, overseeing its name." This speaks of Tang’s non-action and Yin’s action, Tang’s namelessness and Yin’s having names. "Oversee" means to take charge, speaking of the Gatekeeper bearing many names of action. These names and models are excessive, revealing both sides. "Zhongni’s exhaustive deliberation" serves as his attendant.

The Master of Rongcheng said: "Remove the days and there is no year; with no inner, there is no outer." This is a name—this name. "Surplus" means excess, remainder. To say this name exists in the world is to speak of surplus patterns, like something superfluous. "Two manifestations" means body and name are divided. If one is intent on making a name, one cannot attain the undifferentiated unity, hence "attaining its two manifestations." What Yi Yin took upon himself was not yet extraordinary, yet Confucius admired him, exhausting his thoughts and deliberations to serve as an assistant in this world—this speaks of the Master wishing to do as Yi Yin had done. This is mockery of the sage’s intent.

The Master of Rongcheng borrows the name of an ancient sage. Combine three days and sixty days to make a year; if you remove the days one by one, you may only call it a day, not a year, hence "remove the days and there is no year." This line is fine in itself—Laozi said, "Count the spokes and there is no cart," which carries the same meaning. The name of the outer arises from the inner; without inner, there is no outer, hence "with no inner, there is no outer." These two lines serve as proof of the natural intent.

When Wei Ying made a pact with Marquis Tian Mou, Marquis Tian Mou betrayed it. Wei Ying grew angry and was about to send an assassin to kill him. Xishou heard of this and found it shameful, saying: "You are a lord of ten thousand chariots, yet you would avenge yourself like a common man? I, Yan, request to receive two hundred thousand armored troops to attack him for you. I will capture his people, seize his cattle and horses, and make his lord’s heart burn within him until his back erupts in sores. Then I will take his state, drive out Ji, and break his spine." Master Ji heard of this and found it shameful, saying: "To build a city wall seventy feet high—once it reaches seventy feet, to tear it down again is the toil of convict laborers. Now, for seven years there has been no war; this is the foundation of your kingship. Yan is a troublemaker; you cannot listen to him."

Master Hua heard of this and found it disgraceful, saying: "One who speaks well of attacking Qi is a troublemaker; one who speaks well of not attacking is also a troublemaker. To say that both attacking and not attacking are the words of troublemakers is yet again the speech of a troublemaker." The lord said: "Then what should be done?" He replied: "My lord, seek only the Dao."

Wei Ying was King Hui of Wei. Tian Hou was King Wei of Qi. *Xumi* were penal laborers conscripted for wall-building. Once a wall is built and then torn down, the laborers find it bitter indeed. For seven years there has been no war—this is the fine achievement of the King of Wei—yet Xishou urges him to deploy troops, like tearing down a wall already built. *Yan* was the given name of Xishou. Master Hua’s words implied that once the word “attack” is uttered, all parties harbor ulterior motives, so he deemed all three positions as those of troublemakers. To know the Dao is to regard war itself as inauspicious. Thus he said: “My lord, seek only the Dao.”

Master Hui heard this and summoned Dai Jinren. Jinren said: “There is a creature called the snail—do you know it?” The king replied: “Yes.” Jinren continued: “On the left horn of the snail dwells the state of Chushi; on the right horn dwells the state of Manshi. From time to time they contend over territory and wage war. Corpses number in the tens of thousands; the pursuit of the routed lasts fifteen days before the victors return.” The king said: “Alas! Is this not an empty tale?” Jinren replied: “Let your servant demonstrate its truth.”

The king pondered: "Do you suppose the four directions and the realms above and below have limits?" The king replied: "They are without limit." Jinren said: "To let the mind wander in the boundless and then return to the lands of communication and passage—do they not seem as if existing, as if not? The king said: "Indeed." Jinren continued: "Within the lands of communication lies Wei; within Wei lies Liang; within Liang lies the king. Is there any distinction between the king and the Manshi?" The king replied: "There is no distinction."

The guest departed, and the king remained in a daze, as if having lost something. When Master Hui entered and saw him, the king said: "This guest is a great man—even a sage cannot compare to him." Master Hui replied: "When one blows into a pipe, there is still a resonant sound; when one blows across the hilt of a sword, there is but a faint whistle. Yao and Shun are praised by all people, yet to speak of Yao and Shun before Dai Jinren is like that faint whistle—utterly insignificant."

Master Hui, having heard of Master Hua’s discourse on seeking the Dao, thus recommended Dai Jinren to the king. Dai Jinren was a man of the Way. The parable of the snail’s horns may seem like an empty tale, yet what follows makes it truly so—hence he said, "Let your servant demonstrate its truth." The boundless refers to the great void. The lands of communication are the Central States. Viewing the Central States from the perspective of the great void, they become exceedingly minute, as if present, as if not—hence the question: "Do they not seem as if existing, as if not?" Du Zimei said: "Gazing down, all is but a single qi—how could one distinguish the imperial domain?" This is the same idea. From the perspective of the Central States, Wei is but small; Liang is its capital, and within Wei, the capital is yet smaller; within the capital, the king’s person is even more minute. From the great void above, descending step by step, the king’s body and the Manshi and Chushi of the snail’s horns are no different—hence the king said, "There is no distinction." This means they are the same.

The king’s dazed state, as if having lost something, reflects his sudden realization that what he once contested was not worth contending. A pipe still has holes; compared to flutes and reeds, though it lacks melody, the one who blows it still produces a resonant sound. But if one blows across a sword’s hilt, there is but a single breath—utterly soundless. This implies that before a man of the Way, even attempts to speak of propriety, righteousness, the Dao, or principle find no place for their voice.

When Confucius traveled to Chu, he lodged at the house of a seller of fermented grain on Ant Mound. A neighbor there—a husband, wife, servant, and concubine—had climbed to the roof’s peak. Zilu said: "What is that bustling crowd doing?" Confucius replied: "They are servants of a sage. They bury themselves among the people, conceal themselves among the fields. Their fame is erased, their aspirations boundless; though their mouths speak, their hearts never truly do. They go against the world, their minds disdaining to align with it. These are the 'land-sunk'—are they not disciples of Shi Nanyilao?" Zilu asked to summon them, but Confucius said: "Enough. He knows I have taken notice of him; he knows I am traveling to Chu. He assumes I will surely persuade the king of Chu to summon him—he would take me for a flatterer. If he feels shame even to hear the words of a flatterer, how much more to meet him in person? What makes you think he remains?" Zilu went to see, but the house was empty.

Ant Mound was a place where a seller of fermented grain lived, and the Master lodged at his home. "Climbing to the roof’s peak" means ascending to the highest point to observe people. *Zongzong* means bustling. "Servants of a sage" refers to the sage’s followers. "Burying themselves among the people" means hiding among the common folk. *Pan* means neighbors—concealing themselves here, even neighbors do not know them. "Their fame is erased" means they flee from renown. *Chen* (sinking) does not refer to water but to land, comparing those who hide in the marketplace’s dust to those submerged. This person must be a disciple of Shi Nanyilao. Nanyilao’s surname was Xiong, and he lived south of the market—a man of Chu.

"Taken notice of him" means he assumes I must know him. A flatterer is one who speaks excessively. "What makes you think he remains?" means he must have departed and not stayed. The house was empty because he fled, fearing the Master would speak of him to the king of Chu and summon him.

Changwu, the border warden, asked Zilao: "In governing, do not be reckless; in ordering the people, do not be careless."

Once, when I farmed grain, I tilled carelessly, and the harvest repaid me in kind; when I weeded recklessly, the yield repaid me likewise. The following year, I changed my methods: I plowed deeply and harrowed thoroughly, and the grain flourished, nourishing me so that I ate my fill all year.

When Zhuangzi heard this, he said: "Most people today, in cultivating their bodies and ordering their minds, resemble what the border warden described—fleeing from their Heaven, departing from their nature, extinguishing their emotions, and losing their spirit, all for the sake of worldly affairs, thus recklessly harming their nature. Desires and aversions sprout like reeds and rushes, first aiding our form, then gradually uprooting our nature. When these fester and erupt without restraint, they manifest as boils, scabies, paralysis, internal heat, and turbid urine. The border warden used farming to illustrate governance; Zhuangzi, in turn, used it to illustrate learning. Su Dongpo’s *On Farming* follows this same analogy.

'Changed my methods' means altering my approach. *Yantie* means to eat one’s fill. 'For the sake of worldly affairs' means such people are common in the world. *E* refers to likes and dislikes. *Nie* means calamity. The harm of likes and dislikes obstructs our inherent nature like dense reeds, akin to the saying 'one’s heart is choked with weeds.' Once nature is obstructed, the growth of base desires spreads like sprouting rushes, filling the body—meaning the entire self becomes consumed by human desires. *Fu* means to assist. When material desires assist our form, sight, hearing, speech, movement, rest, and diet all lose their natural principles. Thus, it is said, 'gradually uprooting our nature.' *Xun* means gradually; *zhuo* means to uproot. At first, true nature is merely obstructed, but as it worsens, it is gradually uprooted, until Heaven’s principles are extinguished. With true nature lost, qi becomes diseased, leading to festering sores, erupting ulcers, and indiscriminate outbursts—any touch may cause illness. 'Festering sores' refer to boils, scabies, and paralysis—diseases of pus and blood. 'Erupting ulcers' refer to internal heat and turbid urine, what we now call wasting disease. This passage warns those who indulge their desires without studying the Dao that they will ultimately destroy themselves.

Boju studied under Lao Dan, saying: "I wish to travel the world." Lao Dan replied: "Enough. The world is everywhere the same." Boju persisted, and Lao Dan asked: "Where will you begin?" He said: "I will begin in Qi." Arriving in Qi, he saw a condemned man. He pushed through the crowd to reach him, removed his court robes to cover him, and wailed to Heaven: "Oh, sir! The world suffers a great calamity, and you alone have encountered it first. Do not steal; do not kill. When honor and disgrace are established, one sees what brings harm; when wealth and property accumulate, one sees what causes strife. Now, you establish what harms people and gather what they contend over, exhausting their bodies without respite. Could one avoid reaching this point?"

'The world is everywhere the same' means the world is universally like this. 'Do not steal; do not kill' implies: "Was your imprisonment due to theft or murder? No, it was not." *Rongru* refers to fame; *huocai* to profit. *Bing* means harm. Those above value fame, and thus such harm arises; those who govern hoard wealth, and thus strife ensues. Laozi said: "Do not exalt the worthy, and the people will not contend; do not prize rare goods, and the people will not steal." This is the same idea. Using fame and profit to enslave people, driving them to endless hardship—how could they not reach this point? His meaning was that in high antiquity, without fame or profit, customs were pure, and states had no criminals.

Ancient rulers regarded success as belonging to the people, failure as their own; uprightness as belonging to the people, crookedness as their own. Thus, if even one person lost their proper form, the ruler would withdraw and take responsibility. Today, it is not so. They conceal matters and deem the unknowing foolish; impose great difficulties and punish those who dare not act; assign heavy burdens and penalize those who cannot bear them; set distant paths and execute those who cannot reach them. When the people exhaust their strength, they resort to deceit. As deception grows daily, how can scholars and commoners not be false?

When strength is insufficient, they feign; when knowledge is lacking, they deceive; when wealth is wanting, they steal. Who is to blame for such thievery? The phrases 'success and failure, uprightness and crookedness' echo: "If the people err, the fault lies with me alone." If even one person fails to live properly, the ruler withdraws and takes responsibility, as if he had cast a commoner into a ditch. But today, it is not so—this refers to later ages. 'Concealing matters' means hiding them and calling the ignorant foolish. 'Imposing great difficulties' means punishing those who dare not act. 'Assigning heavy burdens' means not measuring people’s strength. 'Setting distant paths' means not calculating people’s journeys. They force people to do what they cannot, then punish their failure; they demand what they cannot reach, then execute their shortfall. Those above issue decrees that grow more deceptive by the day—how can scholars and commoners not be false? Forcing what their strength cannot bear, they must respond with deceit; forcing what their knowledge cannot grasp, they must respond with fraud; taking excessively without restraint, they must steal to supply the demand. Thus, we drive them to deceit, fraud, and theft. Who, then, is to blame?

Ju Boyu, at sixty, transformed sixty times, never failing to begin with what he deemed right and end by deeming it wrong. How could what he called right at sixty not have been wrong at fifty-nine?

At sixty, he transformed sixty times—each year’s insight surpassing the last. Yet how can we be certain that what he deemed right at sixty was truly right? This is one point to consider.

All things have life, yet none see their roots; all things emerge, yet none see their gates. People all honor what their knowledge knows, but none know that they must rely on what their knowledge does not know before true knowing arises—can this not be called great doubt? Enough, enough! There is no escaping what is called "so" and "so indeed."

Life must have its roots; emergence must have its gates—only people do not see them. This is what lies beyond knowing. For one to know what they know yet not know what they do not know is the height of subtlety—such is the person of great delusion.

"There is no escaping" means that it is naturally so, so of itself. This unknowing knowing spans past and present, penetrates above and below—all is thus. Where is there a place not governed by this principle? How could one escape it?

"Is it so, indeed?" is a concluding phrase. To call it "so"—is it truly so? When Zigong replied, "So, yet not so," he expressed this very meaning. (See the *Duke Ling of Wei* chapter.) *Ran yu* is read as *yu*.

Confucius questioned the Grand Historian Da Qiang, Bo Changqian, and Xi Wei, saying: "Duke Ling of Wei indulged in wine and revelry, neglecting the governance of his state; he devoted himself to hunting and fowling, ignoring the affairs of the feudal lords. How then did he come to be called 'Ling'?"

Da Tao replied: "It was because of *this* that he was so called."

Bo Changqian said: "Duke Ling had three wives, with whom he bathed in shared licentiousness. When the historian You presented himself in attendance, bearing the ceremonial gifts, the duke had others support and escort him—so extreme was his insolence. Yet when he encountered a worthy man, he would whistle thus in admiration. This is why he was called 'Ling.'"

Xi Wei said: "When Duke Ling died, divination for burial at the ancestral tomb proved inauspicious, while divination at Shaqu was auspicious. Upon digging several *ren* deep, a stone outer coffin was found. After washing it, an inscription was revealed: *'It shall not serve his son.'* Duke Ling seized it and buried it again. That Duke Ling was called 'Ling' had long been so—how could these two men suffice to understand it?"

"Fowling and hunting" refers to the taking of birds and beasts. He ignored all the rites of intercourse between feudal lords. Given such conduct, why was he posthumously titled 'Ling'? The implication is that the title was insufficient to match his wickedness.

Da Tao said: "This was also because the people of the state collectively affirmed it in naming him thus." (The first *shi* character here is synonymous with *ci*, meaning "this.") "Presenting his residence" refers to bringing him to his place of dwelling. "Bearing attendance" is akin to what is now called "summoning for audience." "Grasping the ceremonial silk" means holding the gifts used in formal presentation. Yet Duke Ling had others support and escort him—this was said to be a mark of propriety. *Su* means "reverence."

Before the tomb of sandalwood and stone there were already guests of Duke Ling—thus this name was fixed before his birth, and what power did men have in it? This passage speaks to how all worldly affairs arise from nature.

The two men were Da Tao and Bo Changqian. Sand Hill was an ancient burial site. "Not entrusting to his sons" means his descendants could not be relied upon, so Duke Ling seized it. *Feng* means "to entrust."

Shaozhi asked Taigong Diao: "What is meant by 'the speech of the mound and village'?"

Taigong Diao said: "The mound and village unite ten clans and a hundred names to form customs. They gather differences to make sameness, and scatter sameness to make differences. Now, if you point to the hundred parts of a horse and cannot find the horse, yet the horse stands before you—it is by establishing its hundred parts that you call it a horse. Thus, hills accumulate the low to become high; rivers gather waters to become great; the great person unites all to become public. Therefore, what enters from without has a master but is not grasped; what issues from within has a norm but is not resisted. The four seasons have distinct *qi*, yet Heaven does not bestow them, and so the year is completed. The five offices have distinct duties, yet the ruler does not favor them, and so the state is governed. The virtues of the cultured and martial great person are not bestowed, and so their power is complete. The myriad things have distinct principles, yet the Dao does not favor them, and so it is nameless. Being nameless, it does nothing; doing nothing, yet nothing is left undone. Time has endings and beginnings; the world has changes and transformations. Fortune and misfortune flow naturally—wisdom may encounter what is adverse yet find what is fitting. In pursuing one’s own path, faces differ; where there is rectification, there is also error. Compared to a great marsh, a hundred materials all meet their measure; gazing at a great mountain, trees and stones share the same ground. This is called 'the speech of the mound and village.'"

Gathering wells makes a mound; clustering fruits makes a village—hence "mound and village." Within one village are ten clans and a hundred names; though people and things differ, customs are the same—this is the metaphor of gathering differences to make sameness. "The speech of the mound and village" is the public speech of a village; gathering differences to make sameness means the myriad things share one principle; scattering sameness to make differences means each thing possesses its own principle. Combining a hundred parts to make a horse, no single part bears the name "horse"—this is scattering sameness to make differences. Establishing its hundred parts to call it a horse is gathering differences to make sameness. Accumulating to make a mountain, converging to make water—this is the same idea. Uniting to become public is gathering the differences of the myriad things to make sameness.

"Having a master but not grasping" means what is mastered lies within yet is not held—holding would not be natural. The norm is the principle of the myriad things. What emerges from the heart shares the same principle as the myriad things, thus naturally harmonizing without resistance. Not grasping, not resisting—this is following nature without intent toward sameness or difference.

"Heaven does not bestow" means it does not claim merit, as if saying it does not act for the sake of bestowal. The five offices are ranked, each with its duty—how could the ruler privately weigh them? The great person’s cultured and martial virtues arise in their time: when culture is needed, culture is used; when martial power is needed, it is employed—this is not a matter of bestowal, hence their power is complete. The myriad things each possess their own principle, thus they are called "distinct principles." The great Dao unites them to become public, hence it is said to be "not partial." "Nameless" means it cannot be named.

*Chunchun* means flowing naturally. The arrival of good and ill fortune is ever-changing; what seems adverse may turn out fitting—this is the meaning of the old man by the frontier who gained and lost a horse. *Fu* means adversity, dissatisfaction; *yi* means fitting, satisfaction. If one clings to self-sacrifice, it is like faces—all are different. Where there is rectification, there is rigidity; where there is rigidity, there may be error—hence the saying, "where there is rectification, there is error."

"Compared" means "for example." For instance, in a great marsh, the materials of a hundred things each meet their measure—none too small or large, all can be used. "Same ground" means the same earth. Trees and stones originally share one mountain—what distinction was there at first? This is gathering differences to make sameness.

Shaozhi said: "Then is it sufficient to call this the Dao?"

Taigong Diao said: "No. Now, the count of things is not limited to ten thousand, yet we speak of 'the myriad things'—this is naming them by their great number. Thus, Heaven and Earth are the greatest of forms; yin and yang are the greatest of *qi*; the Dao is their public principle. It is permissible to name and speak of them by their greatness, but once a name exists, how can it be compared? If one were to argue thus, it would be like comparing dogs and horses—they fall far short. Things are not limited to ten thousand, yet we speak of 'the myriad things'—this is their total number. *Qi* means 'to approximate,' to speak concisely. Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, are but general names for forms and *qi*. Forms and *qi* are not limited to Heaven and Earth, yin and yang—we speak of them by their greatness. The Dao as public principle is also spoken of by its greatness. Though the name 'Dao' already exists, how can it be compared or explained thus? Hence it is said, 'once a name exists, how can it be compared?' Dogs and horses cannot be classed together. *Si* means 'to compare.' If one were to use the name 'Dao' to make comparisons and arguments, it would be like trying to unite dogs and horses—utterly unequal. *Bu ji* means 'not comparable'; *yuan* means 'far off.'"

Shaozhi said: "Within the four directions, encompassing the six conjunctions, whence do the myriad things arise?"

Taigong Diao said: "Yin and yang illuminate and cover, regulate and order each other; the four seasons succeed, give birth to, and destroy each other. Desires and aversions, departures and approaches arise in this way; male and female, paired and joined, are ever thus."

Safety and danger alternate, fortune and misfortune give rise to one another; urgency and leisure rub against each other, gathering and scattering thus take form. These are the names and realities that may be recorded, the subtleties that may be inscribed. Following the sequence of their inherent patterns, rising and operating in mutual employment—when exhausted, they return; when ended, they begin anew. These are the inherent properties of things, the limits of speech, the extent of knowledge—nothing more than the exhaustion of things.

Those who perceive the Dao do not follow what has decayed, nor trace what has arisen—this is where discussion halts.

From whence do the myriad things begin? Hence it is said, "whence do they arise?"

*Xiang zhao* means "to respond"; *xiang gai* means "to converge"; *xiang zhi* means "to wax and wane." The four seasons succeed one another—spring gives life, autumn destroys—each following its time without deviation. From this arise desires and aversions, departures and approaches, the pairing and separation of male and female, safety and danger, fortune and misfortune, urgency and leisure, gathering and scattering. This is to say: only after the existence of Heaven and Earth, yin and yang, do the affairs of the human world arise. All these instances are differences within sameness.

*Qiao* means "to rise prominently." *Pian* means "to divide." *Pian he* thus means "division and union." *Yong you* means "constantly present." *Yi cheng* conveys the sense of mutual completion, merely altering a single word for stylistic effect.

From desires and aversions down to gathering and scattering, their names and realities may all be recorded, their subtleties all inscribed—each clearly visible, not only expressible in speech but also recordable in writing. Following the sequence of their times, they order one another, just as yin and yang regulate each other. *Qiao* means "to rise"; rising and operating, they mutually employ one another in waxing and waning. When exhausted, they return to openness; when ended, they begin anew. These are the necessary properties of all things. Speech, when taken to its limit, reaches only this; knowledge, when pursued to its utmost, reaches only this. Exhausting heart and effort, one speaks only of "things"—hence it is said, "nothing more than the exhaustion of things."

Only those who understand the Dao regard what decays and what arises as all returning to nothingness, all returning to spontaneity. Thus their discourse halts at this point—here, there is nothing left to say.

Shaozhi said: "Jizhen’s doctrine of *wu wei* (‘non-action’) and Jiezi’s doctrine of *huo shi* (‘contingent agency’)—which of these two theories accords with reality, and which is partial in its reasoning?"

Taigong Diao said: "The crowing of roosters and the barking of dogs—these are what people know. Yet even one of great wisdom cannot articulate in words the transformations they undergo, nor can anyone fathom in thought what they will do next. If one dissects this principle, its subtlety reaches the unparalleled, its vastness the immeasurable.

The doctrine of *huo shi* (‘contingent agency’) and *wu wei* (‘non-action’) remain entangled with things and ultimately incur error. Jizhen and Jiezi were two contemporaries, each advancing their own theories—one advocating *wu wei* (‘non-action’), the other *huo shi* (‘contingent agency’). *Wu wei* holds that in the unseen depths, there is no governing agency, all is mere coincidence; *huo shi* holds that there is a governing agency, and nothing occurs without its agency—what moves is made to move, what halts is made to halt.

*Accords with reality* means it aligns with the truth; *partial in reasoning* means it grasps only one side. Which of these two is correct, and which is mistaken?

The crowing of roosters and the barking of dogs serve as metaphors for differences. Since human knowledge already varies, even one of great wisdom cannot exhaustively articulate it in words, nor can they fully comprehend it in thought. *What undergoes self-transformation*—this refers to the marvels they themselves perceive. *Du* means "to recite." How can one recite their words and thereby know the marvels they perceive? *What they will do*—what they intend to do. How can one fathom in thought what they intend?

*Si* refers to this principle. If one analyzes this principle, one may speak of it in terms of greatness or smallness—its scope is inexhaustible. *Wu lun* ("without peer") is the extreme of smallness; *bu ke wei* ("unfathomable") is the extreme of vastness. Both doctrines remain entangled with things and ultimately incur error—each has its flaws.

*Huo shi* is substantive; *wu wei* is insubstantial. That which has name and reality resides within things; that which has no name and no reality dwells in the emptiness of things. What can be spoken or conceived only drifts further from the truth.

*Huo shi* is substantive—it posits that in the unseen depths, there is something that governs, which is real. *Wu wei* is insubstantial—it posits that in the unseen depths, there is fundamentally no governing agency, which is empty. If there is reality, then names accompany it—this is to be entangled with things. *Ju* means "to reside"; it means to be within things—hence it is said, "this resides within things." If one speaks of nothingness, then names and realities are both absent, yet what is called "nothing" still exists and cannot be equated with the absence of absence—this too is entanglement with things. Hence it is said, "it dwells in the emptiness of things."

In general, whether one speaks of being or non-being, both can be conveyed in words and conceived in thought—yet both remain bound to language, and thus drift ever further from the Dao.

What has not yet been born cannot be prevented; what has already died cannot be obstructed. Death and life are not distant—their principle cannot be seen. *Ji* means "to forbid." At the inception of what has not yet been born, one cannot prevent its birth; once born, death cannot be defied or obstructed. The principle of life and death is right before us, not at all distant—yet one wishes to see it and cannot. Hence it is said, "their principle cannot be seen."

The doctrines of *huo shi* and *wu wei* are crutches for doubt. Observing their root, their going is without end; seeking their end, their coming is without limit. Without end and without limit—speech reaches nothingness, sharing the same principle as things. If one holds to *huo shi* or *wu wei*, then the doubts of the world arise from these assumptions—how can one be free from entanglement?

*Ben* means "beginning," the time before movement. Observing from the time before movement, one already sees that what goes is without end.

The *mo* means "end," the time when movement ceases after having begun. Observing from the time when movement has ceased, one already sees that what is coming has no end. Viewed thus, only by dissolving into wordlessness can one merge with the myriad things and await the one principle—hence it is said, "speech reaches nothingness, sharing the same principle as things."

*Huoshi* and *wuwei* are the root of speech, accompanying things from beginning to end. The Dao cannot be possessed; what is possessed cannot be without. The name "Dao" is but a borrowed term for its circulation. *Huoshi* and *wuwei* are but partial aspects of things—how could they encompass the great Dao? When these two doctrines are traced to their source, whether one calls it *huoshi* or *wuwei*, they have not yet departed from things, merely seen to accompany them from beginning to end—hence it is said, "accompanying things from beginning to end." If one cannot depart from things, then this is possession—how can one claim the Dao is possessed? Thus it is said, "the Dao cannot be possessed." Yet once it is called possession, how can what is possessed be made to cease? It cannot be separated—hence it is said, "what is possessed cannot be without." Viewed in truth, the term "Dao" is but a borrowed name for its circulation in the world—thus it is said, "the name 'Dao' is but a borrowed term for its circulation." These two doctrines remain mired in things and confined to one side—how can they be called the great Dao? *Yiqu* means "one-sided"; *dafang* means "the great Dao."

Having concluded the above, two further lines are wondrously spoken: If speech suffices, then speaking all day exhausts the Dao; if speech does not suffice, then speaking all day exhausts only things. At the extremity of Dao and things, neither speech nor silence can contain them. Beyond speech and silence, discussion reaches its limit. This saying is the same: if I truly have insight, then calling it speech may fully express the Dao, and speaking all day does no harm—hence it is said, "if speech suffices, speaking all day exhausts the Dao." If I have no insight, then speech does not suffice to express the Dao, and no matter how much one speaks, it remains confined to mere appearances—hence it is said, "if speech does not suffice, speaking all day exhausts only things." The Dao is essence; things are coarse. Seeking at the extremity of essence and coarseness, neither speech nor silence suffices to exhaust them. *Zai* means "to be present," implying they are not contained therein. Within the realm beyond speech and silence, there exists the ultimate discussion. *Jiyi* means "ultimate speech." This is akin to the Buddhist saying: "As I press my finger, the ocean seal emits light; as you raise your mind, the dusts of labor arise first." It is also said, "I am the Dharma King, autonomous in the Dharma"—for one who has realized the Dao, speaking is right, and not speaking is also right; but for one who has not realized the Dao, even if you speak correctly, it is not.

How does this chapter differ from the Inner Chapters? *Nanhua Zhenjing Kouyi*, Scroll Twenty-Six concludes. *Nanhua Zhenjing Kouyi*, Scroll Twenty-Seven, by Yuanzhai Lin XiYi.

**Miscellaneous Chapters: External Things**

External things cannot be relied upon, thus Longfeng was executed, Bigan slain, Jizi feigned madness, Elai died, and Jie and Zhou perished. No ruler fails to desire loyalty from his ministers, yet loyalty does not necessarily earn trust—hence Wu Yun was cast into the river, and Chang Hong died in Shu, his blood stored for three years before transforming into jade. No parent fails to desire filial piety from their children, yet filial piety does not necessarily bring love—thus Xiaoji grieved and Zeng Shen mourned.

External things are matters beyond the self, for they are sought in what lies within. In the time of Jie and Zhou, the worthy and the unworthy alike suffered calamity—this is their unreliability. These are all events of Zhou’s reign, yet Jie is mentioned alongside him; one may infer the meaning. Chang Hong was exiled and returned to Shu, where he disemboweled himself in death. The people of Shu placed his blood in a casket, and after three years, it turned into jade. This account differs slightly from that in the *Zuozhuan*, and its details seem fantastical. When Emperor Yuan of Jin blamed his minister for delayed grain shipments and executed him, the blood spurted upward against a pillar. In Qi, due to the prophecy of the "Bright Moon," Hulü Guang was killed, and his blood on the ground could not be wiped away—such things do occur in the world.

Xiaoji was the son of Gaozong of Yin, driven away by his stepmother. As for Zengzi, no record of his weeping is found; perhaps it refers to his fleeing when his father wielded a large staff. Those who read this book should grasp its intent—matters like these need not be rigidly scrutinized. Loyalty and filial piety are virtues men prize, yet they may bring harm to the self: all are external things that cannot be relied upon.

When wood rubs against wood, fire ignites; when metal is held to fire, it melts. When yin and yang clash, heaven and earth convulse. Thus, thunder and lightning arise, and fire burns within water, even consuming the great locust tree. Wood naturally produces fire when rubbed—today’s boatmen use elm and willow in the same way. Metal, though hardest, flows when exposed to fire. This too speaks to the unreliability of things.

"Great convulsion" means great disorder. During violent thunderstorms, trees may burn—hence "fire within water" that scorches the great locust. It does not speak of other trees but the locust, for the locust can generate fire, as the *Huainanzi* says: "Old locust trees produce fire" (*Fanlun* chapter). Yet it is not only the great locust that burns—all such phenomena arise from yin and yang clashing. Unusual disasters, too, illustrate their unreliability.

In extreme distress, one is trapped on both sides with no escape. *Chen* and *dun* evoke unease and restlessness; unable to find resolution, the heart hangs suspended between heaven and earth. Oppression and stagnation, *weimin* and *chentun*, intertwine; profit and harm grind against each other, generating intense fire. The multitude burns their harmony, and the moon cannot withstand the flames. Thus, one collapses, and the Dao is exhausted.

"Extreme distress" means utmost suffering. "Trapped on both sides" refers to either human or natural calamities—*Ren Jian Shi* speaks of these two, and this is the same idea. *Chen* and *dun* describe fear and disquiet. "Unable to find resolution" means that in extreme distress, with no escape, one’s emotions remain unsettled. "The heart hangs suspended between heaven and earth" speaks of the mind bound and tormenting itself. *Weimin* is gloom; *chentun* is sinking into peril. When profit and harm war within the breast, the inner heat surpasses scorching fire—hence "generating intense fire." These are all worldly people who do not understand the Dao, unaware that external things cannot be relied upon, and thus overtax their minds, burning the harmonious qi within their breasts. Hence, "the multitude burns their harmony." The moon represents one’s nature. In life, people receive from heaven this principle of perfect harmony, like the moon, but when obscured by worldly desires, their flames blaze like fire, and the moon cannot prevail, leading to the burning of harmony. As Shan Gu says, "The original mind is like the sun and moon; profit and desire eclipse it"—this is precisely the meaning. "Collapsing" describes a state of utter release. "The Dao is exhausted" means the heavenly principle is extinguished. For the multitude, drowned in profit and desire, lives without awakening, until the heavenly principle is utterly destroyed.

When Zhuangzi was poor, he went to borrow grain from the Marquis of the River. The marquis said, "Very well. I will soon receive tax revenue from my fief; I will lend you three hundred gold pieces—will that suffice?" Zhuang Zhou flushed with anger and said, "Yesterday, on my way here, I heard someone calling out. I turned to look and saw a crucian carp in the rut of a cart wheel. I asked it, 'Crucian carp, what are you doing here?' It replied, 'I am a wave-minister of the Eastern Sea. Might you have a pint or quart of water to save me?' I said, 'Very well. I am about to travel south to persuade the kings of Wu and Yue, and I will divert the waters of the West River to welcome you—will that do?' The crucian carp flushed with anger and said, 'I have lost my usual element and have nowhere to go. I could be saved with a pint or quart of water, yet you speak like this—you might as well seek me in the dried-fish market!'"

The Marquis of the River, according to the *Shuo Yuan*, was Duke Wen of Wei—though this is not necessarily true. He may have been an official overseeing the river, addressed as "Marquis," or "Marquis" may have been his surname. "Tax revenue from my fief" refers to the tribute from his domain. "Wave-minister" is akin to "water official." This passage likely records a jest from the time, illustrating the modern saying, "Distant water cannot quench a nearby fire." The "dried-fish market" means that by the time the water arrives, the fish will already be dried. "Usual element" refers to what one habitually relies upon.

Task Public Master fashioned a great hook with a massive black rope, baiting it with fifty bullocks. He crouched upon Mount Kuaiji, cast his line into the Eastern Sea, and fished day after day—yet after a full year, he caught nothing. Then, a colossal fish took the bait, dragging the enormous hook and heavy tackle downward. It surged and thrashed, its dorsal fins breaking the surface, white waves towering like mountains, the sea churning violently. The sound shook heaven and earth, terrifying even spirits, its thunderous roar striking fear for a thousand *li* around.

When Task Public Master landed the fish, he butchered and dried it. From the lands east of the Zhi River to the north of Cangwu, none went unsatisfied by its flesh. Yet afterward, those of mediocre talent and street-corner orators all marveled and spread the tale. For those who wield a slender pole with a flimsy line, who chase minnows in shallow streams and guard the tiniest of fish—how could they ever hope to land a great catch? Those who polish trivial words to curry favor with proclamations are as far from true enlightenment as the heavens from the earth.

Thus, those who have never heard of the Task clan’s way are all the more unfit to govern the world. The "massive black rope" was a thick, dark cord. "Bullocks" refers to cattle. The character *xiè* (䱇) is interchangeable with *xiàn* (陷). "The sea churned violently, its sound shaking spirits" describes how the fish’s thrashing stirred the waters, its roar terrifying to behold. "Striking fear" means that even those a thousand *li* away heard its sound and trembled. "Satisfied" means they feasted upon its flesh to their fill. "Mediocre talent" refers to those of shallow judgment and limited vision. "Street-corner orators" are those who repeat hearsay. Knowing only the ordinary and blind to the extraordinary, seeing only the small and missing the great—no wonder they marveled and spread the tale.

A "flimsy line" is a thin cord. "Chase" means to pour. "Shallow streams" refers to minor waterways. "Minnows" are small fish. "Proclamations" are like today’s posted notices—*xiàn* (县) is interchangeable with *xuán* (悬), meaning the displayed decrees or rewards. This describes how petty men adorn their words to ingratiate themselves with authority, seeking to match the standards set forth. Even if they succeed, what is truly gained? Thus, it is said they are far from great attainment.

The vulgar of the world cannot be spoken to of the Way of governing—hence, "the vulgar are all the more unfit to govern the world." "Far" here means "greatly so."

The Confucians who rob graves with *Odes* and *Rites*:
The great Confucian proclaimed in relay: "The east is stirring—how goes the affair?"
The lesser Confucian replied: "The skirt and jacket are not yet undone, but there is a pearl in the mouth."
The *Odes* indeed say:
*"The green, green wheat grows on the hillside mound.
Living, he gave nothing; why hold a pearl in death?"*
Grasping the temples, pressing the chin,
The Confucian used a metal pick to pry open the jaw, gently parting the cheeks—lest the pearl in the mouth be harmed.

This passage likely satirizes those who use the words of the *Odes*, *Rites*, and sages to cloak their deceit. Speech from superior to inferior is called *lú*; from inferior to superior, *jù*. "Proclaimed in relay" means the great Confucian took the lead in instructing his followers. *"The green, green wheat grows on the hillside mound"* describes the grave’s field. *"Living, he gave nothing; why hold a pearl in death?"* mocks the wealthy. This poem consists of only four lines—whether it is an ancient verse or composed by Zhuangzi himself is unknown.

The lines from *"Grasping the temples"* onward are the great Confucian’s instructions to the lesser. "Grasping" means to seize. "Pressing" means to hold down with the hand. "Chin" refers to the area beneath the jaw. "Prying open the jaw" means to force it apart. "Parting" also means to open. The verse says, *"Why hold a pearl in death?"*—so now they take it. This aligns with the meaning of the ancient poem.

When Master Lao Lai’s disciple went out to gather firewood, he encountered Confucius. Returning, he reported: “There is someone over there—tall above, yet hastening below, his back slightly stooped yet his ears set back. His gaze seems fixed on the Four Seas, yet I know not whose son he may be.”

Master Lao Lai said: “That is Qiu.”

He summoned him to come.

When Confucius arrived, Master Lao Lai said: “Qiu, cast off your bodily pride and your cultivated wisdom—only then may you become a true gentleman.”

Confucius bowed and withdrew, his expression altered as he asked: “May my practice still advance?”

Master Lao Lai replied: “To recoil from the sorrow of one age yet startle at the calamities of ten thousand generations—is this not stubborn poverty of spirit, or perhaps a failure of foresight? To take delight in recklessness as kindness brings lifelong disgrace. The conduct of the common people advances thus: drawing one another by fame, binding one another by concealment. Rather than praise Yao and condemn Jie, it were better to forget both and seal away all praise. To turn back is never without harm; to act is never without deviation. The sage hesitates to initiate affairs, yet thereby achieves success in every endeavor. Why then should you persist in bearing this pride to the end?”

"Went out to gather firewood" means he went forth to collect kindling. "Tall above" describes his upper body as long. "Hastening below" refers to his gait, which was swift and resonant. "Slightly" means faintly, indicating his back bore a subtle curvature. "Ears set back" means that when viewed from the front, his ears were not visible. "Gaze fixed on the Four Seas" conveys the sense of gazing anxiously upon the world’s ills. "Bodily pride" refers to the self-importance of one’s bearing. "Cultivated wisdom": "cultivated" means external adornment, while "wisdom" refers to thought and deliberation. "May my practice still advance?" asks whether the Way and its cultivation may still be pursued. "The sorrow of one age" refers to the pitiable suffering of the people of the time.

"Haughty" conveys the meaning of arrogance without concern. It means that while you fret over the affairs of a single era, you apply your mind universally yet remain haughtily indifferent to the calamities you bequeath to later generations. Given this, the exhaustion of the Way is only fitting. "Destitute" means impoverished; "fitting" means proper. Your Way has reached such an impasse because you fail to recognize that worldly affairs transcend the reach of mere strategy—hence the saying, "Have you forgotten the schemes that fall short?" "Forgotten" is synonymous with "lost." "Benevolence" means bestowing kindness upon others; "delight" means seeking the joy of others. To regard the pursuit of others' delight through benevolence as haughtiness, and to be startled by the world’s disapproval of such conduct, is a lifelong disgrace. This is precisely what mediocre people strive for—hence the saying, "the conduct of the common folk advances thus." "Common folk" refers to the mediocre. They vie for reputation, conceal their schemes, and form alliances—such is the way of the mediocre. When Yao and Jie are both forgotten, there is neither blame nor praise—hence the saying, "close off what you praise." "Reverse" means to turn one’s back. To turn one’s back on the natural principle is to engage in nothing but actions that harm the Way. To favor movement over stillness is to indulge in nothing but perverse conduct. The sage does not act thus.

"Hesitant" describes the state of wanting to advance yet holding back. To initiate action with hesitation is to act only when compelled. Precisely because he is without intent, he succeeds time and again. "Burdened" means self-importance. Why do you persist in carrying yourself with such haughty pride? Hence the saying, "How can you remain so burdened by self-importance?" This line is remarkably incisive.

Duke Yuan of Song dreamed in the dead of night of a man with disheveled hair peering through the side gate, who said: "I come from the abyss of Zailu. I was sent by the spirit of the Qing River as an emissary to the River Lord, when the fisherman Yu Qiu caught me." The duke awoke and had the dream interpreted. The diviner said, "This is a divine turtle." The duke asked, "Is there a fisherman named Yu Qiu?" His attendants replied, "There is." The duke said, "Summon Yu Qiu to court." The next day, Yu Qiu appeared at court. The duke asked, "What did you catch while fishing?" Yu Qiu replied, "I caught a white turtle in my net, five feet in circumference." The duke said, "Present your turtle." When the turtle arrived, the duke wavered between killing it and sparing it. Unsure, he consulted the oracle, saying, "Killing the turtle for divination will bring good fortune." He then disemboweled the turtle, drilling seventy-two holes without a single miscast.

Confucius said: "The divine turtle could appear in Duke Yuan’s dream yet could not escape Yu Qiu’s net. Though it knew how to drill seventy-two holes without error, it could not avoid the disaster of being disemboweled. Thus, knowledge has its limits, and divinity has its shortcomings. Even the wisest cannot prevail against the schemes of ten thousand men. Fish do not fear nets but fear pelicans. Discard petty wisdom, and great wisdom becomes clear; abandon the pursuit of goodness, and goodness naturally follows. Infants learn to speak without a great teacher simply by being among those who can speak."

"Side gate" refers to a curved gate. "Zailu" is the name of an abyss. "I was sent by the spirit of the Qing River as an emissary to the River Lord." "Wavering between killing and sparing" describes his repeated hesitation. He consulted the oracle, which deemed killing auspicious, so he killed it. "Seventy-two holes" signifies that even if one were to employ seventy-two stratagems in divination, how could they rival the turtle’s wisdom? This illustrates that if I act with intent, others will respond in kind. Only by relinquishing petty wisdom and entrusting oneself to nature can great wisdom become clear. Abandon the desire to be known for goodness, and goodness will naturally return to you—hence the saying, "Abandon goodness, and goodness follows."

"Stone" is synonymous with "great." A "stone teacher" is a great teacher, one capable of instructing others. Infants learn to speak not by seeking a teacher but by being among those who can speak. The turtle’s wisdom surpasses that of humans, yet it could not save itself—hence the saying, "Knowledge has its limits, and divinity has its shortcomings." This implies that knowledge, when named, has its bounds. The following lines broadly illustrate worldly affairs to substantiate this point.

Even the wisest cannot single-handedly overcome the schemes of ten thousand men. Pelicans catch fish by draining the water and then consuming them all—this is a deliberate harm far worse than a net. The above speaks of how others may act with intent to harm a single individual. Great wisdom and natural goodness are principles of nature. The analogy of learning to speak without instruction is also natural.

Hui Shi said to Zhuangzi, "Your words are useless." Zhuangzi replied, "Only when one understands uselessness can we discuss usefulness. The earth is neither narrow nor small, yet what people use is merely enough to stand upon. If one were to dig beside one’s feet until reaching the Yellow Springs, would the ground still be of use?" Hui Shi said, "It would be useless." Zhuangzi said, "Then the usefulness of uselessness is also clear."

"Digging" means excavation. Beyond the space for one’s feet lies an abyss, rendering it impassable—this echoes the earlier idea of treading only where one does not step. Hence the saying, "the usefulness of uselessness."

From the *Xu Wugui* chapter:
Zhuangzi said: "If a man has the ability to wander freely, can he choose not to? If he lacks the ability, can he wander at all? Those with drifting ambitions and resolute actions—alas, are they not unfit for the tasks of utmost wisdom and profound virtue? Falling and unable to recover, rushing forward without looking back—though they may serve as ruler and minister for a time, when the age changes, they will have no means to belittle one another. Thus, the perfected person does not linger in their conduct."

Those who revere antiquity and disparage the present belong to the ranks of scholars. Yet if we observe the present age through the lens of the age of Xiwei, who could avoid being swept along by the current? Only the perfected person can wander through the world without deviation, following others without losing themselves. They teach without instruction, and their intentions are understood without being imposed.

Those who can wander do so; those who cannot will forever remain unable. This speaks of the world’s having those who attain understanding and those who do not. To wander is to delight in oneself. To drift and flee is to pursue things and forget to return. To cut oneself off is to stand apart from the world in stark distinction. *Task* means *to act*. Those of utmost wisdom and profound virtue, who follow nature, act without the faults of drifting or cutting themselves off. To fall and sink is to be mired in worldly entanglements. To rush like fire is to be swept along by the world’s urgency. All these are bound by worldly burdens and cannot turn back to reflect on themselves—hence the saying, “unable to turn back or look,” meaning they cannot reverse their gaze inward. Though for a time there may be noble and base, ruler and minister, after death what becomes of noble and base? Thus it is said, “Who could avoid being swept along?” Scholars’ view of antiquity and the present begins only with the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors. This is a veiled criticism of those ancient rulers. *Deviant* means *partial*. To wander through the world without bias is not to judge right and wrong by antiquity or the present. Though one may blend with the dust and not clash with the world, what one preserves remains intact—hence the saying, “following others without losing oneself.” They teach what they deem correct, but I do not study it; yet I comply with their intent without division between self and other. This speaks of kings and ants alike, all reduced to mounds of earth. Only the perfected person’s conduct leaves no lingering attachment in the world—hence the saying, “the perfected person does not linger in their conduct.” Human nature in antiquity and today is largely the same; where is the difference between simplicity and decadence? Scholars revere antiquity and disparage the present because they do not understand the changes of the world. Xiwei was before the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors. If we view the present through the lens of the world’s beginning or high antiquity, all appear as those swept along by currents, having lost their nature. This aligns with the idea of equalizing things and following what is so—hence the saying, “their intentions are understood without being imposed.”

Eyes that penetrate are called *bright*; ears that penetrate are called *keen*; the nose that penetrates is called *acute*; the mouth that penetrates is called *sweet*; the mind that penetrates is called *wise*; wisdom that penetrates is called *virtue*. The Dao does not desire obstruction; obstruction leads to choking, and if choking persists without cease, it treads a path that gives rise to manifold harms. All sentient beings depend on breath for awareness; if it is not ample, the fault does not lie with heaven. Heaven pierces it day and night without cessation, yet people deliberately block its openings. *Penetrate* means *to flow freely*—when one attains the principle of nature and achieves great penetration, what the eyes and ears perceive is true keenness and brightness; what the nose and mouth smell and taste is true acuity and sweetness; what the mind knows is true wisdom, and virtue is the highest virtue. *Obstruction* means blockage and impediment. *Choking* means constriction and lack of flow. *Treads a path* refers to the marks left by footsteps. If my understanding of the Dao is obstructed and choked, unable to awaken, it becomes bound by traces. *Without cease* means delusion without knowing when to stop. Once bound by traces, manifold harms arise. *Breath* means *life*. Life is called *nature*; all possess it, and only with this nature of being born do they have awareness. This awareness depends on breath. All people are thus, yet some act contrary to principle—how could heaven have failed to grant them ample breath? The principle of heaven in the human mind manifests its apertures day and night without end—hence the saying, “Heaven pierces it day and night without cessation.” *Pierces* refers to the apertures of the mind. *Without cessation* means without stop. *Openings* also refer to the apertures of the mind. People, deluded by material desires, block these openings themselves.

The womb has layered membranes; the mind has the wandering of heaven. If a room lacks emptiness, mother and daughter-in-law quarrel; if the mind lacks the wandering of heaven, the six senses vie with one another. The great forests and mountains are good for people, yet even the spirit cannot overcome them. Virtue overflows into fame; fame overflows into haste. Plans rely on recognition; wisdom arises from contention. Firewood is born from guarding; official affairs are settled by accommodating the many. When spring rains come in season, grasses and trees flourish. Hoeing and weeding begin then, and more than half of the planted grasses and trees perish without knowing why. The *womb* is the bladder membrane. Within the body’s flesh lies a layered membrane enclosing it. *Layered membranes* means *spaciousness*. Within the body’s spaciousness, if the mind rules with heavenly principle and delights in itself, it is called *the wandering of heaven*. *Quarrel* means *conflict*. In a cramped house, mother and daughter-in-law are always face-to-face, easily leading to conflict—this is the metaphor for lack of emptiness. When the mind is obstructed and does not know the joy of heavenly principle, the six senses inevitably clash and rebel. The *six senses* are the six roots. Great forests and mountains are pleasing to people because their ears and eyes are habitually narrow, unable to preserve the spirit of nature to overcome external things. Suddenly seeing vast and open land, they rejoice—hence the saying, “even the spirit cannot overcome them.” Seeking fame externally causes virtue to overflow; haste and restlessness cause fame to overflow. Plans depend on recognition; wisdom emerges from contention. Firewood is born from guarding; official affairs are resolved by accommodating the many.

The words coincide with the loss of name. Only with a sense of urgency does one then deliberate on matters of strategy and planning. *Yi* (discussion) is akin to *xian* (tension). Only with a competitive heart do strategies and plans arise. Clinging rigidly without transformation gives rise to the obstinate and joyless. *Guo* means "fruit," "obstruction," or "fullness"; in *Qi Wu* (Equalizing Things), the belly is likened to the fullness of *guo*.

Seeking to make all affairs fitting before assigning tasks leads to the flaw of inevitable obstruction. This speaks of the fool who settles official matters—official matters cannot be settled thus. *Diao nou* are farming tools. When spring rains arrive, grasses and trees sprout vigorously—hence "anger of growth." At this time, if one prepares farming tools for plowing and planting, one must hoe and uproot the grasses and trees. Those grasses and trees, having just taken root with the rain, will be toppled more than halfway. *Dao* is the same as *dǎo* (to fall). As Du Fu said, "Frost topples half the pond’s lotuses"—this is the same *dǎo*. Are those who wield *diao nou* harming the life of grasses and trees? For the sake of farming, they cannot but do so, unaware of the harm to the vitality of growth. This meaning suggests that while life grows, uprooting continues; though grasses and trees are removed, the crops grow anew—thus its success is its destruction, its destruction its success.

Viewed thus, success and failure, gain and loss, life and death, fortune and misfortune—all should be left to nature. Why harbor intentions? From the overflow of virtue into name downward, all are the faults of harboring intentions. If one can be free of such intentions, one attains the heavenly wandering.

Stillness can mend illness; cutting away can rest old age; tranquility can halt haste. Yet these are the tasks of the toiling, not the concerns of the carefree who have never inquired into them. *Jingran* (stillness) means serenity. To mend illness is to shed the old and renew, to abandon the branches and return to the root. If the heart can be serene, past losses can be mended and made whole. *Zì* is pronounced *jiǎn*; *cuì* is pronounced *miè*. *Zī cuì* (cutting away) means removing desires to preserve heavenly principle, allowing one to wander leisurely into old age. *Jù* means urgency. If the heart can be tranquil, haste can be stilled.

These three phrases all speak of recovery after loss, much as Yangzi said: "First illness, then healing." Thus it is said: "Yet these are the tasks of the toiling." This sentence concludes here, meaning that only after experiencing the suffering of being burdened by things can one come to regret; as for those who are carefree and self-content, their hearts are originally at peace and self-sufficient, so they never inquire into such matters. *Yi* means self-contentment. "Not the concerns of the carefree" is akin to saying "not the affairs of the carefree." *Suo* is like *suo* in "that which is without idleness."

The reason the sage startles the world is something the spirit-like person has never inquired into; the reason the worthy startles the age is something the sage has never inquired into; the reason the noble startles the state is something the worthy has never inquired into; the reason the petty person conforms to the times is something the noble has never inquired into. In Yanmen, when a man’s kin died, he was enfeoffed as a court master for his virtuous mourning, and half of his fellow villagers mourned themselves to death. Thus, without ever asking a single question, four more sentences follow. *Xie* is pronounced the same as *hai* (to startle).

The sage governs the world through benevolence and righteousness—this is what startles the world, yet the spirit-like person has no part in it. The worthy astonishes the age with overflowing virtue—yet the sage has no part in it. The nobleman startles his state with reputation and renown—yet the worthy has no part in it. The petty person busily strives to conform to the times—yet the nobleman has no part in it.

Yanmen is a place name. *Shan hui* (virtuous mourning) is filial piety. Having gained rank through filial piety, he became an official master, and his fellow villagers, admiring him, even mourned themselves to death—this speaks of the burden of seeking fame. *Guan shi* (official master) is what we now call an official.

When Yao offered the world to Xu You, Xu You fled; when Tang offered it to Wu Guang, Wu Guang grew angry. When Ji Tuo heard of this, he led his disciples to crouch by the Kuang River, and the feudal lords came to offer condolences. After three years, Shen Tu Di followed suit and drowned himself in the Yellow River. Xu You and Wu Guang gained fame through reclusion, and Ji Tuo, admiring them, likewise led his followers into hiding by the Kuang River. *Cun* is pronounced the same as *dun* (to crouch), with a tone of disdain. Ji Tuo’s intent was that the feudal lords would yield their states to him, yet they merely came to commiserate with his hardship. His own folly was laughable, and three years later, Shen Tu Di, coveting the fame of reclusion, threw himself into the river. This is the extreme to which the burden of seeking fame can lead.

The *quan* is what catches the fish, yet once the fish is caught, the *quan* is forgotten. The *ti* is what snares the hare, yet once the hare is snared, the *ti* is forgotten. Words are what convey meaning, yet once the meaning is grasped, the words are forgotten. Where might I find a man who has forgotten words, that I might speak with him?

The above having been fully expounded, it concludes with the analogy of the *quan* and *ti*, much like the earlier passage’s "words suffice" and "words do not suffice" in structure. The *quan* and *ti* are tools for catching fish and hares—once their purpose is served, they are of no further use. Words lodge meaning; once the meaning is grasped, the words are forgotten. Those who cannot forget words become mired in them and lose the meaning. Only one who has forgotten words may truly be spoken to. This essay, too, is finely wrought. "In the hare" means the intent is to catch the hare.

*Southern Florescence Perfected Scripture: Oral Exegesis*, Scroll Twenty-Seven, concludes.
*Southern Florescence Perfected Scripture: Oral Exegesis*, Scroll Twenty-Eight, by Lin Xi of Yuanzhai.

The "Miscellaneous Chapters" begin with "Parables": nineteen-tenths are parables, seventeen-tenths are reiterations, and *zhi*-words emerge daily, harmonized by the celestial norm.

Nineteen-tenths are parables, borrowing external voices to expound. A father does not act as matchmaker for his own son; his praise carries less weight than that of one who is not his father. The fault is not mine—it is the fault of others. When views align with one’s own, they are affirmed; when they diverge, they are rejected. What accords with oneself is deemed right; what differs is deemed wrong.

At the outset of this chapter, Zhuangzi himself explains the three modes of discourse in his work. *Parables* (*yuyan*) employ one’s own words but attribute them to others. "Nineteen-tenths" signifies that nine-tenths of this text consists of such parables—examples include Nie Que, Wang Ni, and Gengsang Chu. *Reiterations* (*chongyan*) borrow the names of ancient figures to lend weight, such as the Yellow Emperor, Shen Nong, and Confucius. "Seventeen-tenths" indicates that seven-tenths of the text falls into this category.

*Zhi* is a wine vessel. All may drink from it, and the drink has flavor—hence, *zhi*-words. "Emerge daily" means that such words appear in every matter. *He* means to harmonize; *tianni* is the celestial principle. It is to harmonize the hearts of all with the celestial principle. *Jie* means to borrow. What does not originate from oneself but from others is called "external," hence "borrowing external voices to expound."

A father who praises his son to arrange a marriage will not be believed; thus, he must borrow another’s praise—this is the analogy. The fault lies not with me but with others’ lack of trust, which necessitates these parables. If it were seen as coming from me, others would inevitably divide into agreement or disagreement, affirming what aligns with them and rejecting what does not. Whether in accord or discord with oneself—this reflects the self-centered views of others.

"Seventeen-tenths are reiterations" serve to silence debate. To be venerable in years is to precede others, yet without the warp and weft of beginnings and ends to mark one as truly venerable, one is not truly prior. A person who has nothing to offer that surpasses others lacks the Way of humanity. One who lacks the Way of humanity is but a "worn-out person." *Yi* means to cease; *yiyan* means to halt contention. Borrowing the weight of the venerable ensures that listeners dare not dispute, thus stifling debate.

The ancient sage-kings and worthies were all venerable elders. "Warp and weft of beginnings and ends" refers to knowing constancy, knowing change, knowing origins, and knowing conclusions. *Qinian* is the age of one hundred years. Though one’s years may precede others, if one’s learning offers no insight, merely being called a venerable elder by virtue of age does not make one truly prior. It means one has nothing to surpass others. A person who cannot surpass others fails to fulfill the Way of humanity and is but a "worn-out person"—a long-standing, useless figure in the world.

This implies that those I borrow are all venerable and worthy of respect, not merely invoked as predecessors. *Zhi*-words emerge daily, harmonized by the celestial norm, flowing and unfolding to exhaust the years. Without speech, all is equal; equality and speech are not equal, nor are speech and equality. Thus, it is said: "No speech." To speak of "no speech" is to speak all one’s life without ever having spoken; to remain silent all one’s life is never to have failed to speak.

There are origins that make things permissible, origins that make them impermissible; origins that make them so, origins that make them not so. How is it so? It is so in being so. How is it not so? It is not so in being not so. How is it permissible? It is permissible in being permissible. How is it impermissible? It is impermissible in being impermissible. Things inherently have what makes them so; things inherently have what makes them permissible. Nothing is not so; nothing is impermissible.

Were it not for *zhi*-words emerging daily, harmonized by the celestial norm, who could attain such enduring truth? All things are seeds, succeeding one another in different forms, beginning and end like a ring with no discernible order—this is called the celestial balance. The celestial balance is the celestial norm.

*Manyan* means to roam freely and find contentment. *Qiong nian* means to pass the days and months thus. Without speech, all is equal—speech without words returns to a single principle. *Qi* means unity. To express this unity in words and then debate it is to introduce partiality, losing the equality of unity. Thus, it is said: equality and speech are not equal, nor are speech and equality.

Only without speech is there equality—without speech, there are words without intent. To speak all one’s life without ever having spoken is to be without intent in speech. To remain silent all one’s life without ever failing to speak is to awaken to principle even in silence, which is not truly silence.

*You zi* means to have an origin. All that people deem permissible, impermissible, so, or not so arises from particular origins, each affirming what it affirms. How, then, can I determine what is so or permissible? I simply follow what is so and permissible in being so and permissible, and what is not so and impermissible in being not so and impermissible.

Things inherently have what makes them so—each thing has its own rightness. Since each has its own rightness, all things are right, hence "nothing is not so, nothing is impermissible." This idea is discussed in detail in the "Equality of Things" chapter.

"Were it not for *zhi*-words emerging daily, harmonized by the celestial norm, who could attain such enduring truth?" If I did not use natural words to harmonize all voices, aligning with their judgments of right and wrong, how could I ensure lasting agreement? For the principle of nature is unassailable across all ages.

All things share a common origin in creation, yet their different forms succeed one another between heaven and earth.

Then humans take grass as grass, trees as trees, birds as birds, and beasts as beasts—seeing only their differing forms while unaware that all emerge from the same primordial *qi*, their origin being one. All things within heaven and earth follow a cycle of coming and going, beginning and ending, as if in ceaseless rotation. The marvel of their order eludes human comprehension, for it cannot be fully known. This is called the "Celestial Equality."

"Equality" means sameness; what is the same in the celestial principle is thus called *Celestial Equality*. Zhuangzi said to Huizi: "Confucius lived sixty years, and in those sixty years, he transformed sixty times. What he once deemed right, he later deemed wrong. How can we know that what he now calls right is not what he deemed wrong at fifty-nine?" Huizi replied: "Confucius diligently applied his will to serve knowledge." Zhuangzi said: "Confucius has abandoned that path, though he has never spoken of it. Confucius once said: 'One receives talent from the Great Root and returns to the numinous to live. When one sings, it accords with the pitch; when one speaks, it accords with the law. When profit and righteousness are arrayed before one, likes and dislikes, right and wrong merely submit to others’ words. If one could make others submit in their hearts without daring to oppose, one would establish the settled order of the world. Alas! Alas! How could I ever reach his level?'"

"Serving knowledge" means serving through action. "Knowledge" refers to intellectual perception. To exert the mind in pursuit of intellectual perception is to engage in broad learning. "Abandoned" means to depart. Zhuangzi means that Confucius had already left behind the pursuit of broad learning to advance toward the Dao, though he had never spoken of this to others. When Zhuangzi cites "Confucius said," he is quoting Confucius’s own words, meaning that Confucius once spoke thus.

"Receiving talent from the Great Root" is like saying "receiving one’s nature from the Great Origin." The "Great Root" is the Creator. "Numinous" refers to the nature of awareness. "Returns" means to revert. Only by returning to the original nature of awareness can one fulfill the Way of human life, hence "returns to the numinous to live." "Sings" also means "speaks." "Pitch" is the law. "Accords" means that all speech conforms to principle. When profit and righteousness are placed before one, and one’s likes and dislikes, right and wrong, merely submit to others’ words, one may win verbal assent but not heartfelt submission. Only by relinquishing profit and righteousness and forgetting likes and dislikes, right and wrong, can one make others submit in their hearts without daring to oppose, thus establishing the settled order of the world. *Jiang* (悟) means opposition; to stand face-to-face is to set oneself in accord while others oppose. The *Rites of Zhou* says, "to receive the opposition of the feudal lords," meaning those who come toward me are deemed opposition.

After praising Confucius’s words, Zhuangzi sighed to Huizi, saying, "Alas! Alas! How could I ever reach the level of that Confucius?" From this alone, it is clear that Zhuangzi was not one who failed to revere our sage. Zengzi took office twice, and his heart transformed twice.
