He said: "When I served while my parents were alive, three *fu* of grain brought me joy; later, when I served with three thousand *zhong*, I could not reach my parents, and my heart grieved." A disciple asked Confucius: "Can Zeng Shen be said to be free of entanglement in fault?" Confucius replied: "He is already entangled. How could one free of entanglement feel sorrow?" To him, three *fu* and three thousand *zhong* were like watching sparrows, mosquitoes, and gnats pass before him.

"Not reaching" means not attaining one’s parents. "Free of entanglement in fault" means: was Zengzi’s statement entangled in fault or free of it? The doubt arises from his two transformations—joy and sorrow. "Already entangled" means that even this joy and sorrow are entanglements. If one were free of entanglement, the weight of external things passing before one would be like birds, insects, and gnats—how could one feel joy or sorrow over them? To feel joy or sorrow is to have a heart.

Yan Cheng Ziyou said to Dongguo Ziqí: "Since I heard your words, after one year, I became rustic; after two years, I followed; after three years, I penetrated; after four years, I became as things; after five years, I came; after six years, spirits entered; after seven years, heaven was completed; after eight years, I knew neither death nor life; after nine years, I attained the Great Mystery."

"After one year, rustic" means returning to simplicity. "After two years, following" means compliance—no opposition to right or wrong, likes or dislikes. "After three years, penetrating" means thorough penetration. "After four years, as things" means becoming like withered wood or dead ashes. "After five years, coming" means that within stillness, there is also non-stillness—what Chan Buddhists call "the great death and yet alive." "Spirits entered" means embracing creation within one’s breast. "Heaven completed" means becoming one with heaven. "Knowing neither death nor life" means being at ease in every situation. "Great Mystery" means the ultimate profundity. From one to nine years, these are merely stages in sequence; such matters cannot be measured by years.

To regard life as existence is death. Exhort the lord with his death, for it has its origin. Yet life is yang—it has no origin. Is this truly so? Where does it go? Where does it not go? These lines speak of the principle of neither life nor death.

"To regard life as existence" means that if one takes life as real, then death follows. To hold the view of life and death is self-centered. If one urges impartiality, one should know that among the Creator’s works, nothing is immortal—hence "exhort the lord with his death." Yet to call it death is to give it an origin. If death has an origin, then seek life at its first stirring—it fundamentally has no origin. Since its beginning is without life, how can there be death? Yang is the beginning of movement. Thus, the principle of life and death is as such—who knows if it is truly so?

Where it goes, it is so; where it does not go, it is not so. Yet when observed in its entirety, where is it so? Where is it not so? To call it existence is not so; to call it non-existence is also not so. Thus, is it truly so? Where does it go? Where does it not go?

Heaven has its celestial reckonings; earth has its human records. Where then shall I seek it? None know its end—how can it be said there is no mandate? None know its beginning—how can it be said there is a mandate? When there is resonance, how can there be no spirits? When there is no resonance, how can there be spirits?

Celestial reckonings refer to the movements of stars, constellations, sun, and moon, recorded in almanacs and calculations. Human records refer to the traces of human activity that can be verified, much like geographical treatises. Yet can one truly exhaust the principles of heaven and earth by seeking them in celestial reckonings and human records? Thus, it is said: Where shall I seek it?

Between heaven and earth, days pass and months flow—who can know their end? As their movement continues, there must be a Creator. How then can it be said there is no mandate? Yet in the primordial vastness, originally there was nothing. How can it be said there is a mandate?

Morning must yield to evening; cold must yield to heat. When the time comes, qi responds with utmost precision. Given such resonance, how can it be said there are no spirits? Yet the humble are not always blessed, the virtuous do not always live long. Between the seen and unseen, there are times when resonance fails. How then can it be said there are spirits? These lines elucidate the unknowability of the Creator.

The multitude of *wangliang* asked the shadow: "Before, you were bowed; now, you are upright. Before, your hair was tied; now, it is loose. Before, you were seated; now, you are standing. Before, you were walking; now, you are still. Why is this?"

The shadow replied: "Hush—why do you ask such trivial things? I have this, yet I know not why. I am like the cicada’s molted husk, the snake’s sloughed skin—similar, yet not the same. Fire and sunlight are my gathering; darkness and night are my succession. That which I depend upon—how much more so for those who depend on what depends? When it comes, I come with it; when it goes, I go with it. When it is strong and yang, I am strong and yang with it. What question is there in this?"

"Hush" conveys the sense of something fleeting and indistinct. "Trivial" means slight or cursory—why ask such a hasty question? What I possess is fundamental, yet I do not know why it is so. Thus, it is said: I have this, yet I know not its origin.

The cicada has transformed, yet its husk remains; the snake has transformed, yet its sloughed skin remains. This is to liken the movement of form to the life of cicadas and snakes, and to compare the shadow to the shed husk and skin. "Similar, yet not the same" means that while this comparison is close, it is not exact. When within the light of sun and fire, this shadow exists—thus it is said to gather and assemble. When day turns to shade without sun, and night falls without fire, the shadow becomes invisible—this is its succession and departure. "That" refers to form; "I" refers to the shadow. It is said: what I depend upon is that—thus, "that upon which I depend." Yet the movement of form itself also depends on something else—hence, "how much more so for those who depend on what depends." "Strong yang" is movement. Form moves by depending on the qi of strong yang; that by which form comes and goes is strong yang. If that moves by strong yang, I follow it—yet what strong yang is, form itself does not know. Why then do you ask me?

This passage parallels the *Equalizing Things*, but adds the explanations of strong yang, fire, and sun—merely playing with the brush. It is what Chan Buddhists call "repeating the gāthā."

Yang Ziju traveled south to Pei, while Lao Dan journeyed west to Qin. They met by chance at Liang, where Laozi looked up to the sky and sighed mid-journey, saying: "At first, I thought you could be taught, but now you cannot." Yang Ziju made no reply. Upon reaching their lodging, he presented water for washing, a towel, and a comb, removed his shoes outside the door, and advanced on his knees, saying: "Earlier, your disciple wished to ask you, Master, but you were walking without pause, so I dared not. Now that there is a pause, I beg to ask: what is my fault?" Laozi said: "You are haughty and overbearing—with whom can you dwell? The purest white seems tarnished; the greatest virtue seems insufficient." Yang Ziju’s expression changed abruptly, and he said: "I respectfully receive your instruction."

When he had gone before, the innkeepers welcomed and saw him off at their home; the master of the house held the mat, his wife held the towel and comb, the guests avoided the seats, and the cook avoided the stove. When he returned, the innkeepers contended with him for seats. "What is my fault?" means: the Master said I could not be taught—where does my fault lie? "Haughty and overbearing" describes a constrained and uneasy demeanor. "With whom can you dwell?" means that he had not forgotten the distinction between self and others, always appearing as if dwelling with others. "The purest white seems tarnished" conveys the idea of brightness concealing itself. "The greatest virtue seems insufficient" means that though one possesses it, one does not presume upon it. "Welcomed and saw off" refers to escorting him. "The master of the house" is the host of the inn. "Holding the mat" and "holding the towel and comb" are acts of service. "The cook" is the one who tends the fire. "Avoiding the seats" and "avoiding the stove" show respect. "Contending for seats" means they no longer knew to respect him. Before hearing Laozi’s words, he had an air of self-importance and self-regard, so people saw him and respected him. After receiving this awakening, he withdrew and concealed himself, and people saw him as an ordinary man. The composition of this chapter is also refined.

*End of the Twenty-Eighth Scroll of the Oral Exegesis of the True Scripture of the Southern Florescence*

**Oral Exegesis of the True Scripture of the Southern Florescence, Scroll Twenty-Nine**
*By Lin Xiyi of Juanzhai*

**Miscellaneous Chapters: "Yielding the Throne"**

Yao offered the realm to Xu You, but Xu You declined.
He then offered it to Zizhou Zhi Fu, who replied: "Were I to be made Son of Heaven, it would be acceptable. Yet I happen to suffer from a hidden affliction and am presently tending to it—I have no leisure to govern the realm."
The realm is of utmost weight, yet he would not let it harm his life—how much less would he allow other things to do so!
Only one who takes no account of the realm may be entrusted with it.

Shun offered the realm to Zizhou Zhi Bo, who said: "I happen to suffer from a hidden affliction and am presently tending to it—I have no leisure to govern the realm."
Thus, the realm is a great vessel, yet one does not exchange life for it—this is how those who possess the Dao differ from the common.

A "hidden affliction" is what we now call a concealed malady.
One who "takes no account of the realm" is one who does not desire to be Son of Heaven; only such a person may be entrusted with it—this is one who possesses the realm yet does not cling to it.
"Differs from the common" means he is not like the worldly.

Shun offered the realm to Shan Juan, who said: "I stand amid the cosmos: in winter, I wear furs; in summer, I wear fine linen. In spring, I plow and sow, and my body is sufficient for labor; in autumn, I reap and gather, and my person is sufficient for rest and sustenance. I rise with the sun and rest at its setting. I wander freely between heaven and earth, and my heart is content. Why should I take the realm for myself? Alas, you do not know me!"
He refused and departed, entering the deep mountains, and none knew his whereabouts.

Shun offered the realm to his friend, the farmer of Shihu, who said: "How earnest is the lord’s conduct—a man who preserves his strength!" Yet he deemed Shun’s virtue not yet perfected. Thereupon, he and his wife, carrying their child, fled to the sea and never returned.
"Earnest" (*juanjuan*) describes the appearance of one who toils on his own behalf.
"Preserves his strength" means to labor diligently.
"Virtue not yet perfected" refers to a virtue that is not yet natural.
Both fled: the wife bore the child upon her head, the husband carried them on his back.

These two passages lack concluding remarks, for their meaning is the same as the preceding.

King Tai of the Zhou dwelt in Bin. The Di tribes attacked, offering furs and silks, but he would not accept; they offered dogs and horses, but he would not accept; they offered pearls and jades, but he would not accept. What the Di sought was land.
King Tai Dan Fu said: "To dwell with a man’s elder brother and kill his younger brother, to dwell with a man’s father and kill his son—I cannot bear it. Go, all of you, and dwell here. What difference is there between serving me and serving the Di?"
Moreover, I have heard that one must not harm what is nurtured for the sake of what nurtures it.
Thereupon, he took up his staff and departed. The people followed in droves, and he established a state beneath Mount Qi.
King Tai Dan Fu may be called one who knew how to honor life.
One who honors life does not, though rich and noble, let what nurtures injure the self; though poor and lowly, does not let profit burden the body.
Yet men of this age who occupy high office and exalted rank all fear losing them. Seeing profit, they lightly cast aside their lives—is this not delusion?
"What nurtures" refers to what one relies upon for self-sustenance—namely, land.
"What is nurtured" refers to the common people.
"Honoring life" means valuing the self and treating external things as light.

This is a rebuke to those of the time who fretted over loss.

The people of Yue murdered their ruler for three generations. Prince Sou, troubled by this, fled into the cinnabar cave, and Yue was left without a ruler. When they could not find Prince Sou, they pursued him to the cave. He refused to emerge, so they smoked him out with mugwort and bore him forth in a jade carriage.
Prince Sou grasped the reins and mounted the chariot, gazing heavenward and crying: "Lordship! Lordship! Can you not spare me this?"
Prince Sou did not hate lordship—he hated the calamity that came with it.
Such a one may be called one who would not let the state harm his life.
This was indeed what the people of Yue desired in a ruler.
"Lordship! Lordship!" means "Do you take me for a lord?"
Only one who has no intention of being lord may be entrusted with the state—thus it is said that he was what the people of Yue desired in a ruler.

Han and Wei contended over encroached land. Master Hua Zi visited Marquis Zhao of Han, who wore a troubled expression.
Master Hua Zi said: "Suppose the world inscribed a contract before you, with these words: 'If you seize it with your left hand, your right hand will be lost; if you seize it with your right hand, your left hand will be lost. Yet whoever seizes it shall possess the realm—could you seize it?'"
Marquis Zhao said: "I would not."
Master Hua Zi said: "Excellent. From this we see that both arms are weightier than the realm, and the body is weightier than both arms. Han is far lighter than the realm, and what you now contend over is far lighter than Han. Yet you grieve, harming your life and body over what you cannot obtain."
The marquis said: "Well said! Many have instructed me, but never have I heard such words."
Master Hua Zi may be called one who knew the measure of light and heavy.

"Seize" (*jue*) means to grasp and take.
"A contract" (*ming*) is like an agreement.
"Lost" means severed and gone.
To seize the contract would be to gain the realm, yet one who cherishes his body would not do so—how much less when Han, compared to the realm, is so light!
To grieve over not obtaining it, to the point of harming one’s life and body, is worse than losing an arm.
Thus it is said he knew the measure of light and heavy.

This analogy offers great benefit to the worldly; this passage resembles the "Inner Chapters."

The Lord of Lu heard that Yan He was a man who had attained the Dao, so he sent an envoy bearing gifts to approach him first. Yan He lived in a humble lane, wearing coarse cloth and personally tending oxen. When the envoy from Lu arrived, Yan He received him himself. The envoy asked, "Is this the home of Yan He?" Yan He replied, "This is the home of He." The envoy presented the gifts, but Yan He responded, "I fear the messenger may have misheard and would thus incur blame. It would be better to verify this." The envoy returned, confirmed the matter, and came back to seek him again—only then did Yan He accept. Thus, one like Yan He truly detested wealth and honor.

Therefore it is said: The true essence of the Dao is for cultivating the self; its remnants and leavings may be used for governing the state; its dregs and chaff may be used for ordering the world. From this perspective, the achievements of emperors and kings are but the surplus affairs of sages—never the means to perfect the self or nurture life. Yet today, the worldly gentlemen often endanger their bodies and abandon their lives to pursue external things—is this not lamentable?

Whenever the sage acts, he must examine both his purpose and his means. Now suppose there were a man here who used the Marquis of Sui’s pearl to shoot a sparrow a thousand *ren* high—surely the world would laugh at him. Why? Because what he employed was weighty, while what he sought was light. How much more so is life itself, which far exceeds the value of the Marquis of Sui’s pearl!

*Ju bu* refers to coarse cloth. *Mishearing* means hearing incorrectly. *Tu zha* (dregs and chaff) is pronounced with the first syllable as *che* and the second as *zhaya*—it signifies worthless residue. The implication is that the governance of the world and the state, within the Dao of the sage, are mere surplus affairs. The self is the foundation of the world and the state; cultivating the self enables one to govern the world and the state. This is the teaching of the sages.

Zhuangzi’s words make such distinctions, leading people to believe he divides things into two separate realms—refined and coarse—yet they fail to grasp his true intent: that one who knows the Dao does not allow external things to burden his fundamental mind. For example, Yao’s heart was not set on the imperial carriage, and Shun and Yu held the world as if it were not theirs. Only thus can one fully realize the governance of non-action. However, his rhetoric may at times be overly emphatic.

The phrases "remnants and leavings" and "dregs and chaff" arise from surplus affairs, much like saying "dust, chaff, and husks can be molded into Yao and Shun." His language sometimes exceeds proper bounds, and this is one such case. Wang Anshi’s scholarship truly took these as two separate matters, attempting to apply them by emphasizing the "remnants and leavings" and "dregs and chaff"—hence Zhu Xi’s thorough refutation.

Zhuangzi’s excessive rhetoric may mislead later generations, yet his true intent was otherwise. To endanger one’s body and abandon one’s life in pursuit of external things is to allow external things to burden the mind.

*Suo yi zhi* means "the purpose of going." The two phrases *suo yi zhi* and *suo yi wei* express a single idea. No one would willingly use a pearl to shoot a sparrow, yet people fail to recognize when external things burden their bodies. This analogy is most clear and apt; this passage, too, resembles the "Inner Chapters."

Liezi was poor, his countenance bearing the hue of hunger. A guest mentioned this to Zi Yang, the minister of Zheng, saying, "Lie Yukou is a man of the Dao. That he dwells in your state yet suffers poverty—could it be that you, my lord, do not favor scholars?" Zi Yang immediately ordered an official to send him grain. When Liezi saw the messenger, he bowed twice and declined. The messenger departed, and upon entering his home, Liezi’s wife struck her breast and said, "I have heard that the wife and children of a man of the Dao all enjoy ease and happiness. Now you bear the look of hunger, yet when the lord sent you food, you refused it—is this not fate?" Liezi laughed and said to her, "The lord does not know me personally. He sent me grain based on another’s words, and if he were to blame me, he would do so based on another’s words as well. This is why I did not accept it."

In the end, the people indeed rose in rebellion and killed Zi Yang. Zi Yang was the minister of Zheng, and Liezi was a native of Zheng. To send grain based on another’s words shows he did not truly know him; if he did not truly know him, then praise could be trusted, but so too could slander. This explanation is most apt and aligns with the *Liezi*.

King Zhao of Chu lost his state, and the butcher Shuo fled alongside him. When the king regained his state and was about to reward those who had followed him, he came to the butcher Shuo. The butcher Shuo said, "When Your Majesty lost the state, I lost my butchery. Now that Your Majesty has regained the state, I have regained my butchery. My rank and emolument have already been restored—what reward is there to give?"

The king said, "Insist that he accept it."

The butcher Shuo replied, "When Your Majesty lost the state, it was not my fault, so I dared not accept punishment. Now that Your Majesty has regained the state, it is not my merit, so I dare not claim reward."

The king said, "Let me see him."

The butcher Shuo said, "According to the laws of Chu, one must have performed great deeds to receive a grand reward before being granted an audience. Now, my wisdom was insufficient to preserve the state, and my courage was insufficient to die in battle against the enemy. When the Wu army entered Ying, I fled from danger to avoid the enemy—it was not that I intentionally followed Your Majesty. Now, if Your Majesty wishes to set aside the law and break the covenant to see me, this is not what I wish to be heard throughout the world."

The king said to Sima Ziqi, "The butcher Shuo dwells in lowly circumstances yet upholds principles of the highest order. You, sir, should extend to him the position of the Three Standards."

The butcher Shuo said, "I know that the position of the Three Standards is nobler than the butcher’s stall, and that the emolument of ten thousand *zhong* is richer than the butcher’s profit. Yet how could I greedily accept rank and emolument and cause my lord to gain a reputation for reckless bestowal? I dare not accept. I wish to return to my butcher’s stall." Thus, he declined and did not accept.

When the king regained his state, Shuo regained his butchery—each returned to his proper place and duty.

The Three Standards refer to the Three Dukes. The carriages and robes of the Three Dukes each bear distinct banners, hence the term "Three Standards." This passage is also excellent.

Yuan Xian dwelled in Lu, his home a wattle hut with walls barely spanning a few paces, its roof thatched with wild grass. The door, woven of brambles, was incomplete; the hinge was made of mulberry wood, and the two windows were fashioned from earthen jars. Coarse cloth stuffed the gaps to block wind and rain. Above leaked, below dampened, yet he sat upright, plucking the strings of his zither.

Zi Gong arrived in a grand carriage, its canopy deep purple, its lower robes pure white, the axle so wide it could not pass through the narrow lane. He came to visit Yuan Xian. Yuan Xian, wearing a hat of birch bark, dragging his hempen shoes, and leaning on a staff of wild thorn, answered the door. Zi Gong said, "Alas! Master, what ails you?" Yuan Xian replied, "I have heard that to lack wealth is called poverty, but to study and fail to practice is called affliction. I am poor, not afflicted."

Zi Gong stepped back, his face flushed with shame. Yuan Xian smiled and said, "To act in pursuit of worldly favor, to befriend for mutual gain, to study for others’ sake, to teach for personal profit, to feign benevolence and righteousness as a cloak for deceit, to adorn oneself with carriages and fine horses—these are things I cannot bear to do."

The thatch refers to the roof covered with grass. Both rooms of the husband and wife had windows made from earthen jars, hence "two rooms with jar-windows." A window is an opening chiseled into a wall to admit light. Coarse cloth stuffed the windows to ward off wind and rain, hence "coarse cloth as a seal." *Xian* means to strum the zither or lute. *Kuang zuo* means to sit upright. *Gan* is a deep blue-red. The outer garment was white, hence "white as the outer robe." The carriage could not pass through the lane, meaning the lane was too narrow for its width. *Hua guan* refers to a hat made of birch bark. *Zong lv* means to drag one’s shoes. "To act in pursuit of worldly favor" describes conduct aimed at currying favor. "To befriend for mutual gain" means associating with unworthy people. To study for others rather than oneself, to teach for profit rather than the Dao, to use benevolence and righteousness as a pretext for villainy—this is what is meant by "the treachery of benevolence and righteousness."

Zengzi lived in Wei, his quilted robe without an outer layer, his complexion sallow and swollen, his hands and feet calloused. For three days, he did not kindle a fire; for ten years, he did not make new clothes. When he straightened his hat, the cord snapped; when he grasped his lapel, his elbow showed; when he put on his shoes, the heels split. Yet as he dragged his tattered hem and sang the *Odes of Shang*, his voice filled heaven and earth, resonant as metal or stone. Neither the Son of Heaven could make him a subject, nor the feudal lords befriend him. Thus, those who cultivate the will forget the body; those who cultivate the body forget profit; those who attain the Dao forget the mind.

The quilted robe refers to today’s padded clothing. "Without an outer layer" means the outer fabric was torn, exposing the padding. *Zhong kuai* describes a bloated, puffy appearance. When he straightened his hat, the cord broke—the cord being what secures the hat. "Elbow showed" means the sleeves of his lapel were torn. "Heels split" means the backs of his shoes were broken. *Ye zong* means to drag one’s hem as one walks. *Shang song* refers to the songs he sang. "Resonant as metal or stone" describes the rhythmic quality of his voice. "To cultivate the will and forget the body" means not to burden the mind with concerns for bodily care. "To cultivate the body and forget profit" means not to exhaust oneself chasing external things. "To attain the Dao and forget the mind" means that without a mind, one approaches the Dao.

Confucius said to Yan Hui, "Hui, come here. Your family is poor and your station low—why do you not seek office?" Yan Hui replied, "I do not wish to serve. Outside the city walls, I have fifty *mu* of fields, enough to provide gruel and porridge; within the city walls, ten *mu* of land, enough to yield silk and hemp. Playing the zither brings me joy, and the Dao I study from you is enough to bring me happiness. I do not wish to serve."

Confucius’s expression changed solemnly as he said, "Excellent, Hui’s intent! I have heard that one who knows contentment is not burdened by profit; one who truly possesses self-mastery is not fearful of loss; one whose conduct is cultivated within feels no shame in any position. I have recited these words for a long time, but only now do I see them in you. This is my gain."

"Outside the city walls" refers to fields; "within the city walls," to gardens. Yan Hui may not have actually possessed these, and Zhuangzi’s words may not be entirely trustworthy. "The Dao I study from you is enough to bring me happiness"—what is this happiness? Thus, the Cheng brothers often taught people to seek the source of Yan Hui’s joy, a matter not to be glossed over lightly. "One who knows contentment is not burdened by profit" means that one who is content with oneself has no need of external things. *Shen* means "truly." If what is within oneself is genuinely sufficient, then the loss of external things brings neither joy nor fear. "No shame in any position" means not feeling ashamed when others do not recognize one’s worth. "I have recited these words for a long time, but only now do I see them in you" means that though he had long heard these words, he now saw them embodied in a person. "This is my gain" refers to truly having gained a friend.

The Prince Mou of Zhongshan said to Shanzi, "Though my body dwells by rivers and seas, my heart remains beneath the palace gates of Wei—what is to be done?" Shanzi replied, "Value life. If you value life, profit will seem light."

The Prince Mou of Zhongshan said, "Though I know this, I cannot overcome myself." Shanzi said, "If you cannot overcome yourself, then follow your inclinations—your spirit will not resent it. If one cannot overcome oneself yet forcibly resists, this is called double injury. A doubly injured person does not belong among the long-lived."

Prince Mou of Wei was the son of a ruler of ten thousand chariots, and his retreat to mountain caves was more difficult than for a commoner. Though he had not yet attained the Dao, he could be said to have grasped its essence. "My heart remains beneath the palace gates" means he had not yet forgotten wealth and rank. "Value life and profit will seem light" means that when one recognizes the preciousness of the original mind, external things grow light. "Though I know this, I cannot overcome myself" means that principle had not yet triumphed over desire. "If you cannot overcome yourself, then follow" means that if the mind cannot yet master itself, one should temporarily yield and comply. This refers to the occasional arising of such thoughts while dwelling by rivers and seas—one need not forcibly suppress them. Forcible suppression may inwardly harm the spirit or even lead to illness, hence "if you cannot overcome yourself, then follow."

To follow is to comply. Complying harms not the spirit, hence "the spirit suffers no aversion." Inability to master oneself is the first injury, occurring when such thoughts arise. If, at the moment these thoughts emerge, one forcibly suppresses and refuses to comply, the strain of self-restraint becomes a second injury—thus "double injury." This is no way to preserve one’s life. Those who do not belong to the long-lived are not counted among their kind.

Wei Mou, though a prince, became a recluse, making self-mastery all the harder for him. Though his learning had not yet attained the Dao, he could be said to have grasped its intent. These words align with the *Doctrine of the Mean*’s encouragement to persevere in practice.

Confucius, beset between Chen and Cai, went seven days without cooked food, subsisting on a broth of greens without grain. His complexion grew gaunt, yet he still strummed and sang in his chamber. Yan Hui picked vegetables. Zilu and Zigong spoke to one another: "The Master was twice driven from Lu, his traces erased in Wei, his tree felled in Song, and now he is destitute between Shang and Zhou, besieged in Chen and Cai. Those who would kill him face no penalty; those who would trample him meet no prohibition. Yet he never ceases his strumming and singing—can a noble person be so shameless?"

Yan Hui, unable to respond, entered and told Confucius. Confucius pushed aside his zither and sighed deeply: "You and Ci are petty men. Summon them, and I will speak to them." Zilu and Zigong entered. Zilu said, "In such straits, one may truly be called destitute." Confucius replied, "What words are these? When a noble person is at one with the Dao, that is success; when cut off from the Dao, that is destitution. Now I embrace the Dao of benevolence and righteousness yet suffer the calamities of a disordered age—how can this be called destitution? Thus, in self-examination I am not cut off from the Dao; facing adversity, I do not lose my virtue. When bitter cold arrives and frost and snow descend, I know the pine and cypress remain verdant. The straits of Chen and Cai may yet prove fortunate for me."

Confucius then calmly returned to his zither and strummed and sang. Zilu, inspired, took up his shield and danced. Zigong said, "I did not know the height of heaven or the depth of earth!" Those of old who attained the Dao found joy in adversity and joy in success—their joy lay not in adversity or success. When the Dao and its virtue are thus realized, adversity and success become as regular as the seasons of cold and heat, wind and rain.

Thus, Xu You found delight by the Ying River, and Gong Bo found contentment on Mount Qiu. "A broth of greens without grain" means there were vegetables but no rice. "Trample" means to oppress. "No prohibition" means no one deemed it a crime.

When the cold of winter arrives, one knows the flourishing of the pine and cypress—this is what is meant by "only in the cold of the year does one know the pine and cypress." Through the straits of Chen and Cai, the Dao of the sage in adversity could manifest itself, becoming a model for later generations. Thus it is said, "How fortunate for me."

*Xiaoran* suggests a carefree and unconstrained manner. "Returned to his zither" means he took up the zither again to play. *Guran* means leaping with joy. Zilu heard these words and rejoiced. The following lines from Zigong indicate his enlightenment.

Mount Qiushou is the name of a mountain. The so-called Gong Bo may not refer to the Gonghe Regency; these are likely allegories, not to be taken as factual. The intent is that Zigong, moved by joy, spoke thus, praising those like Xu You who could remain reclusive to the end, finding joy in adversity through the Dao. Xu You and Gong Bo are invoked through Zigong’s words.

During the Shang and Zhou dynasties, the Zhou capital included the former lands and people of Shang. Shun offered the world to his friend, the Northerner Wuze. Wuze said, "How strange is the ruler’s conduct! Dwelling in the fields and yet frequenting Yao’s court—this alone would have been improper. Now he further seeks to defile me with his disgraceful conduct. I am ashamed to see him." Thereupon he cast himself into the Clear and Cold Abyss.

"Would have been improper" means Shun’s actions were already wrong. Your own faults are yours alone to bear—why further seek to sully me? Thus he drowned himself. No other records attest to this event; it too is likely allegorical. *Ru xing* means "defiled virtue."

When Tang was about to attack Jie, he consulted Bian Sui, who said, "This is not my affair." Tang asked, "Who then is suitable?" Bian Sui replied, "I do not know." Tang then consulted Wu Guang, who said, "This is not my affair." Tang asked, "Who then is suitable?" Wu Guang replied, "I do not know." Tang said, "What of Yi Yin?" Wu Guang answered, "He is strong and enduring, patient of disgrace. I know nothing beyond this." Tang then conspired with Yi Yin, overthrew Jie, and succeeded him. He offered the throne to Bian Sui, who declined, saying, "When the ruler plotted against Jie, he consulted me—he must have thought me a villain. Now that he has triumphed, he offers me the throne—he must think me greedy. I live in a chaotic age, and a ruler without the Dao twice seeks to defile me with his disgraceful conduct. I cannot bear to hear such things again." Thereupon he cast himself into the Thicket Waters and drowned.

Tang then offered the throne to Wu Guang, saying, "The wise plan, the martial execute, the benevolent rule—this is the ancient Way. Why do you not ascend?" Wu Guang declined, saying, "To depose a ruler is unrighteous; to kill the people is unbenevolent. Others bear the hardship while I enjoy the gain—this is dishonorable. I have heard that one does not accept emoluments from unrighteous sources, nor tread the soil of a lawless age. How much less would I accept such honor? I cannot bear to witness this any longer."

Then he strapped stones to himself and drowned in the Lu River. "Strong in effort" signifies the intent to achieve. "Enduring disgrace" means tolerating the world’s defilements.

"Martial ones complete it" refers to those who succeed through war. "The benevolent dwell in it" describes Wu Guang as a man of benevolence. Bian Sui and Wu Guang were both recluses of antiquity, yet their act of drowning themselves remains unverifiable—perhaps it was merely allegory.

In the rise of the Zhou, two scholars dwelt in Guzhu, named Boyi and Shuqi. The two conferred, saying: "We have heard there is one in the west who seems to possess the Dao. Let us go and observe." Arriving at Qiyang, King Wu learned of them and sent Shu Dan to meet them, proposing an oath: "I shall double your rank and appoint you to the highest office, sealing the pact with blood and burial." The two exchanged glances and laughed: "Strange indeed! This is not the Dao as we know it.

In the days when Shennong ruled the world, sacrifices were made with utmost reverence yet without prayers for blessing. Toward men, he was loyal and trustworthy, governing thoroughly yet without demand. He delighted in governance as governance, in order as order. He did not build himself up through others’ ruin, nor exalt himself through others’ lowliness, nor profit from the times.

Now Zhou, seeing Yin’s chaos, hastily seizes power. Above, it schemes; below, it bribes. It deploys force to preserve might, slaughters beasts to swear oaths as trust, parades its deeds to please the masses, and wages war for gain—merely replacing one tyranny with another.

We have heard that in ancient times, when the world was well-ordered, the worthy did not shirk their duty; when it was disordered, they did not cling to mere survival. Today, the world is benighted, Zhou’s virtue wanes. To align with Zhou would sully our persons—better to withdraw and keep our conduct pure."

The two journeyed north to Mount Shouyang and starved to death. As for Boyi and Shuqi, when it came to wealth and rank, if they could have obtained them without compromise, they would not have refused. Their lofty integrity and unyielding conduct were their joy alone; they served no worldly cause—such was the resolve of these two scholars.

Shu Dan—*Shu* being a term for younger brother. "Double your rank" meant doubling their emolument. "Appoint you to the highest office" referred to the pinnacle of officialdom. The oath was sealed by slaying an animal, drawing its blood, and burying the remains.

Invoking Shennong was to contrast with the ancient age, which was not like this. "Sacrifices in season" meant timely rites. "Without prayers for blessing" meant sacrificing without seeking favor. "Governing thoroughly yet without demand" meant no desire for renown. "Delighting in governance as governance, in order as order" implied action without self-interest.

"Hastily seizes power" described Zhou’s eagerness to enact good governance. "Below, it bribes" referred to using ranks and emoluments to lure the world’s scholars. "Deploys force" meant resorting to perilous measures. "Preserves might" meant establishing martial authority. "Parades its deeds" meant broadcasting its reputation. "Replacing one tyranny with another" meant Zhou’s deeds were no better than Zhou Xin’s.

"To align with Zhou" meant joining Zhou in this age—defiling themselves, as if clad in court robes and cap while seated in filth and ashes. "Would not have refused" meant not taking such things as their due.

Later, the mountain inscription read: "In youth, one relies on emoluments"—hence the use of *rely*. "Unyielding" meant conduct so rigid it verged on defiance. To "carve intent" was to act with such extremity—this was "unyielding conduct." Boyi and Shuqi did not seek lofty integrity or unyielding conduct; had there been even a hint of justifiable acceptance in wealth and rank, they would have accepted. Only when no such justification existed did they act thus.

"The world is benighted" referred to Shang’s chaos. "Zhou’s virtue wanes" meant Zhou, though rising, acted as it did—its use of cunning to seize the world was called "waning virtue."

This passage does not fully resemble Zhuangzi’s style, though its metaphors—like casting a pearl to strike a sparrow, or prizing one’s arms over the world, or the parables of the butcher and the sheep—are still fine. Yet it falls short of his other works. As for *Robber Zhi*, *Discoursing on Swords*, and *The Old Fisherman*, they are even more so.

*The Oral Exegesis of the Southern Florescence Perfect Scripture*, Scroll Twenty-Nine concludes.
Variant readings: *Nai* (乃) is written as *yi* (以) in the Ming edition. *Shuo* (说) is written as *yue* (越). *Gao* (高) is written as *yan* (焉). *Su shang* (素裳) originally read *biao su* (表素), emended per the Ming edition. *Qin* (琴) is written as *se* (瑟). *Shu* (树) is written as *mu* (木). *Shou* (受) is written as *ai* (爱).

*The Oral Exegesis of the Southern Florescence Perfect Scripture*, Scroll Thirty
By Lin Xiyi of Yanzhai

**Miscellaneous Chapters: Robber Zhi**

Confucius was a friend of Liuxia Ji, whose younger brother was named Robber Zhi. Robber Zhi commanded nine thousand followers, rampaging across the world and oppressing the feudal lords. He broke into chambers and forced open doors, driving off people’s oxen and horses, and seizing their wives and daughters. Greedy and forgetful of kinship, he paid no heed to parents or brothers and did not offer sacrifices to his ancestors. Wherever he passed, great states fortified their cities, small states took refuge in their strongholds, and the common people suffered greatly.

Confucius said to Liuxia Ji: "As a father, one must instruct one’s son; as an elder brother, one must teach one’s younger brother. If a father cannot instruct his son, or an elder brother cannot teach his younger brother, then the bond of father and son, elder and younger brother, is of no worth. Now, sir, you are a man of talent in this generation, yet your younger brother is Robber Zhi, a scourge upon the world, and you cannot teach him. I am secretly ashamed for you. Allow me to go and reason with him."

Liuxia Ji replied: "You say that as a father one must instruct one’s son, and as an elder brother one must teach one’s younger brother. But if a son does not heed his father’s instruction, or a younger brother does not accept his elder brother’s teaching, what can even your eloquence do? Moreover, Zhi’s nature is such that his mind surges like a spring, his intentions gust like the wind. He is strong enough to resist enemies, and his eloquence suffices to gloss over wrongs. He is pleased when his heart is followed, enraged when it is opposed, and easily provoked by words. You must not go."

Confucius did not listen. With Yan Hui driving his carriage and Zigong as his attendant, he went to see Robber Zhi. Robber Zhi was then resting his troops on the southern slopes of Mount Tai, mincing human livers to eat. Confucius alighted from his carriage and approached the messenger, saying: "I, Kong Qiu of Lu, have heard of the general’s lofty virtue and respectfully bow twice to the messenger."

The messenger entered and announced Confucius to Robber Zhi, who flew into a rage. His eyes blazed like stars, his hair bristled to lift his cap, and he said: "Is this not that crafty and deceitful Kong Qiu of Lu? Tell him this: You fabricate words and concoct phrases, falsely invoking Wen and Wu. You wear a cap of twigs and gird yourself with the flanks of dead oxen. You spout a torrent of specious arguments, eating without plowing, clothing yourself without weaving. You flap your lips and wag your tongue, stirring up right and wrong to delude the rulers of the world, causing scholars everywhere to abandon their roots and falsely perform filial piety and brotherly love in hopes of attaining enfeoffment and wealth. Your crimes are grave and heavy. Flee at once, or I shall add your liver to my midday meal."

Confucius sent word again: "I am fortunate to be acquainted with Ji and wish to gaze upon the hem of your robe." The messenger relayed this, and Robber Zhi said: "Let him come forward." Confucius hastened forward, stepped back from his mat, and bowed twice to Robber Zhi.

Robber Zhi was enraged. He stretched out his legs, grasped his sword, glared with bulging eyes, and roared like a nursing tiger: "Come forward, Qiu. If your words please me, you shall live; if they oppose me, you shall die."

Confucius said: "I have heard that there are three virtues under heaven. To be born and grow tall, surpassingly handsome, so that young and old, noble and base all delight in seeing you—this is the highest virtue. To comprehend the bounds of heaven and earth and distinguish all things—this is the middle virtue. To be brave, resolute, and daring, gathering multitudes and leading troops—this is the lowest virtue. Whoever possesses even one of these virtues is fit to face south and call himself a lord. Now, general, you combine all three: your body stands eight feet and two inches tall, your face and eyes radiant, your lips bright as cinnabar, your teeth even as clamshells, your voice attuned to the Yellow Bell. Yet you are called Robber Zhi. I am secretly ashamed for you that you do not claim a nobler name. If you are willing to heed me, I shall go south to Wu and Yue, north to Qi and Lu, east to Song and Wei, and west to Jin and Chu. I shall have a great city of several hundred *li* built for you, establish a settlement of several hundred thousand households, and honor you as a feudal lord. Together with the world, you may begin anew, disband your troops, rest your soldiers, care for your brothers, and jointly sacrifice to your ancestors. This is the conduct of a sage and a man of talent, and the wish of all under heaven."

Robber Zhi flew into a rage and said: "Come forward, Qiu. Those who can be guided by profit or admonished by words are but the foolish and vulgar common folk. As for being tall and handsome, delighting all who see you—this is the legacy of my parents. Even if you do not praise me, do I not know it myself? Moreover, I have heard that those who flatter others to their faces also slander them behind their backs. Now you tell me of great cities and multitudes of people, seeking to guide me with profit and treat me as a herded beast. How can this last long? The greatest of cities is none other than the world itself. Yao and Shun possessed the world, yet their descendants had not even a place to plant an awl. Tang and Wu became Sons of Heaven, yet their posterity perished. Was this not because their profit was too great?

Furthermore, I have heard that in ancient times, beasts were many and people few. Thus, people dwelled in nests to avoid them, gathering acorns by day and roosting in trees by night. Hence, they were called the People of the Nest-Builder. In ancient times, people did not know clothing. In summer, they amassed firewood; in winter, they warmed themselves by it. Hence, they were called the People Who Knew Life. In the age of Shennong, they lay at ease and rose without care. People knew their mothers but not their fathers and lived among elk and deer. They plowed to eat and wove to clothe themselves, harboring no thought of harming one another. This was the height of perfect virtue. Yet the Yellow Emperor could not sustain this virtue. He fought Chiyou on the plains of Zhuolu, and blood flowed for a hundred *li*. Yao and Shun arose and established hosts of ministers. Tang exiled his lord, and King Wu killed Zhou. Ever since, the strong have oppressed the weak, and the many have bullied the few. From Tang and Wu onward, all have been men of disorder.

Now you cultivate the Way of Wen and Wu, grasp the world’s eloquence to instruct later generations, wear embroidered robes and sashes, utter false and deceptive words to delude the rulers of the world, and seek wealth and honor."

No thief is greater than you, yet why does the world not call you "Robber Qiu" and instead call me "Robber Zhi"? You beguiled Zilu with honeyed words to make him follow you, causing him to remove his warrior’s cap, lay aside his long sword, and receive your teachings. The world all says that Confucius can halt violence and forbid wrongdoing. Yet in the end, Zilu sought to kill the lord of Wei, failed in the attempt, and was impaled at the eastern gate of Wei—this was the result of your incomplete instruction.

Do you truly consider yourself a man of talent and a sage? You were twice driven from Lu, your traces erased in Wei, impoverished in Qi, besieged between Chen and Cai, and found no refuge anywhere under heaven. You taught Zilu to bring about this disaster—above, he had no way to preserve himself; below, he had no way to serve others. Is your Way truly worthy of esteem?

Of those the world exalts, none surpasses the Yellow Emperor, yet even he could not preserve his virtue and fought on the plains of Zhuolu, where blood flowed for a hundred *li*. Yao was not compassionate, Shun was not filial, Yu exhausted himself, Tang exiled his lord, King Wu attacked Zhou, and King Wen was imprisoned at Youli. These six men, whom the world reveres—when closely examined, all were deluded by profit and forced their true natures into false paths. Their conduct is truly shameful.

As for the world’s so-called worthy men, Boyi and Shuqi: they renounced the lord of Gubu and starved to death on Mount Shouyang, their flesh and bones left unburied. Bao Jiao adorned his conduct to condemn the age and died embracing a tree. Shentu Di remonstrated but was not heeded; he carried a stone and drowned himself in the river, where fish and turtles fed on him. Jie Zitui was utterly loyal, cutting flesh from his thigh to feed Duke Wen, yet later the duke betrayed him. Enraged, Zitui departed and burned to death in a tree. Weisheng made a tryst with a woman beneath a bridge; when she did not come and the waters rose, he refused to leave and drowned clutching the pillar. These four men differ not from dismembered dogs or drifting swine, or beggars clutching gourd ladles—they all pursued fame and scorned death, heedless of preserving their lives and nurturing their longevity.

As for the world’s so-called loyal ministers, none surpass Prince Bigan and Wu Zixu. Zixu was drowned in the river, Bigan had his heart carved out—these two, whom the world calls loyal ministers, yet in the end became objects of ridicule. From the highest perspective, even Zixu and Bigan are not worthy of esteem.

As for what you, Qiu, have tried to persuade me with: if you spoke to me of ghostly matters, I would not understand them; if you spoke of human affairs, it would be no more than this—all things I have already heard. Now let me tell you of human nature: the eyes desire to see beauty, the ears to hear sound, the mouth to savor taste, and the will to be fulfilled. The longest-lived reach a hundred years, the average eighty, the shortest sixty. Subtracting illness, emaciation, mourning, death, and sorrow, the days one opens one’s mouth to laugh in a month number no more than four or five. Heaven and earth are without end, yet human death comes at its appointed time. Clutching this finite vessel and entrusting it to the boundless, it vanishes in an instant, no different from a swift steed galloping past a crack in the wall. Those who cannot delight their will and nurture their lives are not masters of the Way.

All that you, Qiu, have said are things I reject. Hurry, leave, and return home—speak no more of it. Your Way is frantic and deceitful, a craft of falsehood and pretense, incapable of preserving the true. What is there to discuss?

Confucius bowed twice, hastened away, exited the gate, and mounted his carriage. Three times he fumbled the reins, his eyes blank and sightless, his complexion ashen, his head bowed against the crossbar, unable to catch his breath. Returning to the eastern gate of Lu, he encountered Liuxia Ji. Liuxia Ji said, "You have been absent for days. Your carriage and horses bear the marks of travel—did you by chance go to see Zhi?"

Confucius looked up to the heavens and sighed, "Yes."

Liuxia Ji said, "Did Zhi perhaps offend you as before?"

Confucius replied, "Yes."

Qiu, what you speak of is like needlessly cauterizing oneself when free of illness. You rush to measure the tiger’s head and braid its whiskers—how nearly did you escape its jaws? To "enter the fortress" means to shut the gates and guard oneself. "The heart like a gushing spring" describes qi in its full vigor. "The intent like a whirling wind" conveys the sense of hollow arrogance and frivolous pride. "Falsely invoking Wen and Wu" means to claim falsely the Way of Kings Wen and Wu as one’s own. "Branch-wood" refers to stripping bark from tree branches to fashion a cap. "Ox-flank" is oxhide. "Found favor with Ji" means to have grown close to Liuxia Ji. "Gazing at his sandals in deference" describes how, upon a single audience with Liuxia Ji, one would long for even the sight of his footwear—this is the language of repeated pleas for an audience. "Knowledge encompasses heaven and earth" means that one’s knowledge can embrace heaven and earth, leaving nothing beyond its scope. "Able to distinguish all things" means that one’s talent can discern the names of all things—implying omniscience. "In the end" refers to the final outcome. "Yu’s partial paralysis" alludes to his calloused hands and feet. "Who would debate it in detail?" means to examine it thoroughly. "Dismembering dogs and butchering swine" describes how one’s own death resembles the slaughter of dogs and pigs. "Holding a gourd to beg" signifies seeking from others. "Detached" means clinging—being mired in fame, hence "detached from fame." "Not contemplating the root" means failing to recognize one’s original, true nature. "Frantic" is synonymous with restless. "Three times he fumbled the reins" means the reins repeatedly slipped from his grasp. "His carriage and horses bore the marks of travel" suggests the appearance of one who had set out and was only now returning. "By chance" means "perhaps"—"Did you by chance go to see Zhi?" "As before" refers to what had been said previously. "As I said before..."

Zizhang asked Mang Goude, "Why not cultivate conduct?" Mang Goude replied, "Without conduct, there is no trust; without trust, no appointment; without appointment, no profit. Thus, when one observes fame and calculates advantage, righteousness is indeed the truth. If one abandons fame and profit and turns inward to the heart, then the scholar’s conduct cannot be neglected for a single day." Mang Goude said, "The shameless grow rich, and the deceitful gain prominence. The greatest fame and profit lie in shamelessness and deceit. Thus, when one observes fame and calculates advantage, trust is indeed the truth. If one abandons fame and profit and turns inward to the heart, then the scholar’s conduct embraces the heavens." Zizhang said, "In ancient times, Jie and Zhou were exalted as Sons of Heaven, possessing all under heaven. Yet if one were to tell Zang Ju, ‘Your conduct resembles Jie and Zhou,’ he would flush with shame. Such disdain marks the baseness of petty men. Confucius and Mo Di lived in poverty as commoners, yet if one were to tell a prime minister, ‘Your conduct resembles Confucius and Mo Di,’ his expression would change, and his color shift. Such praise is deemed insufficient—for the scholar, true nobility lies therein. Thus, to hold the power of the Son of Heaven does not necessarily confer nobility, nor does poverty as a commoner necessarily mean baseness. The distinction between noble and base rests in the goodness or evil of one’s conduct." Mang Goude said, "Petty thieves are imprisoned, while great thieves become lords. At the gates of lords, righteous scholars reside. In former times, Duke Huan of Qi, Xiaobai, killed his brother and took his sister-in-law, yet Guan Zhong served as his minister. Tian Chengzi murdered his lord and usurped the state, yet Confucius accepted his gifts."

To condemn in speech yet defer in conduct—this is the contradiction of words and deeds warring within the breast. Is this not perverse?

Thus the Book says: "Who is vile? Who is noble? The successful become the head, the failed the tail." Zizhang said, "If you do not act, kinship and affection will lack order, noble and base will lack righteousness, elder and younger will lack sequence—how then shall the Five Constants and Six Positions be distinguished?" Mang Goude replied: "Yao killed his eldest son, Shun exiled his younger brother—where is the order in kinship? Tang punished Jie, King Wu slew Zhou—where is the righteousness in noble and base? King Ji was the rightful heir, yet the Duke of Zhou killed his elder brother—where is the sequence in elder and younger? The Confucians preach hypocritical words, the Mohists advocate universal love—how can the Five Constants and Six Positions be distinguished? Moreover, you rectify for the sake of reputation, I rectify for the sake of profit. The substance of reputation and profit does not accord with principle, nor does it reflect the Dao. Daily I dispute with you before Wu Yue, saying: 'The petty man dies for wealth, the gentleman dies for reputation.' Though their motives for altering their nature differ, when they abandon what they should do to die for what they should not, they are the same. Thus it is said: 'Do not be a petty man, and in turning back, follow Heaven. Do not be a gentleman, and follow Heaven’s principle.' Whether crooked or straight, they form the ultimate pattern of Heaven. Observe the four directions, and move with the seasons. Whether right or wrong, grasp the round mechanism. Alone in your intent, wander with the Dao. Do not turn against the Way in action, do not seek success in righteousness—you will lose what you strive for. Do not rush toward wealth, do not die for success—you will abandon your Heaven. Bi Gan was disemboweled, Wu Zixu had his eyes gouged out—such are the calamities of loyalty. Zhigong testified against his father, Weisheng drowned—such are the disasters of trustworthiness. Master Bao stood rigid, Shen Buhai did not defend himself—such are the harms of integrity. Confucius did not see his mother, Kuangzi did not see his father—such are the failures of righteousness. These are the tales handed down from high antiquity, the lessons repeated in later ages to instruct scholars: rectify your words and align your conduct, yet they still suffer misfortune and encounter disaster.

Why not act? Why not cultivate virtue and conduct? To observe reputation and calculate profit, only righteousness is truly right. If a man abandons reputation and profit, he reverses his heart’s desires and finds no joy—he must seek them, and only through righteous conduct can he do so. This is the intent of those who study to obtain office. The trustworthy become eminent—this means using trustworthy words to seek glory. Such words feign trustworthiness for self-interest. Zizhang speaks of seeking profit through righteousness, while Mang Goude says that those who seek reputation and profit today do so through deceit alone.

If one claims to abandon reputation and profit yet reverses his heart’s desires, insisting on obtaining them, then following the heart’s desires in a self-satisfied, opportunistic scheme is still to embrace one’s natural Heaven, free from artifice. Thus it is said: "Hold fast to your Heaven." Petty thieves are imprisoned, great thieves become lords—this is the argument from the *Opening the Trunk* chapter. The contradiction of words and deeds warring within the breast means that actions disregard words, and words disregard actions. "The successful become the head, the failed the tail"—this is what was previously called "those who seize the moment are righteous followers, those who miss it are usurpers." The underlying meaning is that acts of benevolence and righteousness are all deceitful and artificial, not natural Heaven.

The Five Constants are the five virtues; the Six Positions are the Three Bonds—ruler and minister, father and son, husband and wife. "You rectify for the sake of reputation" means you seek to obtain through the name of benevolence and righteousness, while I seek only profit, without feigning such names. Both reputation and profit are not true principles, thus it is said: "The substance of reputation and profit does not accord with principle, nor does it reflect the Dao." Wu Yue means unrestrained, following nature. Mang Goude and Wu Yue are names with implied meanings, like "Knowing Non-Action" in the previous chapter.

"Abandoning what one should do" means forsaking what one ought to do, failing to preserve life and protect one’s nature. "Dying for what one should not do" refers to pursuing profit and reputation, which are not what one should do. Following Heaven’s natural principle eliminates the distinction between gentleman and petty man, thus it is said: "Do not be a petty man, and in turning back, follow Heaven. Do not be a gentleman, and follow Heaven’s principle." This means neither being a gentleman nor a petty man, so one can follow the natural principle of Heaven.

Whether crooked or straight, when viewed in relation to one another, they are all the ultimate principle of Heaven. Thus it is said: "Whether crooked or straight, they form the ultimate pattern of Heaven." The four directions each have their place, and the seasons of spring, summer, autumn, and winter belong to them—ebb and flow are all of a single qi. Thus it is said: "Observe the four directions, and move with the seasons." Grasping the round mechanism eliminates right and wrong, thus it is said: "Whether right or wrong, grasp the round mechanism." Acting on true intent alone, one attains the Dao, thus it is said: "Alone in your intent, wander with the Dao."

"Turning" means going against. Acting against the Dao, self-righteously seeking success, one loses what is truly natural. Thus it is said: "Do not turn against the Way in action, do not seek success in righteousness—you will lose what you strive for." Rushing toward wealth and dying for success will cause one to lose one’s natural Heaven. Thus it is said: "Do not rush toward wealth, do not die for success—you will abandon your Heaven." "Do not" means "do not act thus," an expression of prohibition.

"Rectifying one’s words" means taking loyal, trustworthy, virtuous, and righteous words as true. "Aligning one’s conduct" means acting with loyalty, trustworthiness, virtue, and righteousness. "Suffer" means to endure; "encounter" means to adhere. Thus one inevitably meets with misfortune and disaster. Why not act? Why not cultivate virtue and conduct? Observing reputation and calculating profit, only righteousness is truly right. If a man abandons reputation and profit, he reverses his heart’s desires and finds no joy—he must seek them, and only through righteous conduct can he do so. This is the intent of those who study to obtain office. The trustworthy become eminent—this means using trustworthy words to seek glory. Such words feign trustworthiness for self-interest. Zizhang speaks of seeking profit through righteousness, while Mang Goude says that those who seek reputation and profit today do so through deceit alone.

Zizhang sought to practice righteousness to attain wealth and recognition, borrowing the language of seeking office to lend it a name. Those who are content with mere acquisition treat such opportunism as the natural Way, thus framing their arguments in question-and-answer form. Their intent is to claim that feigning virtue to gain advantage is inferior to following one’s true nature. This distorts Mencius’ distinction between the Heavenly office and the human office.

Wu Zu asked Zhi He: “No man is without the impulse to pursue fame and profit. The wealthy attract followers; followers submit to them; submission leads to reverence. To be revered and submitted to—this is the Way to long life, bodily ease, and joy of mind. Yet you alone show no interest. Is your wisdom insufficient? Or do you understand but lack the strength to act? Why do you persist in upholding principle without letting go?”

Zhi He replied: “These men you speak of—born in the same era, dwelling in the same land—believe themselves to be transcendent sages beyond the common world. Yet they lack any guiding principle, drifting with the times to judge right and wrong. They conform to worldly customs, abandoning what is most weighty and most noble, all for the sake of their pursuits. How can such conduct be the Way to long life, bodily ease, and joy of mind? Grief and sorrow, contentment and joy—these are not reflected in their bodies. Fear and dread, delight and apprehension—these are not mirrored in their hearts. They know how to act but not *why* they act. Thus, though they may be honored as Son of Heaven and possess all under Heaven, they cannot escape suffering.

‘Persisting in upholding principle without letting go’ means: Do you truly lack the wisdom to desire wealth and honor? Or do you *know* this path but lack the power to follow it? Thus, I press the right principle to curb the craving for wealth and status, yet you cannot forget it. These men—these wealthy and honored men—live in the same world and the same land as I do. They are not sages who transcend the age; they are no higher than anyone else. My point is that they are ordinary men, and I am no less aware of this than you. Their hearts have no fixed anchor, no grasp of the true nature of life and destiny. They merely chase the trends of the moment to secure their own advantage, swept along by the tide of custom. Their judgments of right and wrong are self-serving, weighing past and present to seek personal gain. What is most weighty and most noble—the natural principle of Heaven—they cast aside, all for the sake of their pursuit of wealth and status. How can this be the Way to long life, bodily ease, and peace of mind?

Those who seek wealth and status may experience bodily comfort or distress, joy or sorrow, yet they remain blind to it all, unable to perceive themselves. Thus it is said: ‘not reflected in their bodies, not reflected in their hearts.’ They know *how* to act—through human effort—but not *why* they act—the principle of Heaven. Even the Son of Heaven, knowing only human effort and not Heaven’s principle, cannot escape harm to his person. How much less can those beneath him?

Wu Zu said: “Wealth brings every advantage to man. It exhausts beauty and exhausts power, reaching what even the most accomplished cannot attain, surpassing what the worthiest cannot match. It harnesses others’ strength to amplify its might, wields others’ wisdom to sharpen its discernment, and appropriates others’ virtue to adorn its goodness. Though not a ruler, it commands awe like a sovereign. Moreover, the allure of sensual pleasures, fine flavors, and power over men’s hearts is innate—no learning is needed to delight in them, no model is required to find them agreeable. Desires and aversions, attraction and avoidance—these are not taught; they are man’s nature. Though all the world may oppose me, who can renounce them?”

Zhi He replied: “The actions of the wise are always for the sake of the people, never transgressing the proper measure. Thus, they have enough and do not contend; having no ulterior motive, they do not seek. Those who lack, seek; they vie for every opportunity yet do not consider themselves greedy. Those who have enough, decline; they renounce all under Heaven yet do not consider themselves noble. True nobility or greed is not imposed from without—it is a reflection of one’s own measure.

Though possessing the power of the Son of Heaven, they do not use their rank to domineer over others. Though owning all under Heaven, they do not flaunt their wealth to toy with men. They weigh the consequences, consider the repercussions, and recognize the harm to their nature. Thus, they decline and do not accept—not to seek fame. Yao and Shun ruled as emperors yet remained at ease, not out of benevolence toward the world, but to avoid allowing beauty to harm their lives. Shan Juan and Xu You declined the throne, not out of empty modesty, but to avoid allowing affairs to harm themselves. All of them pursued what benefited them and declined what harmed them. Though the world calls them worthy, they did not act to cultivate reputation.

Here, Wu Zu speaks not of honor but only of wealth. ‘Exhausting beauty’ means indulging every desire; ‘exhausting power’ means exercising every prerogative. Even the most accomplished and worthy cannot match this—it speaks to the sheer force at one’s disposal. ‘Harnessing others’ and ‘wielding others’ both describe how wealth can command men, embodying the idea of ‘moving even the gods.’ Desire for wealth and aversion to poverty, fleeing poverty and pursuing wealth—these require no instruction, for they are not learned from a teacher. They arise from the spontaneity of human nature. Though all the world may condemn it, how can I renounce it?” This is the argument of the greedy.

Wu Zu—whose name means ‘Never Enough’—and those like ‘Content with Mere Acquisition’ are insatiable. The actions of the wise are always guided by what the people share from Heaven, never daring to transgress the proper measure.

The people’s shared endowment from Heaven consists of tangible things and their inherent principles—measure is principle. To be content and not contend means one’s virtue suffices for oneself, leaving nothing to dispute. To act without purpose is not to seek action; this lies not in man but in Heaven, for human effort plays no part—hence “to act without purpose.” Recognizing that human effort plays no part, one ceases to seek. If what lies within oneself is insufficient, one may exhaust the four quarters in pursuit without being deemed greedy—this is the pursuit of virtue, the search for what lies within. When virtue suffices and overflows, one renounces all external things; even if one were to renounce the world, it would not be for comfort.

These two—seeking sustenance and comfort—are not pursued for others, nor do they involve external striving; rather, they both return to the principles and measures of Heaven’s pattern and reflect upon them—hence “returning to reflect upon the measure.” To dazzle others with wealth is to stir the world. To consider the reverse is to turn inward and reflect. *Yong* means the people at peace in times of change. Not allowing beauty to harm life means acting without contrivance, not letting a fine reputation harm oneself, and possessing the world without clinging to it. One *can* possess it, for the worthy name of the world can be rightfully claimed without shame. Such conduct in the Dao and virtue arises from the sincerity of the heart, not from seeking to establish fame.

Here again, Yao, Shun, and Xu You are all treated as fond of persuasion. Wu Zu says: “One who clings to reputation, hardens the body, rejects sweetness, and restricts nourishment to preserve life is like one long afflicted by chronic illness yet does not die.” Zhi He says: “Balance brings fortune; excess brings harm—nothing is otherwise, and wealth is the most extreme case. Now the rich man’s ears are filled with the sounds of bells, drums, pipes, and flutes; his mouth savors the flavors of fine meats and wines, stirring his mind and causing him to neglect his affairs—this may be called disorder. Overwhelmed by pent-up *qi*, he labors like one bearing a heavy load uphill—this may be called suffering. Coveting wealth, he exhausts himself; grasping for power, he depletes himself. In quietude, he drowns; in abundance, he swells—this may be called sickness. Driven by the desire for wealth and profit, he rushes forward like one with ears blocked, unable to avoid danger, pressing on relentlessly—this may be called disgrace. Wealth accumulates yet goes unused; he clings to it without release, his heart filled with sorrow and distress, ever seeking more without cease—this may be called anxiety. Within, he fears the threats of extortion and robbery; without, he dreads bandits and thieves. His inner chambers are fortified, and he dares not walk alone—this may be called fear. These six are the greatest harms in the world, yet they are forgotten and left unexamined. When calamity strikes, one seeks to exhaust one’s nature and deplete one’s wealth to return to a single day of carefree ease—but it cannot be obtained.

Thus, when one gazes upon reputation, it is not seen; when one seeks profit, it is not gained. Yet one strains the mind and exhausts the body in contention for these—is this not delusion? ‘Clinging to reputation’ means insisting on seeking fame while forsaking the benefits of wealth and honor, thereby needlessly tormenting oneself—though alive, one is like one gravely ill. ‘Rejecting sweetness’ means forgoing fine flavors. ‘Restricting nourishment’ means frugality in self-care. ‘Long afflicted by chronic illness yet does not die’ echoes the *Yijing*’s ‘steadfast in illness, ever undying.’ Balance brings fortune; excess brings harm—nothing is otherwise, and wealth is the most extreme case.

Though this passage’s branches and leaves are somewhat coarse, falling short of the *Rang Wang* and *Yu Fu*, even a single line here is well-phrased—how could it be erased? *Qian* means to stuff the mouth full. The monkey’s cheek is called *qian*. ‘Stirring his mind’ means agitating his thoughts, implying enslavement of the heart. ‘Neglecting his affairs’ means forsaking what he ought to do. *Feng qi* means angering the *qi* so that it cannot flow. *Hai* means drowning, being ill at ease, like one carrying a heavy load uphill. ‘Seeking sufficiency’ means seeking fulfillment. ‘Seeking depletion’ means exhausting all. As the common saying goes, ‘Do not use all your power.’ ‘In quietude, he drowns’ means being unable to endure idleness and sinking into desires. ‘In abundance, he swells’ means that when the body is plump and sleek, it becomes full and arrogant. ‘High as a wall’ means wealth piled high like a wall—what is called ‘that thing by the bed.’ ‘Unable to avoid’ means insatiable, ever pursuing without cease. *Feng* means reliance. Relying on this for boasting, he cannot let go. ‘Clinging without release’ means constant remembrance, never forgotten. ‘Constant remembrance’ means only seeing sorrow and distress filling the heart—hence ‘the heart filled with sorrow and distress.’ So afflicted, he still seeks more without cease. *Cha qing* means extortion and robbery.”

Those who hoard within their houses, fearing robbers, construct lofts and lattice windows all around their chambers. When transporting goods abroad, fearing great bandits, they must assemble a retinue of followers and dare not travel alone. *Shu* means windows; *lou* refers to the upper stories of walls.

These six are called chaos, suffering, illness, disgrace, sorrow, and fear. "Neglected and unexamined" means losing all self-restraint without awareness. *Dan* means alone. *Dan* also signifies "merely," as in "mere affairs." *Fan* means to return. Once illness and misfortune have taken form, though one may seek to preserve life and relinquish wealth, merely longing for a single day’s return to the carefree poverty of former times is no longer possible.

"Exhausting one’s nature" means fully preserving life. *Jie* means to remove. "Reversed desire" means abandoning wealth to embrace poverty. By the time one reaches this point, where then is fame? Where then is profit? "Entangled thoughts and severed body" describes the binding of one’s body and mind. In the pursuit of profit, one merely ensnares body and mind, only to bring about such calamity—is this not folly?

Su Dongpo observed that the four chapters following *Rang Wang* were not the work of Zhuangzi, a judgment of great insight. Among these four, *Dao Zhi* is the most extreme, yet Sima Qian’s *Biography of Zhuangzi* merely states that he composed *Yu Fu*, *Dao Zhi*, and *Qu Qie* to slander and ridicule Confucius’s disciples, without the slightest doubt regarding the differences in refinement or consistency of the texts. Why is this? What was Zichang’s intent?

Moreover, did he speak of criticizing the Master merely to overlook the quality of the text? If not, then this book and this chapter, having survived into the Han dynasty and beyond, may have suffered from scattered fragments later interpolated by others—much like the *Liezi* of today.

**Miscellaneous Chapters: "Discourse on Swords"**
Formerly, King Wen of Zhao delighted in swords. Swordsmen thronged his gates as retainers, numbering over three thousand. Day and night, they clashed before him, with over a hundred dying or wounded each year. His obsession knew no end, and after three years of this, the state declined, and the feudal lords plotted against him. The crown prince, Kui, grew anxious and offered a reward to his attendants: "Whoever can persuade the king to abandon his fondness for swordsmen shall receive six thousand gold pieces." His attendants replied, "Zhuangzi would be capable of this."

The crown prince then sent envoys bearing a thousand gold pieces to present to Zhuangzi, but Zhuangzi declined and accompanied the messengers back. Meeting the crown prince, he said, "What instruction does the prince have for Zhou, that he offers Zhou a thousand gold pieces?" The crown prince replied, "I have heard that you, Master, are enlightened and sagely. I humbly present this thousand gold as a gift for your attendants. If you refuse, how dare I speak further?"

Zhuangzi said, "I have heard that the prince wishes to employ Zhou to end the king’s obsession. If I were to persuade the king but contradict his will, or fail to please the prince, I would face execution. How then could I accept the gold? But if I persuade the king and satisfy the prince, what in Zhao could I not obtain?"

The crown prince said, "Indeed. What my king sees are only swordsmen."

Zhuangzi replied, "Very well. Zhou is skilled in the sword."

The crown prince said, "Yet the swordsmen my king favors all have unkempt hair, bristling sideburns, drooping caps, tassels of coarse silk, short-backed robes, glaring eyes, and speak in harsh tones. The king delights in them. If you, Master, appear before him in Confucian garb, the matter will surely go awry."

Zhuangzi said, "Permit me to prepare sword attire." After three days of preparing his sword attire, he appeared before the crown prince, who then presented him to the king. The king, gripping his unsheathed blade, awaited him.

Zhuangzi entered the palace gates without haste and did not bow upon seeing the king. The king said, "What would you teach me, that the crown prince has gone before you?"

Zhuangzi replied, "I have heard that Your Majesty delights in swords, so I have come to present my swordsmanship."

The king asked, "What can your sword do to restrain or control?"

Zhuangzi said, "My sword can strike down one man every ten paces and traverse a thousand *li* without hindrance."

The king, greatly pleased, exclaimed, "You would be invincible in the world!"

Zhuangzi said, "For the swordsman, one displays emptiness, entices with advantage, strikes after the opponent moves, and arrives before the opponent. I wish to demonstrate this."

The king said, "Rest now, Master."

He was lodged in the guest quarters to await the king’s command. The king then ordered a sword exhibition to be arranged and invited the Master. Over seven days, the king assembled swordsmen, of whom over sixty were killed or wounded, leaving only five or six. These were made to present their swords at the palace steps, and then Zhuangzi was summoned.

The king said, “Today, let us have the warriors test their swords in contest.”

Zhuangzi replied, “I have long awaited this.”

The king asked, “What length of weapon does the Master wield?”

Zhuangzi said, “Any length I am given will suffice. Yet I possess three swords, and whichever the king chooses to employ, I shall first describe and then demonstrate.”

The king said, “I would hear of the three swords.”

Zhuangzi said, “There is the Sword of the Son of Heaven, the Sword of the Feudal Lords, and the Sword of the Common Folk.”

The king asked, “What is the Sword of the Son of Heaven like?”

Zhuangzi said, “The Sword of the Son of Heaven has its blade forged from Yanxi and Shicheng, its edge from Mount Tai of Qi, its spine from Jin and Wei, its guard from Zhou and Song, and its hilt from Han and Wei.
