It is bound by the Four Barbarians, wrapped in the Four Seasons, encircled by the Bohai Sea, and girded by Mount Chang. Its governance follows the Five Phases, its judgments balance punishment and virtue, its opening aligns with yin and yang, its grasp is held in spring and summer, and its execution proceeds in autumn and winter. This sword, when thrust, knows no forward obstacle; when raised, knows no height above; when pressed, knows no depth below; when swung, knows no side beside. Above, it cleaves the floating clouds; below, it severs the earth’s foundations. When this sword is once employed, it rectifies the feudal lords, and all under heaven submits. Such is the Sword of the Son of Heaven.”

King Wen, dazed and self-abashed, asked, “And what of the Sword of the Feudal Lords?”

Zhuangzi said, “The Sword of the Feudal Lords has its blade in the wisdom and courage of knights, its edge in the purity and integrity of scholars, its spine in the worthiness and goodness of gentlemen, its guard in the loyalty and sagacity of ministers, and its hilt in the heroism and valor of warriors. This sword, when thrust, likewise knows no forward obstacle; when raised, no height above; when pressed, no depth below; when swung, no side beside. Above, it models the round heavens, following the Three Luminaries; below, it models the square earth, aligning with the Four Seasons; within, it discerns the people’s will, bringing peace to the four quarters. When this sword is once employed, it strikes like the thunder’s shock, and within the four borders, none fail to submit and heed their lord’s command. Such is the Sword of the Feudal Lords.”

The king asked, “And what of the Sword of the Common Folk?”

Zhuangzi said, “The Sword of the Common Folk is wielded by those with disheveled hair and unkempt topknots, their caps askew, their tassels coarse and rough, their robes short and trailing. They glare fiercely and speak in challenge. They clash before one another, striking above at necks and throats, below at livers and lungs. This sword of the common folk differs not from cockfighting—one life is lost in a day, and it serves no purpose in the affairs of state. Now, though Your Majesty holds the position of the Son of Heaven, you delight in the sword of the common folk. I humbly deem this unworthy of Your Majesty.”

Thereupon, the king led Zhuangzi up to the hall. The royal steward presented the feast, and the king circled the table thrice. Zhuangzi said, “May Your Majesty sit composed and settle your qi. The matter of the sword has now been presented in full.”

From that day, King Wen did not leave the palace for three months, and the swordsmen all prostrated themselves and perished where they stood. Those who delighted in the sword were fond of such swordplay as sport. To "flank the gates" means to crowd the gates. Over three thousand swordsmen, treating their swordsmanship as a profession, were retained as guests at the king’s gates. "With gifts as followers" refers to those who received such offerings as their stipend, akin to what is now called "rewarding followers." "Disheveled hair and unkempt topknots" describes their hair and sideburns left exposed. "Caps askew" means their headgear was not properly raised, like a wrapped kerchief today. "Tassels" are what hang beneath the neck. "Coarse and rough" describes their uncouth manner. "Short and trailing robes" means their garments were not hemmed. "Speaking in challenge" refers to their verbal provocations when seeking combat. "Displaying emptiness and enticing with advantage" means luring the opponent forward with an opening. "Striking after the opponent moves yet arriving first" describes the raptor’s crouch before it strikes. "Arranging the exhibition" means setting up the swordplay display. "Testing swords" refers to the decisive clash of blades. "Wielding the weapon" means to use and grasp it. "Blade" refers to the sword’s tip. "Edge" is the cutting part. "Guard" is the sword’s mouth. "Hilt" is the sword’s handle. "Wrapped in the Four Seasons" signifies its use is timely. "Governed by the Five Phases" means it follows the principles of the Five Phases. The sun represents virtue, the moon punishment; the sun and moon embody yin and yang, and spring, summer, autumn, and winter all accord with the natural order of creation. "Thrusting, raising, pressing, and swinging" all describe the sword’s vast and boundless application. "Dazed and self-abashed" means that upon hearing such grand discourse, the king realized the shallowness of his own preferences and thus felt abashed. "Above modeling heaven, below modeling earth, and within harmonizing the people’s will" corresponds to the harmony of heaven’s timing, earth’s advantage, and human accord. "The four quarters" refers to the four directions. "Led up to the hall" means he was drawn upward. "Circling thrice" means he did not sit but walked three times around the place where the food was set, an expression of his shame. "Prostrated" shares the same meaning as "submitted"; since the king no longer favored such displays, the swordsmen all withdrew and perished in their quarters.

**Miscellaneous Chapters: The Fisherman**

Confucius wandered in the Ziwei Forest and rested, sitting upon the Apricot Platform. His disciples read their books while Confucius strummed his zither and sang, playing a melody not yet halfway through when a fisherman descended from his boat and approached. His temples and brows were mingled with white, his hair unbound, and his sleeves swaying as he walked. Ascending from the marshland, he stopped at the shore, his left hand resting on his knee, his right hand supporting his chin, listening. When the song ended, he beckoned to Zilu and Zigong. Both responded, and the stranger pointed at Confucius, asking, “What is that man doing?”

Zilu replied, “He is a gentleman of Lu.”

The stranger asked about his clan.

Zilu answered, “His clan is Kong.”

“And what does the Kong clan govern?”

Zilu did not respond, but Zigong answered, “The Kong clan cultivates loyalty and trust in nature, embodies benevolence and righteousness in conduct, refines ritual and music, and selects the principles of human relations. Above, they serve the rulers of the age with loyalty; below, they transform the common people, seeking to benefit the world. This is what the Kong clan governs.”

The stranger then asked, “Is he a lord with lands?”

Zigong said, “No.”

“Is he an advisor to kings and princes?”

Zigong said, “No.”

The stranger laughed and turned away, walking off as he spoke: “Benevolent, indeed, he is—but I fear he will not escape harm to himself. His heart labors and his form toils, endangering his true nature. Alas, how far he is from the Dao!”

Zigong returned and reported this to Confucius. Confucius pushed aside his zither and rose, saying, “Is he a sage?” He then descended to seek him, reaching the marsh’s edge. The fisherman was just then poising his pole to draw his boat when he turned and saw Confucius standing with his face toward home. Confucius retreated a few steps, then advanced and bowed twice.

The stranger said, “What do you seek?”

Confucius replied, “Earlier, sir, you left with words unfinished. I, unworthy as I am, did not understand. I have secretly waited here, hoping to hear even the sound of your cough or sigh, that I might receive your instruction to the end.”

The stranger said, “Ah! How earnest is your love of learning!”

Confucius bowed twice and rose, saying, “From my youth I have cultivated learning until now, at sixty-nine years of age. Yet I have never heard the ultimate teaching. How dare I not be humble in heart?”

The stranger said, “Like attracts like, and like sounds resonate—this is the principle of heaven. Let me set aside what I possess and explain to you what you should know. What you should know concerns human affairs. The Son of Heaven, the feudal lords, the great officers, and the common people—these four ranks are the perfection of proper governance. If these four abandon their positions, no greater disorder can arise. When officials govern their duties and people attend to their tasks, none encroach upon another. Thus, fields lie fallow and homes stand exposed, clothing and food are insufficient, taxes and levies are unmet, wives and concubines are discordant, and elders and juniors lack order—these are the worries of the common people. Inability to fulfill one’s role, official duties left undone, conduct that is not pure, subordinates who are negligent, achievements unrecognized, ranks and emoluments unstable—these are the worries of the great officers. The court lacks loyal ministers, the state is benighted and disordered, craftsmen lack skill, tribute is unworthy, seasonal rites are delayed or out of order, and the Son of Heaven is not obeyed—these are the worries of the feudal lords. Yin and yang are not in harmony, cold and heat arrive untimely, harming all things; feudal lords act with violence and disorder, seizing and attacking one another, ravaging the people; ritual and music lack moderation, resources are exhausted, human relations are unrefined, and the hundred clans are licentious—these are the worries of the Son of Heaven’s ministers.

Now, you possess neither the authority of a lord or minister above nor the office of a great officer below, yet you presume to refine ritual and music, select the principles of human relations, and transform the common people. Is this not overreaching?

Moreover, people have eight flaws, and affairs have four perils—these cannot be left unexamined.

To meddle in affairs that are not one’s own is called *zong* (meddlesomeness);
To advance where none heed you is called *ning* (obsequiousness);
To guide speech by anticipating others’ wishes is called *chan* (flattery);
To speak without discerning right or wrong is called *yu* (sycophancy);
To delight in speaking of others’ faults is called *chan* (slander);
To sever friendships and divide kin is called *zei* (treachery);
To praise falsely and deceive, leading others to ruin, is called *te* (depravity);
To fail to distinguish good from bad, accommodating both sides, stealthily seizing what one desires, is called *xian* (perfidy).

These eight flaws externally confuse others and internally harm oneself. The noble person does not befriend such people, nor does the enlightened ruler employ them.

As for the four perils:
To love undertaking great affairs, altering and changing the constant, seeking to hang one’s name upon achievements, is called *tao* (presumptuousness);
To monopolize knowledge, arrogate affairs, encroach upon others, and act on one’s own, is called *tan* (greed);
To see one’s faults yet not change, and to hear admonition yet grow worse, is called *hen* (obduracy);
To approve of what accords with oneself and disapprove of what does not, even if it is good, is called *jin* (arrogance).

These are the four perils. Only when one has cast off the eight flaws and refrains from the four perils can one begin to be taught.

*Ziwei* is the name of the forest. *Yumei* means to swing one’s sleeves. *Selecting human relations* means choosing their principles to teach people. *Walking and speaking* means departing without telling Zigong and Zilu, speaking as he went. *How far he is from the Dao* means he is distant from the Dao. *Na* is a boat pole. *Retreating and walking* means stepping back a few paces before advancing. *Unfinished words* refers to brief remarks that were not exhaustive. *To the end assist so-and-so* means to ultimately teach and aid that person. *Like attracts like, like sounds resonate* means this principle is shared by all people. *Setting aside what I possess* means putting aside the Dao I possess. *Explaining what you should know* means systematically presenting what people ought to know. *Setting aside* means to let go and not speak of it. *Systematically presenting* means to arrange in order. The *four ranks being proper* means each fulfills its duty; the *four ranks abandoning their positions* means they encroach upon one another’s affairs. Each office governs its own duty, and each person attends to their own task. *Worry* means to think. The *Book of Songs* says, “In office, think of its worries.” *None encroach upon another* means none usurp or seize from one another. *Taxes and levies unmet* means they are not continuous.

Not claiming credit for achievements is to have no merit. *Not holding fast* means being unable to maintain and guard. *Spring and Autumn out of order* means the sequence of court audiences is lost. *The Son of Heaven’s officials* refers to the Son of Heaven’s dukes and ministers. *Taking up what is not one’s affair* is called meddling—presuming to handle what is not one’s own business. *Advancing without being heeded* means forcing one’s words forward without being asked, flaunting one’s eloquence. *Flattery* is glib speech. *Sowing discord* means severing others’ close relationships. *Harming* means to injure. *False praise* means praising what should not be praised, a private act of deception. *Slandering* is like disgracing—destroying what should not be destroyed. When slander and praise arise from private motives, they are nothing but treachery. *Concealing* is deceit. *Adapting one’s countenance to others’ preferences* is called *facial compliance*. *Pleasing all without distinction* means courting favor with both good and bad alike, hence *two-faced*. *Probing others’ desires and subtly encouraging them* fosters their faults—such a person is treacherous. These *eight flaws* refer to eight grave moral diseases. *The noble person does not befriend them*—the noble person should not associate with such people. *The enlightened ruler does not employ them*—petty men must not be used, for they will surely throw the state into chaos.

*Delighting in great affairs* means taking pleasure in managing the state’s major matters. *Constantly altering and changing* means altering established laws to set up one’s own high reputation—*hanging* means elevating. *Presumptuous* means shameful. *Relying solely on private judgment*, monopolizing authority, encroaching on others’ power while delighting in self-assertion—this is greed. *Obstinate* means stubborn and refusing admonition. *Even when others have virtue*, if it differs from one’s own, one deems it unvirtuous—this is self-aggrandizement. These *four* are humanity’s great failings. Only by removing these flaws and perils can one begin to study the Dao, hence it is said, “Only then may one be taught.”

All these are what you should employ in navigating the world, hence it is said, “what you should use.” *Employing* means using them to examine oneself.

Confucius sighed deeply, bowed twice, and rose, saying: “I was twice exiled from Lu, my traces erased in Wei, my tree felled in Song, and I was besieged in Chen and Cai. I do not know what fault of mine brought these four slanders upon me—why was this?”

The guest’s expression turned somber as he replied: “How difficult it is for you to awaken! There was a man who feared his shadow and loathed his footprints, so he ran to escape them. The more he lifted his feet, the more footprints he made; the faster he ran, the more his shadow clung to him. Believing he was still too slow, he ran without rest until he collapsed and died. He did not know that by standing in the shade he could rest his shadow, and by remaining still he could cease his footprints—how utterly foolish!

You scrutinize the boundaries between benevolence and righteousness, examine the divisions of similarity and difference, observe the changes of movement and stillness, adjust the measures of giving and receiving, order the passions of like and dislike, and harmonize the moderation of joy and anger—yet you nearly could not avoid calamity. If you carefully cultivate yourself and guard your true nature, returning things to others, you will have no encumbrances. Now, instead of cultivating yourself, you seek from others—is this not misplaced?

*Not knowing what fault* means not knowing what error was committed. The *four slanders* refer to the four humiliations in Lu, Wei, Song, Chen, and Cai. *Standing in shade, remaining still*—this is a metaphor for the Dao. *Scrutinizing the boundaries between benevolence and righteousness* means debating the differing principles of benevolence and righteousness. *The divisions of similarity and difference* refer to the distinctions of right and wrong. *The changes of movement and stillness* mean adapting to the needs of the time. *The measures of giving and receiving* refer to the moderation of accepting and declining. *The passions of like and dislike, the moderation of joy and anger*—these clarify the principles of human nature.

The Fisherman’s meaning is that your actions, Master, are all for others rather than for yourself, which is why you could not escape the four slanders. If you cultivate yourself and guard your original, natural Dao, without opposition between self and others, you will have no encumbrances. *Returning things to others* means giving external things back to others and returning wholly to nature, so that self and others do not stand in opposition. Now, instead of seeking within yourself, you rush about serving others—this is attending to externals rather than internals.”

Confucius sighed deeply and said: “May I ask what is meant by *the true*?”

The guest replied: “The true is the utmost of sincerity. Without purity and sincerity, one cannot move others. Thus, forced weeping, though sorrowful, is not mournful; forced anger, though stern, lacks awe; forced affection, though smiling, is not harmonious. True sorrow is silent yet mournful; true anger, though unexpressed, is awe-inspiring; true affection, though not smiling, is harmonious. When the true resides within, the spirit moves without—this is why the true is prized.

Applied to human affairs: serving parents, it is filial devotion; serving a lord, it is loyalty; drinking wine, it is joy; mourning, it is grief. Loyalty is centered on accomplishment; drinking wine, on joy; mourning, on grief; serving parents, on suitability. When accomplishment is perfected, none resemble it; serving parents with suitability disregards the means; drinking wine with joy disregards the vessels; mourning with grief disregards the rites.

Rites are what the common customs establish; the true is what one receives from Heaven, natural and unalterable. Thus the sage models Heaven and prizes the true, not bound by custom. The foolish do the opposite: they cannot model Heaven but worry about people, not prizing the true, blindly following custom’s changes—hence they are inadequate. Alas! You were early immersed in human artifice and late to hear the great Dao.

Without purity and sincerity, one cannot move others—this is the meaning of utmost sincerity moving the spirits. *Forced weeping, forced anger, forced affection; true sorrow, true anger, true affection*—these six phrases are most precise. *When the true resides within, the spirit moves without*—what is within must manifest without. *The spirit moving* means the spirit is outwardly affected.

*Serving parents with suitability* means suiting the parents’ wishes.”

The beauty of accomplishment leaves no trace—it is achieved yet unpossessed, with no single act bearing its mark. *"Not selecting its instruments"* means not choosing its flavors. *"Without inquiring into its rites"*—between ease and sorrow, sorrow is preferable. Rites are mere adornments of externals, hence called the creations of worldly custom. The true is the principle of Heaven’s natural mandate. *"Modeling Heaven and prizing the true without being bound by custom"* means not being constrained by what worldly custom favors. *"Worrying about people"* means fretting over failing to conform to others. Not knowing the nobility of Heaven’s rank, one *"does not know to prize the true."* Taking worldly emoluments as one’s reward and willingly being transformed by vulgar custom—this is *"blindly following custom’s changes."* Such people are always seen as inadequate, their demeanor perpetually dissatisfied. *"Immersed in human artifice"* means drowning in learning that pursues externals.

Confucius bowed twice and rose, saying: *"Today I have been fortunate indeed. As if blessed by Heaven, you have not disdained to treat me as a servant, instructing me in person. Dare I ask where you dwell? I would follow and receive your teachings to complete my study of the great Dao."*

The stranger replied: *"I have heard that those who can be led may be guided to the subtle Dao; those who cannot be led do not understand the Way—beware of accompanying them, lest you bring harm upon yourself. Strive on, I leave you now, I leave you now."* With that, he poled his boat away, gliding along the reeds. Yan Yuan turned the carriage, and Zilu handed the reins, but Confucius did not look back, waiting until the water’s ripples stilled and the sound of the pole could no longer be heard before daring to board.

Zilu stepped beside the carriage and asked: *"I have long served you, yet never have I seen you meet someone with such reverence. Even rulers of ten thousand chariots or lords of a thousand, when they receive you, do not fail to observe proper courtesy, yet you still carry yourself with dignity. But today, this old fisherman stood with his staff facing you, and you bent at the waist, bowing deeply in response—was this not excessive? The disciples all find it strange. How has this fisherman earned such deference?"*

Confucius leaned on the crossbar and sighed: *"How difficult you are to transform, Zilu! You have been steeped in rites and righteousness for some time, yet your crude and rustic heart remains unchanged. Come closer, let me tell you: to meet an elder without respect is a breach of ritual; to meet a worthy without reverence is a lack of benevolence. If he were not a perfected person, he could not humble himself before others. Without utmost sincerity in humbling oneself, one cannot attain the true—thus one harms oneself for long. Alas, the lack of benevolence in a person! No greater misfortune exists, yet you alone cling to it. Moreover, the Dao is the path by which all things proceed. All beings that lose it die; those that attain it live. Acting against it brings failure; following it brings success. Thus, wherever the Dao resides, the sage honors it. This fisherman possesses the Dao—how could I not revere him? Comparing myself to a servant means treating him as a disciple. Asking where he dwells means inquiring about his abode. Gliding along the reeds describes poling the boat along the shore—a vivid four-character brushstroke. Waiting for the water’s ripples to still means the boat had gone far. 'Such reverence' refers to such awe and respect. 'Facing me' means standing directly opposite. Bowing in response means clasping hands in a bow. 'Steeped in rites and righteousness for some time' means you have long been immersed in the study of ritual and righteousness. 'If he were not a perfected person, he could not humble himself'—if this fisherman were not a perfected person, how could he elicit such deference and reverence? 'Without utmost sincerity in humbling oneself, one cannot attain the true'—only by wholeheartedly lowering oneself to seek instruction can one hope to hear true teachings. This is the foundation of learning. 'Thus one harms oneself for long' means that failing to do so brings no benefit to the self but only harm. The life and death of all things lie within the Dao, and the fisherman possesses it—thus I honor the Dao by revering him."*

From *"Yielding the Throne"* onward, the four chapters do not resemble Zhuangzi’s style. *"Yielding the Throne"* still contains one or two passages of merit, and *"The Old Fisherman"* also has its strengths, but *"Robber Zhi"* is even more distant from the truth than *"Discourse on Swords."* In *"Robber Zhi,"* the term *"prime minister"* is used, yet no such title existed in the Warring States period—this is clearly a later fabrication. The *Han Dynasty’s* *Art and Literature Annals* records fifty-two chapters of *Zhuangzi*, a number differing from the present text. The *Tang Dynasty* catalog lists only forty chapters, which are the ones now in circulation. It is unknown whether the fifty-two chapters included works like *"Yielding the Throne"* and *"Discourse on Swords,"* or if there were other chapters by Zhuangzi that have not survived.

---

When Lie Yukou was traveling to Qi, he turned back midway and encountered Bohun Maoren. Bohun Maoren asked: *"Why have you returned?"*

Lie Yukou replied: *"I was startled."*

*"What startled you?"*

*"I once drank at ten porridge stalls, and at five of them, they served me first."*

Bohun Maoren said: *"If that is so, why were you startled?"*

Lie Yukou replied: *"When inner sincerity is not dissolved, one’s demeanor shines with a radiant light, which externally pacifies others’ hearts, causing them to slight their elders and disregard their concerns. Those porridge-sellers merely peddle food and broth for profit—small gains from modest surpluses, their influence slight and their power light. Yet even they behaved thus—how much more so a ruler of ten thousand chariots? If I exhaust myself in service to the state and expend all my knowledge on affairs, he will entrust me with tasks and measure me by my achievements. That is why I was startled."*

Bohun Maoren said: *"A keen observation! If you conduct yourself thus, others will protect you."*

Not long after, when he went to visit, the shoes outside the door were piled high. Bohun Maoren stood facing north, leaning on his staff and pressing it against his chin. After standing for a while, he left without a word.

A visitor reported this to Liezi. Liezi, grasping his shoes, rushed barefoot to the gate and said: *"Master, since you have come, will you not dispense your remedy?"*

*"It is done,"* he replied. *"I had already told you that others would protect you—and so they have. It is not that you can make others protect you, nor that you cannot prevent them from doing so. What use is it to you? Their delight and surprise arise from your peculiarity. You must have stirred some response, disturbing your fundamental nature—all to no purpose. Those who wander with you offer no true counsel; their petty words are all poison to men. None awaken, none comprehend—how could they scrutinize one another? The cunning toil and the wise fret, while the incapable seek nothing. They eat and roam freely, drifting like an untethered boat—empty, they wander without restraint. Where is the turning back? Where do words return?*

*At a stall of ten porridge-sellers, five offered their wares first without waiting for purchase—such was the respect the man commanded. Harmony and compliance accumulate within, and blossoming brilliance emerges without: this is the teaching of the sages’ gate. If inner sincerity remains unresolved, it accumulates within but does not transform. ‘Resolution’ means transformation. ‘Planning’ means action. ‘Formed plans’ describe the appearance of conduct. Cheng Guang refers to one with radiant bearing—the outward manifestation of inner accumulation. Yet here, it is taken as a learning of visible traces. ‘To pacify the hearts of others’ means to subdue and win them over. It means: since I could not eliminate traces, others perceived them, and thus their hearts submitted in respect.*

*Zhaozhou said: ‘This old monk’s cultivation lacks strength; even ghosts and spirits see through it’—this is the same idea. The noble and the aged command respect, yet now, though neither old nor noble, the man is revered while others are slighted. This means his respect surpasses that of the noble and aged. ‘聚’ means to gather, to accumulate. Such matters, when accumulated over time, must become harmful. The more one’s fame and traces are exposed, the less one can escape the perils of the age. ‘Modest surpluses’ means their pursuit of profit seeks only excess, desiring more than mere gain. Those with power in the world can weigh others lightly or heavily. A porridge-seller is insignificant, initially lacking the power to influence others, yet even he could show such respect—how much more so a ruler?*

*When the body is wearied and wisdom exhausted, he will surely seek you out and employ you, demanding you present your achievements. This is what is meant by ‘disregarding their concerns.’ ‘Present’ means to offer. Bohun Maoren rejoiced in this, saying: ‘A keen observation!’—meaning you possess a single discerning eye. He also said: ‘You have stopped’—meaning you need not wander further, for others will gather to you and guard you as their teacher. ‘Stop’ means to remain. ‘已’ is an auxiliary particle. ‘Protect’ means to guard; ‘gather’ means the crowd guarding his gate. This single word ‘protect’ already hints at insufficiency, for Bohun Maoren’s vision rises yet higher. ‘The shoes outside the door were piled high’—his disciples were many. ‘Leaning on his staff and pressing it against his chin’ means he planted his staff firmly and rested it against his chin. ‘蹙’ means to press. ‘A visitor’ refers to one who receives guests.*

*‘Dispense your remedy’ means to instruct, enlighten, and treat like medicine. ‘It is done’ means ‘say no more.’ I had already told you that others would guard you. You cannot prevent them from protecting you—this is what is meant by ‘forgetting oneself is easy, but making others forget you is difficult.’ ‘What use is it to you?’ means: why have you acted thus? Those who are moved and delighted by you must be unable to contain themselves, causing their peculiarities to manifest outwardly—hence ‘delight and surprise arise from peculiarity.’ Since you are thus, not only can you not conceal your outward manifestations, but you must also stir and shake your fundamental nature—this is of no benefit to your person. ‘No purpose’ means ‘no benefit.’ ‘又’ here intensifies the meaning."*

Those who accompany you in your journeys are your friends, yet their learning remains incomplete, their words shallow and common—hence they are called "petty words." Their speech is capable of poisoning and harming others, and since none can admonish or correct you, you will never awaken. Who, then, would still inquire how you fare?

*Xiangshu* means "to inquire of one another"—the sense of mutual questioning. All people in the world: the cunning inevitably exhaust themselves, the wise inevitably torment themselves. Only those who embody the Dao and follow nature without employing their abilities make no demands upon external things, content merely to eat their fill and wander at leisure. They drift like an untethered boat, their hearts unattached to anything. This culminates in the single word *xu* (emptiness). Emptiness unites with the great void, and thus they wander at the origin of things. *Wu neng* ("without ability") is the meaning of *wu wei* ("non-action").

Among the people of Zheng, there was Huan, who chanted and intoned over the land of the Sang clan. After just three years, Huan became a Confucian scholar. His virtue moistened the land for nine *li*, and his beneficence extended to three generations, even enabling his younger brother to study Mohism. When the Confucian and Mohist brothers debated, their father sided with Di. After ten years, Huan took his own life. His father dreamed of him, saying: "It was I who made your son a Mohist." He then looked toward his grave, where the cypress and cedar had already borne fruit. The Creator’s retribution does not punish the person but the Heaven within the person—thus it was destined for him.

People consider themselves distinct from others, despising their kin. The villagers of Qi who drew water from the same well would seize one another. Thus it is said: "All in this world are Huan." From this, those with virtue pretend ignorance—how much more so those with the Dao?

In ancient times, this was called "the punishment of fleeing from Heaven." *Shen yin* means "to chant and intone." *Zhi san nian* ("just three years") means "exactly three years." *He run jiu li* ("the river moistens nine *li*") is a metaphor for the breadth of his beneficence. With his remaining resources, he enabled his younger brother to study Mohism. Huan became a Confucian, while his brother Di became a Mohist; their differing studies led to debates. Their father, favoring the younger brother, sided with him, and Huan, resenting his father, killed himself. He then appeared in his father’s dream, saying: "It was my residual beneficence that enabled your son to become a Mohist." Now that the brothers had quarreled to the point of suicide, the pines and cypresses on his grave had already grown and borne fruit—signifying the length of time since his death.

*Liang* may also be written as *yin* (pronounced *lang*), meaning "grave." *He hu chang shi qi liang* ("Why did he ever look at his grave?") means: "Why did he not look upon my grave?" *He* and *hu* both mean "why."

Zhuangzi then proceeded to judge this past event, saying: Huan believed it was he who enabled his brother to study Mohism, yet he did not understand that in the workings of creation there is a principle of retribution for men—one that does not respond to human ability but rather to what a person has received from Heaven. That his brother studied Mohism and mastered it was Heaven’s response to his innate nature, not something achieved by Huan’s human effort in providing resources. "It was Heaven that enabled him"—the first "him" refers to creation, the second to his brother Di. As for Huan, he considered himself exceptional, believing his study of Confucianism had extended his beneficence to three generations, surpassing others. In scorning his kin—resenting his father—he showed he did not comprehend Heaven’s design. A wellspring flows from nature itself. *Zuo* means to wrestle or grapple in conflict. The people of Qi drank from natural waters and fought over them, yet was that water their private possession? Their perception was the same as Huan’s. People today, unaware of Heaven, contend with private motives, and so it is said: the people of this age are all Huans.

Observe how "it was Heaven that enabled him" and the passage on well-water drinking are quintessentially Zhuangzian prose. How could such language appear in the four chapters beginning with *Yielding the Throne*? Even those of virtue regard creation as unfathomable—how much more so those who have attained the Dao?

Zhuangzi’s words often suggest that beyond one layer lies another, hence the distinction between those of the Dao and those of virtue. To flee from Heaven is to abandon one’s Heavenly principle. To be punished is to offend creation. This line reproaches those like Huan. The sage finds peace in what is naturally so and does not seek peace where it cannot be; the multitude finds peace where it should not and cannot find peace where it should. Zhuangzi said: Knowing the Dao is easy; refraining from speech is difficult. To know and not speak is to align with Heaven; to know and speak is to align with man. The ancients aligned with Heaven, not man.

What is naturally so is the principle of spontaneity; what is not naturally so is human contrivance. "Refraining from speech is difficult" means it is hard to forget words. To know the Dao and forget speech is to become Heaven’s companion; to know the Dao yet not forget speech is still entangled in human artifice, still bound by traces. The ancients were purely of Heaven, not man. *Zhi* means "to be" or "to go." "To align with Heaven" and "to align with man" convey the idea of returning to Heaven or man.

Zhu Pingman studied dragon-slaying under Zhi Liyi, exhausting a thousand gold pieces from his family. After three years, his skill was perfected, yet he had no use for his craft. *Dan* means "to exhaust," signifying he spent all his wealth. Though his learning was complete, there were no dragons to slay—this metaphor speaks for itself. Zhuangzi’s Dao is vast and has no place for application.

The sage treats the inevitable as if it were not, thus avoiding conflict; the multitude treats the inevitable as if it were not, thus inviting strife. To follow conflict is to act with desire; to rely on conflict is to perish. The inevitable is the unknowable. To treat the unknowable as knowable is to claim knowledge of the unknown. "Avoiding conflict" means avoiding contention. The multitude takes what cannot be certain and makes it certain, hence their many disputes. They resort to arms to settle them—here, the greatest conflicts are cited as examples. If one follows the heart of contention, one’s conduct in the world will always seek adversaries, for the distinction between self and others cannot be forgotten. Thus it is said: to follow conflict is to act with desire. To rely on the struggle of knowledge and power is to court one’s own destruction. Thus it is said: to rely on conflict is to perish.

The petty man’s knowledge does not extend beyond bribes and inquiries, wasting his spirit on such things. Shallow and narrow, he yet seeks to guide and benefit all things, to embody the Great Unity and formless emptiness. Such a one is deluded by the cosmos, burdened by form, and unaware of the Great Beginning. The perfected person, however, returns his spirit to the beginningless and finds sweet repose in the realm of nothingness.

*Baoju* refers to gifts; *gandu* to mutual inquiries and courtesies—these are trivial, insignificant matters. The petty man exhausts his spirit, considering such things wisdom, and seeks to benefit all under Heaven, to guide the myriad things toward the Great Unity’s origin and formless mystery. How could this be achieved? *Xingxu* means formless. With such limited vision, he is bewildered by the universe—space above and below, time past and future—and, burdened by form, remains ignorant of the Great Beginning’s natural principle. Only the perfected person returns his spirit to the beginning of nothingness and dwells content in the realm of non-action. *Gan* means "pleasing"; *ming*, "sleep." The metaphor of sweet sleep illustrates contented dwelling.

Water flows from the formless and disperses into the Great Purity. Alas! You take knowledge to reside in the finest hair yet do not know great tranquility. People see water flowing as if it had form, yet do not realize it originates from the formless—speaking of existence arising from non-existence. When it disperses and departs, they do not know it returns to the Great Purity. The Great Purity is the Great Void. This analogy laments that ordinary people, like those observing water, do not grasp the beginning and end of things. Thus it is said: "knowledge resides in the finest hair," meaning their perception is small. Great tranquility is the principle of non-action and spontaneity. The phrase "Alas!" precedes "you take," lamenting their narrow vision.

There was a man of Song named Cao Shang who was sent by the King of Song as an envoy to Qin. On his departure, he received several carriages; the king, pleased with him, added a hundred more. Returning to Song, he visited Zhuangzi and said: "To dwell in a cramped alley, impoverished and weaving sandals, with a withered neck and sallow face—this is what I am unskilled at..."

A single awakening to a ruler of ten thousand chariots, followed by a hundred chariages—this is my strength."

Zhuangzi said: "The King of Qin fell ill and summoned physicians. Those who lanced boils and drained abscesses received one chariot; those who licked his hemorrhoids received five chariots. The baser the treatment, the greater the reward. Did you, perchance, treat his hemorrhoids? How else could you have gained so many chariots? Begone!

'Cramped and weaving sandals' speaks of poverty and self-made footwear. 'Withered neck and sallow face' speaks of old age. A withered neck is gaunt and fleshless; a sallow face is yellowed and sunken at the temples. An abscess is akin to a boil. Boils appear above, hemorrhoids below—yet the lower the cure, the richer the reward. To gain chariots by licking hemorrhoids is base, a humiliation unworthy of esteem."

Duke Ai of Lu asked Yan He: "I regard Confucius as the state’s pillar; will the realm not be well-ordered?" Yan He replied: "Perilous indeed! Dangerous and crumbling! Confucius adorns feathers with paint, engages in florid speech, exalts the branch over the root, and forces his nature to govern the people—yet he neither knows nor trusts himself. His heart clings to this, his spirit is ruled by it. How could he be fit to lead the people? Does he truly benefit you, or do you merely sustain him? You would be deceived. Now, if you cause the people to abandon truth and study falsity, this is no way to instruct them. If you consider posterity, it would be better to cease. A steadfast pillar suffices to support affairs.

The *Book of Songs* says: 'The pillar of the state.' A steadfast pillar is like a worthy assistant. 'There is healing' means the state’s ills can yet be cured. *Ji* means peril; *dai* likewise means danger. 'Perilous indeed! Dangerous and crumbling!'—this is extreme peril. *Hua* means color; after coloring an object, he further adorns it with feathers—his embellishments are excessive. 'Florid speech' refers to ornate, extravagant words. 'Exalting the branch over the root' means his guiding principle lacks foundation. 'Forcing his nature' means artificial zeal. 'Governing the people' means standing above them. 'Neither knows nor trusts' means he does not recognize his own insincerity. 'His heart clings to this' means his heart is fixated on it. 'His spirit is ruled by it' means his spirit takes it as its master. 'How could he be fit to lead the people?' means he is unfit to guide them. 'He' refers to the Master; 'you' refers to Duke Ai. 'Does he truly benefit you?'—thus he says, 'Does he suit you?' *Yi* means to nourish. If you regard him as worthy and sustain him, he will bring you no benefit but only deception. 'Deceived, perhaps' means deception may well occur. Now, if you cause the people of the state to abandon truth and learn deceit, this is no way to teach them. *Shi* means to instruct. If you consider posterity, it would be better to cease. *Xiu* means to stop.

Difficult to govern! To act upon others yet not forget it is not the Heavenly Way. Merchants are not esteemed; even if circumstances force one to rank with them, the spirit does not esteem them. External punishments are metal and wood; internal punishments are action and transgression. When petty men incur external punishments, metal and wood interrogate them; when they incur internal punishments, yin and yang consume them. Only the true person can escape both internal and external punishments.

The people need not be governed; to govern with intent is to make governance difficult—thus it is called 'difficult to govern.' 'To act upon others yet not forget' means governing with intent. *Shi* means to administer policy. *Bu* means to display. The Heavenly Way is the Heavenly Principle. To administer policy and instruction with intent is not the Heavenly Principle. It is like merchants: a gentleman would never rank with them, and even if circumstances force a gathering, his spirit remains displeased. Likewise, a person of the Dao would not rank with those who act with intent. This analogy likens merchants to scholars of benevolence and righteousness.

External punishments are the blade, saw, and cangue; internal punishments are action and transgression. A person’s movements and faults are akin to corporal punishment. *Xun* means interrogation. 'Yin and yang consume them' means they are afflicted by the Creator’s reproach. *Shi* is like the eclipse of the sun—it brings illness. The first clause describes external punishment; the second, internal. *Li* means attachment.

Confucius said: "In general, the human heart is more treacherous than mountains and rivers, harder to know than Heaven. Heaven has its seasons—spring, autumn, winter, summer, dawn, and dusk—but man has a thick exterior and deep emotions. Thus, some appear honest yet seek profit; some seem talented yet conceal their abilities; some are gentle and yielding yet discerning; some appear firm yet are weak and pliant; some seem slow yet are quick-tempered. Therefore, those who rush to righteousness are as thirsty for it as they are eager to flee it. Thus, the gentleman sends them far to observe their loyalty, brings them near to observe their respect, burdens them to observe their ability, questions them suddenly to observe their knowledge, sets urgent deadlines to observe their trustworthiness, entrusts them with wealth to observe their benevolence, warns them of danger to observe their integrity, intoxicates them with wine to observe their restraint, and mingles them with others to observe their demeanor. When all nine tests are complete, the unworthy are revealed.

'Thick exterior and deep emotions' means that feigned appearances are not easily seen, and hidden feelings are not easily fathomed. Some appear simple and honest yet secretly seek profit; some harbor great talent yet outwardly seem incapable. *Bu xiao* means 'not resembling.' Some are gentle and yielding yet discerning; *man* means entangling. Some seem firm yet are weak and pliant—*The Book of Songs* says: 'Once a hundred-fold refined steel, now pliable as a finger’s curl.' *Man* means to curl around a finger. *Han* means urgency. Some seem slow yet are quick-tempered. All this shows how inscrutable people are. 'Rushing to righteousness as if thirsty' describes their fervent advance."

Those who abandon righteousness as if scorched retreat swiftly—this describes their hasty withdrawal. The phrase "advancing fervently, retreating swiftly" is thus rendered with striking precision.

Those far apart are easily deceived, so observe their loyalty from afar. Those close and intimate are prone to familiarity and disrespect, so observe their reverence up close. Those tasked with urgent and complex matters may falter under pressure, so assign them sudden burdens to test their competence. Those slow to perceive hesitate in response, so question them abruptly to gauge their wisdom. Pressing deadlines easily lead to broken promises, so impose tight schedules to assess their trustworthiness. Facing wealth, one may resort to improper gain, so entrust them with riches to observe their benevolence—here, *benevolence* aligns with the term *Dao/Way*. Confronted with peril, one may seek cowardly escape, so warn them of danger to examine their integrity. Wine clouds the mind, so observe their dignity when drunk. Beauty bewitches, so place them in mixed company to see if they maintain self-restraint. *Zheng* means verification. Testing them through these nine methods reveals the worthy from the unworthy.

This passage’s reasoning is sound, though attributed to Confucius, showing that Zhuangzi was not disrespectful toward him. When Zheng Kaofu received his first appointment, he stooped; at the second, he bent; at the third, he prostrated himself, shuffling along walls—who would dare not follow his example? Yet there are those who, upon their first appointment, strut with arrogance; at the second, dance atop chariots; and at the third, address elders by name—who could reconcile such conduct with the ways of Yao and Xu You? *Yu* means a hunched back; *lou*, a bent waist; *fu*, bowing to the ground—all signify that the higher one’s rank, the lower one’s posture. Shuffling along walls shows one dares not walk the main path, embodying humility. If the world had such virtuous men, who would not take them as models? *Gui* means model. *Er fu* refers to such men. *Lü ju* describes a haughty demeanor; dancing on chariots, frivolous behavior; calling elders by name, arrogance toward kin. *Tang* refers to Yao; *Xu*, to Xu You. Yao offered the throne to Xu You, who refused—how could such petty men, upon slight success, grow so arrogant, oblivious to the examples of Yao and Xu You? *Xie* means alignment. Comparing them to Yao and Xu You reveals the disparity. *Shu xie* asks: who could align them with such paragons?

No thief is greater than one whose virtue is deliberate, whose mind has eyes—once it has eyes and turns inward, inward vision leads to ruin. These words strike closest to the heart of those who pursue the Dao/Way. Chan Buddhists call this the "leaking mind" or the "second thought," capturing this very idea. *De/virtue* here means "to practice virtue." To practice virtue while being conscious of it is to act with intent—this is the greatest hindrance to those on the Dao/Way, hence "no thief is greater than one whose virtue is deliberate." Within this intent, if one begins calculating and scheming, it is as if the mind grows another eye—this is the "leaking mind," the "second thought." With this eye turned inward, distinctions multiply, chaos reigns, and the primordial unity is lost, leaving no path to the Dao/Way. Thus, it is called *ruin*—failure.

There are five pernicious virtues, with the central one foremost. What is the central virtue? It is self-satisfaction that scorns what one does not do. The five pernicious virtues correspond to the heart, ears, eyes, nose, and mouth, with the central virtue being the heart. The harm of the ears, eyes, nose, and mouth does not compare to that of the heart, hence "the central virtue is foremost." *Having self-satisfaction* means believing in one’s own abilities. *Pi* means to disparage or mock. To belittle others for what they cannot do is to render the heart unfit for the Dao/Way. The *Yuanjue Sutra* says: "Do not disdain long practice or slight beginners." Dahui warned: "Never think, 'I understand, they do not'—this is the very meaning here."

Exhaustion has eight extremes, success three certainties, and the body six repositories. Handsome beards, tall stature, robust build, radiant beauty, strength, courage, and boldness—eight traits surpassing others—lead to ruin when relied upon. Compliance, adaptability, and timidity, though inferior to others, ensure smooth passage. Wisdom and cunning, when outwardly displayed, breed resentment; courage and daring invite grievances; benevolence and righteousness bring reproach. Those who grasp the essence of life are enigmatic; those who grasp knowledge are elusive. Those who grasp the great mandate follow; those who grasp the small mandate encounter.

*Exhaustion has eight extremes* means that reliance on any trait leads to ruin. *Success has three certainties* means that those who humbly acknowledge their shortcomings will inevitably thrive. *Beautiful* refers to appearance; *ran*, to having a beard (as Fang Xuanling said of Li Wei’s beard). *Tall* means height; *large*, girth; *strong*, physical power; *radiant*, splendor; *brave*, vigor; *daring*, resolve. These are the eight extremes—traits that surpass others. Relying on them leads to ruin. *Compliance* means yielding and adapting to circumstances. *Adaptability* means rising after falling. *Timidity* means distress and fear. These three traits, though inferior to others, ensure smooth passage, as people favor those who do not compete. These are Zhuangzi’s contrarian arguments.

*The body has six repositories* refers to the six accumulations within the human form. *Repository* means a place of storage. Wisdom is one repository; *outwardly displayed* means applying wisdom externally to seek success. Courage is another; relying on strength breeds resentment. Benevolence and righteousness form another; seeking fame through them invites reproach.

Kuai (sounds like "魁").

*Attaining life* is one repository—violating the principles of life leads to haughty self-exaltation. *Attaining knowledge* is another—grasping the insights of the multitude necessitates scrutinizing every matter. Xiao (sounds like "消").

*Attaining destiny* is another repository. That which lies with Heaven is great; that which lies with oneself is small. To attain what lies with Heaven is to follow and yield to it, heeding nature. To attain what lies with oneself is to accept whatever one encounters as fate. Though encounters may bring gain or loss, a heart that entrusts itself to destiny remains free of attachment. These two are distinct in meaning. The six repositories conclude with the character *destiny*, which is elaborated into two clauses—this is a matter of literary structure.

There was a man who had an audience with the King of Song. The king bestowed upon him ten carriages, and with these ten carriages, he grew arrogant toward Zhuangzi. Zhuangzi said: "By the river lived a poor family who made their living weaving reeds. Their son dived into the depths and obtained a pearl worth a thousand gold pieces. His father said to him, 'Bring a stone and pound it!' For a pearl of such value must lie in the ninefold abyss beneath the chin of a black dragon. That you could obtain it means you must have encountered the dragon while it slept. Had the black dragon been awake, what scrap of you would have remained?"

"Now, the depths of the state of Song are not merely a ninefold abyss, and the King of Song is fiercer than a black dragon. That you could obtain these carriages means you must have encountered him while he slept. Had the King of Song been awake, you would have been ground to powder."

*Arrogance* here means haughty condescension, as if patting Zhuangzi like a child. *Weaving* means to plait; *reeds* are rushes. This is the same as the character for "编曲." They relied on this craft for sustenance, selling their wares. "Bring a stone and pound it" expresses disdain for the pearl and the desire to destroy it. This analogy illustrates that those who seek wealth and rank tread a perilous path, deceiving their ruler. If the ruler awakens, they will surely face execution. "What scrap of you would have remained" means being devoured without a trace.

Someone sent an invitation to Zhuangzi, who replied to the messenger: "Have you seen the sacrificial ox? It is clothed in embroidered silk and fed with fine hay and beans. Yet when it is led into the grand temple, though it may wish to be a lone calf, how could that be possible?" This echoes the earlier passage about the turtle dragging its tail in the mud.

When Zhuangzi was near death, his disciples wished to bury him with lavish rites. Zhuangzi said: "I take heaven and earth as my inner and outer coffins, the sun and moon as my paired jades, the stars and constellations as my pearls and beads, and the myriad things as my funeral gifts. Are not my burial preparations already complete? What could be added to them?"

His disciples said: "We fear that crows and kites will feast on you."

Zhuangzi replied: "Above, I would be eaten by crows and kites; below, by ants and mole crickets. To snatch me from one to give to the other—how partial you are!" This was a rebuke of those in his time who practiced extravagant burials. To take from crows and kites to give to ants and mole crickets is partiality. Though his words may seem extreme, they are not easily matched by those who have not truly attained the Dao.

To level with what is not level is to fail to achieve levelness; to verify with what is unverified is to fail to achieve verification. The enlightened are but servants of things; the spiritually attuned verify them. That the enlightened cannot surpass the spiritually attuned has long been so. Yet fools rely on their limited perceptions to impose upon others, seeking merit in externals—is this not lamentable?

The principles of the myriad things are fundamentally level. If I use an unlevel mind to level what is already level, then what was level becomes unlevel. The principles of the myriad things are each verifiable. If I use an unverified mind to verify them, then what was verifiable becomes unverified. Thus it is said: to level with what is not level is to fail to achieve levelness; to verify with what is unverified is to fail to achieve verification.

*Verification* means confirmation. "Servants of things" describes those who, though they do nothing, are made to act as if by something else—this is to impose intention where there is none. The enlightened are often burdened in this way. As for the spiritually attuned, they simply allow things to respond naturally. That the enlightened cannot surpass the spiritually attuned means that human effort cannot surpass non-action. Fools rely on their private views to impose upon others, constantly seeking merit in externals—is this not lamentable?

*Oral Exegesis of the Southern Florescence Perfect Scripture*, Scroll Thirty-One (concluded)
*Oral Exegesis of the Southern Florescence Perfect Scripture*, Scroll Thirty-Two

Lin Xiyi of Yanzhai Studio, *Miscellaneous Chapters: "The World"*

The world abounds with those who cultivate methods of governance, each deeming their own approach unsurpassable. Yet where, truly, does the ancient *Dao*-art reside? It is said: nowhere it is not present. Then by what means does the numinous descend, and from whence does clarity emerge? The sage’s arising and the king’s accomplishment both originate from the One. Not departing from the Source is called the "Heavenly Person." Not departing from essence is called the "Spiritual Person." Not departing from the authentic is called the "Perfected Person." Taking Heaven as their source, virtue as their root, and the Dao as their gate, presaging through transformation—this is the sage. Taking benevolence as their thought, righteousness as their principle, propriety as their conduct, and music as their harmony, suffused with compassion and kindness—this is the noble person. Taking law as their division, names as their markers, conduct as their verification, and examination as their judgment—such is the enumeration of one, two, three, four, by which the hundred officials rank themselves. Taking duty as their norm, clothing and food as their priority, they foster growth, store provisions, and care for the elderly, the weak, the orphaned, and the widowed—all to nurture the people. Such is the governance of the common folk.

The ancients were truly complete. They matched the divine luminaries, harmonized with Heaven and Earth, nurtured the myriad things, brought harmony to the world, and extended their blessings to the hundred clans. Clear about fundamental principles and connected to the yet-unmeasured, their operation—encompassing the six directions and the four openings, the refined and the coarse, the great and the small—was nowhere absent. Those manifestations of clarity that reside in measures and degrees are still largely preserved in the transmitted records of ancient laws. Those found in the *Odes*, *Documents*, *Rites*, and *Music* are often elucidated by the scholars of Zou and Lu, the girdle-wearing masters. The *Odes* guide the will, the *Documents* guide affairs, the *Rites* guide conduct, the *Music* guides harmony, the *Changes* guide yin and yang, and the *Spring and Autumn* guide names and duties. These principles, dispersed throughout the world and established in the Central States, are at times expounded and transmitted by the hundred schools.

Yet when the world fell into great disorder, the worthy and the sagely were obscured, the Dao and virtue were no longer unified, and the world’s people each grasped but a single insight to cherish as their own. Like the ear, eye, nose, and mouth—each possessing its own clarity yet unable to communicate with the others—so too are the hundred schools and their various arts, each possessing its own strength and occasional utility. Nevertheless, they are neither comprehensive nor all-encompassing, being but partial scholars. To judge the beauty of Heaven and Earth, to analyze the principles of the myriad things, to examine the wholeness of the ancients—few can fully embody the beauty of Heaven and Earth or match the countenance of the divine luminaries. Thus, the Way of inner sageliness and outer kingship has grown dim and obscured, stifled and unexpressed. The people of the world each pursue what they desire, fashioning their own methods.

Alas! The hundred schools have gone forth and not returned; they will surely never converge. Later scholars, unfortunate in not witnessing the purity of Heaven and Earth or the greatness of the ancients, will see the *Dao*-art rent asunder by the world.

In the final chapter, Zhuangzi’s preface on the learning of past and present resembles the closing of Mencius’ work, where "hearing knowledge" and "seeing knowledge" are discussed. From "The world abounds with those who cultivate methods of governance" to "the *Dao*-art will be rent asunder by the world," it serves as a clear introduction. Having provided this general preface, he then proceeds to discuss the various schools, placing his own work among them. Yet the learning of Zou and Lu is expounded within the general preface, revealing that this elder’s intent was never to dismiss the Confucian tradition as merely one-sided or extreme—he was well aware that the Sage’s gate was the true standard. Reading this preface, one sees that his learning was fundamentally sound. As Su Dongpo observed, Zhuangzi never disparaged the Master.

*Fangshu* means "learning" or "art." Each person deems their own learning unsurpassable, for all are self-assured. The ancient *Dao*-art—this *yan* (衍) is akin to "benevolent arts" or "heart arts." Where does it reside? Nowhere it is not present—this conveys the idea of the "mean in timing," for though the hundred schools differ, the Dao is never absent from their midst. By what means does the numinous descend, and from whence does clarity emerge? This asks how the Way of spirit and luminosity may be perceived. The sage’s accomplishments in arising and the king’s in completion are the same as the principles of Heaven and Earth’s generation—all originate from the One. The One is creation itself. "Source," "essence," and "authentic" are all synonymous with the One, differing only in phrasing.

Taking Heaven as their source, virtue as their root, and the Dao as their gate—all are non-action and spontaneity. "Presaging through transformation" is the same as "originating from the One." The sage is thus the Heavenly Person, the Perfected Person, and the Spiritual Person. "Suffused with compassion and kindness" describes their demeanor. Laws entail distinctions, hence "taking law as their division." Names serve as standards, hence "taking names as their markers." "Taking conduct as their verification" and "examination as their judgment" mean that their verifications and judgments are each grounded in evidence. The enumeration of one, two, three, four signifies meticulous clarity in all details. "Ranking themselves" means that great and small, high and low are ordered. "Taking duty as their norm" means each has a regular office. "Taking clothing and food as their priority" means teaching the people agriculture and sericulture. "Fostering growth and storing provisions" refers to practices like storing a year’s food for every three years of farming. "Caring for the elderly, the weak, the orphaned, and the widowed" means that in enacting governance and bestowing benevolence, these four groups must come first. All their divisions of offices, arrangements of duties, governance, and instruction are for the nurturing of the people.

"The ancients were truly complete" means the ancient sages could fulfill all these. They could match the divine luminaries and harmonize with Heaven and Earth. "Harmonized" means attuned. "Nurturing the myriad things, harmonizing the world, extending blessings to the hundred clans" describes the vastness of their efficacy. "Fundamental principles and yet-unmeasured degrees" are akin to "refined and coarse, root and branch." "Connected" means interrelated, signifying that root and branch do not depart from one another. "Six directions and four openings" mean east, west, south, north, above, and below—nowhere is unusable. "Operation" means the Dao.

The operation of the Dao encompasses the small and large, refined and coarse—all are the Dao, hence it is said to be present everywhere without exception. Examining these several lines, one sees that the substance and function of the Dao are never left obscure.

Numerical standards and degrees are what can be recorded, meaning their methods and measures—clear and traceable—are all transmitted through established models of past ages. *Shi* refers to written records. There are still many such accounts, for all these matters are documented therein.

The scholars of Zou and Lu, the girdled gentlemen—these refer to the sagely lineage, explicitly speaking of Confucius’ Six Classics. The *Spring and Autumn* upholds proper names and distinctions, for even the two words "names and distinctions" already contain a warning against rebellious ministers and traitorous sons. Their teachings spread throughout the world, meaning that while Zou and Lu preserved the complete tradition, its learning dispersed across the land, establishing instruction in the Central States and branching into a hundred schools. There were still those who occasionally spoke of these matters, yet none could match the completeness of the learning of Zou and Lu.

The great disorder of the world refers to the period after the *Spring and Autumn*. The worthy and sagely were no longer manifest; above, there were no Wen or Wu, no Duke of Zhou, and below, no disciples like Confucius or Yan Hui. The Way and virtue were no longer unified, scattering into a hundred schools. Many in the world grasped but a single fragment, examining it and taking pride in it, meaning they merely scrutinized one aspect and boasted of it. The ears, eyes, nose, and mouth cannot function interchangeably—ears cannot see, eyes cannot hear, mouths cannot smell, noses cannot taste—each follows its own capacity, hence it is said that each has its own clarity. This analogy applies to the hundred schools and their various arts: each has its strengths and may be useful at times, yet none can fully encompass the comprehensive Way of the sages. Thus, they are but partial and one-sided scholars.

The beauty of Heaven and Earth is thereby divided and incomplete; the principles of the myriad things are thereby fragmented and discordant. If one examines them through the complete learning of the ancients, one knows that the one-sidedness of the hundred schools rarely embodies the full beauty of Heaven and Earth or matches the countenance of the divine luminaries. *Beauty* refers to the Dao within, its substance; *countenance* refers to the Dao without, its function. *Matching* means being fitting. Few can truly match the countenance of the divine luminaries, meaning they fall short of being fitting.

Inward sageliness is substance; outward kingship is function. With the Dao of inner and outer thus obscured, each person pursues what they desire and fashions their own methods. The learning of the hundred schools, from this point onward, has strayed and cannot return, making reunification impossible. Later scholars cannot perceive the pure wholeness of Heaven and Earth or the complete body of the ancient Way—this is the misfortune of later ages.

The arts of the Dao in the world have since become fragmented, hence it is said, "The arts of the Dao will be torn asunder throughout the world." This concluding line is exceptionally forceful and finely wrought.

Not extravagant toward later ages, not wasteful toward the myriad things, not dazzled by numerical standards, yet using the carpenter’s line to correct oneself and prepare for the world’s emergencies—such were the ancient arts of the Dao. Mo Di and Qin Guli, hearing of this approach, delighted in it. Yet they carried it to excess, imposing rigid uniformity, creating the doctrine of "opposing music" and calling it "frugality." They forbade singing in life and mourning in death; Mozi advocated universal love, mutual benefit, and opposition to conflict. His Way eschewed anger, and he was fond of learning and transmitting without deviation, yet he did not align with the former kings, instead condemning the rites and music of antiquity.

The Yellow Emperor had the *Xianchi*, Yao the *Dazhang*, Shun the *Dashao*, Yu the *Daxia*, Tang the *Huo*, King Wen the music of the *Biyong*, and King Wu and the Duke of Zhou composed the *Wu*. In ancient mourning rites, noble and base had their proper forms, superior and inferior their respective ranks. The Son of Heaven had seven layers of inner and outer coffins, the feudal lords five, high ministers three, and officers two. Yet Mozi alone forbade singing in life and mourning in death, using a paulownia coffin three inches thick without an outer coffin as the model. Teaching others thus seems unloving; practicing it oneself is surely self-neglect.

This does not yet defeat Mozi’s Way. Yet to sing yet oppose singing, to weep yet oppose weeping, to delight yet oppose delight—is this truly reasonable? Their lives are toilsome, their deaths meager; their Way is harsh, causing people sorrow and grief. Their conduct is difficult to uphold, and one fears it cannot be the Way of the sages. It runs counter to the hearts of the world, and the world cannot endure it. Though Mozi alone could bear it, what could he do about the world? Separated from the world, he is far from the kingly Way.

Mozi spoke of the Dao, saying: "In ancient times, Yu controlled the floodwaters, dredged the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers, and connected the four barbarians and the nine provinces. There were three hundred famous rivers, three thousand tributaries, and countless smaller streams. Yu personally wielded the spade and basket, mingling with the laborers across the land’s rivers. His calves bore no flesh, his shins no hair; he bathed in heavy rain and combed his hair in fierce winds, establishing ten thousand states. Yu was a great sage, yet he wearied his body for the world." Thus, later Mohists often wore coarse garments of felt and hempen sandals, laboring day and night without rest, taking self-imposed hardship as the ultimate virtue. Those who could not endure this were deemed unworthy of the Mohist name and insufficient to be called followers of Yu.

The disciples of Xiangli Qin and the followers of Wu Hou, along with the southern Mohists like Ku Huo, Ji Chi, and Deng Lingzi, all recited the Mohist canon yet diverged in their interpretations, calling one another "deviant Mohists." They engaged in debates over the "hard and white" and "same and different," responding to one another with sophistry and contrariness. They revered the *Juzi* as a sage, all wishing to serve as his representative, hoping to succeed him, yet to this day they remain unresolved.

Mo Di and Qin Guli’s intentions were sound, but their conduct was misguided. They would have later Mohists necessarily wear themselves out—calves without flesh, shins without hair—competing in asceticism. This is the height of disorder and the nadir of governance.

Though indeed, Mozi was truly one who loved the world—one whom one might seek in vain, yet even if he withered away, he would not abandon his cause. A man of true talent! He did not indulge later generations, nor did he teach them indulgence. "Lavishness" means adornment; he did not take the embellishments of the myriad things as adornment. "Radiance" means splendor; he did not take ritual, music, measures, or numbers as radiant splendor. The "inked line" was self-restraint; he restrained himself to correct the world, desiring that all under Heaven have abundance. His intent lay in frugality to ensure sufficiency, thus he spoke of meeting the world’s urgent needs, for people take clothing and food as urgent, leading to strife and disorder.

Among the arts of the Dao of antiquity, there were those that resided in this. Yet only Mo Di and Qin Guli heard of this teaching and rejoiced in it, hence it is said they "heard its wind and delighted in it." Precisely because they rejoiced in it, they proceeded to act upon it. "Excessive" means going too far. "Following" means compliance; "great compliance" refers to their doctrine’s overbearing restraint, thus it is called "their own great compliance." "Their own" conveys the sense of suppression. *Against Music* and *Moderation in Use* are chapter titles in Mozi’s writings. Having composed these, Mozi desired that in life, people would not sing—rejecting music—and in death, they would have no mourning garments, nearing bare burial, all to moderate use. "Universal love and mutual benefit" meant loving all without exception, thus deeming strife wrong and non-anger the Way. "Broad and undifferentiated" meant esteeming uniformity. Expanding his doctrine to serve as instruction, he centered it on esteeming uniformity. Though he sought unity, his teachings did not align with the former kings. From the Yellow Emperor to King Wu, none had done without music, yet Mozi sought to abolish it. From ancient times, from the noble to the base, none had lacked mourning rites, yet Mozi sought to abolish them, setting a standard of three-inch coffins without outer coffins—moderation in use. Teaching people thus was too harsh, hence it is said, "I fear this does not love others," for it is not the way to love people. "Not loving oneself" means self-affliction. "Ultimate ruin" means Mozi’s Way, in the end, cannot be practiced. People cannot live without song, yet Mozi deemed song wrong; human nature cannot do without weeping, yet Mozi deemed weeping wrong; they cannot do without joy, yet he deemed joy wrong. His Way was entirely removed from human sentiment, thus it is said, "Does this truly resemble it?" "Resemble" means proximity. Does this truly align with human sentiment? In life, they toiled in hardship; in death, they practiced meager burials. "Too crude" means too unrefined. Their conduct was difficult to emulate. They opposed the hearts of all under Heaven, being far from human sentiment. Though all under Heaven could not endure it, Mozi alone could—endurance, too, is endurance. Yet if only one can endure while all under Heaven cannot, what can be done? Having estranged the hearts of the people, it cannot serve as the Way to rule all under Heaven.

The great rivers between Heaven and Earth are called "famous rivers"; the tributaries were dredged by Yu. The *nang* was a vessel for carrying earth; the *si* was a tool for digging. The Nine Rivers were brought together, their functions harmonized to govern all the rivers under Heaven. Mozi’s doctrine held that Yu was a great sage who labored thus himself—how much more should others? "Raised heels" and "flat feet" are the same; "straw sandals" and "wooden clogs" are the same—wooden footwear is called *ji*, straw footwear *jue*. "Service" means use.

Xiangli was a surname; Qin was a given name, also a student of Mohism who became a teacher in the world. His disciples were all followers of the five feudal lords, indicating many studied under him. Ku Huo, Ji Chi, and Deng Lingzi were the names of three men. All three resided in the south, also studied the Mohist canon, yet their eccentricities surpassed even Mozi’s. Moreover, their doctrines all differed, so they named themselves "deviant Mohists," meaning separate branches of Mohism. "Not contrary" means not differing. Odd and even are inherently distinct, yet they claimed they did not conflict—this was forced sophistry. They used such contrarian rhetoric in their exchanges, hence it is said they "responded to one another." The *Juzi* was akin to the "foremost disciple," what Chan schools call a "Dharma heir." Among those who transmitted his teachings, they took the most accomplished as sages and made them their leaders. "Corpse" means leader. Hoping to become his successors, the *Juzi* transmitted it to their disciples as their posterity. "Posterity" still means descendants. "Unbroken" means uninterrupted, indicating its transmission continues to this day.

Tracing its origins, Mo Di’s intent was indeed noble, but his conduct was excessive, hence it is said, "his intent was sound, but his conduct was misguided." "Vying with one another" means emulating one another, for those who transmitted Mozi’s Way emulated self-affliction, desiring thereby to govern all under Heaven. Yet before governance could be seen, they first brought about disorder, hence it is said, "the height of disorder." Though Mozi’s goodness arose from the sincerity of his heart, there are no such people in the world today. "Seek in vain" means there are no longer such men.

"Unceasing" means unrelenting. Though they exhausted themselves to the point of emaciation, they never ceased their efforts—such men may indeed be called heroic scholars. "Scholars of talent" is a term for heroic figures. Mencius rejected Yang Zhu and Mo Di, and this text likewise mentions them together repeatedly. Yet when discussing the various schools by their doctrines, it omits the Yangists, for their teachings are deemed unworthy of inclusion.

Unburdened by convention, unadorned by externals, uncompromising toward others, unopposed to the multitude, they wished for the world’s peace to preserve all lives, seeking only that all—self and others—be fully provided for, and no more. In this they purified their hearts. Among the ancient arts of the Dao, some were found in this. Song Jian and Yin Wen, hearing of their example, were delighted. They fashioned the *Huashan* cap as their emblem, engaging all things by beginning with "distinguishing constraints," and called their teaching of the heart’s capacity "the conduct of the heart." They sought to harmonize and unite, to reconcile and pacify, proposing to establish this as their guiding principle.

They endured insult without shame, sought to end the people’s strife, forbid aggression, and halt warfare to save the age from conflict. With this, they traveled the world, persuading rulers above and instructing the people below. Though the world rejected them, they persisted stubbornly, unyielding in their advocacy—hence it is said, "both high and low grew weary of them, yet they forced themselves upon all."

"Unburdened by convention" means free from worldly entanglements. "Unadorned by externals" means not indulging in material things. "Unopposed to the multitude" means not defying human nature. Their wish was for all to live, seeing others as themselves, desiring only that each be sufficiently provided for. In this they centered their hearts and proclaimed it to the world—such was the teaching of Song Jian and Yin Wen.

*Huashan* is the name of their cap. "Distinguishing constraints" is akin to "being in ease." To "distinguish" is to abide by one’s lot, and to "be in ease" is to rest in spacious tranquility. "Beginning" means foundation. They engaged all things with this intent—"engaging" means drawing others in. "The heart’s capacity" refers to the heart’s inherent state. They expounded its nature to others, calling it "the conduct of the heart," for conduct is the heart’s function. This is akin to what the Buddhists call "the great function manifesting before one."

With the intent to harmonize, they sought to unite others in joy, to reconcile and unify all under Heaven, proposing to exalt Song Jian and Yin Wen as the leaders of their teaching. Seeing the people’s love of strife, they taught "enduring insult without shame" to save them. Seeing the age’s love of war, they taught forbidding aggression and halting warfare to save it. Above, they persuaded rulers; below, they instructed the common people. Though the world ignored them, they persisted stubbornly in their advocacy, boasting and expounding without cease.
