Both high and low grew weary of them, yet they forced themselves upon all—this saying must have been common at the time, hence it is repeated here to conclude.

Yet their concern for others was too great, and their care for themselves too little. They said: "Let us simply secure five *sheng* of rice—this will suffice." The master feared he would not be full, while the disciples, though hungry, never forgot the world, laboring day and night without rest, saying: "We must surely save lives!" How haughty were these would-be saviors of the world! Their concern for others was excessive, and their self-imposed suffering too great.

Their teaching held that each day, five *sheng* of rice would suffice for master and disciples to share. The master would still go hungry, so how could the disciples not? Thus, both master and disciples endured hunger to uphold their teaching. Yet they claimed: "We do not forget the world, laboring day and night without cease." They said: "Our self-imposed suffering is thus—how could this be a path to long life? But we do this to correct those who falsely claim to save the world while seeking their own gain." Hence it is said: "How haughty were these would-be saviors of the world!" "Haughty" means to correct. This is akin to Yu Rang’s words: "What I do is most difficult, to shame all those ministers who harbor divided loyalties." Li Bai’s poem *Drinking Alone, Sent to Wei Liu* contains the line: "I think of you wandering the world’s dust, haughty and self-mocking"—this is the same sense of "haughty."

They said: "The noble man does not engage in petty scrutiny, nor lend himself to things. If something is of no benefit to the world, clarifying it is not as good as abandoning it."

To take the prohibition of attack and the cessation of warfare as external matters, and the reduction of emotions and desires as internal ones—such are the distinctions between the great and the small, the refined and the coarse, and their practice extends no further than this.

Their teaching further states: "Do not engage in petty scrutiny, for petty scrutiny is contrary to the principle of *bie you* (distinguishing boundaries)." This means one should not insist on the distinction between self and other. "Not lending oneself to things" means that in all matters, one acts for oneself and does not rely on others for assistance. If something brings harm to the world and no benefit, even if one clearly knows it can be done, it is better to abandon it. Hence it is said: "Clarifying it is not as good as abandoning it."

The essence of their learning is this: externally, one should eliminate the conflicts of attack and warfare; internally, one should eliminate the turbulence of emotions and desires. *Gua qian* (reduction and restraint) refers to diminishing and curtailing emotions and desires. Though their learning varies in scale and refinement, the general thrust of their practice amounts to no more than this. *Shi* means "only."

Impartial yet not partisan, yielding yet without self-interest, resolute yet without fixed position, following things without duality, unburdened by deliberation, unguided by cunning—indiscriminate toward things, moving with them in unison: such were the ancient arts of the Way.

Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao heard of this teaching and delighted in it. They took the equalization of the myriad things as their guiding principle, saying: "Heaven can cover all things but cannot bear them; earth can bear all things but cannot cover them; the great Dao can encompass all things but cannot distinguish them. Knowing that all things have their *ke* (what is permissible) and their *bu ke* (what is not permissible), they said: 'Selection is never universal; teaching never reaches all; only the Dao leaves nothing behind.'"

Thus, Shen Dao abandoned knowledge and self, following only what could not be avoided. He let things flow naturally, taking this as the principle of the Dao, saying: "To know that one does not know is to approach the thinnest edge of knowledge—this is harmful." Xi Tan (or Xidan) said: "Without responsibility, he mocked the world’s esteem for worthies; unrestrained and unprincipled, he rejected the world’s great sages." Pushing and pulling, turning with things, he abandoned right and wrong, seeking only to avoid trouble. He did not rely on wisdom or planning, nor did he distinguish before or after. He was like a drifting gale, like a spinning feather, like a grinding stone’s rotation—whole yet without fault, moving or still without error, never incurring blame. Why? Because things without knowledge have no peril of self-assertion, no burden of cleverness. Moving or still, they do not depart from principle, and thus they pass their lives without praise. Hence it is said: "One reaches the state of things without knowledge, rendering worthies and sages useless."

A clod of earth does not lose the Dao. Yet the heroic laughed together, saying: "Shen Dao’s Way is not the conduct of the living but the principle of the dead—how bizarre!" Tian Pian was the same. He studied under Peng Meng and attained the teaching of "no instruction."

Peng Meng’s master said: "The ancient men of the Way reached the point of neither affirming nor denying anything." Their manner was abrupt and unyielding, difficult to describe. They often opposed others, avoided gatherings, and did not fall into the trap of rigid distinctions. What they called the Dao was not the Dao, and what they spoke of could not escape being wrong.

Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao did not understand the Dao. Nevertheless, in general, they had once glimpsed something of it.

"Not partisan" means also "without self-interest."

The *Yi* is level and smooth. *Jue* means to discard private intentions and have no partiality. "Following things" refers to the principles and tendencies of the myriad things. "Not two" means oneness. "Not turning to deliberation, not scheming with wisdom" means having no calculation. "Toward things, no selection"—no choosing—means the eye’s scope is even. "Going along with them" means following nature and acting. Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao were all recluses of Qi. Their teachings held that heaven and earth are also one among the myriad things, and if one calls them "one," then all are equal. Yet what leads them is the Way of non-action. Heaven can cover but cannot bear; earth can bear but cannot cover—this speaks of their partiality. The "Great Way" refers to the scholars of the Daoist school. They knew only to embrace all as one without distinction, a mode of discourse that existed in their time. "Each has what it affirms and what it denies" means each has its own partiality. If one selects among the myriad things, then one cannot be all-encompassing. To take this as a teaching is to fail to reach its ultimate. But if one returns to the Way, then nothing is left out. Hence it is said: "The Way leaves nothing behind." Selection entails affirmation and denial; to abandon knowledge, discard the self, and follow necessity—this is non-action. *Lingtai* means uninhibited. "Cool and unburdened toward things" means free from constraint. What they took as the principle of the Way was that things move without obstruction as the highest truth. Their teaching said: If one divides by knowledge and ignorance, one will be pressed by knowledge and come near to self-harm. *Bo* means pressing; *lin*, near. *Xikuo* describes something crooked and unstable. "No responsibility" means not fixing the mind on affairs. *Ren* means esteeming worthies to take up tasks. Since they did not engage in affairs, they laughed at the world’s esteem for worthies. The learning of the sage must uphold conduct, but since they were unrestrained and without conduct, they took the world’s scholars of sageliness as wrong. "Pushing and cutting off"—both mean having no sharp edges. "Turning with things" means having no sharp edges, no affirmation, no denial, with the aim of merely avoiding worldly entanglements. "Not taking knowledge and deliberation as a teacher" means having no thought. "Not knowing before and after" means no calculation. *Wei* (read as *wei*)—*weiran* means the sense of being towering and unmoving. "Pushed, then it moves; pulled, then it goes; pressed, then it responds"—this means rising only when compelled. "Wind returning, feather whirling, the path of a millstone"—all are metaphors for being without intent and turning with things. *Sui* means turning, revolving. They sought to preserve themselves by not being seen as wrong in the world, moving and resting in accord with nature without excess, thus avoiding offense to others. What was the basis of their learning? It was this: Only things without knowledge have no urgency for self-affirmation and no burden of concern. Moving and resting all follow the natural, so they do not depart from principle. Not seeking knowledge from human desires, they live their lives without praise. Precisely because they have no praise, they have no blame. Hence it is said: "They never incurred fault." Things without knowledge—such as wood, stone, tiles, and pebbles—are of this kind. "Establishing the self" means affirming the self and standing alone. Thus their teaching said: In living in the world, why use the names of sages and worthies? If one can be like a clod of earth, a thing without knowledge, then one does not lose the Way. Hence it is said: "The clod does not lose the Way." These words resemble those of the ascetics who practice austerities in remote mountains and valleys. Thus the heroic laughed at them, saying they were like dead men. "Strange indeed!" refers to Peng Meng and his followers being seen as odd by the world. "Received no instruction" means that in their early learning, they naturally resonated without needing teaching. Peng Meng was jealous of having a teacher, but his teacher’s words said: The ancients who possessed the Way took the absence of right and wrong as their foundation. *Huo ran*—the sound of wind—means their speech was like the rushing of wind. Without concern, though they spoke, what was there to hold in their words? Hence it is said: "How could one speak of it?" Their views were always contrary to the world, unable to gather and observe with others, thus becoming a one-sided teaching. "Not exempt from"—they merely sought to have no sharp edges. *Yuanduan* means having no sharp edges. Though their words were grand, what they called the Way was not the Way, so they were not exempt from the world’s ridicule. *Wei* is the same as *wei*. Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao did not understand the Way—this is Zhuangzi’s concluding judgment. "In general"—viewing them broadly, they had all heard something of this Way, but did not grasp its true essence. Such closing lines reveal his literary style.

The root is taken as essence, things as coarse; accumulation is seen as insufficient. Serene and alone, they dwelled with the spirit-like clarity—this was one of the ancient arts of the Way. Guan Yin and Lao Dan heard of their teachings and delighted in them. They established them on the constant of "nothingness and being," centered them on the Great One. They took gentleness, weakness, humility, and yielding as their outward form, and emptiness, non-destruction of the myriad things as their substance. Guan Yin said: "Abiding nowhere in the self, the forms of things manifest on their own. In movement, they are like water; in stillness, like a mirror; in response, like an echo. Fleeting as if vanished, silent as if pure. Those who are the same are in harmony; those who grasp lose. They never precede others but always follow." Lao Dan said: "Know the masculine, keep to the feminine, and be the world’s valley. Know the white, keep to the disgraceful, and be the world’s lowland. When others all seek to be first, I alone seek to be last, saying: I receive the world’s filth. When others all seek the substantial, I alone seek the empty. Having no store, thus I have surplus."

Abiding thus, it stands towering and ever-abundant. In conducting oneself, it is unhurried yet without waste, effortless yet mocking all contrivance. While others seek fortune, I alone seek the preservation of wholeness through bending, saying: "Merely to avoid blame." Taking depth as the root, restraint as the guiding principle, I say: "What is hard will shatter; what is sharp will break." Ever tolerant toward things, never carving away at others—this may be called the ultimate attainment.

Ah, Guan Yin and Lao Dan—were they not the great perfected of antiquity? The root is the Dao; things are the ten thousand affairs. Those who regard accumulation as insufficiency speak of treasuring wealth for all under heaven. Dwelling with the numinous and luminous is to guard the natural. That Guan Yin was a disciple of Lao Dan—this merely means that the disciple came first and the master later, a fleeting stroke of the brush. Taking nothingness as the essence, the inception of the Great Ultimate as the ruler—establishing this, too, is to rule.

"Gentle, weak, humble, and yielding" express the meaning of "the soft tongue endures." As outward form, this describes how one engages the world and interacts with things as seen externally. In emptiness, all things are preserved whole; thus it is said: "Taking emptiness and non-destruction of the myriad things as substance." Substance is the true principle. As Le Xuan said: "Where nothing exists, all things are complete."

"Abiding nowhere in the self" means having no private agenda. "The forms of things manifest on their own" means that the appearances of things arise naturally as they are. The movement of water, the stillness of a mirror, the response of an empty valley—all are without intent. "Fleeting as if vanished" describes the indistinct presence of something that seems both there and not there. "Silent as if pure" means that purity is not seen as purity. Harmony comes from being the same as things; to grasp is to lose. "Never preceding others but always following" means acting only when pressed, rising only when unavoidable.

"Know the masculine, keep to the feminine"—this is to conceal ability within inability. "Know the white, keep to the disgraceful"—this is to remain lowly while knowing one’s worth. Valleys and lowlands lie below yet contain all things; to be a valley or lowland is to embody the greatness of receptivity. "When others all seek to be first, I alone seek to be last"—this is the same as never preceding others but always following. "Receiving the world’s filth" is to know purity yet guard disgrace. Not taking the substantial for emptiness, nor emptiness for substance, thus when others all seek the substantial, I alone seek the empty. "Having no store, thus I have surplus"—this is the same as regarding accumulation as insufficiency. Only by taking emptiness as substance does one remain towering and ever-abundant, for where nothing is stored, all things are complete.

"Unhurried" means at ease. "Without waste" means without loss. While others prize skill, I find skill in non-action, thus I mock their contrivance. While others seek fortune, I seek fortune in the absence of misfortune. "Preservation of wholeness through bending" means that by yielding, one preserves oneself. "Merely to avoid blame"—there is no greater fortune than the absence of misfortune. "Taking depth as the root" means that the foundation lies in the inception of the Great Ultimate. "Taking restraint as the guiding principle" means that the utmost simplicity and frugality are the methods of preserving oneself. "Guiding principle" means method. All things that are hard or sharp will break or be blunted—this is what is meant by "teeth, being hard, will shatter."

Taking the capacity to contain all things as one’s measure, nothing can diminish one. "Never carving away at others" means preserving one’s own life alone. "This may be called the ultimate attainment"—this is the ultimate Dao under heaven. To call them "great perfected" is an expression of reverence.

Vast and formless, ever-changing and constant, death and life as one, coextensive with heaven and earth, moving with the numinous and luminous—where does it go? Where does it wander? All things are encompassed, yet none can be its refuge. Among the arts of the Dao in antiquity, some were like this. Zhuang Zhou heard of their teachings and delighted in them, expounding with absurd and boundless words, wild and unbounded speech, limitless and unconstrained phrases, at times unrestrained yet never partial, never showing bias in his views.

He saw the world as sunk in turbidity, unfit for solemn discourse, so he used "goblet words" to ramble, "weighty words" as truth, and "parables" to broaden his meaning. Alone he roamed with the spirit of heaven and earth, yet never looked down upon the ten thousand things, never reproached right or wrong, and lived among the common world. Though his writings were intricate and marvelous, they flowed without harm; though his words were uneven and strange, they were profound and worth contemplating. His fullness could not be exhausted. Above, he wandered with the Creator; below, he befriended those beyond death and life, without beginning or end.

In regard to the root, his teachings were vast and expansive, profound and unbridled. In regard to the essence, they may be called well-tempered and supremely attained. Yet in responding to transformation and dissolving things, his principles were inexhaustible, his arrival unchanging. Vague and obscure, their depths remain unfathomed.

Vast and formless—this is nothingness. Ever-changing and constant—this is to take non-unity as unity. Death and life as one—this is to be ignorant of life and death. From this single phrase, one knows that the learning of the Śākya has long been present. "Coextensive with heaven and earth"—this is to be of the same body as heaven and earth. "Moving with the numinous and luminous"—this is to move in harmony with creation. "Where does it go? Where does it wander?"—this is to act without trace. "All things are encompassed"—this is to fully realize the principles of the ten thousand things. "None can be its refuge"—this means that none can know its ultimate destination.

"Absurd and boundless" means distant and unfathomable. "Wild and unbounded" means vast and limitless. "Limitless and unconstrained" means without beginning or end. "At times unrestrained yet never partial"—his teachings were free yet without faction. "Partial" means partisan. "Never showing bias in his views"—his insights were not confined to one aspect. "Bias" means singularity.

He saw the people of the world as foolish and sunk in turbidity, unable to be enlightened by sincere and earnest speech. "Solemn discourse" means dignified and truthful speech.

Spreading and unfolding—this means boundless. "To be true" means to invoke the weight of antiquity, first desiring others to regard it as real. "To be vast" means to lodge meaning in words that are broad and unrestrained. To commune with the spirit of Heaven and Earth, to befriend the natural workings of creation—this is to be a true companion. "Not scorning the ten thousand things" means not using this to scorn the world. Yet Zhuangzi’s intent was precisely to scorn this world, and thus he spoke in such contrary terms.

"Not reproving right and wrong" means that right and wrong are not clung to. Only when there is no right and no wrong can one dwell among the common customs of the age. "Magnificent and grand"—this means lofty and majestic. "Interwoven and harmonious"—this conveys the meaning of blending and merging as one. "No harm"—this means no mockery of others. "Uneven and irregular"—sometimes this, sometimes that; sometimes suppressed, sometimes exalted—it cannot be fixed. "Playful and cunning"—this means witty, slippery, and elusive. These two lines reveal the intent behind his writing: though his words may seem strange and absurd, they are worthy of contemplation. Once these two lines are understood, one can read Zhuangzi.

"That which is replete and cannot be restrained"—this means that within his book, principles fill every space, making it a work the world cannot do without. "Root" means the fundamental teaching. The root and teaching of his book are nothing other than the vast, profound, and harmonious Dao. "Opening wide"—this means expansive. "Unfettered"—this means freely released. "Ascending to fulfillment"—this means it can ascend to the principles of Heaven. Though his words are all of non-action and naturalness, when applied to the world, they respond to transformation and resolve the principles of things—meaning they can civilize customs and clarify principles.

"Its principles are inexhaustible"—this means their use is never depleted. "Not shedding"—this means his words arise from the Dao and do not depart from it. "Vast and obscure"—this describes the profound depth of his book. "Not yet fully expressed"—this means that what he attained in his heart cannot be fully conveyed in words.

From the beginning onward, he distinguishes five teachings and places himself last, following Laozi, explicitly stating that his learning derives from Laozi. The first three sections each begin with "though," all making definitive statements about the validity of his learning. Only Laozi is free of such judgments. Here, he again uses "though," saying his learning is not without use in the world. This is where the text shifts, displaying its highest literary skill—it must be read with great care.

Hui Shi was versatile in many arts; his writings filled five carts. Yet his Dao was contradictory and flawed, and his words did not hit the mark. His "intent in surveying things" states: "That which is supremely great has no outside—this is called the Great One. That which is supremely small has no inside—this is called the Small One. Without thickness, it cannot accumulate, yet its greatness spans a thousand *li*. Heaven and Earth are low; mountains and marshes are level. The sun is just at its zenith yet already slanting; things are just born yet already dying. Great sameness differs from small sameness—this is called the small sameness and difference. The ten thousand things are entirely the same and entirely different—this is called the great sameness and difference."

Mo Di, Song Xing, Peng, Tian, and Shen Dao were all partial in their grasp of the Dao, but Hui Shi merely delighted in debate and thus did not partake in the true arts. His mention in the "Lineage of Those Who Have Heard the Wind" appears only at the end of the chapter. "His writings filled five carts"—this means his books, though numerous, could not be contained even by five carts. Yet despite their volume, his learning was not correct, and his words were not apt, hence the criticism of their contradictions and inaccuracy.

"Intent in surveying things"—this means examining one by one the ideas he discussed regarding things. "Supremely great has no outside"—this refers to the great void. "Supremely small has no inside"—this refers to things like the tip of an autumn hair. These eight characters align with what Zhuangzi said, but by calling them the Great One and Small One, he introduces the beginning of disputation. If one speaks of "the One," there is no great or small; yet within the One, he distinguishes great and small—this is sameness within difference and difference within sameness.

"Without thickness"—this means supremely thin. "Cannot accumulate"—for if it accumulates, it becomes thick. Accumulate without cease, and its greatness can reach a thousand *li*. Thus, he speaks of great and small as the same: the vastness of a thousand *li* is merely the accumulation of that which has no thickness. Though Heaven is high and Earth spread low, when Heaven’s *qi* descends, it too becomes low—hence "Heaven and Earth are low." Though mountains are higher than marshes, the *qi* of marshes can reach mountains, so "mountains and marshes are level."

"Slanting"—this means looking sideways. When the sun is at its zenith, if one looks at it sideways, it is no longer at the center. Thus, "just at its zenith yet already slanting." Things are just born, yet their seeds must have come from what died before—hence "just born yet already dying." To speak of great and small is to speak of small sameness and difference. To unite the ten thousand things in sameness and difference is to speak of great sameness and difference. Though one may call it great, it does not transcend the accumulation of small things; though one may call it small, when combined, it can become great—thus there is neither sameness nor difference.

"The south has no limit yet has a limit. Today I go to Yue, yet I came yesterday. Linked rings can be unlinked. I know the center of the world—it is north of Yan and south of Yue. Embracing all things with universal love—Heaven and Earth are one body." Hui Shi regarded these as grand insights into the world, and those skilled in debate among the world’s debaters delighted in them.

"The south"—this refers to the sea. Though it is boundless, to call it a "direction" implies it must have a limit. This is true of all four directions, but he speaks only of the south not merely to illustrate one and imply the other three, but because Heaven leans to the northwest and the sea lies only in the south, while the other three directions in the north are distant—hence he speaks of it specifically.

"Today I go to Yue, yet I came yesterday"—though my feet have not yet reached Yue, knowing of Yue’s name and having come later, today’s departure can also be called yesterday’s arrival. Two rings linked together cannot be unlinked, yet each ring is itself a circle and cannot adhere to the other. If they do not adhere, they are not truly linked rings.

"Embracing all things with universal love—Heaven and Earth are one body"—this is the teaching of Mo Di. Hui Shi took this as a grand vision of the world, and those skilled in debate among the world’s debaters rejoiced in it.

In the north lies Yan, in the south Yue—neither is the center of the world. Yet the people of Yan know only Yan, and the people of Yue know only Yue. At the world’s beginning, neither knew of the other, each taking their own land as the center of Heaven and Earth.

All things form one body with Heaven and Earth, so though Heaven and Earth are vast, they are but one thing among the ten thousand things. How then can there be great or small? They are of one body.

The grand vision claims this as uniquely lofty above all under Heaven, and thus its doctrine is taught to those who study debate. Once the world’s scholars rejoiced in it together, its influence spread ever wider, giving rise to the following arguments:

Eggs have hair.
A chicken has three feet.
Ying possesses all under Heaven.
A dog can be a sheep.
A horse lays eggs.
A tadpole has a tail.
Fire is not hot.
Mountains speak.
Wheels do not touch the ground.
Eyes do not see.
Fingers do not reach, yet what reaches is not continuous.
A tortoise is longer than a snake.
A carpenter’s square is not square; a compass cannot draw a circle.
A chisel does not fit its socket.
The shadow of a flying bird never moves.
An arrow in flight has a moment of neither motion nor stillness.
A dog is not a hound.
A yellow horse and a black ox make three.

A white dog is black. A solitary colt has never had a mother. A one-foot staff, halved each day, will never be exhausted for ten thousand generations. Debaters used these arguments to engage with Hui Shi, exhausting themselves without end.

Huan Tuan and Gongsun Long, disciples of the debaters, adorned men’s minds and altered their intentions. They could overcome others in speech but could not win over their hearts—such was the confinement of the debaters. Hui Shi daily wielded his knowledge to contend with others, uniquely crafting monstrosities with the world’s debaters; this was his foundation.

Yet Hui Shi, in his oral disputations, deemed himself the most worthy, declaring, “How grand are Heaven and Earth!” Though he maintained a bold stance, he lacked true method.

As for the claim that eggs have hair: though the hair within an egg is not yet visible, the feathers of sparrows and chickens differ. For instance, if a chicken were to brood a duck’s egg, what emerges would bear duck feathers, not chicken feathers—thus, eggs have hair.

A chicken, by nature, has two feet, but there must be something that moves and propels it—hence, three.

That Ying possesses all under Heaven: the capital of Chu was at Ying, where its ruler declared himself king, no different from one who has gained the world.

That a dog can be a sheep: the names “dog” and “sheep” arise from human convention, not from the things themselves. Had the first beings called a dog a sheep, people today would likewise regard it as a sheep; had they called a sheep a dog, people today would regard it as a dog.

That a horse lays eggs: though live birth differs from egg-laying, the terms “womb-born” and “egg-born” are human constructs. If one may call a womb an egg, then the same logic applies to dogs and sheep.

Dingzi refers to the toad or frog; in Chu, it is called *dingzi*. Though the toad has no tail, it begins as a tadpole, which does have a tail—thus, one may say the toad has a tail.

That fire is not hot: heat and cold are also human designations. Moreover, there are fire-dwelling rats and fire-washed cloth. If rats can enter and exit fire, and fire can wash cloth, then it is not hot.

That mountains speak: empty valleys transmit sound; when one calls out, an echo answers—is this not the mountain having a mouth?

That wheels do not touch the ground: when a wheel rolls upon the earth, it is a wheel, but the moment it touches the ground, it cannot turn—thus, one may say wheels do not tread the earth.

That eyes do not see: only after the eye sees can the finger reach. Yet the eye cannot reach what the finger cannot see—thus, what reaches is neither separable from nor continuous with the eye and finger.

That a tortoise is longer than a snake: if a tortoise were as long as a snake, it would no longer be called a tortoise. Since it is called a tortoise, its length is naturally thus—one may also say it is longer than a snake.

That a carpenter’s square is not square, and a compass cannot draw a circle: once called a square, it cannot also be called square; once called a compass, it cannot also be called round.

That a chisel does not fit its socket: though the tenon rests within the mortise, its rotation cannot be restrained by the mortise—thus, one may say it does not fit, or that the fit is imperfect.

That the shadow of a flying bird never moves: once the bird takes flight, the shadow follows it away. One may speak of the bird’s flight, but not of the shadow’s movement.

That an arrow in flight has a moment of neither motion nor stillness: when the arrow is on the bowstring, it is at rest; when it strikes the target, it is in motion. Between leaving the string and reaching the target, there is a moment of neither motion nor stillness.

That a dog is not a hound: dog and hound are the same thing. If called a dog, it cannot be called a hound; if called a hound, it cannot be called a dog—thus, a dog is not a hound.

That a yellow horse and a black ox make three: horse and ox are two bodies; yellow and black are two colors. To speak of two bodies alongside two colors is to make three.

That a yellow horse and a black ox make three: yellow and black are two colors; horse and ox are two bodies. When two colors attach to two bodies, they become three.

That a white dog is black: the names “black” and “white” do not arise from the original nature of things. Thus, one may also call white black.

That a solitary colt has never had a mother: to name it “solitary” is to deny it ever had a mother; one cannot say it is solitary yet once had a mother.

A one-foot staff, broken in half each day: today one uses this half, tomorrow that half. Though divided endlessly, it will never be exhausted for ten thousand generations.

All the above arguments were learned from Master Hui, expanding his doctrines to engage with him. Throughout their lives, they ceaselessly debated—such were Huan Tuan, Gongsun Long, and their ilk.

To adorn men’s minds is to obscure them; to alter their intentions is to confuse them. In a moment’s debate, though one may silence another in speech, the other’s heart remains unconvinced. The debaters, lost in their own labyrinth, do not perceive this—thus, it is called their *enclosure*.

Hui Shi daily wielded his knowledge to contend with others, relying on his cleverness to overpower them in debate. Alone, he and his followers became objects of astonishment—yet this was the extent of his ability, and thus it is called his *foundation*. *Foundation* means root.

He prided himself on his rhetorical skill, deeming his grandeur equal to Heaven and Earth. Though he maintained a bold stance, he was truly devoid of learning and method.

In the south there was a man named Huang Liao who asked why Heaven and Earth do not collapse or sink, and the causes of wind, rain, thunder, and lightning. Hui Shi did not decline but answered without hesitation, discoursing on the myriad things without pause. Though his words were many, he deemed them few and added ever more monstrosities.

He took contrarianism as truth and sought to prevail over others in reputation, which is why he never fit in with the crowd. Weak in virtue yet strong in disputation, his path grew ever more obscure.

Viewing Hui Shi’s abilities through the Dao of Heaven and Earth, he was no more than a mosquito or gadfly’s labor—what use was he to the world? To fill one vessel is possible; to exalt the Dao further is near perfection. Yet Hui Shi could not find peace in this. Scattered among the myriad things, never satisfied, he ultimately gained fame as a master of debate.

Alas for Hui Shi’s talent—so unbounded yet unfulfilled, chasing the myriad things without return! He exhausted echoes for sound, while form and shadow raced in vain. How lamentable!

Those who lean upon others are men of strange divergence. In the south there was a solitary lofty man named Huang Liao, who questioned Hui Shi: “Why does Heaven not fall? Why does Earth not sink? Who truly brings forth wind, rain, thunder, and lightning?” These are the marvels of Creation—how could words contain them? Yet Hui Shi did not decline but answered without hesitation, responding without deliberation, discoursing on the ten thousand things in endless variety. The myriad things are manifold indeed. Though his words were many, he deemed them few and added ever more monstrosities. Taking contrarianism as truth, he sought to prevail over others through eloquence, crafting a reputation for himself—thus he never harmonized with the world. *Not fitting* means not finding accord. Within, he had no true attainment, hence “weak in virtue.” Outwardly, he forced disputation, hence “strong in things.” *Ào* means dark and secluded; his path was neither bright nor upright but obscure and crooked.

Viewing Hui Shi’s abilities through the Dao of Heaven and Earth, he was no more than a mosquito or gadfly’s labor. What use was he to the world of men? To fill one vessel is possible; to deem this superior to exalting the Dao is perilous. *Yù* means to surpass; *jī* means peril. Unable to find peace within himself, he scattered his efforts among the myriad things, never satisfied, ultimately knowing not the Dao but gaining fame as a master of debate. *Zú* means in the end.

Hui Shi was indeed a man of talent, yet his dissipation brought no attainment, and his pursuit of externals left him without return—how regrettable! *Dài* means dissipation. Echo arises from sound, sound being the root and echo the branch; to exhaust echoes for sound is to forget the root. Shadow arises from form, form being the root and shadow the branch; to seek rest for the shadow without stopping the form is to race with it—another parable of forgetting the root.

This concludes the *Zhuangzi*, ending with Hui Shi. Though he did not stand among those who grasped the Dao, his words as a debater were ever turning nothing into something, and his speech was indeed extraordinary—thus he fittingly closes this chapter. For though this work differs from composition, it too has its own structure, with deliberate openings and endings. Like the *Spring and Autumn Annals*’ final brushstroke at the capture of the qilin, or the *Doctrine of the Mean*’s “Heaven’s charge is soundless, scentless,” this book’s Inner Chapters—with “Hundun’s seven orifices”—all follow a single pattern, which must not be overlooked.

Those who explain the classics in terms of literary technique may not grasp the principle; those who grasp the principle may overlook the literary art. Thus their readings lack vitality, and their interpretations lack savor. Only Master Aixuan, whose Dao was lofty and whose prose was exquisitely refined, gave the Six Classics an interpretation that stands apart through the ages. Alas, after Wangshan and Lexuan, his learning was not transmitted, and no one today knows of it.

The *Book of Southern Florescence* is a marvel of brushwork across past and present. Yet those who revere it may drift into hollow emptiness, while those who mock it may doubt its strangeness and extravagance. Though its literary brilliance cannot be erased, its annotations have long remained obscure, a lasting burden upon the text.

In my youth, I served Master Chen Lexuan, hearing fragments of his discourse. I came to admire the text but could not fully grasp its passages. Later, I traveled and studied with Zhuxi, often taking it up to read together. I delighted in its lucid dissections, though its divergences from common understanding were many. The more I read, the deeper my admiration grew.

After passing the imperial examinations and returning south, I lived in leisure for a long while. I devoted myself to the study of the classics, and with this book, the more I read, the more I loved it—and the more I doubted it. For this book is difficult to comprehend: its words often differ from our own, its arguments sometimes contradict the ancient sages, and its purport resists inquiry—like grasping at shadows in midair or seizing a horned dragon with bare hands. Its unifying principle eludes certainty, like tracing the three rivers to their hidden tributaries or following the nine streams to their lost courses.

Each time I opened the scroll, I could not help but leap with joy, nor could I avoid sinking into confusion. In the year *wuwu*, I visited Zhuxi by the stream, and in conversation, he suddenly said to me: "I once wished to cleanse Master Nanhua’s old immortal of Guo Xiang’s vulgarities, but with each meal and every shift of circumstance, I never found the time to shut my door and write. Since misfortune and setbacks have forced me into retirement, I have turned to this work to ease my cares and amuse my old age. Now, at last, the book is complete."

Overjoyed, I sought it out. Upon returning, I read it eagerly and saw how it divided and analyzed, branched and dissected, with no empty phrases in its chapters, no superfluous words in its lines. It unfolded with boundless freedom, stirring and transforming like a dance without end. Yet every word and phrase had its place, as if waking from a dream to find clarity, or being freed from bonds to gain release.

Only then did I understand that this book stands as a school unto itself, unbound by conventional meanings. Though it roams the profound and obscure, it does not neglect worldly affairs. It does not fail to recognize the worth of sages and worthies but disdains mere conformity. It does not ignore the excesses of cunning and deceit but champions defiance of the vulgar. Whether in ancient or modern times, those who recite it may differ, but all have merely glimpsed its fence without reaching its inner sanctum.

Since assuming my post in this humble district, though official documents pile high and my days are constrained, in the quiet of early dawn before the clerks assemble, I must light a lamp and chant its verses—sometimes finishing a single chapter, sometimes an entire scroll—dancing with hands and feet, as if meeting the author in person.

Thus I declare: the *Book of Southern Florescence* is indispensable to this world, and Zhuxi’s exegesis is indispensable to *Southern Florescence*. For Zhuxi’s learning derives from Lexuan, Lexuan’s from Wangshan, and Wangshan’s from old Master Aixuan, transmitted through three generations without deviation. Zhuxi not only mastered his teacher’s transmission but also scoured the Buddhist and Daoist texts beyond the Six Classics, the Masters, and the Histories. Thus he was able to fathom the hidden subtleties of this old master and exhaust his ingenious insights. If *Southern Florescence* were to return to life, he would surely be its confidant.

Now, those who read this book may do so without regret. Though our district is remote, my devotion to it runs deep, and I wished to spread its transmission. By economizing on furs and provisions, I have fortunately brought the project to completion. Here I record why I love it, how I came to understand it, and the joy it has brought me.

Zhuxi of the Lin family, styled Suweng, once held office as a literary official. Now he serves as *Baomo* Director of the Jade Bureau Abbey. *Yanzhai* is the name of his study. His prose often resembles that of Zhuangzi. This book is titled *Oral Exegesis* because it does not strive for literary polish but freely mixes the colloquial with direct exposition.

In the first year of the Jingding era, during the Zhonghe Festival, Lin Jingde, *Xuanjiao Lang* and Magistrate of Jianning County in Shaowu Prefecture, composed this preface.

Zhuangzi’s prose soars with heroic grandeur, traversing all things in spirit and roaming beyond the cosmos in mind—his joy and insight unmatched by any in antiquity. His words surge and transform, eclipsing sun and moon, cleaving through clouds and rivers, at once subtle and flowing, resplendent as scales and feathers, vast as heaven and sea. Though lavish, they never entangle; though bold, they never overreach—truly the most towering literary achievement under heaven.

Yanzhai’s exegesis of this work is like the soaking immersion of rivers and seas, the nourishing moisture of fertile rains. He enters Zhuangzi’s emotions as his own, follows his thoughts as his own, dreams his dreams and awakens to his awakenings. Thus, he speaks Zhuangzi’s words and points to his pointers, bringing forth voice, laughter, and presence as if in person—so that readers encounter him face to face. How could this be achieved by mere luck or effort?

Yanzhai’s learning is profound, his discernment peerless; his roots run deep, his practice refined. In the realm of his awakening, no height is too lofty to brush against; in stillness and depth, his insight ascends effortlessly. I observe Yanzhai: his bearing is noble, his form and function harmonious with heaven and earth, his spirit full and luminous, stretching forth with self-assured majesty—is he not like the *kun* and *peng*? Yet he has also steeped himself in this text, and who but Yanzhai could grasp its words as he does?

Now, Yanzhai’s work stands resolute, reviving Zhuangzi from dry bones and unlocking a treasure trove of millennia. Is Yanzhai not himself a figure of great magnanimity, a heroic and towering scholar? When I first obtained this text, I read it with astonishment, recording my marvel at the end to pass down to my descendants—not that I dare claim to fully comprehend Yanzhai’s exegesis.

When the Old Immortal of Qiyuan composed this work, his vision of the Dao was precise, his indignation at the world keen. Only his reclusive and untrammeled ways allowed him to express it, and only his extraordinary vigor allowed him to unfold it—venturing into boundless obscurity, stirring transformations beyond measure. One may trust the reach of his eye and the force of his brush. Yet he did not know when he overstepped, when he verged on the extravagant. Did he ever intend, at the outset, to leave this for posterity or establish a teaching? Or to exalt Laozi while suppressing the Confucians? Why, then, do readers fail to perceive this? Some dismiss it as mere "emptiness and nothingness," others condemn it as "heterodoxy." They see its transcendent vision, hear its world-shaking words, yet often stumble over incomplete sentences or unclear characters, resorting to doubt, omission, or excuses. Did Zhuangzi ever wish for such treatment from later generations?

Master Yanzhai of the Jade Bureau, Lord Lin, received the Dao of the Sage from Lexuan. Lexuan’s relation to Zhuangzi is like that of Ziyun to later ages; Yanzhai’s to Lexuan, like Houba to the *Great Mystery*. Thus, he emerged to compose this work—organizing its chapters, parsing its sentences, clarifying its characters—so that no chapter lacks explanation, no sentence lacks resolution, no character lacks illumination. What was once empty is now solid, what was divergent now unified, what was doubtful now certain, what was fragmented now complete. Only after thousands of years does the *Nanhua Jing* become a whole book in the world. Not only will the Old Immortal leap for joy above the ninefold heavens, but Lexuan, too, will surely dance with hands and feet between the seen and unseen.

Some ask: If one applies philological scholarship to a text on life and destiny—like Master Zhu’s "culmination of all learning," which offers exegesis from the *Book of Changes* to the *Songs of Chu*, yet leaves Zhuangzi’s work untouched—is this not a flaw? I reply: Does not Han Yu’s saying hold—"from the ancient *Ya* and *Song* to Zhuangzi and Qu Yuan"? And did not Master Zhu himself say, "The scholars of the Jin and Song did not fully grasp Zhuangzi’s truth"? If not, is there still more to uncover, or was this left for a reason yet to come? Yanzhai’s achievement may well stand no lower than Master Zhu’s.

I fear that later scholars, forgetting past difficulties and delighting in present ease, may grow complacent. Thus, I reiterate these words.

chunks.original_text: 庄子口义发题 庄子，宋人也，名周，字子休，生睢阳蒙县。 在战国之初，与孟子同时，隐遁而放言者也。 所着之书名以庄子，自分为三，内篇七，外篇十五，杂篇十一，虽其分别次第如此，而所谓寓言、重言、卮言三者，通一书皆然也。 外篇、杂篇则即其篇首而名之，内篇则立为名字，各有意义，其文比之外篇、杂篇为尤精，而立言之意则无彼此之异。 陈同甫尝曰：天下不可以无此人，亦不可以无此书，而后足以当君子之论。 若庄子者，其书虽为不经，实天下所不可无者。 郭子玄谓其不经而为百家之冠，此语甚公。 然此书不可不读，亦最难读。 东坡一生文字，只从此悟入。 大藏经五百四十函，皆自此中细绎出。 左丘明、司马子长诸人笔力，未易敌此，是岂可不读。 然谓之难者，何也。 伊川曰：佛书如淫声美色，易以惑人，盖以其语震动而见易摇也。 况此书所言仁义性命之类，字义皆与吾书不同，一难也； 其意欲与吾夫子争衡，故其言多过当，二难也； 鄙略中下之人，如佛书所谓为最上乘者说，故其言每每过高，三难也； 又其笔端鼓舞变化，皆不可以寻常文字蹊径求之，四难也； 况语脉机锋多如禅家顿宗所谓剑刃上事，吾儒书中未尝有此，五难也。 是必精於语、孟、中庸、大学等书，见理素定，识文字血脉，知禅宗解数，具此眼目而后知其言意，一一有所归着，未尝不跌荡，未尝不戏剧。 而大纲领大宗旨未尝於圣人异也。 若此眼未明，强生意见，非以异端邪说鄙之，必为其所恐动，或资以诞放，或流而空虚，则伊川淫声美色之喻诚不可不惧。 希逸少尝有闻於乐轩，因乐轩而闻艾轩之说，文字血脉稍知梗概。 又颇尝涉猎佛书而后悟其纵横变化之机，自谓於此书稍有所得，实前人所未尽究者。 最后乃得吕吉甫、王元泽诸家解说，虽比郭象稍为分章析句，而大旨不明。 因王吕之言，愈使人有疑於庄子。 若以管见推之，则此书自可独行天地之间，初无得罪於圣门者，使庄子复生，谓之千载而下，子云可也。 非敢进之作者，聊与诸同志者共之。 鬳斋林希逸序。 庄子宋人也，名周，字子休。 生睢阳蒙县，尝为蒙漆园吏，学无所不窥，要本归於老子之言，故其着书十余万言，大抵率寓言也。 其言洸洋自恣以适已，故自王公大人不能器之。 楚威王闻周贤，使使厚币迎之，许以为相，周笑谓使者：千金重利，卿相尊位也，子独不见郊祭之牺牛乎，养食之数岁，衣以文绣，以入太庙，当是之时欲为孤豚，其可得乎。 子亟去，无污我。 我宁游戏污渎之中自快，无为有国者所羁，终身不仕，以快吾志焉。 唐封南华真人书为南华真经。 南华真经口义卷之一
chunks.translated_text:
**Preface to *Oral Explications of the Zhuangzi***

Zhuangzi was a native of Song, named Zhou, styled Zixiu, born in Meng County of Suiyang. Flourishing at the beginning of the Warring States period, he was a contemporary of Mencius, a recluse who spoke freely and without restraint. The book bearing his name is divided into three parts: seven Inner Chapters, fifteen Outer Chapters, and eleven Miscellaneous Chapters. Though thus arranged, the three modes of expression—*yuyan* (parables), *zhongyan* (weighty sayings), and *zhiyan* (spontaneous words)—pervade the entire work. The Outer and Miscellaneous Chapters take their titles from their opening lines, while the Inner Chapters bear thematic names, each with its own significance. Their language is more refined than that of the Outer and Miscellaneous Chapters, yet the intent behind their words differs not at all.

Chen Tongfu once remarked: "The world cannot do without such a man, nor without such a book, for only then can the discourse of the noble person be complete." Though the *Zhuangzi* may be deemed unorthodox, it is in truth indispensable. Guo Zixuan called it the crown of the Hundred Schools despite its heterodoxy—a most just assessment. Yet this book, while essential, is also the most difficult to read. Su Dongpo’s entire literary corpus was enlightened by its insights. The five thousand and forty volumes of the *Great Treasury of Scriptures* were all meticulously distilled from its depths. The narrative power of Zuo Qiuming and Sima Zichang pales in comparison—how could one not read it?

Yet why is it called difficult? As Master Yichuan observed: "Buddhist texts are like seductive music and alluring beauty, easily bewitching the mind, for their words are stirring and their appearances deceptive." How much more so with this book? Its discussions of benevolence, righteousness, nature, and destiny differ in terminology from our own classics—this is the first difficulty. Its intent is to rival the teachings of our Master Confucius, so its language often exceeds proper bounds—this is the second difficulty. It addresses the coarse and vulgar as if expounding the highest Mahayana doctrines, so its words frequently soar too high—this is the third difficulty. Its brushwork dances and transforms in ways that cannot be traced through ordinary literary paths—this is the fourth difficulty. Moreover, its linguistic threads and spiritual thrusts resemble the "sword’s edge" of Chan sudden enlightenment, a style absent in our Confucian texts—this is the fifth difficulty.

Only one well-versed in the *Analects*, *Mencius*, *Doctrine of the Mean*, and *Great Learning*, with a firm grasp of principle, an understanding of textual veins, and knowledge of Chan techniques, can discern its meaning, finding each word and phrase grounded in truth. Though its style is unrestrained and playful, its grand principles and fundamental aims never deviate from the Sage’s Way. Without such discernment, one may impose arbitrary interpretations, either dismissing it as heretical and perverse or being swayed by its allure, leading to licentiousness or emptiness. Thus, Master Yichuan’s warning about "seductive music and alluring beauty" is not to be taken lightly.

I, Xi Yi, once heard of this work from Le Xuan, and through him, of Ai Xuan’s teachings, gaining a rough understanding of its textual veins. After extensive study of Buddhist texts, I grasped its mechanisms of free and transformative expression, believing I had attained some insight into this book—insights unexhausted by previous scholars. Later, I encountered the commentaries of Lü Jifu and Wang Yuanzhe, which, though more detailed in chapter and verse than Guo Xiang’s, obscured its grand purpose. Their interpretations only deepened doubts about the *Zhuangzi*. Yet in my humble view, this book stands alone in the world, never having offended the teachings of the Sage. If Zhuangzi were to return today, he might well say, "A thousand years later, only Ziyun (Yang Xiong) could match me." I do not presume to elevate it to the level of its author but merely share these reflections with fellow seekers.

—Preface by Lin Xiyi of Yuanzhai

---

Zhuangzi was a native of Song, named Zhou, styled Zixiu. Born in Meng County of Suiyang, he once served as the keeper of the Lacquer Garden in Meng. His learning was vast, but its essence returned to the words of Laozi. Thus, he composed a book of over a hundred thousand words, mostly in the form of parables. His language flowed freely and unconstrained, suiting only himself, so even kings and nobles could not employ him.

King Wei of Chu, hearing of Zhuang Zhou’s worthiness, sent envoys with generous gifts to invite him, offering the position of prime minister. Zhuangzi laughed and said to the envoys: "A thousand gold pieces are a great profit; the office of minister is a lofty rank. Have you not seen the sacrificial ox of the suburban rites? Fed for years and adorned with embroidered robes, it is led into the great temple. At that moment, if it wished to be a solitary piglet, could it do so? Begone quickly, and do not defile me! I would rather roam and play in the filth of ditches, delighting in myself, than be fettered by rulers. I will never serve, that my will may be fulfilled."

During the Tang dynasty, he was posthumously enfeoffed as the True Man of Nanhua, and his book was titled the *True Scripture of Nanhua*.

**Oral Explications of the *True Scripture of Nanhua*, Volume One**

chunks.original_text: 鬳斋林希逸 内篇逍遥游 逍遥游者，此篇所立之名也。 内篇有七，皆以三字名之。 游者，心有天游也； 逍遥，言优游自在也。 论语之门人形容夫子只一乐字，三百篇之形容人物如南有憀木，如南山有台，曰乐只君子，亦止一乐字。 此之所谓逍遥游即诗与论语所谓乐也。 一部之书以一乐字为首，看这老子胸中如何，若就此见得有些滋味，则可以读芣苢矣。 芣苢一诗，形容胸中之乐，并一乐字，亦不说此诗法之妙，譬如七层塔上，又一层也。 北冥有鱼，其名为鲲。 鲲之大，不知其几千里也。 化而为乌，其名为鹏，鹏之背，不知其几千里也，怒而飞，其翼若垂天之云。 是鸟也，海运则将徙於南冥，南冥者，天池也。 齐谐者，志怪者也。 谐之言曰：鹏之徙於南冥也，水击三千里，抟扶摇而上者九万里，去以六月息者也。 野马也，尘埃也，生物之以息相吹也。 天之苍苍，其正色邪，其远而无所至极邪。 其视下也，亦若是则已矣。 且夫水之积也不厚，则负大舟也无力，覆杯水於坳堂之上，则芥为之舟。 置杯焉则胶，水浅而舟大也。 风之积也不厚，则其负大翼也无力，故九万里则风斯在下矣。 而后乃今培风，背负青天而莫之夭关者，而后乃今将图南。 蜩与鸒鸠笑之曰：我决起而飞，抢榆枋，时则不至而控於地而已矣。 奚以之九万里而南为。 此段只是形容胸中广大之乐，却设此譬喻其意。 盖谓人之所见者小，故有世俗纷纷之争，若知天地之外有如许世界，自视其身，虽太仓一粒，不足以喻之。 戴晋人所谓蜗角蛮触，亦此意也。 北冥，北海也，鲲鹏之名亦寓言耳。 或以阴阳论之，皆是强生节目。 乌之飞也必以气下，一怒字便自奇特。 海运者，海动也，今海濒之俚歌犹有六月海动之语。 海动必有大风，其水涌沸自海底而起，声闻数里。 言必有此大风而后可以南徙也。 南冥亦海也，庄子又以天池训之。 齐谐书名也，其所志述皆怪异非常之事，如今山海经之类。 然此书亦未必有，庄子既撰此说，又引此书以自证，此又是其戏剧处。 抟，飞翔也； 扶摇，风势也； 三千、九万，即形容其高远也。 去以六月息者，此鸟之往来必歇住半年方可动也。 野马尘埃三句，此是他文字最奇处，前后说多不通。 野马，游丝也，水气也，子美所谓落花游丝白曰静是也。 言此野马尘埃自何而得，皆世间之生物，以其气息自相吹嘘，故虚空之中有此物也。 此三句本要形容下句，却先安顿於此，谓人之仰视乎天，见其苍苍，然岂其正色，特吾目力既穷，其上无所极止，故但见蒙蒙然尔。 鹏之飞也既至於天上，则其下视人间，不知相去几千万里，其野马尘埃相吹之息，亦必如此蒙蒙然，犹人之在下视天上也。 此数句只是形容鹏飞之高，如此下，得来多少奇特。 若如从前之说，以鹏为大，野马尘埃为细，与前句不相接，后句不相关，如何见得他笔力。 水之积也不厚，为下句风之喻也。 坳堂，堂上坳深处也，其水既微，但能浮一芥而已，以杯盏之类置其间，则胶住矣。 胶音教，言粘住不动也。 鹏在天上，去地下九万里，风自汉谷而起，而后蓬蓬然周遍四海。 鹏既在上，则此风在下，培，厚也，九万里之风乃可谓之厚风，如此厚风，方能负载鹏翼。

**Oral Explications of the *True Scripture of Nanhua*, Volume One**
*By Lin Xiyi of Yanzhai*

The "Free and Easy Wandering" is the title established for this chapter. The Inner Chapters number seven, each named with three characters. *Wandering* signifies the mind’s roaming through the heavens; *free and easy* describes a state of unconstrained ease. In the *Analects*, the disciples depict the Master with but a single word—*joy*; in the *Three Hundred Poems*, when portraying figures such as "the forlorn tree in the south" or "the terrace on Southern Mountain," they say, "Joyful is the noble man"—again, but a single word, *joy*. Thus, what this chapter calls *free and easy wandering* is precisely what the *Poetry* and the *Analects* mean by *joy*. The entire work begins with this single word, *joy*—consider then the vastness of this old man’s heart! If one can perceive even a trace of its savor here, then one may proceed to read the poem *Fou Yi*. That poem depicts the joy within the heart, yet without ever uttering the word *joy*—its artistry lies in this very subtlety, like ascending a seven-tiered pagoda to find yet another level above.

"In the Northern Darkness there is a fish, and its name is Kun. The Kun’s greatness—no one knows how many thousand *li* it spans. It transforms into a bird, and its name is Peng. The Peng’s back—no one knows how many thousand *li* it stretches. When it rises in fury and takes flight, its wings are like clouds hanging from the sky. This bird, when the sea surges, will journey to the Southern Darkness. The Southern Darkness is the Celestial Pond.

*The Equalizing Harmony* is a record of marvels. It states: When the Peng journeys to the Southern Darkness, it strikes the water for three thousand *li*, spiraling upon the whirlwind to ascend ninety thousand *li*, departing with the winds of the sixth month. The *wild horses*, the dust motes—all living things are blown aloft by one another’s breath. The azure of the sky—is that its true color? Or is it so distant that it has no end? From above, its view of what lies below is no different.

Moreover, if the water’s accumulation is not deep, it lacks the strength to bear a great vessel. Pour a cup of water into a hollow in the hall, and a mustard seed becomes a boat; place a cup there, and it sticks fast—too shallow for so large a vessel. If the wind’s accumulation is not deep, it lacks the strength to bear great wings. Thus, at ninety thousand *li*, the wind lies beneath. Only then, with the wind as its foundation, its back against the blue sky and nothing to obstruct it, does it at last set its course southward.

The cicada and the fledgling dove laugh at it, saying: ‘We burst forth and fly, striking the elm and sandalwood, and if we do not reach them, we simply alight upon the ground. Why go ninety thousand *li* to the south?’ This passage merely depicts the boundless joy within the heart, employing such metaphors to convey its meaning. It suggests that human vision is narrow, hence the ceaseless strife of the mundane world. But if one knows that beyond heaven and earth lie such vast realms, one sees oneself as but a single grain in the granary of Tai—insignificant beyond measure. This is the same idea as Dai Jinren’s ‘warring ants on a snail’s horn.’

The Northern Darkness is the Northern Sea; the names Kun and Peng are but allegory. Some interpret them through the lens of yin and yang, but this is merely forcing divisions where none exist. That a bird’s flight must rely on the qi below—this ‘fury’ is already extraordinary. *Sea surging* means the sea in motion; even today, folk songs from coastal regions speak of the ‘sixth-month sea surge.’ Such surges arise from great winds, their waters churning from the ocean’s depths, their roar audible for miles. The passage insists that only such winds can carry the Peng southward. The Southern Darkness is also a sea, yet Zhuangzi calls it the Celestial Pond.

*The Equalizing Harmony* is the name of a book, its records filled with strange and extraordinary events, much like the *Classic of Mountains and Seas*. Yet this book may not have existed at all; Zhuangzi, having crafted this tale, then cites it as proof—another instance of his playful artistry. *Spiraling* describes its flight; *whirlwind* refers to the wind’s force. The numbers three thousand and ninety thousand simply convey its vast height and distance. *Departing with the winds of the sixth month* means this bird’s journeys require half a year’s rest before it can move again.

The three lines about *wild horses* and *dust motes* are among the most extraordinary in his writing, though they seem disconnected from what precedes or follows. *Wild horses* are drifting filaments, water vapor—what Du Fu called ‘fallen blossoms and drifting filaments, white days at peace.’ The question is: whence do these *wild horses* and *dust motes* arise? They are but the breath of living things, blown aloft by one another’s qi, filling the emptiness of space. These lines are meant to set up the next, yet they are placed here first: when one gazes upward at the sky, seeing its azure hue, is that its true color? Or is it merely that our vision fails, unable to reach its limit, so that all we perceive is a hazy expanse? The Peng, having flown to the heavens, looks down upon the world below—how many tens of thousands of *li* lie between? The breath of *wild horses* and *dust motes* must appear just as hazy, like the view from below looking up. These few lines, depicting the Peng’s lofty flight, achieve a marvelous effect. If one were to interpret the Peng as vast and the *wild horses* and *dust motes* as tiny, the passage would lose its coherence, its power unraveling.

The line about the water’s accumulation not being deep serves as a metaphor for the wind below. A *hollow in the hall* is a depression in the floor; with so little water, it can only float a mustard seed. Place a cup there, and it sticks fast—*sticks* as in *glued*, meaning it cannot move, for the water is too shallow for so large a vessel. The Peng, ninety thousand *li* above the earth, with winds rising from the river valleys to fill the four seas—this wind lies beneath it. *Foundation* means depth; only a wind of ninety thousand *li* can be called deep. Such a wind alone can bear the Peng’s great wings."

chunks.original_text: 背负青天，言飞之高也； 莫之夭阏，无障碍也； 图南，自北海而谋南徙也。 图，谋也； 蜩，蝉也； 鸒鸠，学飞之小鸠也。 誉或作鸒，音预，亦小鸟而已，两字皆通。 决起者，奋起而飞也； 抢，突也。 奋起而飞欲突至於榆枋之上，不过丈尺之高，有时犹不能至，又投诸地。 控，投也，言我所飞不过如此，且有不能，彼乃欲藉九万里之风而南徙於天池，奚以奚用也。 此意谓浅见之人，局量狭小，不知世界之大也。 适莽苍者，三飧而反，腹犹果然； 适百里者，宿舂粮； 适千里者，三月聚粮。 之二虫又何知。 小知不及大知，小年不及大年，奚以知其然也。 朝菌不知晦朔，蟪蛄不知春秋，此小年也； 楚之南有冥灵者，以五百岁为春，五百岁为秋，上古有大椿者，以八千岁为春，八千岁为秋。 而彭祖乃今以久特闻，众人匹之，不亦悲乎。 莽苍者，一望之地，莽苍然不见，我欲适之，一往一来，不过三饭，而腹犹果然。 果，实也，食未尽消也，言其近也。 将为百里之往，则必隔宿舂捣粮米，而去非可三飧而已。 为千里之行，则须三月聚粮矣。 此三句以人之行有远有近，则所食亦有多有少，亦如人见有小大，则所志趣亦有远近，又为鹏与蜩鸠之喻也。 二虫者，蜩鸠也。 言彼何足以知此，故曰又何知。 小知不及大知，小年不及大年，此两句又是文之一体。 以小知大知一句结上鹏鸠，又以小年大年一句生下一段譬喻。 朝菌，大芝也，亦名日及，生於粪上，暮生，见日则死。 彼但知有朝暮而已，安知有晦朔也。 蟪蛄，寒蝉也，春生夏死，夏生秋死，不见四时之全，故曰小年。 冥灵，木名也，大椿亦木名也。 此亦寓言，不必求其实。 言冥灵之生一千年方当一岁，大椿之生一万六千年方当一岁，彭祖仅年八百，至今乃以高寿特闻於世，众人皆欲慕之而不及，亦是见小而不知大也。 久，寿也，匹，慕而求似之也。 汤之问棘也是已。 穷发之北有冥海者，天池也； 有鱼焉，其广数千里，未有知其修者，其名为鲲； 有鸟焉，其名为鹏，背若太山，翼若垂天之云，抟扶摇羊角而上者九万里，绝云气，负青天，然后图南，且适南冥也。 斥鴳笑之曰：彼且奚适也。 我腾跃而上，不过数仞而下，翱翔蓬蒿之间，此亦飞之至也，而彼且奚适也。 此小大之辨也。 此段只是前段又翻说一个证据。 言向来汤曾问棘，即此事也。 棘，人名也。 是已，即是也。 据此一句合结在下，以结语为起语，此其作文鼓舞处。 穷发，不毛也； 扶摇，风势也； 羊角，亦风之屈曲势也； 抟，飞翔也； 绝云气者，言九万里之上更无云气。 人言泰山绝顶，云皆在山下，雷鸣如婴儿声，然今人亦言云只在半天是也。 图南，且谋适南冥也。 言谋为南徙之计，而后往南海也。 斥，小泽也。 斥泽之鴳，小鸟也。 飞之至者，言我翱翔蓬蒿之间，其飞如此，亦至乐矣，又何必他往哉，其意即与前段同。 故夫知效一官，行比一乡，德合一君而征一国者，其自视也亦若此矣。 而宋荣子犹然笑之，且举世而誉之而不加劝，举世而非之而不加沮，定乎内外之分，辨乎荣辱之境，斯已矣。 彼其於世，未数数然也。 虽然，犹有未树也。

Its back bears the azure sky—this speaks of its soaring height; "no obstacle blocks its way"—this means no hindrance exists. *Tu-nan*: from the Northern Sea it plans its southward migration. *Tu* means "to plan." The *tiao* is the cicada; the *yujiao* is the fledgling dove learning to fly. *Yu* may also be written as *鸒*, pronounced *yu*, and is merely another small bird—both characters are interchangeable. *Jue-qi* means to surge upward in flight; *qiang* means to dash forward. When it surges upward to dash toward the elm or sandalwood, it rises no more than a few feet, and sometimes fails even to reach that height, falling back to the ground instead. *Kong* means "to cast down"—it says, "My flight goes no higher than this, and often falls short. Yet that creature would rely on a wind of ninety thousand *li* to migrate south to the Celestial Pond—what use is that to it, and how could it serve?" This means that those of shallow vision and narrow capacity do not comprehend the vastness of the world.

One who journeys to the *mangcang* returns after three meals, his belly still full; one bound for a hundred *li* lodges the night before to hull grain; one traveling a thousand *li* gathers provisions for three months. What do these two insects know? "Lesser knowledge cannot reach greater knowledge; short years cannot reach long years"—how do we know this is so? The morning mushroom knows nothing of dusk and dawn; the cicada knows nothing of spring and autumn—these are short-lived creatures. South of Chu there is the *Mingling*, which takes five hundred years as its spring and five hundred years as its autumn; in high antiquity there was the Great *Chun*, which takes eight thousand years as its spring and eight thousand years as its autumn. Yet Pengzu alone is renowned for his longevity—if ordinary people compare themselves to him, is it not lamentable?

The *mangcang* is a land within a single glance, hazy and indistinct. If I were to journey there, going and returning would take no more than three meals, and my belly would still be full. *Guo* means "full"—the food has not yet been digested, showing how near it is. To travel a hundred *li*, one must hull grain the night before, for the journey cannot be made on three meals alone. For a thousand-*li* journey, one must gather provisions for three months. These three lines illustrate that human travel varies in distance, and thus the food required varies in quantity—just as human perception varies in scope, so too do aspirations differ in reach. This is another metaphor for the Peng and the cicada-dove.

The "two insects" refer to the cicada and the dove. It says, "What could they possibly know of this?"—hence, "what do they know?" "Lesser knowledge cannot reach greater knowledge; short years cannot reach long years"—these two lines form another structural unit in the text. The first line, on lesser and greater knowledge, concludes the earlier comparison of the Peng and the dove, while the second, on short and long years, introduces the next set of analogies.

The morning mushroom is the great *zhi*, also called the "sun-fungus," which grows on dung. It sprouts at dawn and dies at sunset. It knows only morning and evening—how could it know of the waxing and waning of the moon? The *huigū* is the winter cicada, born in spring and dying in summer, or born in summer and dying in autumn. It does not witness the full cycle of the four seasons—hence, it is short-lived. The *Mingling* is the name of a tree, as is the Great *Chun*. This is also a parable and need not be taken literally. It says that the *Mingling* takes a thousand years to complete one year, and the Great *Chun* takes sixteen thousand years to complete one year. Pengzu lived only eight hundred years, yet today he is uniquely renowned for his longevity. People all admire him but cannot match him—this too is a case of seeing the small but not the great. *Jiu* means "longevity"; *pi* means "to admire and seek to emulate."

This is the same as Tang’s question to Ji. Beyond the barren north lies the Dark Sea—the Celestial Pond. There is a fish there, thousands of *li* in breadth, its length unknown, called the *Kun*. There is a bird there called the Peng, its back like Mount Tai, its wings like clouds hanging from the sky. It mounts the whirlwind and spirals upward ninety thousand *li*, piercing the clouds and bearing the azure sky, then plans its southward journey to reach the Southern Darkness. The *chiyan* laughs at it, saying: "Where is it going? I leap and soar upward no more than a few yards before descending, wheeling among the mugwort and wormwood—this is the height of flight. Where could *it* be going?" This is the distinction between small and great.

This passage merely restates the previous one as further evidence. It says that Tang once questioned Ji about this very matter. *Ji* is the name of a person. *Shi yi* means "it is so." This line serves to link the conclusion below, using the closing words as the opening—this is where the prose gains its momentum. *Qiongfa* means "barren land"; *fuyao* refers to the force of the wind; *yangjiao* describes the wind’s spiraling motion; *tuan* means "to soar"; "piercing the clouds" means that ninety thousand *li* above, there are no more clouds. People say that atop Mount Tai, clouds lie below, and thunder sounds like an infant’s cry—yet today it is also said that clouds only reach halfway up the sky. *Tu-nan* means "to plan a journey to the Southern Darkness." It speaks of devising a southward migration before setting out for the Southern Sea.

The *chi* is a small marsh; the *chiyan* is a tiny bird. "The height of flight" means that its wheeling among the mugwort and wormwood is flight’s ultimate joy—why should it go elsewhere? Its meaning is the same as in the previous passage. Thus, those whose knowledge suffices for a single office, whose conduct is compared to a single village, whose virtue matches a single lord and whose proof lies in a single state—they regard themselves in the same way. Yet Song Rongzi would still laugh at them. Though the whole world praises them, they are not encouraged; though the whole world blames them, they are not disheartened. They have settled the distinction between inner and outer, discerned the boundary between honor and disgrace—this is all. In their relation to the world, they are not frantically active. Even so, they have yet to establish their true foundation.

chunks.original_text: 夫列子御风而行，泠然善也，旬有五日而后反。 彼於致福者，未数数然也，此虽免乎行，犹有所待者也。 若夫乘天地之正，而御六气之辩，以游无穷者，彼且恶乎待哉。 故曰至人无己，神人无功，圣人无名。 知效一官，言其智能可以办一职之事也。 行比一乡，言其德行可以比合一乡而，使人归向也。 德见知於一君，是为遇合而可以号召於一国，言主一国之事也。 此三等人，各以其所能为自足，其自视亦如斥鴳之类。 宋荣子见之大者也。 犹然，笑貌也。 宋荣子之为人，虽举世毁之誉之而不加劝沮，言不以为意也。 视彼一乡一国之士，但见可笑。 然宋荣子之所以能此者，何也。 盖知本心为内，凡物为外，故曰定内外之分。 在外者则有荣辱，在内者则无荣辱，知有内外之分，则能辨荣辱皆外境矣。 斯已矣者，言道理只如此也。 彼既以本心为重，外物为轻，则岂肯汲汲然以世俗为事。 数数，汲汲也。 虽然宋荣子之能固如此，亦未有大树立作家处。 若列子者，以身御风而行虚空之间，半月而后反。 其御风之时泠然而善，此形容其飘飘之貌也，泠然，飘然也，善，美也。 彼既能乘风而行，又视修身以求福，汲汲然惟恐不及者，不足言矣。 未数数者，言其未肯似他如此数数也。 人之行也在地，列子之行也御风，此虽免乎行矣，而非风则不可，故曰犹有所待。 若夫乘天地之正理，御阴阳风雨晦明之六气，以游於无物之始而无所穷止，若此则无所待矣。 此乃有进无迹之分也，至於无迹则谓之至人矣，谓之神人矣，谓之圣人矣。 无己、无功、无名，皆言无迹也。 特下三句赞美之又赞美之也。 尧让天下於许由曰：日月出矣而爝火不息，其於光也不亦难乎。 时雨降矣而犹浸灌，其於泽也不亦劳乎。 夫子立而天下治，而我犹口之，吾自视缺然，请致天下。 许由曰：子治天下，天下既已治也。 而我犹待子，吾将为名乎。 名者，实之宾也，吾将为宾乎。 鹪鹩巢於深林，不过一枝； 偃鼠饮河，不过满腹。 归休乎君，予无所用天下为。 庖人虽不治庖，尸祝不越樽俎而代之矣。 爝火，炬火也。 日月既明何用把火，时雨既降何用抱瓮。 尧谓许由立则天下自治，而必使我主此，我自见其不足，故以爝火浸灌自喻也。 尸者，主也。 政天下者，言以天下归之汝也。 名不出於我而出於人，则是在外者也，以名对实则实为主而名为宾。 吾不为宾者，言吾不以外物自丧其身也。 鹪鹩偃鼠，许由自喻也，言其有以自足也。 偃，伏也，偃鼠，潜伏之鼠也。 归休乎君，言君且归去休，不必来访我也。 庖与尸祝其业不同，言我不能舍我之所乐以代汝，各守其所守，亦犹尸祝不肯违越去其樽俎，而代庖人烹割也。 肩吾问於连叔曰：吾闻言於接舆，大而无当，往而不反，吾惊怖其言，犹河汉而无极也，大有径庭，不近人情焉。 连叔曰：其言谓何哉。 曰：藐姑射之山，有神人居焉。 肌肤若冰雪，绰约若处子，不食五谷，吸风饮露。 乘云气，御飞龙，而游乎四海之外。 其神凝，使物不疵疠而年谷熟。 吾以是狂而不信也。 连叔曰：然。
chunks.translated_text:
Liezi rode the wind in flight, soaring with effortless grace, and only after fifteen days did he return. Though he sought no frantic pursuit of fortune, this was still to rely on something. Even if one is spared the toil of walking, one still depends on external conditions.

As for one who rides the inherent purity of Heaven and Earth, who harnesses the transformations of the six qi—yin and yang, wind and rain, darkness and light—and roams the boundless, what does such a one depend upon? Thus it is said: the Perfected One has no self, the Spirit Man has no merit, the Sage has no name.

"Knowledge suffices for a single office" means one’s intelligence is adequate to manage the affairs of one post. "Conduct is compared to a single village" means one’s virtue and conduct can align with a whole village, drawing people to follow. "Virtue is recognized by a single lord" means one has met with favor and can rally an entire state—this refers to governing a nation’s affairs. These three types of people each take satisfaction in their own abilities, regarding themselves much like the marsh pipit. Song Rongzi perceives the greater truth.

*You ran* describes his laughing expression. Song Rongzi’s character was such that, though the whole world praised or blamed him, he remained unmoved, paying it no heed. Compared to those who content themselves with a village or a state, he saw only cause for amusement. Yet how was Song Rongzi able to achieve this? He recognized the original heart as inner and all things as outer—thus he "settled the distinction between inner and outer." What lies outside may bring honor or disgrace, but what lies within knows neither. Understanding this division, he could discern that honor and disgrace are merely external conditions. "This is all" means the principle extends no further.

Since he valued the original heart and dismissed external things as trivial, how could he be frantically preoccupied with worldly affairs? *Frantic* describes such restless striving. Though Song Rongzi’s ability was indeed as described, he had yet to establish a true foundation.

As for Liezi, he could ride the wind and travel through the void, returning only after half a month. When he rode the wind, he moved with a light, graceful ease—*effortless grace* describes his floating, drifting manner. *Effortless* means drifting, *grace* means beauty. Having mastered wind-borne flight, he would not deign to pursue fortune through self-cultivation with anxious haste. *Not frantic* means he would not stoop to such restless striving as others. While ordinary people walk upon the earth, Liezi rode the wind—this spared him the toil of walking, yet without wind he could not proceed, so he still depended on something.

As for one who rides the inherent principle of Heaven and Earth, who harnesses the six qi—yin and yang, wind and rain, darkness and light—and roams the boundless beginning of all things without limit, such a one depends on nothing. This is the realm of progress without trace. To be without trace is to be called a Perfected One, a Spirit Man, a Sage. "No self," "no merit," "no name"—all describe the absence of trace. These three phrases are repeated to extol such a state further.

When Yao offered the world to Xu You, he said: "The sun and moon have risen, yet the torch still burns—is it not difficult for its light to compare? The seasonal rains have fallen, yet one still waters the fields—is it not laborious for its benefit to compare? If you stand forth, the world will be well-governed, yet I still speak of this—how lacking I feel! I beg you to take the world."

Xu You replied: "You govern the world, and the world is already well-governed. Yet I would still await you—would I do so for the sake of a name? A name is but the guest of reality; would I become a guest? The wren nests in the deep forest, yet needs only a single branch; the mole drinks from the river, yet takes only its fill. Return, my lord, and leave me to my uselessness. Though the cook does not prepare the feast, the invocator would not overstep his vessel and altar to take his place."

A torch is but a flame. Once the sun and moon shine, what need is there for a torch? Once the seasonal rains fall, what need is there for a watering pot? Yao meant that if Xu You stood forth, the world would govern itself, yet he insisted on offering it to him—he saw his own inadequacy, comparing himself to the torch and watering pot. The *invocator* is the master of ceremonies. To "govern the world" means to entrust the world to another. If a name does not arise from oneself but from others, it is external; when weighed against reality, reality is the master and name the guest. "I would not become a guest" means I would not lose myself to external things. The wren and the mole are Xu You’s self-comparisons, showing his contentment with little. *Crouching* means lying low; the *mole* is a burrowing rodent. "Return, my lord" means you should go back and rest, there is no need to visit me.

The cook and the invocator have different duties—just as I cannot abandon what I delight in to take your place, each must guard their own role. It is like the invocator refusing to overstep his vessel and altar to replace the cook in carving and cooking.

Jian Wu asked Lian Shu: "I heard Jie Yu’s words—they were vast but without substance, going on without return. I was alarmed by his speech, like the Milky Way stretching endlessly, so grand and distant, so far from human concerns."

Lian Shu said: "What did he say?"

Jian Wu replied: "On the distant Guye Mountain dwells a spirit-man. His skin is like ice and snow, his bearing as graceful as a maiden. He eats no grain, but drinks the wind and sips the dew. He rides the clouds and drives flying dragons, roaming beyond the four seas. His spirit is concentrated, so that things suffer no blight and the harvest ripens. I consider this mad and do not believe it."

Lian Shu said: "Indeed."

chunks.original_text: 瞽者无以与乎文章之观，聋者无以与乎钟鼓之声，岂唯形骸有聋盲哉，夫知亦有之。 是其言也，犹时女也。 之人也，之德也，将磅礴万物以为一。 世蕲乎乱，孰弊弊焉以天下为事。 之人也，物莫之伤，大浸稽天而不溺，大旱金石流土山焦而不热。 是其尘垢秕糠，将犹陶铸尧舜者也，孰肯以物为事。 肩吾、连叔皆未必实有此人，此皆寓言，亦不必就名字上求义理，中间虽有一二，亦可解说而实不皆然也。 无当者，无实也，往而不反者，谓其大言只说前去而不回顾也。 河漠，天河也，河汉无极，谓天河在天，不知其首尾之所极。 径音径，庭音趁，径庭只言强界遥远也。 大有，甚有也； 其言不近人情，言非世俗所常有也。
chunks.translated_text:
The blind have no part in the spectacle of patterns and colors; the deaf have no part in the sound of bells and drums. Yet is it only the body that may be deaf and blind? The mind, too, may suffer such afflictions. His words are like those spoken to a child.

This man, this power of his—it would embrace the myriad things and fuse them into one. Should the world seek to set itself aright, who would wear himself out taking the world as his concern? This man—nothing harms him. Though the great floods rise to the heavens, he does not drown; though great drought melts metal and stone, scorches earth and mountains, he does not burn.

His dust and chaff, his husks and refuse, would still suffice to mold a Yao or Shun. Who would trouble himself to take things as his concern?

Jian Wu and Lian Shu may not have truly encountered such a man—these are but allegories. Nor should one seek meaning in their names. Though one or two points may be explained, in truth, not all can be so readily accounted for.

"Without substance" means without reality. "Going on without return" means his grand words press ever forward without looking back. "Milky Way" refers to the celestial river. "The Milky Way stretching endlessly" means the river in the sky has no discernible beginning or end. *Jing* is pronounced as "path," *ting* as "courtyard." "So grand and distant" merely describes an immense and remote separation. "So grand" means "so very much so." "So far from human concerns" means his words are not what the world commonly knows.

chunks.original_text: 藐姑射，山名也，冰雪莹洁也，所养者全，阳气伏而不动，故凝然若冰雪，今之服气道人亦有能为此者。 绰约者，柔媚可爱也； 处子，处女也。 则神全不食以下四句，言其神妙也。 其精神凝然而定所居之地，百物自无疵疠之病而年谷自熟。 盖接舆之言如此。 狂与诳同，肩吾以其言为欺诳而不可信也。 曰然者，言固是如此也，汝固疑而不信也。 文章之观示，钟鼓之音声，人皆见之闻之而瞽者聋者无预，此形骸之病也。 岂唯形骸有此病，在心亦有此病，言其心无见识，犹聋瞽然，故不知此语而以为诳也。 时，是也，女与汝同，前后解者皆以此时女为处子，故牵强不通其意。 盖谓如此言语岂是汝一等人能之。 此等人其为德也，周游乎万物之上而世自治，彼岂肯弊弊然以治天下为事，言其无为无不为也。
chunks.translated_text:
The Miao Gu Ye is the name of a mountain, where ice and snow gleam with pristine purity. Those who cultivate themselves there preserve their wholeness, and the yang qi lies concealed and unmoving—thus they remain serene and still as ice and snow. Even today, practitioners of the qi-absorbing arts may achieve this.

"Graceful and delicate" describes their supple, lovely charm; "maiden" means a virgin. The four lines beginning with "their spirit whole, without eating" speak of their wondrous numinosity. Their essence and spirit congeal in stillness where they dwell, so that the hundred creatures naturally suffer no blight or pestilence, and the harvest ripens of itself. Such were Jie Yu’s words.

"Mad" is akin to "deceitful"—Jian Wu dismissed his words as falsehoods not to be trusted. "Indeed" means it is truly so, yet you stubbornly doubt and disbelieve. The display of patterns and colors, the sound of bells and drums—all see and hear them, yet the blind and deaf take no part, for this is a malady of the bodily form. Yet is this affliction confined to the body? The mind, too, may suffer it, for if the mind lacks perception, it is as deaf and blind—thus it fails to grasp these words and deems them lies.

"Thus" means "this"; *nü* is the same as "you." Earlier commentators all took *nü* here to mean "maiden," which distorts the meaning. Rather, it means: how could such words be within the grasp of the likes of you? Such beings, in their virtue and power, roam beyond the myriad things while the world governs itself—would they deign to wear themselves out with the affairs of ruling the world? This speaks of their non-doing that is yet non-not-doing.

"The Milky Way stretching endlessly" means the river in the sky has no discernible beginning or end. *Jing* is pronounced as "path," *ting* as "courtyard." "So grand and distant" merely describes an immense and remote separation. "So grand" means "so very much so." "So far from human concerns" means his words are not what the world commonly knows.
