chunks.original_text: 蕲与祈同，乱者，治也，言一世之人自析乎治，我但无为而彼自治，我何用自劳，弊弊，自劳之意也。 物莫之伤者，言外物不能动其本心也。 稽，至也，水之大可以至天，而斯人不溺； 旱之甚可使金石融流、土山焦枯，有彼亦不热，言其无入而不自得也。 尘垢秕糠，绪余也，谓此人推其绪余可以做成尧舜事业，岂肯以事物为意。 物者，事物也，为事犹言从事也，陶铸，做成之意也。 据此一语便是郭子玄所谓不经者。 但其着书初意正要鄙夷世俗之儒，故言语有过当处，不可以此议之。 如李太白曰：尧舜之事不足惊，莫比夷齐事高洁。 与此何异。 宋人资章甫而适诸越，越人断发文身无所用之。 章甫，冠也。 越人既断发，不用衣冠。 宋人以此为货而往越，宜其无卖处也。 庄子此言盖谓其所言广大，今世之人无非浅见，此言何所用，谓世不足与语此也。 尧治天下之民，平海内之政，往见四子藐姑射之山，汾水之阳，窅然丧其天下焉。 此章亦见广而后知自陋之意。 以尧之治天下，古今第一人矣，而於汾水之南，见四子於藐姑射之山，犹且恍然自失，况他人乎。 丧其天下，忘其天下也； 窅然，茫茫之意也。 四子既无名，或以为许由、啮缺、王倪、被衣，或曰山海经云：藐姑射在寰海外，汾阳，尧都也，在尧之都而见姑射之神，即尧心也，一本二迹，三非本非迹，四非非本迹也。 如此推寻转见，迂诞不知，此正庄子滑稽处。 如今人所谓断头话，正要学者如此揣摸前后，解者正落其圈中，何足以读庄子。 其实皆寓言也，大抵谓人各局於所见而不自知，其迷着必有大见识方能自照破也。 惠子谓庄子曰：魏王贻我大瓠之种，我树之成而实五石。 以盛水浆，其坚不能自举也； 剖之以为瓢，则瓠落无所容。 非不呺然，大也。 吾为其无用而掊之。 庄子曰：夫子固拙於用大矣。 宋人有善为不龟手之药者，世世以洴澼统为事。 客闻之，请买其方百金。 聚族而谋曰：我世世为洴澼絖，不过数金； 今一朝鬻技百金，请与之。 客得之，以说吴王。 越有难，吴王使之将，冬与越人水战，大败越人，裂地而封之。 能不龟手，一也； 或以封或不免於洴澼统，则所用之异也。 今子有五石之瓠，何不虑以为大樽而浮乎江湖，而忧其瓠落无所容，则夫子犹有蓬之心也夫。 瓠，可为瓢者也，实瓠之子也。 一瓠之大，其子五石，则亦可盛五石之水 矣，坚，重也，瓢，半匏也，瓠落浅而大之貌也。 掊击，碎之也。 不龟手者，言冬月用此药而手不裂也。 洴澼，打洗也，絖，絮也。 以有此药而为人洗絮，数世以此为业也。 樽，浮水之壶也。 以壶系腰乃可浮水，故曰：中流失船，一壶千金。 庄子既以不龟药之事喻其不知所用，乃曰有此大瓠，何不思之以为浮江之壶。 虑，思也。 何不虑者，言子之思何不及此也。 蓬心，犹茅塞其心也。 此段之意亦谓见小不能用大而已。 惠子谓庄子曰：吾有大树，人谓之樗。 其大本拥肿而不中绳墨，其小枝卷曲而不中规矩，立之涂匠者不顾，今子之言大而无用，众所同去也。 庄子曰：子独不见狸狂乎，卑身而伏，以候敖者，东西跳梁，不避高下，中於机辟，死於网罟。 今夫斄牛，其大若垂天之云，此能为大矣，而不能执鼠。
chunks.translated_text:
"Qí" is the same as "qǐ," meaning to seek; "luàn" means governance. This speaks of the people of the world dividing themselves over governance—yet I practice non-doing, and they govern themselves. Why should I wear myself out? "Bìbì" expresses the idea of self-exertion.

"Nothing can harm them" means external things cannot disturb their fundamental mind. "Jī" means "to reach"; the vastness of water can ascend to the heavens, yet such a person does not drown. The most severe drought can melt metal and stone, wither mountains and parch the earth, yet they do not feel the heat—this speaks of their unobstructed self-possession in all circumstances.

"Dust, grime, chaff, and husks" refer to trivial remnants. This means that if such a person were to apply even their leftover efforts, they could accomplish the deeds of Yao and Shun—how could they deign to concern themselves with worldly affairs? "Things" here means affairs, and "to engage in affairs" means to take action. "Molding and casting" means to bring something to completion.

This single phrase aligns with what Guo Xiang called "unconventional." Yet the original intent of the text was to scorn the vulgar Confucians, so its language sometimes exceeds proper bounds—one should not judge it by this alone. As Li Taibai said: "The deeds of Yao and Shun are not so astonishing; none compare to Boyi and Shuqi in lofty purity." How is this different?

The people of Song took ceremonial caps to Yue, but the Yue, with their shorn hair and tattooed bodies, had no use for them. "Zhangfu" refers to caps. Since the Yue cut their hair, they did not wear caps. The people of Song brought these as goods to Yue, yet they found no market for them. Zhuangzi’s words here imply that his teachings are vast, while the people of this age possess only shallow vision—what use are such words? This means the world is unworthy of such discourse.

Yao governed the people of the world and brought order to the realm, yet when he went to see the Four Masters on Mount Miaogushe by the southern bank of the Fen River, he was suddenly lost to his own realm. This passage also conveys the idea that only by seeing the vast can one recognize one’s own limitations. Yao, the greatest ruler of ancient and modern times, upon seeing the Four Masters by the southern bank of the Fen River on Mount Miaogushe, was still struck with bewilderment—how much more so for others? "Lost to his realm" means he forgot his realm; "yǎorán" conveys a sense of vast emptiness.

The Four Masters have no names; some say they were Xu You, Nie Que, Wang Ni, and Pi Yi, while others claim the *Classic of Mountains and Seas* states that Mount Miaogushe lies beyond the encircling sea, and Fenyang was Yao’s capital—thus, seeing the spirits of Miaogushe in his own capital was like seeing his own heart. The first was neither substance nor trace, the second neither non-substance nor trace, the third neither substance nor non-trace, and the fourth neither non-substance nor non-trace. Such interpretations grow increasingly convoluted and absurd—this is precisely Zhuangzi’s playful wit. It is like what people today call "headless talk," meant to lead scholars to ponder its context, yet commentators fall right into his trap. How can one read Zhuangzi this way? In truth, these are all allegories, generally meaning that people are confined by their own limited vision and do not realize it—only those with great insight can break free from such delusion.

Huizi said to Zhuangzi: "The King of Wei gave me seeds of a great gourd. I planted them, and they grew to hold five *dan*. When I used it to hold water, its weight was too great to lift; when I split it to make a ladle, it was too shallow and broad to hold anything. It was not that it wasn’t vast—it was simply useless. So I smashed it."

Zhuangzi said: "You are truly inept at putting great things to use. There was a man from Song skilled in making an ointment that prevented chapping. For generations, his family had made a living by washing silk floss. A traveler heard of this and offered a hundred gold pieces for the formula. The family gathered and deliberated: 'For generations, we’ve washed silk floss and earned only a few pieces of gold. Now, in a single morning, we can sell this skill for a hundred gold pieces—let us give it to him.' The traveler acquired it and presented it to the King of Wu. When Yue invaded, the King of Wu made him a general. In winter, they fought on the water, and he crushed the Yue forces, for which he was granted a fief. The ability to prevent chapping was the same, yet one man gained a fief while another remained washing silk floss—this was simply a matter of how it was used.

Now you have a gourd that holds five *dan*—why not consider making it into a great float to drift upon rivers and lakes, instead of fretting that it is too shallow and broad to hold anything? Clearly, your mind is still as obstructed as a clump of reeds." "Hù" refers to what can be made into a ladle; it is the seed of the bottle gourd. A single gourd so large that its seeds hold five *dan* could also hold five *dan* of water. "Firm" means heavy. "Piáo" is half a gourd; "hùluò" describes its broad, shallow appearance. "Pǒu" means to strike and break. "Does not chap" means that in winter, hands do not crack when using this ointment. "Píngpì" means washing; "kuàng" means silk floss. For generations, they had used this ointment to wash silk floss. "Zūn" is a floating gourd. By tying a gourd to one’s waist, one can float in water—hence the saying, "In midstream, a lost boat makes a gourd worth a thousand gold." Zhuangzi, having used the ointment parable to illustrate Huizi’s failure to recognize proper use, then said: "With such a great gourd, why not think of making it into a float for the river?" "Lǜ" means to consider. "Why not consider" means: why does your thinking not extend to this? "A mind like reeds" means a mind as obstructed as tangled reeds. The meaning of this passage is simply that one who sees only the small cannot use the great.

Huizi said to Zhuangzi: "I have a great tree—people call it the *chū*. Its trunk is gnarled and swollen, unfit for the carpenter’s line; its branches are twisted and crooked, unfit for the compass and square. It stands by the road, yet carpenters do not even glance at it. Now your words are vast but useless—everyone rejects them alike."

Zhuangzi said: "Have you never seen a wildcat? It crouches low, lying in wait for prey, leaping east and west, heedless of high or low—yet it is caught in a trap or snared in a net. Now consider the yak: as vast as a hanging cloud in the sky, great indeed—yet it cannot catch mice."

chunks.original_text: 今子有大树患其无用，何不树之於无何有之乡，广莫之野，彷徨乎无为其侧，逍遥乎寝卧其下，不夭斤斧，物无害者，无所可用，安所困苦哉。 樗，恶木之名也。 大本，树之身也。 拥肿，盘结而瘰块也。 不中绳墨规矩，言其不中用也。 立之涂，近於道旁也。 此惠子戏以喻庄子之大言无用也。 狸狂，狐之类也； 敖者，物之游遨者也，伺候而欲食之。 方其跳梁之时，不避高下，亦最小而桀点者。 一旦为机网所中，遂杀其身。 辟，法也，机辟，犹言机械也。 斄牛，旄牛也，其牛至大而不能如狸牲之执鼠。 此意盖喻世间之物有大有小，各自不同，不可以大者皆为无用也。 无何有之乡，广莫之野，言造化自然至道之中，自有可乐之地也。 役役人世，有福则有祸，若高飞远举以道自乐，虽无所用於世而祸害亦不及之，即退之所谓刀锯不加，理乱不闻也。 故曰不夭斤斧物无害者，安所因苦哉。 惠子之间，庄子之答，如今人说隐语然。 后人就此机紬多少文字，其原实出於此。 南华真经口义卷之一竟 南华真经口义卷之二
chunks.translated_text:
Now you have a great tree and fret over its uselessness—why not plant it in the land of Nothing-Whatsoever, the boundless wilds? There you may wander idly by its side, roam freely beneath its shade, lie down at ease beneath its boughs. No axe will fell it before its time, no thing will harm it. Useless? Where then is the hardship?

*Chū* is the name for a worthless tree. *Great trunk* refers to the tree’s body. *Gnarled and swollen* means knotted and lumpy. *Unfit for the carpenter’s line or compass and square* means it is of no use. *Standing by the road* means it is near the wayside. Here Huizi jestingly compares Zhuangzi’s grand words to this uselessness.

*Wildcat* refers to creatures like foxes. *Prey* means creatures that roam and play, which the wildcat lies in wait to devour. When it leaps and bounds, heedless of high or low, it is at its most nimble and daring—yet one day it is caught in a trap or net and killed. *Ji* means a mechanism; *jibi* refers to traps or snares.

The *lí-ox* is the yak, vast as a cloud hanging in the sky, great indeed—yet it cannot catch mice like a wildcat. This illustrates that things in the world, whether great or small, each have their own nature; one cannot dismiss all great things as useless.

The *land of Nothing-Whatsoever* and the *boundless wilds* refer to the realm of the Dao’s natural creation, where there is a place of joy. Those who toil in the human world may meet with fortune or misfortune, but if one soars high and far, delighting in the Dao, though of no use to the world, neither will misfortune or harm befall them—just as the saying goes: "No blade or saw touches them, nor do they hear of order or chaos."

Thus it is said: "No axe will fell it before its time, no thing will harm it. Useless? Where then is the hardship?" Huizi’s question and Zhuangzi’s answer are like the riddles people speak today. Later generations have spun countless words from this exchange, but its origin lies here.

*End of the First Scroll of the Oral Exegesis of the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*

chunks.original_text: 鬳斋林希逸 内篇齐物论上 物论者，人物之论也，犹言众论也。 齐者，一也，欲合众论而为一也。 战国之世，学问不同，更相是非，故庄子以为不若是非两忘而归之自然，此其立名之意也。 天籁、地籁、人籁，就声上起譬喻也。 南郭子綦隐几而坐，仰天而嘘，嗒焉似丧其耦。 颜成子游立侍乎前，曰：何居乎。 形固可使如槁木，而心固可使如死灰乎。 今之隐几者，非昔之隐几者也。 子蔂曰； 偃，不亦善乎，而问之也。 今者吾丧我，汝知之乎。 隐几者，凭几也； 嗒然者，无心之貌也； 丧其耦者，人皆以物我对立，此忘之也； 槁木者，无生意也； 死灰，心不起也。 今之隐几者，言今日先生之隐几非若前此见人之隐几也。 有我则有物，丧我，无我也，无我则无物矣。 汝知之乎者，言汝知此理乎。 吾即我也，不曰我丧我，而曰吾丧我，言人身中才有一毫私心未化，则吾我之间亦有分别矣。 吾丧我三字下得极好。 洞山曰：渠今不是我，我今正是渠。 便是此等关窍。 汝闻人籁而未闻地籁，汝闻地籁而未闻天籁夫。 子游曰：敢问其方。 子綦曰：夫大块噫气，其名为风，是唯无作，作则万窍怒号，而独不闻之翏翏乎。 山林之畏佳，大木百围之窍穴，似鼻，似口，似耳，似枅，似圈，似曰，似洼者，似污者，激者謞者，叱者吸者，叫者号者，完者咬者，前者唱于而随者唱喁。 泠风则小和，飘风则大和，厉风济则众窍为虚，而独不见之调调之刁刁乎。 子綦因子游一问，知其亦有造理之见。 欲以天籁语之，遂如此发问也。 方，道也，问此理果何如也。 大块，天地也，天地之间因何有风，亦犹人之噫气也。 是唯无作，言其不作则已也； 作则万窍怒号者，言才动则满世界皆是也。 万窍，万木之窍也； 翏乎，长风之声也。 畏音伟，佳音翠，上声#1畏佳者，林木摇动之貌。 百围言木之大也，两手相挐曰围。 上言万窍，此但以一树之大者言之，则其他可知，文法也。 大木之窍穴，其形之不同，各有所似。 枅，柱上方木斜而深者。 圈如桮圈之员者。 洼曲者，污下者，此皆言其窍穴之形。 自激者至咬者，言窍穴中之声。 于之声轻，吗之声重，言风之前去其声如唱千，随其后而至者则如唱喁，轻重相和也。 泠风，小风也，风小则其相和之声亦小。 飘风，大风也，风大则其相和之声亦大。 厉风者，猛厉之风也。 济者，止也。 风既止则众窍之中向之为声者皆不闻矣，故曰为虚。 调调刁刁，皆树木为风所摇动之形，前曰独不闻，后曰独不见，此一段文字之关锁也。 而，汝也。 庄子之文好处极多，如此一段，又妙中之妙者。 一部书中，此为第一文字，非特庄子一部书中，合古今作者求之亦无此一段文字。 诗是有声画，谓其写难状之景也，何曾见画得个声出。 自激者至咬者八字，八声也，于与喁又是相和之声也。 天地间无形无影之风，可闻而不可见之声，却就笔头上画得出，非南华老仙安得这般手段。 每读之，真使人手舞足蹈而不知自己也。 此段只是说地籁，却引说后段天籁，自是文势如此，说者或谓此言地籁自然之声，亦天籁也，固是如此，风非出於造化，出於何处。 然看他文势说地籁，且还他说地籁，庶见他血脉纲领。 子游曰：地籁则众窍是已，人籁则比竹是已。
chunks.translated_text:
Lin Xiyi of Yanzhai’s *Exegesis on the "On the Equality of Things" (First Part of the Inner Chapters)*

"On the Equality of Things" speaks of the discourses of men and things—akin to what we call "the many opinions." "Equality" means oneness, the desire to unify the many opinions into one. In the Warring States era, schools of thought diverged, each contending over right and wrong. Thus, Zhuangzi believed it better to forget both right and wrong and return to spontaneity—this is the intent behind the title.

The "Heavenly Pipe," "Earthly Pipe," and "Human Pipe" are metaphors drawn from sound. Nan Guo Ziqi, leaning against his armrest, sat with his gaze lifted to the sky, exhaling deeply. Lost in reverie, he seemed to have forgotten his counterpart. Yan Cheng Ziyou stood in attendance before him and asked, "What is this?" Can the body truly be made like withered wood, and the heart like dead ashes? The one who leans on the armrest today is not the same as the one who leaned on it before.

Zilou said: "Is this not well? Yet you ask." Today, I have lost my self—do you understand? To lean on the armrest is to rest upon it; *ta ran* describes a state of mindlessness; to forget one’s counterpart means that while others perceive a division between self and things, here it is forgotten. Withered wood signifies the absence of vitality; dead ashes, the stillness of the heart. "The one who leans on the armrest today" means that the Master’s present repose is not like that of others seen before. Where there is a self, there are things; to lose the self is to be without self, and without self, there are no things. "Do you understand?" asks whether you grasp this principle. *Wu* is the self, yet he does not say "I have lost my self" but "I have lost my *wu*," for even the slightest trace of private thought within the body creates a distinction between *wu* and self. The phrase "I have lost my *wu*" is exquisitely chosen. Dongshan said: "He is no longer me; I am now truly him." This is precisely the crux of the matter.

"You have heard the Human Pipe but not the Earthly Pipe; you have heard the Earthly Pipe but not the Heavenly Pipe."

Ziyou said: "May I ask the method?"

Ziqi replied: "The Great Clod exhales *qi*, and this is called wind. It arises of itself—when it does not act, all is still; when it acts, the myriad hollows roar in fury. Have you alone not heard the *liao liao* of the long wind? The towering forests, the great trees with trunks a hundred spans around, their hollows like noses, mouths, ears, crossbeams, rings, mortises, basins, or pools—some gushing, some whistling, some scolding, some inhaling, some shrieking, some wailing, some moaning, some biting. The first cry out *yu*, and those that follow echo *yong*. A gentle breeze brings a faint harmony; a whirlwind, a mighty one. When the fierce gale subsides, all the hollows fall silent—have you alone not seen the *tiao tiao* and *diao diao* of the swaying trees?"

Ziqi, perceiving from Ziyou’s question that he had some insight into the principle, sought to instruct him on the Heavenly Pipe and thus posed this query. "Method" here means the Way—he asks what this principle truly is. The "Great Clod" is heaven and earth; the wind between them arises as naturally as a man’s exhalation. "It arises of itself" means that when it does not act, all is still; "when it acts, the myriad hollows roar in fury" means that once it stirs, the entire world resounds. The "myriad hollows" are the hollows of the myriad trees; *liao liao* is the sound of the long wind. *Wei* (towering) is pronounced like *wei* (great), and *jia* (fine) like *cui* (emerald). The rising tone of *wei jia* describes the swaying of the forest. "A hundred spans" speaks to the trees’ girth—a span is the measure of two hands clasped together. Above, he speaks of the "myriad hollows"; here, he describes a single great tree, and the rest may be inferred—this is a matter of literary technique. The hollows of the great trees take different forms, each resembling something: crossbeams are the slanted timbers atop pillars; rings are like the circular rims of cups; basins are concave; pools, low-lying. All describe the shapes of the hollows. From "gushing" to "biting," he speaks of the sounds within the hollows. The sound of *yu* is light, while *yong* is heavy—the wind’s passage is like a lead voice singing *yu*, and those that follow echo *yong*, light and heavy in harmony.

A gentle breeze brings a faint harmony; a whirlwind, a mighty one. A fierce gale is a violent wind; when it ceases, the sounds that once filled the hollows vanish, and thus they are called empty. *Tiao tiao* and *diao diao* describe the trees swaying in the wind. The earlier "have you alone not heard" and the later "have you alone not seen" serve as the structural keys to this passage. Zhuangzi’s writing excels in many ways, and this passage is among its finest—a masterpiece within a masterpiece. Not only is it the finest in the entire book, but even among all the works of ancient and modern writers, none can match it. Poetry is said to be a painting in sound, for it depicts scenes that are otherwise indescribable. Yet when has a painting ever captured sound? From "gushing" to "biting," eight sounds are named, while *yu* and *yong* are the harmonizing echoes. The wind between heaven and earth is formless and invisible, its sound audible yet unseen—yet with his brush, he paints it into being. Without the immortal wisdom of Nanhua, how could such skill be attained? Every time I read this, I find myself dancing with joy, forgetting myself entirely.

This passage speaks of the Earthly Pipe, yet it leads into the Heavenly Pipe—such is the flow of the prose. Some commentators say that this describes the natural sounds of the Earthly Pipe, which are also the Heavenly Pipe, and indeed, if the wind does not arise from the workings of creation, from where else could it come? Yet in terms of the text’s structure, it speaks of the Earthly Pipe, and so we should take it as the Earthly Pipe, that we may discern its veins and sinews.

Ziyou said: "The Earthly Pipe is simply the myriad hollows; the Human Pipe, the bamboo flutes."

chunks.original_text: 敢问天籁。 比竹，笙黄之类也。 人籁岂特比竹，金石丝匏之类皆是，此特举其一耳。 前说地籁，后说天籁，却把人籁只一句断送了，此亦是文法。 读庄子之文，须如此子细检点，庶得个入处。 子綦曰：夫吹万不同而使其自己也，咸其自取，怒者其谁耶。 吹万，万物之有声者也。 言万物之有声者，皆造物吹之，吹之者造物也，而皆使其若自己出。 吹字使字皆属造物自取者，自取於己也。 咸其自取，言万物皆以为我所自能，而不知一气之动谁实使之。 气发於内，而为言遂下一怒字，与怒而飞同，亦属造物。 大知闲闲，小知间间； 大言炎炎，小言詹詹。 大知者，上知之人也； 闲闲者，从容自得也。 小知，小计较者也； 间间者，言算星算两自分别也。 大言者，气焰大者也，炎炎者#2，有光辉也。 庄子之意，伊周孔孟皆在此一句内。 小言者，小小见识之人也； 詹詹者，瞻前顾后也。 百家之说，市井之谈，皆在此一句内。 此四句总说世间有此两种人，知理会事功者，言理会学术议论者。 其寐也魂交，其觉也形开，与接为构，日以心斗。 既说上四句了，却就人身上发明。 其寐也魂交，言夜则神集於其心也； 其觉也形开，言昼则四体皆动用也。 此两句自帝王至庶人皆在内。 构，合也，应於外者为接。 言人夜则安寝，平旦以来，遇合之间便有应接，内役其心如战斗然。 日日如是，故曰与接为构。 日以心斗，即孟子所谓旦昼之所为，有桔亡之者。 孟子说得便平善，被他如此造语，精神百倍，亦警动人。 后之禅家，其言语多是此等意思。 缦者，窖者，密者，小恐惴惴，大恐缦缦。 缦者，有一种人做事缦怛怛地； 又有一种人，出着言语便有机阱，故曰窖； 又有一种人，思前算后不漏落一线路，故曰密。 此皆言世之应物用心者。 然皆不得自在，皆有忧苦畏惧之心，所谓小人长戚戚是也。 孔子则谓小人戚戚，庄子之意则尧舜周孔皆为戚戚矣。 事之小者则惴惴然而惧，故曰小恐惴惴； 事之大者则忧深思远，若失若疑，故曰大恐缦缦。 其发若机括，其司是非之谓也。 其留如诅盟，其守胜之谓也。 其杀如秋冬，以言其日消也。 其溺之所为之，不可使复之也。 其厌也如缄，以言其老洫也。 近死之心，莫使复阳也。 喜怒哀乐虑叹变慹，姚佚启态，乐出虚，蒸成菌。 其议论是非各有所主。 若射者之谋中的然，故曰其发若机括，谓一语不虚发也。 司，主也。 好胜之心自守不化，留恋於胸次，若与人有诅盟。 然用心忧劳，日销月铄，谓其内自苦也。 物生於春夏，杀於秋冬，憔悴之时也，故以为日消之喻。 此三句下是意，上是譬喻，却如此下语，意有所溺，一去而不可回，故曰溺之所为之。 上之字助语也，下之字往也，不可使复之也。 此之字亦训往，言不可复挽回也。 其为物欲所厌没，如被缄滕然，至老而不可救拔，故曰老洫，洫者，谓其如坠於沟壑也。 此等人身虽生而心已若死者矣，故曰近死，谓其胸中无知也。 阳，生也，言其心已死不复活也。 此以上形容世俗之用心，喜怒以下十二字又形容其状貌，谓其在内者如此，故其见於外也。 或喜或怒，或哀或乐，时乎忧虑，时乎嗟叹，时乎变换意态，如此不得又欲如彼。 慹者，忧疑而不动之貌；

"May I inquire about the Heavenly Pipe?" Bamboo flutes, panpipes, and reed organs are of this kind. Yet the Human Pipe is not limited to bamboo instruments—metal, stone, silk, and gourd instruments all belong to it; this merely cites one example. Earlier, the Earthly Pipe was discussed, then the Heavenly Pipe, while the Human Pipe was dismissed in a single phrase—such is the structure of the prose. To read *Zhuangzi*, one must examine it with such care to find an entry point.

Master Qi said: "Though the myriad winds blow differently, each is made to follow its own nature. All take what they take for themselves—who then is the one that rouses them?" "Blowing the myriad" refers to all things that produce sound. It means that all sounding things are blown by the Creator, and the one who blows is the Creator, yet each is made to seem as if it arises of itself. The words "blows" and "makes" both belong to the Creator, while "takes for itself" means each takes from its own nature. "All take what they take for themselves" means that all things believe their sounds arise from their own power, unaware that it is the stirring of a single *qi*—who indeed is the one that moves it? When *qi* surges from within and becomes speech, the word "rouses" is used, akin to "rousing to flight," and both belong to the Creator.

"The great knowledge is broad and unhurried; the petty knowledge is narrow and calculating. The grand words blaze with brilliance; the petty words chatter endlessly." The "great knowledge" refers to those of superior understanding; "broad and unhurried" describes their ease and self-possession. "Petty knowledge" refers to those of small schemes; "narrow and calculating" describes their meticulous distinctions, counting stars and weighing grains. "Grand words" belong to those of towering presence; "blazing with brilliance" describes their radiance. Zhuangzi’s intent encompasses Yi, Zhou, Confucius, and Mencius in this single phrase. "Petty words" belong to those of limited vision; "chattering endlessly" describes their hesitation, looking back and forth. The doctrines of the Hundred Schools and the gossip of the marketplace all fall within this phrase. These four lines summarize the two kinds of people in the world: those who understand principles and manage affairs, and those who discuss learning and debate theories.

"In sleep, their spirits intertwine; when awake, their forms unfold. They engage in constant construction, daily battling with their hearts." Having expounded the four lines above, the text turns to the human body for illustration. "In sleep, their spirits intertwine" means that at night, the spirit gathers in the heart; "when awake, their forms unfold" means that by day, the four limbs are all in motion. These two lines encompass everyone from the emperor to the commoner. "Construction" means union; what responds externally is "engagement." It means that at night, one rests, but from dawn onward, in every encounter, there is response, and the heart is inwardly taxed as if in battle. This occurs day after day, hence "engaging in constant construction." "Daily battling with their hearts" echoes Mencius’s words about the deeds of the day and night, where there are those who undermine them. Mencius’s phrasing is gentle, but Zhuangzi’s language here is a hundredfold more vivid, startling the reader. Later Chan masters often expressed similar ideas in their words.

"Some are sluggish, some are cunning, some are secretive. In small fears, they tremble; in great fears, they dissolve." The "sluggish" are those who act in a dull, hesitant manner. Another kind speaks with hidden traps, hence "cunning." Yet another plans meticulously, leaving no thread unexamined, hence "secretive." All describe those in the world who respond to things with their hearts. Yet none attain freedom, all harboring anxiety and dread—the very "petty men ever sorrowful" of which Confucius spoke. Zhuangzi’s meaning, however, is that even Yao, Shun, the Duke of Zhou, and Confucius were all "sorrowful." In minor matters, they tremble with fear, hence "small fears make them tremble"; in great matters, their worries run deep, their thoughts far-reaching, as if lost or doubtful, hence "great fears make them dissolve."

"Their outbursts are like the release of a crossbow trigger—this refers to their judgment of right and wrong. Their retention is like a sworn oath—this refers to their clinging to victory. Their decline is like autumn and winter—speaking of their daily erosion. What they are submerged in cannot be restored. Their weariness is like a sealed letter—speaking of their aging and decay. The heart near death cannot be revived." Their debates on right and wrong each have their own basis, like an archer aiming at a target, hence "their outbursts are like the release of a crossbow trigger," meaning no word is spoken in vain. "Judgment" means control. The desire to prevail remains unyielding, lingering in the breast like a sworn oath. Yet the heart, burdened by care and toil, is worn down day by day—this describes their inner suffering. Things flourish in spring and summer, wither in autumn and winter; the time of emaciation is thus likened to daily erosion. The three lines above are metaphors, while the three below convey meaning. The phrasing is such that once submerged in a course, it cannot be reversed, hence "what they are submerged in." The first "之" is an auxiliary particle; the second "之" means "to go," hence "cannot be restored." The latter "之" also means "to go," indicating it cannot be retrieved. Overwhelmed by desires, they are bound like a sealed letter, aging beyond salvation, hence "aging and decay." "Decay" means falling into a ravine. Such people, though their bodies live, their hearts are as if dead, hence "near death," meaning their minds are devoid of awareness. "Yang" means life; their hearts are already dead and cannot be revived.

The above depicts the worldly use of the heart. The twelve characters beginning with "joy and anger" further describe their outward appearance, showing how their inner state manifests externally. Some are joyful, some angry, some sorrowful, some delighted; at times they worry, at times they sigh, at times they shift their demeanor, never content, always desiring something else. "Dread" describes the look of anxiety and hesitation, unmoving...

chunks.original_text: 姚，央庠之貌； 佚，纵逸也； 启，开放不收敛之貌态，做模打样也。 其人虽如此，实皆不自由。 如乐之出於虚，如气之蒸成菌，言许多种人皆是造物使之，便是吹万如此。 说造物处，又不谓自然而然，言人不能以道自持，则做出许多丑差，皆若鬼神使之然。 读庄子者，却要如此体认得子细。 日#3夜相代乎前，而莫知其所萌。 已乎已乎，旦暮得此，其所由以生乎。 非彼无我，非我无所取，是亦近矣，而不知其所为使。 若有真宰，而特不得其眹。 可行已信而不见，其形有情而无形。 日夜相代乎前，造物之往来者也。 莫知所萌，言不见其所起之处也。 已乎已乎，犹今人言是了是了，意谓所萌之地虽不可知，然旦暮之间，不过得此而已。 此者，造物也。 这一此字甚重，不是轻下。 非彼无我这彼字，却是上面此字，言非造物则我不能如此。 然造物之所为必因人身而后见，故曰非我无所取。 如此说得来，虽若近而可见矣。 然其所为见使於造物者，人实不知之，故曰是亦近矣，而不知其所为使。 真宰，造物也，若有者，似若有之而不敢以为实有也。 眹，萌芽之地也，不得其眹，即莫知其所萌也。 可行者，言天行之可见者也。 已信者，甚实也。 造物之所行信乎，有之而但不见其形，即莫知其所为使也。 有情言有实也，即已信也，无形即不见其形也。 自日夜相代以下皆言造物之所为，虽在面前而人不可见。 反反覆覆紬绎许多语句，辞甚切而意甚至，盖欲人於此着意自点检也。 百骸九窍六藏，赅而存焉，吾谁与为亲。 汝皆悦之乎，其有私焉。 如是皆有为臣妾乎，其臣妾不足以相治乎。 其递相为君臣乎，其有真君存焉。 如求得其情与不得，无益，损乎其真。 百骸九窍六藏，即人一身之所有者也。 此以下又就人身上发明一段，更是奇特。 赅者备也，存在也，言人之一身备此而皆在也。 吾谁与为亲者，言吾所独亲者谁乎，这一亲字下得极有理，且如人身或有病在手，为其所苦，则方病之时手乃为身之雠也，六根皆然。 汝皆悦之乎者，言六根之中皆喜之乎，亦有所私喜乎，且其在身之用何者为贵，何者为贱，如头痒而手搔，则手者头之役，望远而足行则足者目之役。 役者，臣妾也，然而不足以相治者乎。 手#4足耳目鼻舌互相为用也，受役者为臣，役之者为君，足时乎而用手，手时乎而用足，故曰递相为君臣。 百骸九窍六藏之君臣既不可得而定名，则心者身之主也，其以心为君乎。 心又不能以自主，而主之者造物，则造物为真君矣。 故曰其有真君存焉，我虽如此推求欲见到实处，然见得与见不得，其所谓君者，初何加损乎情实也。 故曰如求得其情与不得，无益损乎其真。 一受其成形，不亡以待尽。 与物相刃相靡，其行尽如驰而莫之能止，不亦悲乎。 终身役役而不见其成功，薾然疲役而不知其所归，可不哀邪。 人谓之不死，奚益。 其形化，其心与之然，可不谓大哀乎。 人之生也固若是芒乎，其我独芒而人亦有不芒者乎。 大抵人之形体非我自有，必有所受者。 既受此形於造物，则造物与我相守，不亡以待此形之归尽而后已。 而人不能一顺乎造物，乃为外物所汩，与之或逆或顺，以此而行，尽其一生，如驹过隙，不能以一息自宁，故曰行尽如驰而莫之能止。
chunks.translated_text:
"Yao" describes a state of languid indecision; "yi" means unrestrained indulgence; "qi" depicts an open, unconstrained demeanor, like striking a pose or setting an example. Though such people appear thus, they are in truth not free. Joy arises from emptiness, just as mushrooms form from the steaming of qi—these many kinds of people are all made by the Creator, blown into being by the myriad transformations. Yet when speaking of the Creator, one does not call it mere spontaneity. If people cannot hold fast to the Dao, they produce many grotesqueries, as if compelled by ghosts and spirits. Those who read *Zhuangzi* must examine this with great care.

Day and night alternate before us, yet none know where they first sprout. "Ah! Ah!"—from dawn to dusk, this is all we attain, and from this our lives arise. Without that, there is no "I"; without "I," there is nothing to grasp. This is nearly so, yet we know not what compels it. As if there were a true master, yet its traces cannot be discerned. It acts with certainty, yet its form is unseen; it has substance but no shape.

Day and night alternate before us—these are the comings and goings of the Creator. None know where it sprouts, for its origin is unseen. "Ah! Ah!"—like saying "so it is, so it is"—though the source of its sprouting remains unknown, between dawn and dusk, this is all we obtain. "This" refers to the Creator. This "this" carries great weight and should not be taken lightly. The "that" in "without that, there is no 'I'" refers back to this "this," meaning without the Creator, "I" could not be thus. Yet the Creator’s work only becomes manifest through the human body, hence "without 'I,' there is nothing to grasp." Though this explanation seems near and visible, what compels us to be thus used by the Creator remains unknown to us. Thus it is said: "This is nearly so, yet we know not what compels it."

The "true master" is the Creator. "As if there were" suggests it seems to exist but cannot be affirmed as truly real. "Zhen" refers to the ground of sprouting; "not discerning its zhen" means not knowing where it first sprouts. "Acts with certainty" refers to the visible workings of Heaven. "Already verified" means it is most real. The Creator’s actions are certain and present, yet its form is unseen—this is why we know not what compels it. "Has substance" means it is real, equivalent to "already verified"; "no shape" means its form is unseen. From "day and night alternate" onward, all describe the Creator’s workings, which unfold before us yet remain invisible. Through repeated and intricate turns of phrase, the words are urgent and the meaning profound, urging people to reflect deeply upon this.

The hundred bones, nine orifices, and six viscera—all are contained within us. To whom among them am I closest? Do you delight in all equally, or do you favor some? Are they all like servants and concubines? Are these servants and concubines insufficient to govern one another? Do they take turns as lord and subject? Is there a true ruler present?

Whether one grasps their nature or not, it neither benefits nor harms the real. The hundred bones, nine orifices, and six viscera comprise all that is within the human body. What follows further elucidates this point from the human form, and it is most extraordinary. "Contained" means complete and present—all these exist within the human body. "To whom among them am I closest?" asks: whom do I uniquely cherish? This "cherish" is profoundly placed. For example, if illness strikes the hand, causing suffering, then at that moment the hand becomes the body’s enemy—so it is with all six senses.

"Do you delight in all equally?" asks: among the six senses, do you take equal pleasure in all, or do you favor some? Moreover, in their functions within the body, which is noble and which base? When the head itches and the hand scratches, the hand serves the head; when the eyes wish to see afar and the feet walk, the feet serve the eyes. Those who serve are like servants and concubines—yet are they insufficient to govern one another?

Hands, feet, ears, eyes, nose, and tongue all serve one another in turn. The one served is the subject, the one serving is the lord. Sometimes the feet are used, sometimes the hands—thus they take turns as lord and subject. Since the lordship and subjecthood of the hundred bones, nine orifices, and six viscera cannot be fixed, then the heart, as the master of the body, must be the lord. Yet the heart cannot govern itself, for what governs it is the Creator—thus the Creator is the true ruler. Hence it is said: "Is there a true ruler present?" Though I seek thus to reach the truth, whether I grasp it or not, what is called the ruler neither gains nor loses in its reality. Thus it is said: "Whether one grasps their nature or not, it neither benefits nor harms the real."

Once we receive our completed form, we do not perish until its end. We clash and grind against things, our actions racing to their limit like a galloping horse, yet none can halt them—is this not lamentable? A lifetime of toil, yet no success is seen; wearily exhausted, we know not where we return—how can this not be sorrowful? People call this "not dying," but what good is it? The body transforms, the heart follows suit—can this not be called great sorrow?

Is human life inherently so deluded? Or am I alone deluded while others are not? Generally, the human form is not self-possessed but must be received from something else. Having received this form from the Creator, the Creator remains with us, not departing until this form is spent. Yet people cannot simply follow the Creator but are instead swept away by external things, sometimes resisting, sometimes yielding. Thus they act throughout their lives, like a colt passing a crack—unable to rest even for a moment. Hence it is said: "their actions race to their limit like a galloping horse, yet none can halt them."

Some are joyful, some angry, some sorrowful, some delighted; at times they worry, at times they sigh, at times they shift their demeanor, never content, always desiring something else. chunks.original_text: 相刃，相逆也，相靡，相随汩没之意。 终身役役，言自苦也。 不见其成功，言无益也。 采得百花成蜜后，不知辛苦为谁甜，即此意也。 薾然疲役，又形容其役役劳苦之状，不知其所归，不知何日可休歇也。 人生之自劳如此，寿虽百年，亦何益。 故曰不死奚益。 其形化者，从衰得白，从白得老也，年弥高而德弥邵，则是形化而心不化。 在我既无见识，徒以心为形役，形衰而心亦疲矣，故曰其心与之然。 芒芒然，无见识也。 彼愚惑之人，亦当回首自思曰：凡人之生，其胸中本若是昧然无见乎。 岂我独昧而人亦有不昧者。 此意盖谓天生蒸民，有物有则，民之秉彝，好是懿德。 天理未尝不明，汝以人欲自昏，故至於此。 知道之人岂如此芒昧乎，此所谓金篦括膜，要汝开眼也。 夫随其成心而师之，谁独且无师乎。 奚必知代，而心自取者有之。 愚者与有焉，未成乎心而有是非，是今日适越而昔至也。 是以无有为有，无有为有，虽有神禹且不能知，吾独且奈何哉。 成心者，人人皆有此心。 天理浑然而无不备者也，言汝之生皆有见成一个天理，若能以此为师，则谁独无之。 非惟贤者有此，愚者亦有之。 知代，古贤者之称也。 代，变化也，言其知变化之理也。 心自取者言其心有所见也，若此心未能见此浑然之理，而强立是非之论，是者自是而不知其理之本然，譬如今日方始适越而谓昔日已至之矣。 天下宁有是理哉，此谓强其不知以为知也。 如此则是本无所见而强以为有，既已无所见而自以为有所见，虽使古圣人复出，於汝亦不可晓，他人又奈汝何哉。 神禹即禹也，借以为古圣人之称也。 夫言非吹也，言者有言，其所言者特未定也。 果有言邪，其未尝有言邪。 其以为异於鷇音，亦有辩乎，其无辩乎。 此篇本为齐物论是非而作。 前既发为三籁之论，谓天地之间凡有声者皆出於造物，却又引而伸之，演说人身皆为造物所使，紬绎发越至成心处而后住。 自此以下却说是非之论。 风之於窍，比竹之声，吹万不同，皆声而已。 声成文而后谓之言，言则非吹比也。 所谓言者皆各言其意也，故曰言者有言。 此四字便是是非之论。 其所言者，特未定也，谓汝虽有此言，其出於汝耶，其出於造物耶。 故曰未定其言。 果汝之言邪，其在汝者未尝有此言，而为造物所使，遂为此言邪。 鷇者，鸟之初出卯者也。 鷇之为音，未有所知，汝之有言，亦不自知，若以为异於鷇音，则实不能，自异则以为与鷇音有分辨乎，无分辩乎。 言其实一同，不可得而分辨也。 南华真经口义卷之二竟 #1声：原本无，据明本增。 #2者：原本无，据明本增。 #3曰：原作『一』，据明本改。 #4手：原本无，据明本增。 南华真经口义卷之三 鬳斋林希逸

Blades clashing—this is mutual opposition; scattering and yielding—this is being swept away and submerged. "Toiling all one’s life" speaks of self-inflicted suffering. "Never seeing one’s achievements come to fruition" speaks of futility. As the saying goes: "After gathering nectar from a hundred flowers to make honey, for whom is the sweetness, and who knows the bitterness?"—this is the same idea. Exhausted and worn, it further depicts the state of endless toil and hardship, not knowing where one is headed or when one may rest.

Human life labors thus of its own accord—even if one lives a hundred years, what good does it do? Hence it is said: "What good is not dying?" "The body’s transformation" refers to declining into gray hair, then from gray hair into old age. As the years grow ever more advanced, virtue grows ever more diminished—this is the body transforming while the heart does not. Within myself, lacking insight, I merely allow the heart to be enslaved by the body. When the body declines, the heart too grows weary—hence it is said: "the heart follows suit." "Muddled and confused"—this is to lack insight. Even those foolish and deluded should turn back and ask themselves: Is the human heart, by nature, so benighted and devoid of understanding? Am I alone benighted, while others are not?

This meaning suggests that Heaven, in giving birth to the multitudes, endows them with things and with principles. The people, holding fast to constancy, naturally incline toward excellent virtue. The heavenly principle has never been obscure—it is you who have obscured yourself with human desire, thus arriving at this state. How could those who understand the Dao be so muddled and confused? This is what is meant by "a golden needle scraping away the film"—it is meant to open your eyes.

Now, if one follows one’s "completed heart" and takes it as a teacher, who would lack such a teacher? Why must one wait for "knowledge of transformation" before the heart naturally possesses its own insights? Even the foolish share in this. To have judgments of right and wrong before the heart is fully formed is like setting out for Yue today yet claiming to have arrived yesterday. Thus, to take what is not as what is, to insist on what is not as what is—even if the divine Yu were to return, he could not comprehend it. What then can I do?

The "completed heart" is something everyone possesses. It is the heavenly principle, vast and undifferentiated, yet lacking in nothing. This means that in your life, you already possess a fully formed heavenly principle. If you could take this as your teacher, who would lack it? Not only the worthy possess it—the foolish possess it as well. "Knowledge of transformation" is a term for the ancient worthies, referring to their understanding of the principles of change. "The heart naturally possesses its own insights" means that the heart has its own perceptions. If this heart has not yet perceived the undifferentiated principle but forcibly establishes judgments of right and wrong, affirming what it affirms without knowing the principle’s original state, it is like setting out for Yue today yet claiming to have arrived yesterday. Is there any such principle in the world? This is to insist on what one does not know as if one knows it.

Thus, if one has no true insight yet insists on having it, even if one believes oneself to possess insight where there is none, not even the ancient sages returning could enlighten you—what then can others do for you? "Divine Yu" is Yu the Great, used here as a term for the ancient sages.

Words are not like the wind’s blowing. Speakers have their say, yet what they say remains unsettled. Is it truly speech? Or has there never been speech at all? Does it differ from the chirping of a fledgling? Can one distinguish it, or is there no distinction?

This chapter was originally composed to discuss the right and wrong of the *Discourse on Equalizing Things*. Earlier, it set forth the theory of the Three Pipes, stating that all sounds in heaven and earth arise from the Creator. It then expanded on this, explaining that the human body is entirely at the Creator’s disposal, unfolding and developing this idea until arriving at the "completed heart," where it pauses. From this point onward, it discusses judgments of right and wrong.

The wind through the hollows, compared to the sound of bamboo, blows in myriad ways—yet all are merely sound. Only when sound takes form does it become speech, and speech is not like the wind’s blowing. What is called speech is each person speaking their own meaning—hence it is said: "speakers have their say." These four words introduce the discussion of right and wrong. "What they say remains unsettled" means that though you may have these words, are they truly yours, or do they arise from the Creator? Hence it is said: "their words remain unsettled."

Is it truly your speech? Or have you never possessed these words, and it is the Creator who moves you to speak them? A fledgling is a bird newly hatched from the egg. Its chirping is without understanding, and your speech is likewise without self-awareness. If you believe it differs from the fledgling’s chirping, in reality it does not. Can you truly distinguish it from the fledgling’s sound, or is there no distinction? In truth, they are the same, and no distinction can be made.

chunks.original_text: 内篇齐物论下 道恶乎隐而有真伪，言恶乎隐而有是非。 道恶乎往而不存，言恶乎存而不可。 道隐於小成，言隐於荣华，故有儒墨之是非，以是其所非而非其所是。 欲是其所非而非其所是，则莫若以明。 物无非彼，物无非是，自彼则不见，自知则知之，故曰彼出於是，是亦因彼。 道本无真伪，不知道因何而隐晦，故有此真伪。 至言本无是非，不知因何而隐晦，故有此是非之论。 恶乎往而不存者，谓大小精粗，是道无乎不在也。 恶乎存而不可者，谓是是非非皆可也。 小成，小见也，一偏之见也，因人之偏见而后此道晦而不明。 荣华者，自相夸诩以求名誉也。 偏见之言，自相夸诩，则至言隐矣。 自是而后，始有儒墨相是非之论。 人之所非，我以为是，彼之所是，我以为非，安得而一定。 若欲一定是非，则须是归之自然之天理方可，明者，天理也。 故曰莫若以明。 物无非彼者，言以我为是则以彼为非也； 物无非是者，言我以为是则人以为非也。 在彼之说，我则不为之。 见察在我，知者则自知之。 物我不对立则无是无非，因物我之对立而后有是有非，故曰：彼出於是，是亦因彼。 彼是方生之说也。 虽然，方生方死，方死方生、方可方不可，方不可方可，因是因非，因非因是。 是以圣人不由而照之于天，亦因是也。 有彼有是止与方生之说同。 此是撰出一个方生字来做譬喻。 盖生必有死，二者不可相离，若只说生而不说死，是见得一边而已。 虽然汝虽见得一边，据道理来他自相离不得。 如生则必有死，死则必有生，才有个可，便有个不可，才有个不可，便有个可，如何离得既知其说之不可离，则不若因其所是而是之，因其所非而非之，古之圣人所以不用一偏之见而照之以天理者，即因其是而已矣。 前说因是因非，此又只言因是省文也。 是亦彼也，彼亦是也； 彼亦一是非，此亦一是非。 果且有彼是乎哉，果且无彼是乎哉。 彼是莫得其偶，谓之道枢。 枢始得其环中以应无穷，是亦一无穷，非亦一无穷也。 故曰莫若以明。 若以是非而论，则它之说一是非也，我之说又一是非也，我与它又何以异。 汝虽分为人我，其实分不得，故曰果且有彼是乎哉，果且无彼是乎哉，言彼与我皆无也。 偶者，对也，若使彼之与我不对而立，混人已而一之，则为道之枢要矣。 环之中必虚，我得道之枢要，则方始如环中然，如环之中则无终无始而无穷矣。 是亦无穷，非亦无穷者，言听其自然也。 如此则为自然之天理，故曰莫若以明，举前一句以结此段也。 以指喻指之非指，不若以非指喻指之非指也。 以马喻马之非马，不若以非马喻马之非马也。 天地一指也，万物一马也。 指，手指也。 以我之指为指，则以人之指为非，彼非指之人又以我指为非，若但以我而非彼，不若就他身上思量他又非我。 物我对立则是非不可定也。 马，博塞之筹也。 见礼记投壶篇下。 马有多寡，博者之相是非亦然。 若以此理而喻之，则天职覆地职载，亦皆可以一偏而相非矣。 万物之不同，飞者走者，动者植者，亦若筹马之不同，亦可以一偏而相非矣。 此盖言世间无是非也，只缘有彼我，则有是非终不成。 天地，亦可以彼我分乎。 此皆譬物论之不可不齐也。
chunks.translated_text:
Where does the Dao conceal itself to produce truth and falsehood? Where do words conceal themselves to produce right and wrong? Where does the Dao go that it ceases to exist? Where do words remain that they cannot be trusted?

The Dao is obscured by partial attainment; words are obscured by florid ornament. Thus arise the disputes of Confucians and Mohists, each affirming what the other denies and denying what the other affirms. If you would affirm what they deny and deny what they affirm, then nothing surpasses illumination.

Nothing exists that is not "that"; nothing exists that is not "this." From "that," one does not see; from self-knowledge, one knows. Thus it is said: "That emerges from this, and this likewise depends on that."

The Dao originally has no truth or falsehood—how then does it become obscured to produce truth and falsehood? Utterances originally have no right or wrong—how then do they become obscured to produce these disputes? As for "where it goes yet does not exist," it means that whether great or small, refined or coarse, the Dao is omnipresent. As for "where it remains yet cannot be trusted," it means that all affirmations and negations are permissible.

"Partial attainment" refers to a limited view, a one-sided perspective. Because of such partiality, the Dao becomes obscured and unclear. "Florid ornament" refers to self-aggrandizement in pursuit of fame and reputation. When partial views are adorned with such embellishment, the profound utterance is concealed. Thereafter begin the disputes between Confucians and Mohists, each affirming what the other denies and denying what the other affirms. What they deny, I affirm; what they affirm, I deny—how can any fixed standard be established? If one seeks to fix right and wrong, one must return to the natural principle of Heaven. "Illumination" is this natural principle. Thus it is said: "nothing surpasses illumination."

Nothing exists that is not "that"—if I affirm myself, I negate the other. Nothing exists that is not "this"—if I affirm myself, others negate me. From the other’s perspective, I do not act; discernment lies within me, and the wise know it for themselves. When self and other do not oppose each other, there is neither right nor wrong. Only through their opposition do right and wrong arise. Thus it is said: "That emerges from this, and this likewise depends on that." This is the doctrine of "that" and "this" arising simultaneously.

Yet as soon as something arises, it dies; as soon as it dies, it arises. As soon as something is permissible, it becomes impermissible; as soon as it is impermissible, it becomes permissible. Affirmation follows negation, and negation follows affirmation. Therefore the sage does not proceed by such means but illuminates all through Heaven—this too is "following affirmation."

The existence of "that" and "this" is no different from the doctrine of simultaneous arising. Here, the term "simultaneous arising" is introduced as an analogy. For life necessarily entails death, and the two cannot be separated. To speak only of life without death is to see only one side. Though you may see only one side, in principle they cannot be separated. Just as life necessarily entails death, and death necessarily entails life, so too does the permissible necessarily entail the impermissible, and the impermissible the permissible. How can they be divided? Once you recognize that their separation is impossible, it is better to affirm what is affirmed and negate what is negated. The sages of old did not rely on partial views but illuminated all through the principle of Heaven—this is simply "following affirmation." The earlier statement about "affirmation following negation" is here abbreviated to "following affirmation."

"This" is also "that," and "that" is also "this." "That" has its own right and wrong, and "this" has its own right and wrong. Is there truly a "that" and "this"? Or is there truly no "that" and "this"? When "that" and "this" find no counterpart, this is called the pivot of the Dao. Once the pivot is grasped at the center of the circle, it can respond endlessly. Affirmation is one endless cycle, and negation is another. Thus it is said: "nothing surpasses illumination."

If we argue over right and wrong, their doctrines are one right and wrong, and our doctrines are another right and wrong—how then do we differ? Though you divide things into self and other, in reality they cannot be divided. Thus it is said: "Is there truly a 'that' and 'this'? Or is there truly no 'that' and 'this'?"—meaning that both self and other are nonexistent. "Counterpart" means opposition. If "that" and "this" do not stand in opposition but are blended into one, this is the pivot of the Dao. The center of a ring is necessarily empty. When I grasp the pivot of the Dao, I am like the center of a ring—without beginning or end, infinite. "Affirmation is one endless cycle, and negation is another" means following the natural course. This is the natural principle of Heaven. Thus it is said: "nothing surpasses illumination," echoing the earlier statement to conclude this passage.

To use a finger to illustrate that a finger is not a finger is not as good as using a non-finger to illustrate that a finger is not a finger. To use a horse to illustrate that a horse is not a horse is not as good as using a non-horse to illustrate that a horse is not a horse. Heaven and Earth are one finger; the myriad things are one horse.

"A finger" refers to a finger of the hand. If I take my finger to be a finger, then I take another’s finger to be not a finger. Yet those who do not take it as a finger also take my finger to be not a finger. If I merely negate the other without considering their perspective, it is better to reflect on how they negate me. When self and other oppose each other, right and wrong cannot be fixed.

"A horse" refers to the counting rods used in games of chance. See the *Record of Rites*, "Touhu" chapter. The number of rods varies, and the disputes of gamblers are likewise divided. If we apply this principle, then Heaven’s duty to cover and Earth’s duty to bear could also be negated from a partial perspective. The myriad things differ—some fly, some walk, some move, some are rooted—just as the counting rods differ, and they too could be negated from a partial perspective. This illustrates that in the world there is no right or wrong; it is only because of self and other that right and wrong never cease. Can Heaven and Earth also be divided into self and other? This all serves to illustrate that the discourse on things cannot but be equalized.

chunks.original_text: 可乎可，不可乎不可。 道行之而成，物谓之而然。 恶乎然，然於然，恶乎不然，不然於不然。 物固有所然，物固有所可，无物不然，无物不可。 可者可之，不可者不可之，故曰：可乎可，不可乎不可。 道无精粗，行之即成，皆自然也。 谓之而然说底便是也。 我何所然乎，因其然者而然之； 我何所不然乎，因其不然者而不然之。 物固有所然者，固，本来也。 言物物身上本来自有一个是底，故曰固有所然，固有所可。 既有所然有所可，则物物皆如是也，故曰：无物不然，无物不可。 故为是举莛与楹，厉与西施，恢恑谲怪，道通为一。 莛，屋梁也； 楹，屋柱也。 梁横而柱直，厉恶而施美。 恢大之与褊狭，诡变之与循常，谲诈之与平直，妖怪之与祥瑞，皆不同者也。 以道观之，则横直者各当其用，美恶者各全其质，皆可通而为一矣。 言皆归之造物也。 其分也成也，其成也毁也。 凡物无成与毁，复通为一。 成毁，物之相戾者也。 然无毁则无成，无成则无毁，譬如木之在山，伐而用之，毁也，以之作室则为成物矣。 譬如用药，吹之咀之，分也，合而和之，可以成药。 有筋有角而后成弓，在弓则为成，在筋角则为毁。 秦不亡则汉不兴，汉虽成而秦则毁。 以此观之，初无成也，亦无毁也。 故曰复通为一。 唯达者知通为一，为是不用而寓诸庸。 庸也者，用也； 用也者，通也； 通也者，得也，适得而几矣。 因是已，已而不知其然谓之道。 唯达道者知此理之为一，则去其是者不用之而寓诸庸之中。 以常为用而随用皆通，通则自得矣。 故曰：庸也者用也，用也者通也，通也者得也，适得而几矣。 几，尽也。 此亦无他，不过因是而无是非之争，如此而已。 惟至於不知其然而循其自然，此则谓之道也。 以下句已字粘上句已字，此是其笔端游戏作文字处。 劳神明为一而不知其同也，谓之朝三，何谓朝三。 曰：徂公赋芋，曰朝三而暮四。 众祖皆怒。 曰：然则朝四而暮三。 众祖皆悦。 名实未亏而喜怒为用，亦因是也。 是以圣人和之以是非而休乎天均，是之谓两行。 神明犹精神也。 劳苦精神自为一偏之说，强相是非而不知理本同者，谓之朝三。 此亦是做两字设譬喻起，与方生一样文法。 芋，山栗也，一名橡子。 名三与四也，实通七数也。 名实未尝变，但移易朝暮而众祖喜怒随之，此喻是非之名虽异而理之实则同，但能因是则世自无争矣。 洪野处云：列子胜於庄子，如此譬喻二书皆同，但把字数添喊处看，便见列子胜不得庄子。 和之以是非者，和其是非而归之一也。 天均者，均平而无彼此也。 两行者，随其是非而使之并行也。 古之人，其知有所至矣。 恶乎至，有以为未始有物者，至矣尽矣，不可以加矣； 其次以为有物矣，而未始有封也； 其次以为有封焉而未始有是非也； 是非之彰也，道之所以亏也。 道之所以亏，爱之所以成，果且有成与亏乎哉，果且无成与亏乎哉。 未始有物者，太极之先也。 古之人者，言古之知道者。 自无物之始看起来，则天下之理极矣。 其次为有物，是无极而太极也。 自有物而有封，是太极分而为两仪也。 两仪虽分，覆载异职，各循#1其理，何尝有所是非。 是非起於人心之私，彰露也，私心既露则自然之道亏丧矣。
chunks.translated_text:
What is permissible is permissible, what is impermissible is impermissible. The Dao is realized through its enactment, and things are affirmed through their designation. Why are they so? They are so because they are so. Why are they not so? They are not so because they are not so. Things inherently possess what they affirm, things inherently possess what they permit—nothing is not affirmed, nothing is not permitted. What is permissible is permitted, what is impermissible is not permitted. Thus it is said: what is permissible is permissible, what is impermissible is impermissible.

The Dao has no refinement or coarseness; when enacted, it is realized—all is natural. To designate and affirm is simply to speak of what is so. What do I affirm? I affirm by following what is affirmed. What do I not affirm? I do not affirm by following what is not affirmed. Things inherently possess what they affirm—*gu* (inherently) means "originally." This means that each thing originally possesses its own affirmation. Thus it is said: inherently possessing what they affirm, inherently possessing what they permit. Since they possess what they affirm and what they permit, then all things are likewise. Thus it is said: nothing is not affirmed, nothing is not permitted.

Therefore, consider the rafter and the pillar, the leper and Xi Shi, the vast and the cramped, the deceptive and the constant, the cunning and the straightforward, the monstrous and the auspicious—all are different. The rafter is horizontal, the pillar vertical; the leper is ugly, Xi Shi beautiful. The vast differs from the cramped, the deceptive from the constant, the cunning from the straightforward, the monstrous from the auspicious—yet all are distinct. Viewed through the Dao, the horizontal and vertical each serve their purpose, the beautiful and ugly each fulfill their nature, and all can be harmonized into one. This means all return to the Creator.

Their division is their completion, their completion is their destruction. All things are neither completed nor destroyed, but return to unity. Completion and destruction are opposed in things. Yet without destruction, there is no completion; without completion, there is no destruction. For example, a tree in the mountains is felled and used—this is destruction; but when used to build a house, it becomes a completed thing. Or consider medicine: it is blown upon and chewed—this is division; but when combined and harmonized, it becomes a remedy. A bow is completed with sinew and horn; in the bow, it is completion, but in the sinew and horn, it is destruction. If Qin had not fallen, Han would not have risen; Han’s completion is Qin’s destruction. Viewed thus, there is originally no completion, nor is there destruction. Thus it is said: they return to unity.

Only the enlightened know this unity. Therefore, they do not employ [partial views] but lodge them in the ordinary. The ordinary is use; use is harmony; harmony is attainment—attaining it is near perfection. Following this, ceasing and yet not knowing why it is so—this is the Dao.

Only those who comprehend the Dao know that this principle is one. Thus, they discard their affirmations, do not employ them, and lodge them in the ordinary. Using the constant, they harmonize all applications; in harmony, they naturally attain. Thus it is said: the ordinary is use, use is harmony, harmony is attainment—attaining it is near perfection. *Ji* (near) means "exhaustive." There is nothing more to this than following what is so and eliminating disputes over right and wrong. Only when one no longer knows why yet follows the natural—this is called the Dao.

The following phrase connects the two instances of *yi* (already), a playful flourish in the text.

To exhaust one’s spirit in forcing unity without recognizing their sameness—this is called "morning three." What is "morning three"? It is said: the Lord of Zhu distributed chestnuts, saying "three in the morning and four in the evening." The monkeys were all enraged. He then said, "Very well, four in the morning and three in the evening." The monkeys were all pleased. The names and realities had not changed, yet joy and anger were employed—this too follows what is so.

Therefore, the sage harmonizes right and wrong and rests in the equality of Heaven, which is called "walking two paths." *Shenming* (spirit) refers to the mind. To labor the mind in clinging to partial views, forcing right and wrong without recognizing the original unity of principle—this is called "morning three." This is another example of setting up a metaphor, following the same structure as "fang sheng" (mutual arising).

Chestnuts are mountain chestnuts, also called acorns. The names "three" and "four" differ, but the total remains seven. The names and realities do not change, yet shifting morning and evening alters the monkeys’ joy and anger. This illustrates that while the names of right and wrong differ, the reality of principle is the same. If one can follow what is so, the world will naturally have no disputes.

Hong Yechu said: *Liezi* surpasses *Zhuangzi*. Though both books share this metaphor, merely expanding the word count reveals that *Liezi* cannot surpass *Zhuangzi*. To harmonize right and wrong is to reconcile them into one. *Tian jun* (equality of Heaven) means impartiality without self and other. *Liang xing* (walking two paths) means allowing right and wrong to proceed side by side.

The knowledge of the ancients reached its utmost. How far did it reach? Some held that there had never yet been things—this is the utmost, the exhaustion, beyond which nothing can be added. Next were those who held that things existed but had never yet been bounded. Next were those who held that boundaries existed but right and wrong had never yet arisen. The manifestation of right and wrong is the diminishment of the Dao. The diminishment of the Dao is the formation of attachment. Is there truly completion and diminishment? Or is there truly no completion and diminishment?

Those who held that there had never yet been things refer to the state before the Supreme Ultimate. "The ancients" refers to those who understood the Dao. Viewed from the beginning before things existed, the principles of the world are exhausted. Next, to hold that things exist is to speak of the Supreme Ultimate emerging from the Limitless. From things emerging with boundaries, the Supreme Ultimate divides into the Two Modes. Though the Two Modes differ—one covering, one bearing—they each follow their principle. How could there be right and wrong? Right and wrong arise from the selfishness of the human mind. Once selfishness is manifest, the natural Dao is diminished.
chunks.overlap_context: y to bear could also be negated from a partial perspective. The myriad things differ—some fly, some walk, some move, some are rooted—just as the counting rods differ, and they too could be negated from a partial perspective. This illustrates that in the world there is no right or wrong; it is only because of self and other that right and wrong never cease. Can Heaven and Earth also be divided into self and other? This all serves to illustrate that the discourse on things cannot but be equalized.

chunks.original_text: 道既亏则有好有恶，在我则爱而在物则恶，佛氏所谓爱河是也。 亏其道而溺於爱，此自人心之私。 然以造物观之，何尝有所成亏，故曰果且有成与亏乎哉，果且无成与亏乎哉。 此言人世是非之争，到了皆归之空也。 此一段固是自天地之初说来，然会此理者眼前便是。 且如一念未起便是未始有物之时，此念既起便是有物。 因此念而后有物我，便是有封，因物我而有好恶喜怒哀乐，便是有是非。 未能回思，悉念未起之时，则但见胸次胶扰，便是道亏而爱成。 及此念一过，依然无事，便见得何尝有成有亏。 庄子之言若迂阔，若能如此体认，则皆是切身受用之事。 有成与亏，故昭氏之鼓琴也。 无成与亏，故昭氏之不鼓琴也。 昭文之鼓琴也，师旷之枝策也，惠，子之据梧也，三子之知几乎，皆其盛者也。 故载之末年，唯其好之也以异於彼。 其好之也欲以明之，彼非所明而明之，故以坚白之昧终。 而其子又以文之纶终，终身无成，若是而可谓成乎。 虽我亦成也，若是而不可谓成乎。 物与我无成也，是故滑疑之耀，圣人之所图也。 为是不用而寓诸庸，此之谓以明。 既说成亏之理，却以鼓琴喻之，最为亲切。 且如有琴於此，用而鼓之，则一操之曲自有终始，此终始生於既鼓之后，若不鼓则安有终始哉。 如人一念若不起，则亦无有物我之同异也。 昭，姓也，名文，古之善鼓琴者。 师旷，乐师也。 策，击乐器之物也，今马鞭亦曰策，左传绕朝赠之以策，羊昙以策击西州门，皆马策也。 枝犹持也，持而击曰枝，此二字想古语有之。 师旷枝策即言师旷击乐器也。 据梧，以梧为几而凭之，故曰据梧。 因上言鼓琴，遂引说二子，言三子之技皆精。 几，尽也，言其智於此技极其尽也。 技精而有盛名於世，故曰皆其盛者也。 载，事也，末年，晚年也，言从事於此终其身也。 三子之好自以为异於天下之人，故曰唯其好之也以异於彼。 三子既自好之，又欲夸说於人，故曰其好之也欲以明之。 我虽如此夸说，而所听之人本自分#2晓，乃强欲以此晓之，枚曰彼非所明而明之。 如惠子之强辩自愚也而以终其身。 坚白本公孙龙之事，庄子却以为惠子，但借其分辩坚白之名耳。 昧，自愚也。 上言三子，此但以惠子之辨为结，亦是文法也。 坚白，注家以为坚石白马之辨。 盖曰坚则为石，言石不必言坚； 白则为马，言白不必言马，亦犹黄马骊牛三也。 史记苏秦传注又曰，龙泉水淬刀剑时坚利，故有坚白之论。 曰黄所以为坚，白所以为利，齐辨之曰：白所以为不坚，黄所以为不利，二说虽殊，皆辨者之事尔。 昭文既以鼓琴终其身，而昭文之子又传文之绪业，亦终其身，纶，绪业也。 上言惠子，下句又以昭文之子结，此是笔端鼓舞处。 终身无成者，言只它一人自会，教别人不得，故曰无成。 几天下之事若只据其所能而可以为了当，则我之现前所能者谓之了当亦可也。 若据此现前者未为了当，则凡天下之人与我皆不得谓之了当。 成犹言了当也。 此两句虽是结上三子之技，然其意甚广，盖所言三子之技亦是譬喻物论是非，非专说三子也。 滑疑，言不分不晓也。 滑乱而可疑，似明而不明也。 耀，明也。 圣人之心其所主者未尝着迹，故其所见之处若有若无。
chunks.translated_text:
Once the Dao is diminished, there arise likes and dislikes—what is love in me becomes aversion in others, which is what the Buddhists call the "river of attachment." To impair the Dao and drown in love is but the selfishness of the human mind. Yet viewed from the perspective of the Creator, how could there ever be completion or diminishment? Thus it is said: Is there truly completion and diminishment? Or is there truly no completion and diminishment? This speaks to how all disputes over right and wrong in the human world ultimately return to emptiness.

Though this passage begins with the origins of Heaven and Earth, one who grasps this principle sees it manifest before their very eyes. For instance, before a single thought arises, it is the time "before things ever existed." Once this thought arises, it is "the existence of things." From this thought comes the distinction between self and other, which is "the emergence of boundaries." From self and other arise likes and dislikes, joy and anger, sorrow and delight—this is the rise of right and wrong. If one cannot reflect back to the time before thoughts arose, one sees only the turmoil within the breast, which is the Dao diminished and attachment formed. Yet when this thought passes, all returns to tranquility, revealing that there was never truly completion or diminishment.

Though Zhuangzi’s words may seem remote, if one can embody them thus, they become matters of immediate and personal relevance. There is completion and diminishment—hence Zhaoshi’s playing of the zither. There is no completion and diminishment—hence Zhaoshi’s not playing of the zither. Zhaowen’s playing of the zither, Master Kuang’s striking of the clappers, and Hui’s leaning upon the elm—these three men’s skills were all at their peak. Thus their deeds are recorded in their later years, for their devotion set them apart from others. Their devotion sought to make their skills known, yet what they sought to clarify was not inherently clear, so they ended in the obscurity of "hard and white." And Zhaowen’s son, in turn, carried on his father’s art to the end, yet achieved nothing in his lifetime. Could this be called completion? Though I, too, may be said to have achieved, can this truly be called completion?

Things and self share no completion. Thus the dazzling confusion of doubt is what the sage seeks to resolve. To refrain from use and lodge it in the ordinary—this is called "illumination through non-action." Having expounded the principle of completion and diminishment, he then uses the zither as a metaphor, which is most apt. Consider a zither here: if one plays it, a piece of music has a beginning and an end, but this beginning and end arise only after playing. If one does not play, how could there be beginning or end? Likewise, if a single thought does not arise, there is no distinction between self and other.

Zhao was a surname; Wen was the given name of an ancient master of the zither. Master Kuang was a court musician. *Ce* refers to the implement used to strike musical instruments—today, a horsewhip is also called a *ce*. In the *Zuozhuan*, Rao Chao gifts one as a *ce*, and Yang Tan strikes the West Gate with one—both are horsewhips. *Zhi* means "to hold," and "to strike" is called *zhi*; these two characters likely existed in ancient speech. "Master Kuang striking the clappers" thus means Master Kuang playing the percussion instrument. *Ju wu* means leaning upon an elm as if it were a table, hence "leaning upon the elm." Following the mention of zither-playing, he then brings up the other two, saying that the three men’s skills were all refined. *Ji* means "exhaustion," indicating that their wisdom in these arts was fully realized. Their skills were so masterful that they gained great renown in the world, hence "all at their peak."

*Zai* means "to engage in," and *monian* means "later years"—referring to dedicating oneself to these pursuits until the end of life. The three men’s devotion set them apart from others in the world, hence "their devotion set them apart from others." Having devoted themselves thus, they sought to display their skills to others, hence "their devotion sought to make their skills known." Though they sought to clarify, those who listened were not inherently enlightened, so they forced understanding upon them, hence "what they sought to clarify was not inherently clear." Like Huizi’s stubborn arguments, which only led to his own confusion, they ended their lives thus. "Hard and white" originally referred to Gongsun Long’s paradox, but Zhuangzi attributes it to Huizi, merely borrowing the name of the "hard and white" debate. *Mei* means "self-delusion."

Above, he spoke of the three men, but here he concludes with Huizi’s arguments—this is a matter of literary technique. "Hard and white," according to commentators, refers to the debates over "hard stone" and "white horse." For example, if something is hard, it is stone, and one need not say "hard"; if something is white, it is a horse, and one need not say "white"—much like the paradox of "yellow horse" and "black ox." The *Records of the Grand Historian*’s commentary on Su Qin’s biography also states that when Longquan water was used to quench swords, they became hard and sharp, giving rise to the "hard and white" debate: yellow represents hardness, white represents sharpness. The Qi debaters countered: white represents lack of hardness, yellow represents lack of sharpness. Though the two arguments differ, both are the work of sophists.

Zhaowen spent his life playing the zither, and his son, in turn, carried on his father’s legacy, also spending his life in this pursuit. *Lun* means "legacy." Above, he spoke of Huizi, and in the next line, he concludes with Zhaowen’s son—this is where the brush dances. "Achieved nothing in his lifetime" means that only he himself could master it, and he could not teach others, hence "no completion." If all things in the world could be resolved merely by relying on one’s abilities, then what I can do in the present could also be called resolution. But if what I do in the present is not truly resolution, then neither I nor anyone in the world can be said to have achieved resolution. *Cheng* here means "resolution."

Though these two lines conclude the discussion of the three men’s skills, their meaning is vast, for the three men’s skills serve as metaphors for the disputes over right and wrong in the world—they are not merely about the three men. *Huayi* means "indistinct and unclear." Confusion that breeds doubt appears bright but is not truly illuminating. *Yao* means "brightness." The sage’s mind does not cling to traces, so what it perceives is as if present, as if absent. To refrain from use and lodge it in the ordinary—this is called "illumination."

How could there be right and wrong? Right and wrong arise from the selfishness of the human mind. Once selfishness is manifest, the natural Dao is diminished.

chunks.original_text: 图，欲也，言圣人之所欲者如此也。 所以去其是不用而寓诸寻常之中，此之谓以明。 自物无非彼以下，至非一无穷也，既解以明二字； 自以指喻指以下至适得而几矣，又解因是二字； 却直至此处又以此之谓以明结之，文势起伏，纵横变化，纲领自是分晓。 仆尝谓齐物论自首至尾只是一片文字，子细看他下字，血脉便见。 今且有言於此，不知其与是类乎，其与是不类乎。 类与不类，相与为类，则与彼无以异矣。 此段又自为是不用一句中是字生来，故曰与是类乎，与是不类乎。 此便是他下字血脉。 前言言非吹也，到此换头又喝起今且有言於此一句，亦是他前后血脉。 以其类者与其不类者，易地而看，则见类与不类皆相类矣。 其意盖曰：把他做我看，把我做他看，则见我与他一般。 故曰与彼无以异矣，此便是以指喻指，以马喻马之意。 虽然，请尝言之。 有始也者，有未始有始也者，有未始有夫未始有始也者。 有有也者，有无也者，有未始有无也者，有未始有夫未始有无也者。 俄而有无矣，而未知有无之果孰有孰无也。 今我则已有谓矣，而未知吾所谓之其果有谓乎，其果无谓乎。 庄子之文才下虽然作一转处，其语皆妙，其意盖谓：虽云无是无非，亦且说一说，故曰请尝言之。 始，太极也，未始有始，无极也。 未始有夫未始有始，此无极之上又一层也。 有有物也，此有之生必自无而始。 故曰有无也者，无字之上又有未始有无，即无极之上一层也。 列子所谓有太质，有太素，有太初，亦是此意。 当初本无个有，不特无个有，亦无个无。 忽然有个无，则必是生出一个有，如此推明其意，盖谓其初，本来无物，因有我而后有物我，因有物我而后有是非，大意不过如此，却恁地发明果是高妙。 据此处合曰：俄而有有矣。 今不曰俄而有有而曰俄而有无，此皆其笔端入妙处。 这个无字虽是有了，果是唤作无得否。 故曰未知有无之果孰有孰无也。 此个无字虽未可知，然既唤作无字，便是有无之名矣。 故曰今我则已有谓矣。 然我虽有此言，谓，即言也，然不知此言果可谓有邪，果可谓无邪。 此与鷇音处同。 圣人论而不议。 春秋，经世先王之志，圣人议而不辩。 故分也者，有不分也； 辩也者，有不辩也。 曰：何也。 圣人怀之，众人辩之，以相示也。 故曰：辩也者，有不见也。 上面既说了彼我是非，到这数句又别生个说话，来发明此老胸中多少玲珑，多少快活。 六合之外，天地之外也，存而不论，即释氏所谓四维上下不可思量也。 六合之内，宇宙之间也，宇宙之间合有许多道理，圣人何尝不说，但不立此议以强天下之知。 春秋，史书之名也，此一句又是既有君臣上下，凡见於史册者，皆是先王经世之意。 圣人岂容不立此议，而何尝与世人争较是非。 盖天下之理，惟其不言则为至言，才到分辩处，便是你胸中自见得不透彻也。 故曰：分也者，有不分也； 辨也者，有不辨也。 到这裹又自发一个何也之间。 怀之者，退藏於密之意也。 圣人於此，卷而怀之，众人於此，则必辩而明之，以相夸示。 才有分辩，便是无见识处，故曰有不见也。 夫大道不称，大辩不言，大仁不仁，大廉不嗛，大勇不忮。 道昭而不道，言辩而不及，仁常而不成，廉清而不信，勇忮而不成，五者园而几向方矣。
chunks.translated_text:
The term *tu* means "desire," indicating that what the sage desires is precisely this. Thus, to set aside "this" without employing it and lodge it in the ordinary—this is called "illumination."

From *"Since things are never without their opposites"* down to *"not one, not inexhaustible,"* the meaning of "illumination" is explained. From *"Using a finger to illustrate a finger"* down to *"one attains it and nearly grasps it,"* the meaning of *"relying on this"* is further clarified. Then, returning directly to this point, the text concludes with *"this is called 'illumination,'"* its structure rising and falling, shifting and transforming, yet its guiding principles remain distinct. I have often said that the *Qi Wu Lun* is but a single continuous text—examining its phrasing closely reveals its vital pulse.

Now, suppose I make a statement here: I do not know whether it belongs to the same category as "this" or not. Whether it belongs or does not belong, if both are considered as belonging to the same category, then it differs in no way from that. This passage arises from the phrase *"not employing this,"* hence the question: *"Does it belong to the same category as this, or not?"* This is the vital pulse of its phrasing. Earlier, it said, *"Words are not the blowing of the wind,"* and now, shifting its opening, it exclaims, *"Now, suppose I make a statement here"*—this, too, is the vital pulse connecting its beginning and end.

When the similar and the dissimilar are viewed from each other’s perspective, one sees that similarity and dissimilarity are themselves alike. The meaning is this: if you regard it as me and me as it, you will see that I and it are the same. Thus, it says, *"it differs in no way from that"*—this is the meaning of *"using a finger to illustrate a finger"* and *"using a horse to illustrate a horse."*

Yet, let me try to speak of it. There is a beginning; there is that which precedes the beginning; there is that which precedes even that which precedes the beginning. There is being; there is non-being; there is that which precedes non-being; there is that which precedes even that which precedes non-being. Suddenly, there is being and non-being, yet I do not know which of the two—being or non-being—is truly being or non-being. Now, I have already made a statement, yet I do not know whether what I have called it is truly a statement or not.

Just as Zhuangzi’s prose takes a turn at *"Yet,"* his words are marvelous. His meaning is this: though there is neither right nor wrong, let us still speak of it—hence, *"let me try to speak of it."* *"Beginning"* refers to the Supreme Ultimate; *"that which precedes the beginning"* refers to the Limitless; *"that which precedes even that which precedes the beginning"* is yet another layer beyond the Limitless. *"There is being"* refers to the arising of things, which must begin from non-being. Thus, *"there is non-being"*—and above *"non-being"* is *"that which precedes non-being,"* another layer beyond the Limitless. The *Liezi* speaks of the Great Simplicity, the Great Pristine, and the Great Beginning—this is the same idea. Originally, there was no being; not only was there no being, there was not even non-being. Suddenly, there was non-being, and from it arose being. Tracing this back reveals the meaning: in the beginning, there was originally nothing. Only with the emergence of the self did things and the self arise; only with things and the self did right and wrong appear. The general idea is no more than this, yet its exposition is truly lofty and wondrous.

Here, it should say, *"Suddenly, there is being,"* but instead, it says, *"Suddenly, there is being and non-being"*—this is where the brushwork attains its subtlety. Though this *"non-being"* has arisen, can it truly be called non-being? Thus, it says, *"I do not know which of the two—being or non-being—is truly being or non-being."* Though this *"non-being"* remains unknowable, once it is called *"non-being,"* it has already acquired the name of being and non-being. Thus, it says, *"Now, I have already made a statement."* Yet, though I have spoken these words—*"statement"* here meaning *"words"*—I do not know whether these words can truly be called being or non-being. This is akin to the passage on the fledgling’s cry.

The sage judges but does not debate. The *Spring and Autumn Annals* records the intentions of the former kings who ordered the world—the sage debates but does not argue. Thus, where there is division, there is also non-division; where there is argument, there is also non-argument. One asks: Why? The sage cherishes it within, while the multitude debates it to display to one another. Thus, it says: *"Where there is argument, there is also non-perception."*

Having already spoken of self and other, right and wrong, these few lines introduce yet another layer of meaning, revealing the boundless subtlety and freedom within this elder’s mind. Beyond the six directions lies the realm beyond heaven and earth—this is what is meant by *"preserving without discussing,"* akin to the Buddhist notion of the four directions and above and below being beyond conception. Within the six directions lies the realm of the cosmos, where countless principles exist. The sage does not refrain from speaking of them, yet he does not establish rigid debates to impose understanding upon the world. The *Spring and Autumn Annals* is the name of a historical record—this line refers to the fact that wherever there is ruler and subject, high and low, all that appears in the annals reflects the intentions of the former kings in ordering the world. How could the sage fail to establish such debates? Yet when has he ever contended with the world over right and wrong? For the principles of the world, silence is the highest speech; the moment one engages in division and debate, it reveals that one’s own understanding is not yet thorough. Thus, it says: *"Where there is division, there is also non-division; where there is argument, there is also non-argument."*

Here, it once more raises the question: *"Why?"* *"Cherishing it within"* means *"withdrawing and concealing in secrecy."* The sage, in this regard, rolls it up and cherishes it within, while the multitude, in this regard, must debate and clarify it to boast and display to one another. The moment there is division and debate, it is a sign of lacking insight—thus, it says, *"there is also non-perception."*

The great Dao is not named; great debate does not speak; great benevolence is not benevolent; great integrity is not modest; great courage is not aggressive. When the Dao is made manifest, it is no longer the Dao; when words are debated, they fall short; when benevolence is constant, it does not achieve; when integrity is pure, it is not trustworthy; when courage is aggressive, it does not succeed. These five, though round, nearly tend toward the square.
chunks.overlap_context: the three men’s skills, their meaning is vast, for the three men’s skills serve as metaphors for the disputes over right and wrong in the world—they are not merely about the three men. *Huayi* means "indistinct and unclear." Confusion that breeds doubt appears bright but is not truly illuminating. *Yao* means "brightness." The sage’s mind does not cling to traces, so what it perceives is as if present, as if absent. To refrain from use and lodge it in the ordinary—this is called "illumination."

chunks.original_text: 故知止其所不知，至矣。 孰知不言之辩、不道之道。 若有能知，此之谓天府。 注焉而不满，酌焉而不竭，而不知其所由来，此之谓葆光。 对立者曰称谓之，大道则无对立者矣。 不言之中自有至言，故曰大辩不言。 无七之迹而后为大仁。 嗛，满也，猴藏物曰嗛。 以康为廉，则有自满之意。 国语曰：嗛嗛之德，不足就也，言其自小。 即此嗛字，清畏人知，清畏人不知，皆不得为大廉矣。 不忮者，不见其用勇之迹也。 既说此五句，下面又再解一转。 昭者明也，道不可以指名，昭然而指名，则非道矣，故曰：不道言而形诸辩，则是自有见不及处矣。 常者，可见之进也，有可见之迹则非仁之大成矣。 廉而至於有自洁之意，则不诚实矣，清，自洁意也。 信，实也。 勇而见於忮，则必丧其勇矣。
chunks.translated_text:
Thus, to know where to halt in what one does not know—this is perfection. Who understands the debate of no-words, the Dao of no-Dao? If one can grasp this, it is called the Celestial Treasury. Pour into it without filling, draw from it without exhausting, yet know not whence it comes—this is called "preserving the light."

That which has an opposite is called a name, but the great Dao has no opposite. Within wordlessness lies the most profound speech, hence it is said, "great debate does not speak." Only when no trace of benevolence remains does it become great benevolence.

"Modesty" (嗛) means fullness; monkeys hide things by stuffing their cheeks. If one takes contentment as integrity, there arises the intent of self-satisfaction. The *Guoyu* states: "The virtue of self-restraint is insufficient to achieve greatness," for it remains small. Thus, whether one is modest for fear of others knowing or for fear of others not knowing, neither attains great integrity.

"Not aggressive" (不忮) means no trace of courage is seen in its use. Having expounded these five phrases, the text further elucidates them in turn.

"Manifest" (昭) means clarity; the Dao cannot be designated by name. If it is made manifest and named, it is no longer the Dao—hence it is said, "to give form to the Dao through debate is to reveal where one’s insight falls short." "Constant" (常) refers to visible progress; if there are visible traces, it is not the full realization of benevolence. Integrity that reaches the point of self-purification lacks sincerity, for "purity" (清) implies the intent of self-cleansing. "Trustworthiness" (信) means authenticity. Courage that manifests in aggression must lose its true courage.
