chunks.original_text: 内篇应帝王 言帝王之道，合应如此也。 啮缺问於王倪，四问而四不知。 啮缺因跃而大喜，行以告蒲衣子。 蒲衣子曰：而乃今知之乎。 有虞氏不及泰氏，有虞氏其犹藏仁以要人，亦得人矣，而未始出於非人。 泰氏其卧徐徐，其觉于于，一以己为马，一以己为牛，其知情信，其德甚真，而未始入於非人。 四问而四以不知答之，即维摩经以不言为不二法门之意。 蒲衣或曰即被衣也。 庄子所言人物名字，多是虚言，即乌有亡是公之类，不必致辨。 啮缺悟其不言之意，故喜以告蒲衣，蒲衣曰而乃今知之者，言汝于今方悟也。 而，汝也。 泰氏，古帝王也，即大庭氏之类。 藏，怀也。 要，结也。 以仁而结人之心亦可以得人。 不出於如天而已，谓其但能与天为徒也。 非人即天也，故曰未始出於非人。 未始出，犹曰不过如此也。 不曰天而曰非人，皆是其弄奇笔处。 其卧徐徐，安也； 其觉于于，自得也。 或以己为马，或以己为牛，皆置之不问，言听人谁何也，其所知皆实理。 情信，皆实也。 其德在己皆天真也。 到此处天字又不足以名之，是其任自然而然又出於造化之上，故曰未始入於非人。 前曰出，后曰入，看他下字处，帝王之道任自然而已，其名篇以应帝王意正在此。 肩吾见狂接舆，狂接舆曰：日中始何以语汝。 肩吾曰：告我君人者，以己出经式义度人，孰敢不听而化诸。 狂接舆曰：是欺德也。 其於治天下也，犹涉海凿河而使蚊负山也。 夫圣人之治也，治外乎，正而后行。 碗乎能其事者而已矣。 且鸟高飞以避矰弋之害，鼷鼠深穴乎神丘之下以避熏凿之患，而曾二虫之无知。 肩吾先见日中始，后见狂接舆。 故接舆以此问之。 经，常也。 式，法也。 义，处事之宜也。 以经式义皆出於己，言以身为天下法也。 度人者，化人也。 以身法而化天下，故曰以己出经式义度人，经式义句法便与和豫通同。 度音渡。 孰敢不听而化，言民皆听顺而化之也。 欺德者，言自欺也，非实德也。 欲以此治天下难於涉海凿河而使蚊虫负山也。 凿河即是疏九河之类。 治外者，言化之以心则无迹，化之以身则有迹也。 正而后行者，顺性命之理而行也。 能其事者，尽此自然之事也。 确乎，断乎也，言其为治断断乎如此。 庄子之意主於无为，故其说如此所以异於吾儒。 鸟高飞而避缯缴，鼠深穴而避熏凿，言有迹者必自累，今不能行无为之化而至於有迹，是其无知之愚，犹不若二虫也。 二虫，鸟鼠也。 神丘犹曰神皋也。 天根游於殷阳，至蓼水之上，适遭无名人而问焉曰：请问为天下。 无名人曰#1：去，汝鄙人也，何问之不豫也。 予方将与造物者为人，厌则又乘夫莽眇之鸟，以出六极之外，而游无何有之乡，以处圹垠之野。 汝又何帠以治天下感予之心为。 又复问，无名人曰：汝游心於淡，合气於漠，顺物自然而无容私焉，而天下治矣。 以为天下为问，便非无为而为之道，故以为鄙人之问而使我不豫。 不豫者，不乐也。 与造物为人者，言处於人世而顺造物之自然也。 厌，足也，饱也，言游於人世既已饱足，则将游於造物之外。 莽眇之鸟，虚无之气也。 无何有之乡，圹垠之野，皆言太虚无极之地也。 何帠，犹何故也。 注训法字，法亦故也。
chunks.translated_text:
**Inner Chapters: "Responding as Emperor and King"**

This chapter speaks of the Dao of emperors and kings, which must be thus in accord. Nie Que questioned Wang Ni four times, and four times received no answer. Thereat Nie Que leapt with great joy and went to tell Master Pu Yi.

Master Pu Yi said: "Have you only now come to know this? The Lord of Yu falls short of the Lord of Tai. The Lord of Yu concealed his benevolence to bind men to him—thus he gained men, yet never transcended the realm of the non-human. The Lord of Tai lay at ease, awoke in leisure; now taking himself for a horse, now for an ox. His knowledge was true to his nature, his virtue most genuine, and he never entered the realm of the non-human."

Four questions met with four answers of unknowing—this is the meaning of the *Vimalakīrti Sūtra*, where non-speech is the non-dual gateway. "Pu Yi" may also be read as "cloaked one." The names and figures in *Zhuangzi* are often fictive, like Master Wu You or Lord Absence—no need to dispute them.

Nie Que grasped the meaning of non-speech, hence his joy in telling Master Pu Yi. "Have you only now come to know this?" means "you have only now awakened." *Er* (而) means "you." The Lord of Tai was an ancient emperor, akin to the Lord of Great Court. *Cang* (藏) means "to harbor"; *yao* (要) means "to bind." To bind men’s hearts with benevolence is also a way to gain them. Yet this does not rise to the level of heaven—it merely keeps company with heaven. The "non-human" is heaven, hence "never transcended the non-human." "Never transcended" means "no more than this." To say "non-human" rather than "heaven" is but a flourish of his brush.

"Lay at ease" means tranquility; "awoke in leisure" means self-contentment. Now taking himself for a horse, now for an ox—all was left unquestioned, as if heedless of others’ judgments. What he knew was the true principle. *Qing xin* (情信) means "true in nature." His virtue was wholly natural. At this point, even "heaven" is insufficient to name it, for his spontaneity transcended even creation, hence "never entered the non-human." First "transcended," then "entered"—observe his choice of words. The Dao of emperors and kings lies in spontaneity alone; the title "Responding as Emperor and King" precisely conveys this.

---

Jian Wu met the madman Jie Yu, who asked: "What did Ri Zhong Shi tell you?"

Jian Wu said: "He told me that one who rules men must issue from himself the constant norms, models, and right principles to transform them. Who would dare disobey and fail to be transformed?"

Jie Yu said: "This is deceptive virtue. To govern the world thus is like crossing the sea by digging a river or making a mosquito bear a mountain. When the sage governs, he governs externally—acting only after rectifying himself. He is resolute in fulfilling his task, and that is all."

Moreover, birds fly high to escape the harm of arrows and nets, and field mice burrow deep beneath sacred mounds to avoid the peril of fumigation and digging—yet you are less wise than these two creatures.

Jian Wu first met Ri Zhong Shi, then Jie Yu, hence Jie Yu questioned him thus. *Jing* (经) means "constant"; *shi* (式) means "model"; *yi* (义) means "right principle in handling affairs." That the constant norms, models, and right principles issue from oneself means making oneself the model for the world. *Du ren* (度人) means "to transform men." To transform the world by modeling oneself is thus called "issuing from oneself the constant norms, models, and right principles to transform men." The phrasing of *jing shi yi* (经式义) aligns with "harmony and ease." *Du* is pronounced *du* (渡), "to cross."

"Who would dare disobey and fail to be transformed?" means the people would all heed and be transformed. "Deceptive virtue" means self-deception, not true virtue. To govern the world thus is harder than crossing the sea by digging a river or making a mosquito bear a mountain. "Digging a river" refers to dredging the Nine Rivers and the like.

"Governing externally" means transforming through the mind leaves no trace, while transforming through the body leaves traces. "Acting only after rectifying himself" means following the principles of nature and fate. "Fulfilling his task" means exhausting this natural course. *Que hu* (确乎) means "resolute"—his governance is resolutely thus. *Zhuangzi*’s thought centers on non-action, hence his teaching differs from that of the Confucians.

Birds fly high to avoid nets and arrows, and mice burrow deep to avoid fumigation and digging—this shows that those who leave traces are self-encumbered. If one cannot practice non-action and instead leaves traces, one’s ignorance is greater than that of these two creatures. The "two creatures" are the bird and the mouse. *Shen qiu* (神丘) means "sacred mound."

---

Tian Gen wandered to Yin Yang and came to the waters of Liao, where he encountered an unnamed man and asked: "May I inquire how to govern the world?"

The unnamed man said: "Begone! You are a vulgar man—why ask so inauspiciously? I am about to become a man with the Creator. When sated, I will ride the boundless bird to soar beyond the six directions and wander in the land of Nothing Whatever, dwelling in the wild expanse. Why trouble my heart with your questions of governing the world?"

He asked again, and the unnamed man said: "Let your mind wander in stillness, harmonize your qi with the vast, follow things as they are without imposing private ends—and the world will be governed."

To ask about governing the world is not the way of non-action, hence he deemed it a vulgar question and made me displeased. *Bu yu* (不豫) means "unhappy." "Becoming a man with the Creator" means dwelling in the human world while following the Creator’s spontaneity. *Yan* (厌) means "sated" or "full"—having had his fill of the human world, he would wander beyond creation. The "boundless bird" is the qi of emptiness. The "land of Nothing Whatever" and the "wild expanse" both refer to the realm of supreme emptiness. *He yi* (何帠) means "why." The annotation glosses *fa* (法) as *gu* (故), "reason."

chunks.original_text: 以治天下之问而感触予之心，所以不豫，此感字犹言激触我也。 帠字崔氏作为，亦是何故之意。 淡者，淡也。 漠，冲漠无形之地也。 气犹性也，以此心此性皆合於自然，故曰游心於淡，合气於漠。 前言无听之以心而听之以气，看此气字便合作性字说。 顺造物之自然而无容心，则天下自治矣，何必为天下乎，有心则私矣。 比天根再问而无名人又以其真实语告之，其名曰无名人，便见前后所称人名皆是子虚鸟有之类，所以后篇有寓言、重言之说。 如称黄帝、孔子、颜子、狂接舆，则是借重於其名，以实己之说。 寓言则是无名人、天根、蒲衣子之类。 阳子居见老聃曰：有人於此，向疾强梁，物彻疏明，学道不倦。 如是者可比明王乎。 老聃曰：是於圣人也，胥易技系劳形怵心者也耳也。 虎豹之文来田，猥狙之便执斄之狥来藉。 如是者可比明王乎。 阳子居蹙然曰：敢问明王#2之治。 老聃曰：明王之治，功盖天下而似不自己，化贷万物而民弗恃。 有莫举名，使物自喜，立乎不测，而游於无有者也。 有人於此，言有个人如此也。 此数句是不指名而讥侮孔子。 向疾，趋走捷疾也； 强梁，刚健也，言敏於学而能力行也。 物，事也； 彻，通也。
chunks.translated_text:
To ask about governing the world stirred my heart—this is why I was displeased. The word *gan* (感) here means "to stir" or "to provoke." The character *yi* (帠), according to Master Cui, also carries the sense of "why." *Dan* (淡) means "serene and unadorned." *Mo* (漠) refers to the formless, empty expanse. *Qi* here is akin to *xing* (性, nature)—since this mind and this nature both align with spontaneity, it is said: "Let your mind wander in serenity, harmonize your qi with the formless." Earlier, it was said, "Do not listen with the mind but listen with qi"—here, *qi* should be understood as *xing* (nature). Follow the Creator’s spontaneity without imposing the mind, and the world will govern itself. Why must one take governing the world as a task? To act with intent is to introduce private bias.

When Tian Gen asked again, the Nameless Man answered him with words of truth. That he is called the Nameless Man shows that all the names mentioned before and after—such as those of fictitious figures—are like "Zixu" or "bird-that-is-not" (empty designations). Hence, later chapters speak of "parable" and "reiterated words." When names like the Yellow Emperor, Confucius, Yan Hui, or the Madman of Chu are invoked, it is to lend weight to the author’s own teachings. The "parable" refers to figures like the Nameless Man, Tian Gen, and Master Pu Yi.

Yang Ziju asked Lao Dan: "Suppose there were a man swift and strong in action, penetrating in understanding, and tireless in learning the Dao. Could such a one be compared to an enlightened king?" Lao Dan replied: "In the eyes of the sage, such a man is but a petty functionary, bound by skill and toil, exhausting his body and startling his mind. The patterns of tigers and leopards attract hunters; the agility of monkeys and the tameness of hounds bring them to the leash. Could such a one be compared to an enlightened king?"

Yang Ziju, dismayed, asked: "Then may I inquire about the governance of an enlightened king?" Lao Dan said: "The governance of an enlightened king: his achievements cover the world yet seem not his own; his transformative influence nurtures the ten thousand things, yet the people do not rely on him. No name is raised, yet things rejoice of themselves. He stands in the unfathomable and wanders in the realm of Nothing Whatever."

"Suppose there were a man..."—these words describe a certain person without naming him, subtly mocking Confucius. *Xiang ji* (向疾) means "swift and eager"; *qiang liang* (强梁) means "unyielding and vigorous"—referring to one who learns keenly and acts with determination. *Wu* (物) means "affairs"; *che* (彻) means "penetrating."

chunks.original_text: 言事事通彻而所见虚明也。 疏，虚也。 以此而学道不倦可以比明王否，言学之为王者事，如此可否。 胥，刑徒也； 易，更也，犹言卒更也。 胥易之名必古有此语，如汉所谓鬼薪是也。 技系者，以工巧而系累技术之人也。 此二等人胥易则劳其形，技系则怵其心，言如此为学，身心俱劳是犹胥易技系而已。 怵心言其心恐恐然也。 虎豹以皮有文，故招来田猎之人。 藉，绳也，所以束缚者也。 斄合作狸，狗能执狸，与猨狙之便捷可观，皆以招来束缚之祸。 言有能必自累也。 执狸字又见天地篇。 若以有为之学可以为王者事，则是虎豹之类亦可比於明王矣。 此贬之之甚之辞也。 此三句文自奇。 功盖天下而似不自己，即功成而不有之意。 化贷万物而民弗恃，此朝野不知而帝力何加之意。 贷，施也，言施化於民也。 凡字训释亦就平仄处呼，施字便与施字同义。 天施地生，云行雨施，天施雨施此二字平仄虽殊，其义则一。 有莫举名者，言其所有，人莫得而举名之，民无得称之意。 使物自喜，言我虽无功可名，而物自得其乐，犹韩文所谓人自得於江湖之外也。 不测者，不可测识也，只是无有字。 立乎不测只是游於无有。 笔端鼓舞大率如此。 以上数段皆是说其名篇应帝王之意。 郑有神巫曰季咸，知人之死生存亡、祸福寿夭，期以岁月旬日若神。 郑人见之皆弃而走，列子见之而心醉。 归以告壶子曰：始吾以夫子之道为至矣，则又有至焉者矣。 壶子曰：吾与汝既其文，未既其实，而固得道与。 众雌而无雄，而又奚卵焉。 而以道与世亢，必信夫。 故使人得而相汝。 岁月旬日，或远或近。 神巫，相者也，其言皆验若神。 弃之而走者，畏其言之验也。 心醉者，心服也。 既其文，尽其外也，未既其实，未尽其内也。 而，汝也。
chunks.translated_text:
Those who speak of penetrating all affairs yet perceive with emptiness and clarity—*shu* (疏) means "emptiness." If one were to learn the Dao with such tirelessness, could this be compared to the governance of an enlightened king? This asks whether such learning constitutes the work of a true king.

*Xu* (胥) refers to convict laborers; *yi* (易) means "to change," akin to "taking turns in service." The term *xu yi* must have been an ancient expression, like the Han dynasty’s "ghost-firewood gatherers." *Ji xi* (技系) describes those bound by their craft and technical skills. These two types of people—those who take turns in labor and those shackled by their skills—exhaust their bodies and unsettle their minds through such learning. Their bodies toil and their hearts tremble, as if they were no more than convict laborers or craftsmen in bondage. *Chu xin* (怵心) describes a heart gripped by constant fear.

Tigers and leopards, with their patterned hides, attract hunters. *Ji* (藉) means "rope," the very thing that binds. The *li* (狸), or wildcat—along with dogs that seize them, and the agile monkeys and macaques—all invite the calamity of capture and restraint. Thus, any ability inevitably brings its own entanglement. The phrase "seizing the wildcat" also appears in the "Heaven and Earth" chapter.

If one were to govern through such active, worldly learning, then even tigers and leopards could be compared to enlightened kings—this is the harshest of rebukes. These three lines stand out for their striking phrasing.

"His achievements cover the world yet seem not his own" echoes the idea of "accomplishing without claiming." "His transformative influence nurtures the ten thousand things, yet the people do not rely on him" reflects the sentiment that "throughout the realm, none know whence it comes, nor what power the emperor wields." *Dai* (贷) means "to bestow," referring to the ruler’s transformative bestowal upon the people. The glosses for characters often follow tonal patterns—here, *dai* aligns with *shi* (施), both meaning "to grant." "Heaven bestows, earth produces; clouds move, rain is granted"—though the tones of *shi* and *dai* differ, their meaning remains the same.

"None can raise a name for what he possesses" means that no one can name his achievements, nor can the people find words to praise him. "Things rejoice of themselves" suggests that though no merit can be ascribed to him, all things find their own joy—much like Han Yu’s phrase, "people find their own contentment beyond the rivers and lakes."

"Unfathomable" means beyond comprehension, synonymous with "Nothing Whatever." "He stands in the unfathomable" is but another way of saying "he wanders in the realm of Nothing Whatever." The brush dances with such vitality throughout. These passages all expound the meaning of the "Responding to Emperors" chapter.

In Zheng there was a divine diviner named Ji Xian, who could foretell life and death, fortune and misfortune, longevity and early demise—his predictions, precise to the year, month, or day, were as if divine. The people of Zheng, upon seeing him, would flee in haste, but Liezi met him and was utterly enchanted. Returning home, he told Master Huzi: "At first, I believed your Dao was supreme, yet now I see there is something even greater."

Huzhi said: "I have shown you only its outward form, not its true substance—how then could you have grasped the Dao? A flock of hens without a rooster will never produce eggs. If you present the Dao to the world in such a manner, you will surely be believed. Thus, others can read your fortune."

Predictions of "years, months, or days" may be distant or near. A *shen wu* (神巫), or divine diviner, is one whose words prove true as if by magic. Those who "flee in haste" do so out of fear of his accuracy. "Enchanted in heart" means utterly convinced. "Having exhausted its outward form" refers to mastering only the external, while "not yet exhausted its true substance" means the inner truth remains untouched. *Er* (而) means "you."

chunks.original_text: 汝未尝尽见其实，固以为能得道乎。 固字有未得谓得之意，当以语势思之。 有雌雄而后有所生，卵，生也。 无雄又奚卵，言无心则无迹也。 此一句是喻其心未能化，故可以形见之意。 亢，高也，台以其道为高於世而欲人必信之，此便是有迹处，便是未化处，故神巫得以相汝。 尝试与来，以予示之。 明日列子与之，见壶子出而谓列子曰：嘻，子之先生死矣，弗活矣，不以旬数矣。 吾见怪焉，见湿灰焉。 列子入，泣涕沾襟，以告壶子。 壶子曰：向吾示#3之以地文，萌乎不震不正，是殆见吾杜德机也。 湿灰者，言其生气将尽如灰，已湿而欲灭也。 地文者，此犹禅家修观之名，萌乎若生而不生之意。 不震者，不动也。 不正#4者，不可指定言也。 此不正字便与孟子必有事焉而勿正同。 惟有若萌动而又不动，故神巫以为湿灰。 灰，活火也，湿灰则是活火欲灭之意。 杜德机亦是修观之名，德机，生意也，杜，闭也，闭其机而不动，故有生意欲灭之状。 季咸遂以为弗活矣。 尝又与来，明日又与之见壶子。

You have never fully witnessed its true substance—how then could you truly claim to have grasped the Way? The word *gu* (固) implies mistaking partial attainment for mastery; consider its rhetorical force. Only with both male and female does generation occur—eggs are life itself. Without the male, how could there be eggs? This means that without the heart, no trace remains. This line illustrates that your heart has not yet transformed, so it may still be perceived through form.

*Kang* (亢) means "lofty"; if you elevate the Way above the world and demand others believe it, this itself is a trace, a sign of incomplete transformation. Thus, the divine diviner could read your fortune.

"Come again and bring him to me, that I may show myself to him."

The next day, Liezi brought him to see Huzhi. As Huzhi emerged, the diviner said to Liezi: "Alas! Your master is dead—he will not live, not even for ten days. I saw something strange: I saw damp ashes."

Liezi entered, his tears soaking his lapels, and told Huzhi what had happened. Huzhi said: "Just now, I showed him the *earthly pattern*—sprouting yet neither stirring nor settling. This was nearly my *blocked virtue-mechanism*. *Damp ashes* means his vital qi is nearly spent, like embers drenched and about to die out. *Earthly pattern* is akin to the meditative terms of Chan Buddhism, suggesting the faintest stirrings of life that are not yet life. *Not stirring* means unmoving; *not settling* means it cannot be pinned down or described. This *not settling* echoes Mencius’ phrase, 'There must be action, but do not fix it.' Only when there is the semblance of movement yet no movement does the diviner perceive *damp ashes*. Ashes are living fire; damp ashes imply living fire on the verge of extinction. *Blocked virtue-mechanism* is another meditative term: *virtue-mechanism* is the impulse of life, while *blocked* means closed off and unmoving. Thus, the appearance is of life about to fade, and Jixian concluded he would not live."

"Bring him again." The next day, Liezi brought him to see Huzhi once more.

chunks.original_text: 出而谓列子曰：幸矣。 子之先生遇我也，有瘳矣，全然有生矣。 吾见其杜权矣。 列子入以告壶子。 壶子曰：尸吾示之以天壤，名实不入而机发於踵，是始见吾善者机也。 杜权，不动之动也。 权与机同，但机微而权则露矣，於杜闭之中而动机已露，故季咸以为全然有生意也。 天壤亦是观名，天田也，天上之田，非壤之壤，即自然之壤也，犹今修养家以舌间为天津，以顶上为泥丸#5之类，此是生意萌动而上之意。 名实不入，即是有无俱遣。 机发於踵，言其气自下而上，微而不可见，故曰机。 菩者机，犹言性之动处也。 尝又与来，明日又与之见壶子。 出而谓列子曰：子之先生不齐，吾无得而相焉。 试齐且复相之。 列子入以告壶子，壶子曰：吾尸示以太冲莫胜，是殆见吾衡气机也。 太冲莫胜，亦观名也。 太冲，太虚也，莫胜踵，不可捉摸也。 衡者，平也，半也，气机之动至於衡平一半之地而止，则是半动半静也。 神巫以为不齐，言其半动半静而不定也。 鲵桓之审为渊，止水之审为渊，流水之审为渊。 渊有九名，此处三焉。 鲵桓、止水、流水，皆是观名。 今佛家以为观，而古人以为渊，渊有九名，犹今观音十二观也。 审，信也。 言鲵桓信乎为一观，止水信乎为一观，流水信乎为一观。 壶子到此方说出向者所以示神巫者皆此渊也。 我有九渊而方示其三，言我之妙处犹有未尽者。 审字作蟠，非。 列子九渊之名皆全，洪野处谓列子胜於庄子，恐未为的论。 若此九渊皆说尽，则不得为奇文矣。 可尽不尽，正是庄子之奇处，精论文者方知之。 此章本有四节，就此说渊九名一项，却入第四节文章，伸缩之法也。 尝又与来，明日又与之见壶子。 立未定，自失而走，壶子曰：追之。 列子追之不及，反以报壶子曰：已灭矣，已失矣，吾弗及已。 壶子曰：向吾示之以未始出吾宗，吾与之虚而委蛇，不知其谁何。 因以为茅靡，因以为波流，故逃也。 已灭已失，言不可见也。 未始出吾宗，亦是观名。 虚，虚无也。 委蛇，顺也。 若无物，若有物，不知其如何，故曰不知其谁何也。 茅音颓，茅靡者拉扱也，波流者莽荡也。 言其看我不出，但见拉扱莽荡，故自失而走也。 然后列子自以为未始学而归，三年不出。 为其妻爨，食豕如食人，於事无与亲，雕琢复朴，块然独以其形立。 纷而封哉，一以是终。 为其妻爨，代其妻执爨於鼎灶之间而不出也。 食豕如食人，言集神於内而不见其外也。 於事无与亲者，言其虽为事而不自知，若不亲为之也。 雕琢其聪明而归复於朴，即前所谓堕枝体黜聪明也。 块然独以其形立，犹木偶人也。 封，有廉隅也，纷，多也。 其形已如木偶，安有封畛廉隅之多乎。 一以是终者，言其终身常如此也。 一，常如此之意。 无为名尸，无为谋府，无为事任，无为知主。 体尽无穷而游无眹，尽其所受乎天而无见得，亦虚而已。 至人之用心若镜，不将不迎，应而不藏，故能胜物而不伤。 庄子於此又说尽无为而为之事。 尸，主也。 不以名为主，是为善无近名也。 府，众也。 前言不慕事，不谋焉用智，即是此意。 有意於谋则是谋聚於此，可谋则谋无所用心，故曰无为谋府。 事虽不可不为，而不以事自任，故曰无为事任。
chunks.translated_text:
Liezi emerged and said to Liezi: "Fortunate indeed! Your master has met me—he is recovering, fully alive. I saw his *blocked potential*."

Liezi entered and reported this to Huzhi. Huzhi said: "I showed him *Heaven and Earth*—names and realities did not enter, yet the mechanism stirred from the heels. This was the first glimpse of my *virtuous mechanism*. *Blocked potential* is movement within stillness. *Potential* and *mechanism* are the same, but the mechanism is subtle while potential is manifest. Within the blocked closure, the dynamic mechanism was revealed, so Jixian took it as full vitality."

"*Heaven and Earth* is also a meditative term: *Heaven* is the celestial field, the field above, not the *Earth* of soil, but the natural *Earth*—akin to how modern cultivators call the space beneath the tongue *Heavenly Ford* and the top of the head *Mud Pill*. This suggests the stirrings of life rising upward. *Names and realities did not enter* means both being and non-being are transcended. *The mechanism stirred from the heels* describes qi ascending from below, so subtle it cannot be seen—hence *mechanism*. *Virtuous mechanism* refers to the movement of inherent nature."

The next day, Liezi brought him to see Huzhi again. Upon leaving, Jixian said to Liezi: "Your master is unsettled; I cannot divine him. Let him settle himself, then I will divine him again."

Liezi entered and told Huzhi, who said: "I showed him *Supreme Vacuity, Unsurpassable*—this was nearly a glimpse of my *balanced qi-mechanism*. *Supreme Vacuity, Unsurpassable* is also a meditative term: *Supreme Vacuity* is the Great Void; *Unsurpassable* means it cannot be grasped. *Balanced* means level, half—when the dynamic mechanism of qi reaches equilibrium, it is half-moving, half-still. The spirit-diviner saw him as unsettled, for he was half-moving, half-still, and thus indeterminate."

"The *coiled leviathan* confirms the abyss, the *still water* confirms the abyss, the *flowing water* confirms the abyss. The abyss has nine names—here are three. *Coiled leviathan*, *still water*, and *flowing water* are all meditative terms. Modern Buddhists use *contemplation*, but the ancients called it *abyss*—just as Guanyin has twelve contemplations, the abyss has nine names. *Confirms* means truly. The *coiled leviathan* truly forms one contemplation, *still water* truly forms one contemplation, *flowing water* truly forms one contemplation. Only now does Huzhi reveal that what he showed the spirit-diviner were all these abysses. I have nine abysses, and I have shown only three—implying my subtleties are not yet exhausted. The character *confirms* is not *coiled*."

"The *Nine Abysses* in *Liezi* are complete, and Hong Yechu claimed *Liezi* surpasses *Zhuangzi*—this is hardly a sound judgment. If all nine abysses were fully explained, it would no longer be extraordinary prose. The art of leaving some things unsaid is precisely Zhuangzi’s marvel; only those who truly understand literature recognize this. This chapter originally had four sections, but the discussion of the nine abysses is woven into the fourth, demonstrating the art of expansion and contraction."

The next day, Liezi brought him to see Huzhi again. Jixian had not yet taken his stance when he lost himself and fled. Huzhi said: "Pursue him." Liezi chased him but could not catch up. Returning, he reported to Huzhi: "He has vanished, he is gone—I could not reach him."

Huzhi said: "Earlier, I showed him *Not Yet Emerged from My Source*. I met him with emptiness and compliance, so he knew not who or what I was. Thus, he took me for *crumbling reeds*, for *drifting waves*—and so he fled. *Vanished* and *gone* mean he could no longer perceive me. *Not Yet Emerged from My Source* is also a meditative term. *Emptiness* is the void; *compliance* is yielding. As if nothing, as if something—he knew not what I was, hence *he knew not who or what*. *Crumbling reeds* suggests collapse; *drifting waves* suggest boundlessness. Seeing me as formless, he saw only collapse and boundlessness—so he lost himself and fled."

Thereafter, Liezi returned home, believing he had never truly studied. For three years he did not venture out. He cooked for his wife, fed pigs as if feeding people, and took no personal interest in affairs. He carved and polished his faculties only to return to simplicity, standing alone like an unhewn block. Amidst the clamor, he remained bounded, ending thus.

"He cooked for his wife"—he took her place at the stove and did not leave. "Fed pigs as if feeding people"—his spirit gathered inward, and he saw no distinction. "Took no personal interest in affairs"—though he acted, he was unaware, as if not personally involved. He carved and polished his brilliance only to return to simplicity—this is what was earlier called "casting off the branches of the body and dismissing cleverness." "Stood alone like an unhewn block"—like a wooden figure. *Bounded* means having edges; *clamor* means excess. If his form was like a wooden figure, how could there be excess edges? "Ending thus"—he remained so for the rest of his life. *Thus* means always thus.

"Do not be a master of fame, do not be a storehouse of schemes, do not take on tasks as your burden, do not be a host of knowledge. Embody the boundless and wander without trace, exhaust what you have received from Heaven without seeking gain—be empty, and that is all. The mind of the perfected one is like a mirror: it neither advances nor retreats, responds but does not store, and thus can master things without harm."

Zhuangzi here exhaustively describes the practice of non-action. *Master* means to preside. Not taking fame as master is to *excel without approaching fame*. *Storehouse* means multitude. Earlier, he said, "Do not admire affairs, do not scheme—what use is wisdom?" This is the same idea. If one schemes intentionally, schemes gather here, and where schemes are possible, the mind has no use for them—hence *do not be a storehouse of schemes*. Though affairs cannot be avoided, one should not take them as a personal burden—hence *do not take on tasks as your burden*.

chunks.original_text: 人虽不能无智而不以智为主，故曰无为知主，心有所主则私矣。 此四个无字是教人禁止之意，与论语四勿字同。 体，察也，见也，见道至於尽而无穷极，而心游於无物之始，故曰体尽无穷而游无眹。 眹，兆也，始也，无眹即无始也。 天之受我以是理，吾能尽之又不自以为有得，故曰尽其所受於天而无见得。 见其有得则近於迹矣。 佛经所谓依幻说觉亦复如是，便是此意。 铺说至此，以一虚字结之，此一句甚有力。 虚即自然也，无所着也。 镜之於物，妍强去来，照者自照，何尝将之，何尝迎之。 将，送也。 照形而见形，照物而见物，谓之应镜中，何尝留之，故曰应而不藏。 至人之心如此，所以於物皆无所件，故曰胜物而不伤。 天道不争而善胜，便是此胜字。 若镜数句，分明是解上面一虚字，文势起伏，岂不奇哉。 平澹之中自有神巧，此等文字也。 南海之帝为倏，北海之帝为忽，中央之帝为混沌。 倏与忽时与遇於浑沌之地，浑沌待之甚善。 倏与忽谋报浑沌之德，曰：人皆有七窍以视听食息，此独无有，尝试凿之。 日凿一窍，七日而浑沌死。 此段只言聪明能为身累，故如此形容堕肢体黜聪明则为浑沌矣。 本是平常说话，妆出日凿一窍之说，皆奇笔也。 倏、忽、浑沌皆是寓言，不可泥着，泥着则为痴人前说梦矣。 浑沌即元气也，人身皆有七窍，如赤子之初，耳目鼻舌虽具而未有知识，是浑沌之全也。 知识稍萌则有喜怒好恶，是窍凿矣。 孟子曰大人不失赤子之心，便是浑沌不凿也。 庄子翻说得来便如此诡怪，但文亦奇矣。 庄子三十二篇分为内外，内篇有七，皆以三字名之，自骈拇而下则只掇篇头两字或三字为名，如学而为政之例，其书本无精粗，内篇外篇皆是一样说话，特地如此，亦是鼓舞万世之意。 但外篇文字间有长枝大叶处，或以为内篇文精外篇文粗，不然也。 又有以七篇之名次第而说，如曰先能逍遥游而后可以齐物论，既能齐物又当自养其身，故以养生主继之，既尽养生之事而后游於世间，故以人间世继之，游於世间使人皆归向於我，故以德充符继之，内德既充而符应於外也，人师於我而我自以道为师，故以大宗师继之，既有此道则可以为帝王之师，故以应帝王继之。 虽其说亦通，但如此拘牵，无甚义理，却与易之序卦不同。 善读庄子却不在此，但看得中间文字笔势出，自无穷快活。 文字最看归结处。 如上七篇，篇篇结得别。 逍遥游之有用无用，齐物论之梦蝶物化，养生主之火传也，德充符之以坚白呜，人世间之命也夫。 自是个个有意，到七篇都尽，却妆撰倏忽浑沌一段，乃结之曰七日而浑沌死。 看他如此机轴，岂不奇特。 中庸一篇起以天命之谓性三句，结以上天之载无声无臭至矣，此亦是文字机轴，但人不如此看得破耳。 向侍先师讲春秋至西狩获麟，先师曰：及其至也，圣人有所不知，所以绝笔於此。 是夜散行西轩廊间，忽问曰：今日获麟处，看得如何。 希逸应日：以中庸圣人所不知之语断之，诸家所未有也。 但经始於王正月，终於西狩获麟，当时下面若更有一句，夫子亦必不书矣。 先师曰：如何。 希逸曰：如此归结一句，更如何添得。 先师不答而出，已夜深矣。 即叩伯已丘丈之门曰：肃翁春秋读得甚好，某与朋友读春秋许多年，未有如此见解者。
chunks.translated_text:
Though man cannot be without wisdom, he should not take wisdom as his master—hence the saying *do not make wisdom your master*. When the mind has a master, it becomes partial.

These four *no’s* serve as prohibitions, akin to the four *not’s* in the *Analects*. *To embody* means to perceive, to see. Seeing the Dao to its utmost without limit, the mind roams in the beginning of nothingness—hence *embody the boundless and wander without trace*. *Trace* means sign, beginning; *without trace* is thus *without beginning*.

Heaven endows me with this principle, and I exhaust it without claiming any gain—hence *exhaust what you receive from Heaven without seeking gain*. To see gain is to approach mere traces.

The Buddhist sutras speak of "awakening through illusion" in the same way. Having expounded thus far, he concludes with a single word: *empty*—this line carries great force. *Empty* is spontaneity, freedom from attachment.

When a mirror reflects things—beauty or ugliness, coming or going—it reflects of itself. It neither sends nor receives. *Sends* means to escort. It reflects forms and reveals forms, reflects things and reveals things—this is called *responding in the mirror*. Yet it never retains them, hence *responds but does not store*.

The mind of the perfected one is like this, so it remains unobstructed by things—hence *masters things without harm*. The Dao of Heaven does not contend yet excels at mastery—this is the meaning of *mastery*. These lines on the mirror clearly explicate the earlier *empty*. The rise and fall of the prose—is it not marvelous? Within its plainness lies divine artistry; such is this writing.

The Lord of the Southern Sea was Shu, the Lord of the Northern Sea was Hu, and the Lord of the Center was Hundun. Shu and Hu often met in Hundun’s land, and Hundun treated them very well. Shu and Hu plotted to repay Hundun’s virtue, saying: "All men have seven apertures for seeing, hearing, eating, and breathing—only he has none. Let us try boring them for him." Each day they bored one aperture, and on the seventh day, Hundun died.

This passage simply illustrates how intelligence can burden the body. Thus, to cast off limbs and reject cleverness is to become Hundun. Though told in plain speech, the tale of boring one aperture each day is a stroke of genius.

Shu, Hu, and Hundun are all allegories; one must not cling to them literally, or one becomes like a fool recounting dreams. Hundun is primordial qi. The human body has seven apertures—like a newborn infant, whose ears, eyes, nose, and tongue exist but lack knowledge; this is the wholeness of Hundun. When knowledge begins to sprout, likes and dislikes arise—this is the boring of apertures.

Mencius said, "The great man does not lose the heart of a newborn infant"—this is Hundun unborrowed. Zhuangzi’s inversion renders it so strangely, yet the writing remains extraordinary.

Zhuangzi’s thirty-two chapters are divided into Inner and Outer sections. The seven Inner Chapters are each named with three characters, while those from *Webbed Toes* onward take only the first two or three characters of the opening line as their titles, following the example of *The Analects*’ *Learning* and *Governance*. The book makes no distinction of refinement; Inner and Outer Chapters speak in the same voice, merely arranged thus to inspire future generations.

Some Outer Chapters contain passages of sprawling prose, leading some to claim the Inner Chapters are refined and the Outer Chapters coarse—this is not so. Others attempt to explain the sequence of the seven Inner Chapters, saying: first one must *Wander Freely*, then *Equalize Things*; having equalized things, one should *Nourish the Life*; after mastering life-nourishment, one may *Roam the World of Men*; roaming the world, one draws all to oneself, hence *Signs of Full Virtue*; with inner virtue full and outer signs manifest, one becomes a teacher of men, hence *The Great Ancestral Master*; possessing this Dao, one may instruct emperors and kings, hence *Responding to Emperors and Kings*.

Though this interpretation holds, such rigid adherence lacks deeper principle and differs from the *Sequence of Hexagrams* in the *Book of Changes*. The true way to read Zhuangzi lies not here, but in grasping the momentum of the text itself—then boundless delight follows.

The most crucial part of any writing is its conclusion. In the seven Inner Chapters, each ends distinctively: *Wandering Freely* with *use and uselessness*, *Equalizing Things* with *the butterfly dream and transformation of things*, *Nourishing Life* with *fire transmitted*, *Signs of Full Virtue* with *hard and white cry out*, *Roaming the World of Men* with *"it is fate!"*

Each carries its own intent, and when all seven are complete, he contrives the tale of Shu, Hu, and Hundun, concluding with *"on the seventh day, Hundun died."* Observe his mechanism—is it not singular?

The *Doctrine of the Mean* begins with *"What Heaven imparts to man is called human nature..."* and ends with *"Only the utmost of the world’s Way leaves no sound, no scent"*—this too is a textual mechanism, though few perceive it thus.

Once, while attending my late teacher’s lecture on the *Spring and Autumn Annals* at the passage *"In the western hunt, a unicorn was captured,"* my teacher said: *"When it reaches its utmost, even the sage has what he does not know—hence he ended his brush here."* That night, as we strolled along the western veranda, he suddenly asked: *"How do you see the place where the unicorn was captured?"*

Xiyi replied: *"Applying the *Doctrine of the Mean*’s line about what the sage does not know—no other school has done this."* He added: *"The *Annals* begins with *'In the first year of the king’s reign'* and ends with *'In the western hunt, a unicorn was captured.'* Had there been one more line, the Master would surely not have recorded it."*

My teacher asked: *"How so?"*

Xiyi said: *"With such a conclusion, what more could be added?"*

My teacher made no reply and left. The hour was late, so he knocked at the gate of Uncle Qiu of Boyi and said: *"Master Su’s reading of the *Spring and Autumn Annals* is excellent. I and my friends have studied it for many years, yet none have matched this insight."*

*The True Classic of Southern Florescence: Oral Exegesis*, Scroll Eleven
By Lin Xiyi of Yuanzhai

**Outer Chapters: "Webbed Toes"**

Webbed toes and supernumerary fingers arise from nature, yet exceed in virtue. Wens and hanging warts arise from form, yet exceed in nature.

Those who employ the manifold methods of benevolence and righteousness arrange them among the five viscera, yet this is not the correct alignment of the Dao and virtue.

Thus, toes webbed together are but conjoined useless flesh; fingers branched apart are but limbs of useless digits. Those who apply manifold methods to the passions of the five viscera indulge in deviant practices of benevolence and righteousness, employing manifold methods in the use of hearing and sight.

The *mǔ* is the big toe; the *zhǐ* is the finger. *Pián* means "to join"; *zhī* means "to branch." What is born together with birth is called *nature*; what all humans equally receive is called *virtue*. Webbed toes and supernumerary fingers are both afflictions. Though they arise naturally, compared to what all humans equally receive, they are excessive—*excess* meaning surplus.

The meanings of *nature* and *virtue* here differ somewhat from those of the sages and worthies.

Wens and hanging warts are also afflictions. Webbed toes and branched fingers exist from birth, whereas wens and warts arise after form has taken shape. Thus, they are said to arise from form yet exceed in nature.

*Duōfāng* means "manifold methods"; *yòng zhī* means "to employ them externally." *Liè yú wǔzàng zāi* means they do not arise from within. They are not the natural expression of the Dao, hence they are said to be "not the correct alignment of the Dao and virtue."

chunks.original_text: 告子言义外，庄子则并以化为外矣。 以仁义为淫僻而与聪明并言，皆以为非务内之学，故但见其多事。 多方犹多事也。 是故骈於明者，乱五色，淫文章，青黄黼黻之煌煌，非乎而离朱是已； 多於聪者，乱五声，淫六律，金石丝竹黄锺大吕之声，非乎而师旷是已； 枝於仁者，擢德塞性以收名声，使天下簧鼓以奉不及之法，非乎而曾史是已； 骈於辩者，囊瓦结绳窜句游心於坚白同异之间，而敝跬誉无用之言，非乎而杨墨是已。 故此皆多骈旁枝之道，非天下之至正也。 五色、文章、青黄黼黻，古者以养目，而庄子以为乱淫，故曰骈於明，即老子五色令人目盲之意。 离朱，明者也。 若以为非乎而用，明之人则以为是矣，故曰非乎而离朱是已。 多於聪意亦然，盖以礼乐为外物也。 擢，抽也； 塞，犹言茅塞也。 德性本静而强於为仁，是擢德而塞性也。 法，礼法也，不及者，人所难及也。 使人行难行之法，故曰使天下簧鼓以奉不及之法。 黄鼓，以言语簧惑鼓动之也。 以瓦而累，以绳而结，事之无益者，辩者之多言连牵不已，景累无穷而无意味，故以累瓦结绳比之。 窜定犹言修改也，修改其言句以为辩，故曰窜句游心於坚白同异之间。 敝，劳也，跬音企，蹻跂也。 其言皆无用而称誉自喜，徒自劳苦，故曰敝跬以誉无用之言。 若以为非乎，而杨墨之徒则以为是矣。 多骈旁枝，犹言余剩也。 自然之道本无多端，此皆余剩之事，非至正也。 至正者，本然之理也。 彼正正者，不失其性命之情，故合者不为骈，而枝者不为跂，长者不为有余，短者不为不足。 是故凫胫虽短，续之则忧； 鹤胫虽长，断之则悲。 故性长非所断，性短非所续，无所去忧也。 意仁义其非人情乎，彼仁义何其多忧也。 正正者，犹言自然而然也。 自然而然则不失其性命之实理，虽合而不为骈，虽枝而不为跂，虽长而不为有余，虽短而不为不足。 此数句极有味，即前所谓天下莫大於秋毫之末而泰山为小也。 跂，起也。 有所跂则不平贴，不平贴则不自在。 看他这般下字，岂苟然哉。 性长性短，言长短出於本然之性也。 长短，性所安，无忧可去也。 凫鹤之喻最佳。 意与噫同，叹也，以凫鹤二端言之，则仁义多端，非人情矣。 故叹而言之，使仁义出於自然，则不如是其多忧矣。 多忧者，言为仁义者多忧劳也。 庄子之为此言，自孔孟而上以至尧舜禹汤，皆在讥侮之数。 且夫骈於拇者决之则泣，枝於手者齕之则啼。 二者或有余於数，或不足於数，其於忧一也。 今世之仁人，蒿目而忧世之患； 不仁之人，决性命之情而饕贵富。 故意仁义其非人情乎。 自三代以下者，天下何其嚣嚣也。 手足之骈枝虽皆为病而不可强去之，去之则为忧苦矣。 枝，多一指也，故曰有余於数。 骈，合二指而不可分，故曰不足於数。 蒿目者，半闭其目也，欲闭而不闭则其睫蒙茸然，故曰蒿目。 蒿者蓬蒿之蒿也，蒿目有独坐忧愁之意。 此庄子下字处。 忧世之患而自劳，仁人也； 贪饕富贵而破坏其性情，不仁之人也。 二者皆为自苦，故并言之又叹曰，仁义非人情乎。 言如此看来，仁义信非出於本然也。 嚣嚣，嘈杂也。 三代而下，此说盛行，何其嘈杂也。 且夫待钩绳规矩而正者，是削其性也；
chunks.translated_text:
Gaozi spoke of *yi* (righteousness) as external, while Zhuangzi went further, treating even transformation as external. He regarded benevolence and righteousness as excesses and perversions, grouping them with cleverness and acuity—all as teachings that fail to focus inwardly, hence appearing merely as "manifold affairs." *Duōfāng* here means "manifold affairs."

Thus, those who are *paired in clarity* disrupt the five colors, indulge in ornate patterns, and dazzle with azure, yellow, embroidered, and brocaded splendor—is this not so? And is not Li Zhu such a one? Those *excessive in hearing* disrupt the five tones, indulge in the six pitch-pipes, and revel in the sounds of metal, stone, silk, and bamboo, of *Huangzhong* and *Dalü*—is this not so? And is not Shi Kuang such a one? Those *branched in benevolence* pluck at virtue and obstruct nature to seize fame, driving the world to clamor like reed-pipes and drums in service of unattainable laws—is this not so? And are not Zengzi and Shishi such ones? Those *paired in disputation* pile tiles and knot cords, tamper with phrases, and roam their minds amid the debates of "hard and white" or "same and different," exhausting themselves in praise of useless words—is this not so? And are not Yangzi and Mozi such ones? All these are the ways of manifold pairings and branching excesses, not the ultimate correctness of the world.

The five colors, patterns, azure, yellow, embroidery, and brocade were in ancient times meant to nurture the eyes, yet Zhuangzi saw them as disruptive and indulgent. Thus, he spoke of being *paired in clarity*, echoing Laozi’s meaning that "the five colors blind the eyes." Li Zhu was one of clarity. If one deems such things incorrect, those of keen sight would consider them right—hence, "is this not so? And is not Li Zhu such a one?" The same applies to being *excessive in hearing*, for he regarded ritual and music as external things.

*Zhuó* means "to pluck"; *sè* means "obstructed," like overgrown thatch. Virtue and nature are inherently still, yet forcing oneself to practice benevolence is to pluck at virtue and obstruct nature. *Fǎ* refers to ritual laws; "unattainable" means what people find difficult to achieve. Compelling others to follow such difficult laws is to "drive the world to clamor like reed-pipes and drums in service of unattainable laws." *Huánggǔ* describes using words to deceive and stir others. Piling tiles and knotting cords are useless acts; the excessive words of disputers drag on endlessly, like unbroken chains with no meaning—hence the comparison to piled tiles and knotted cords. *Cuàndìng* means "to revise and fix," referring to refining phrases for debate, thus "tampering with phrases and roaming the mind amid 'hard and white' or 'same and different.'" *Bì* means "toil"; *kuǐ* is pronounced *qǐ*, meaning "to stand on tiptoe." Their words are useless yet praised with self-satisfaction, laboring in vain—hence, "toiling in tiptoe praise of useless words." If one deems this incorrect, the followers of Yangzi and Mozi would consider it right.

*Duō pián páng zhī* means "manifold pairings and branching excesses." The Way of nature is fundamentally without excess, yet these are all superfluous affairs, not the ultimate correctness. Ultimate correctness is the principle of inherent nature. Those who are *truly correct* do not lose the truth of their nature and life. Thus, what is joined is not called *paired*, what is branched is not called *excessive*, what is long is not called *surplus*, and what is short is not called *insufficient*. Therefore, though the teal’s legs are short, lengthening them brings sorrow; though the crane’s legs are long, severing them brings grief. Thus, what is long by nature should not be cut, and what is short by nature should not be extended—there is no sorrow to remove.

Does this suggest benevolence and righteousness are not human nature? Why do they bring so much sorrow? *Zhèng zhèng* means "naturally so." Being naturally so does not lose the true principle of nature and life. Though joined, it is not *paired*; though branched, it is not *excessive*; though long, it is not *surplus*; though short, it is not *insufficient*. These lines are deeply meaningful, echoing the earlier idea that "nothing in the world is greater than the tip of an autumn hair, yet Mount Tai is small." *Qǐ* means "to rise." To rise is to be unbalanced, and unbalanced is to be ill at ease. Observe how precisely he chooses his words—how could it be casual?

"Long by nature" and "short by nature" mean length and shortness arise from inherent nature. Length and shortness are what nature finds comfortable—there is no sorrow to remove. The analogy of the teal and crane is most apt. *Yì* is like *āi*, an exclamation. Speaking of these two extremes, benevolence and righteousness are manifold—are they not contrary to human nature? Thus, he sighs and says: if benevolence and righteousness arose naturally, they would not bring such sorrow. "Much sorrow" refers to the toil of practicing benevolence and righteousness.

In making these remarks, Zhuangzi includes all from Confucius and Mencius back to Yao, Shun, Yu, and Tang in his ridicule. As for those with *paired toes*, severing them brings tears; those with *branched fingers*, biting them brings wails. Whether surplus in number or deficient in number, their sorrow is the same. The benevolent of today gaze with half-closed eyes, grieving over the world’s calamities; the unbenevolent sever the truth of their nature and life to glut themselves on wealth and honor. Does this not suggest benevolence and righteousness are not human nature? From the Three Dynasties onward, why has the world been so clamorous?

Though *paired toes* and *branched fingers* are both afflictions, they cannot be forcibly removed—removing them brings sorrow. *Branched* means an extra finger, hence "surplus in number." *Paired* means two fingers joined and inseparable, hence "deficient in number." *Hāomù* means half-closed eyes; to close them yet not fully close them leaves the lashes tangled—hence, *hāomù*. *Hāo* refers to mugwort; *hāomù* conveys the sense of sitting alone in sorrow. This is how Zhuangzi chooses his words. Grieving over the world’s calamities and laboring oneself is the way of the benevolent; craving wealth and honor while destroying one’s nature is the way of the unbenevolent. Both are forms of self-suffering, hence he speaks of them together and sighs: are benevolence and righteousness not human nature? Seen thus, benevolence and righteousness are truly not inherent. *Xiāoxiāo* means "clamorous." From the Three Dynasties onward, this doctrine has flourished—why is it so noisy?

Moreover, those who rely on hooks, cords, compasses, and squares to correct things are *whittling away at their nature*...

chunks.original_text: 待绳约胶漆而固者，是侵其德也。 屈折礼乐、呴俞仁义，以慰天下之心者，此失其常然也。 性，自然也； 德，自得於天也，皆非人力所为，若必得修为而后正，则是自戕贼矣。 钩绳、绳约、胶漆，皆修为之喻也。 侵削，戕贼也； 固，定也。 屈折其身以为礼乐，呴俞其言以为仁义，欲以此慰天下之心，皆是失其本然之理，故曰失其常然。 呴俞犹妪抚也。 天下有常然。 常然者，曲者不以钩，直者不以绳。 圆者不以规，方者不以矩，附离不以胶漆，约束不以纆索。 故天下诱然皆生而不知其所以生，同焉皆得而不知其所以得。 故古今不二，不可亏也。 则仁义又奚连连如胶漆纆索，而游乎道德之间为哉，使天下惑也。 常然以下数语，与合者不为骈，枝者不为跋以下意同。 曲直方圆，或附或离，或加约束，皆当出於自然而不用人力，则为正理，诱与莠同，莠然而生者，孰生之； 物之所同者，孰与之，皆自然也。 故曰不知其所生，不知其所得，古今不二者一也。 不可亏者，亘古穷今不加损也； 连连，不已也； 胶漆，自固泥也； 纆索，自拘束也。 离性以为仁义，为之不已则固泥拘束，何以游於道德之门，徒以惑天下也。 庄子与孟子同时，孟子专言化义，庄子专言道德，故其书专抑仁义而谈自然，亦有高妙处，但言语多过当。 大抵庄子之所言仁义，其字义本与孟子不同，读者当知自分别可也。 夫小惑易方，大惑易性，何以知其然邪。 自虞氏招仁义以挠天下也，天下莫不奔命於仁义，是非以仁义易其性与。 故尝试论之。 自三代以下者，天下莫不以物易其性矣，小人则以身殉利，士则以身殉名，大夫则以身殉家，圣人则以身殉天下。 故此数子者，事业不同，名声异号，其於伤性，以身为殉一也。 惑，迷也； 方，四方也。 小迷则东西南北易位矣，大惑则失天地之性矣。 借上句以形下句，招犹今人言招牌也。 立仁义之名以挠乱天下，使天下之人皆趋於仁义奔命，为其所使而奔趋也。 知仁义而不知道德，是以外物易其性也。 在小人则殉利，在君子则殉名，卿大夫则殉其家，人主则殉天下。 殉，从也，忘其身以从之曰殉。 若庄子之意，则天下国家名利均为外物也，以天下国家与名利并言，以小抑大，以下抑高，此书之中大抵如此。 数子者，指上言圣人、大夫、士、小人也。 事业名声虽不同，而其忘身伤性则一，此皆殉物之失也。 臧与谷二人相与牧羊而俱亡其羊。 问臧奚事，则挟策读书。 问谷奚事，则博塞以游。 二人者事业不同，其於亡羊均也。 伯夷死名於首阳之下，盗跖死利於东陵之上，二人者所死不同，其於残生伤性均也，奚必伯夷之是而盗跖之非乎，天下尽殉也。 彼之所殉仁义也，则俗谓之君子； 其所殉货财也，则俗谓之小人。 其殉一也，则有君子焉，有小人焉。 若其残生损性，则盗跖亦伯夷已，又‘恶取君子小人於其间哉。 博塞、读书，二事之美恶不同而亡羊则均，此喻最佳。 挟策即执卷也，投琼曰博，不投琼曰塞，琼犹今骰子也，亦曰齿，亦曰目。 塞与赛同。 伯夷、盗跖，庄子岂不知其贤否，特借此以立言，此皆是其过当处。 君子小人虽异而残生损性则一，其意主於讥君子，故借小人以形之。 是皆以小抑大，以下抑高之意也。
chunks.translated_text:
Those who rely on cords, adhesives, and lacquer to secure things are *encroaching upon their virtue*. Bending and contorting oneself for ritual and music, cooing and murmuring for benevolence and righteousness to comfort the hearts of the world—this is to *lose one’s constant nature*. Nature is the spontaneous; virtue is what one naturally attains from Heaven. Neither is the work of human effort. If one must rely on cultivation to achieve correctness, then one is *self-mutilating*. Hooks, cords, adhesives, and lacquer are all metaphors for cultivation. *Encroaching* and *whittling away* are forms of self-mutilation; *securing* means fixing. To twist one’s body for ritual and music, to soften one’s words for benevolence and righteousness, seeking thereby to comfort the hearts of the world—all this is to lose the principle of one’s original nature, hence it is called *losing one’s constant nature*. *Cooing and murmuring* are like soothing and caressing.

There is a constant nature in the world. What is constant is this: the crooked do not rely on hooks, the straight do not rely on cords, the round do not rely on compasses, the square do not rely on squares, adhesion does not rely on glue and lacquer, and restraint does not rely on ropes. Thus, the world grows enticingly, all unaware of why it grows; all attain it alike, unaware of why they attain it. Therefore, from ancient times to the present, there has been no duality—it cannot be diminished. Then why must benevolence and righteousness cling like glue, lacquer, and ropes, wandering between the Dao and virtue, only to confuse the world?

The passage from *constant nature* onward shares the same meaning as *what joins is not forced into parallelism, what branches is not made to limp*. Crooked or straight, square or round, adhering or separating, binding or restraining—all should arise from spontaneity without human effort, for that is the correct principle. *Enticingly* is like *lushly*; when things grow lushly, who causes them to grow? What all things share in common—who grants it to them? It is all spontaneous. Hence it is said: unaware of why they grow, unaware of why they attain it. *From ancient times to the present, there has been no duality* means it is one and the same. *It cannot be diminished* means it remains unchanged from ancient times to the present, without any loss. *Clinging* means unceasing; *glue and lacquer* mean self-fixation; *ropes* mean self-restraint. To depart from one’s nature for benevolence and righteousness, pursuing them without end, is to become fixed and restrained—how then can one wander through the gate of the Dao and virtue? It only confuses the world.

Zhuangzi and Mencius were contemporaries. Mencius focused on transforming through righteousness, while Zhuangzi focused on the Dao and virtue. Thus, his writings consistently suppress benevolence and righteousness while discussing spontaneity, which has its own lofty subtlety—though his language often exceeds proper bounds. Generally, when Zhuangzi speaks of benevolence and righteousness, his terminology fundamentally differs from Mencius’s. Readers should recognize and distinguish this for themselves.

How do we know that minor delusion confuses direction while major delusion alters one’s nature? Ever since the Yu clan *promoted* benevolence and righteousness to *agitate* the world, none in the world have not *rushed to serve* benevolence and righteousness—is this not using benevolence and righteousness to alter their nature? Let us examine this. From the Three Dynasties onward, none in the world have not exchanged their nature for external things. The petty man sacrifices himself for profit, the scholar sacrifices himself for fame, the grandee sacrifices himself for his family, and the sage sacrifices himself for the world. Though these several types differ in their undertakings and their reputations bear different names, in harming their nature and sacrificing themselves, they are one and the same.

*Delusion* means confusion; *direction* refers to the four directions. Minor confusion reverses east and west, south and north; major delusion loses the nature of Heaven and Earth. The upper phrase is borrowed to illustrate the lower. *Promoted* is like what people today call a *signboard*—establishing the name of benevolence and righteousness to agitate the world, causing all to rush toward benevolence and righteousness, driven to serve it. Knowing benevolence and righteousness but not knowing the Dao and virtue is to exchange one’s nature for external things. The petty man sacrifices himself for profit, the gentleman for fame, the minister for his family, and the ruler for the world. *Sacrifice* means to follow, to forget oneself in pursuit of something. In Zhuangzi’s view, the world, the state, fame, and profit are all external things. To speak of the world and the state alongside fame and profit is to belittle the great and humble the lofty—this is common throughout his work.

The *several types* refer to the sages, grandees, scholars, and petty men mentioned above. Though their undertakings and reputations differ, in forgetting themselves and harming their nature, they are the same—all are losses from sacrificing to external things.

Zang and Gu were herding sheep together when both lost their flock. Asked what Zang was doing, he was found clutching a book and reading. Asked what Gu was doing, he was found playing games of chance. Though their activities differed, in losing their sheep, they were the same. Boyi died for fame beneath Shouyang, while Robber Zhi died for profit atop Dongling. Though their deaths differed, in harming their lives and nature, they were the same. Why must Boyi be right and Robber Zhi wrong? The world is entirely given to sacrifice.

Those who sacrifice themselves for benevolence and righteousness are commonly called gentlemen; those who sacrifice themselves for wealth and property are commonly called petty men. In their sacrifice, they are the same—some are gentlemen, some are petty men. But in harming their lives and nature, Robber Zhi is no different from Boyi. Then *how can one distinguish between gentleman and petty man*?

Gaming and reading—though one is base and the other noble, in losing their sheep, they were the same. This is an excellent analogy. *Clutching a book* means holding a scroll. *Gaming* refers to casting dice; *chance* means not casting dice. Dice are like today’s *shakers*—also called *teeth* or *pips*. *Chance* is the same as *gaming*. Zhuangzi was certainly not unaware of Boyi’s and Robber Zhi’s worthiness or lack thereof; he merely used them to make his point. These are all instances of his excess. Though gentlemen and petty men differ, in harming their lives and nature, they are the same. His aim was to criticize gentlemen, so he used petty men to illustrate them. This is another example of belittling the great and humbling the lofty.

chunks.original_text: 且夫属其性乎仁义者，虽通如曾史，非吾所谓臧也； 属其性於五味，虽通如俞儿，非吾所谓臧也； 属其性乎五声，虽通如师旷，非吾所谓聪也； 属其性乎五色，虽通如离朱，非吾所谓明也。 吾所谓臧非仁义之谓也，臧於其德而已矣。 吾所谓臧者，非所谓仁义之谓也，任其性命之情而已矣。 吾所谓聪者，非谓其闻彼也，自闻而已矣。 吾所谓明者，俳谓其见彼也，自见而已矣。 夫不自见而见彼，不自得而得彼者，是得人之得而不自得其得者也，适人之适而不自适其适者也。 夫适人之适而不自适其适，虽盗跖与伯夷是同为淫僻也。 余愧乎道德，是以上不敢为仁义之操，而下不敢为淫僻之行也。 属性，犹言留意也。 曾，曾子也，讳参。 史，子鱼也，名鳅。 以俞儿、师旷、离朱而比曾史，亦是以下抑高之意。 臧，善也。 言虽如此，非吾所善也。 善於其德，任其性命之情，即顺自然也。 此数语之中，如所谓聪者非谓其闻彼也，自闻而已矣； 所谓明者非谓其见彼也，自见而已矣，一大藏经不过此意，安得此语。 若此等语，皆其独到不可及处。 这一彼字不是轻可下得，禅家所谓狂犬逐块，所谓幻花又生幻果，便是这个彼字。 自得其得、自适其适，即自见自悟也，大抵分别本心与外物耳。 不得其本心而驰惊於外，则皆为淫僻矣。 自闻自见若在吾书，即论语所谓默而识之； 易所谓默而成之，不言而信； 孟子所谓施於四体，不言而喻，伊川春秋传序曰优游涵泳，默识心通，皆是此意，但说得平易尔。 晦黄惩象山之学，谓江西学者皆扬眉瞬目，自说悟道，深诋而力辟之，故论语集解以识音志曰，默而记之尔。 孟子不言而喻，亦曰不待人言而自喻，不肯说到顿悟处，盖有所惩而然，非语孟二书之本旨也。 若以伊川默识心通之语观之，岂得音志乎。 然学道者若用功之时。 常有等待通悟之心，比尤不可。 所谓执迷待悟，则隔须弥山矣，顿渐自有二机，不可谓有渐而无顿，亦不必人人皆自顿悟得之。 仲弓之持敬渐，颜子之克己复礼，顿也。 不然何以曰，一日克己复礼，天下归仁焉。 仁何物也，一日而得之，非顿悟而何。 看此数语，先提起一句曰克己复礼为仁，乃曰一日克己复礼，天下归仁焉，又曰为仁由己，由人乎哉。 语势起伏，便与禅家答话一同，子细吟玩，方见其味。 颜子既於言下领略，乃曰请问其目，此即禅家所谓如何保任之时，四非四勿便是尽心、知性、知天。 之下继以存心、养性、事天、修身、俟命之事也，其曰为仁由己，即禅家所谓此事别人着力不得也。 先师尝曰佛书最好证吾书，证则易晓也。 上不敢为仁义之操，是为善无近名也； 下不敢为淫僻之行，是为恶无近刑也。 道德，自然也，余恐有愧於道德，虽不为近刑之事，亦不为近名之事，近名则非自然矣，故曰余愧乎道德，是以上不敢为仁义之操，而下不敢为淫僻之行也。 观庄子此语，何尝不正心修身，其戏侮尧舜、夫子、曾史、伯夷，初非实论，特鼓舞其笔端而已。 塘东刘叔平向作庄骚同工异曲论曰：庄周愤悱之雄也。 乐轩先生甚取此语，看来庄子亦是愤世疾邪，而后着此书。 其见既高，其笔又奇，所以有过当处。 太史公谓其善属书离辞，指事类情，用剽剥儒墨，虽当世宿学不能自解免#1也。
chunks.translated_text:
Moreover, those who bind their nature to benevolence and righteousness—though as accomplished as Zengzi and Master Shi*—are not what I call *good*. Those who bind their nature to the five flavors—though as accomplished as Yu’er—are not what I call *good*. Those who bind their nature to the five sounds—though as accomplished as Music Master Kuang—are not what I call *keen*. Those who bind their nature to the five colors—though as accomplished as Li Zhu—are not what I call *clear-sighted*.

What I call *good* does not refer to benevolence and righteousness; it is goodness in one’s *power* alone. What I call *good* does not mean benevolence and righteousness; it is simply following the natural tendencies of one’s nature and fate. What I call *keen* is not hearing *that* but hearing *oneself* alone. What I call *clear-sighted* is not seeing *that* but seeing *oneself* alone.

For those who do not see themselves but see *that*, who do not attain themselves but attain *that*—they attain others’ attainments and do not attain their own, they follow others’ paths and do not follow their own. Those who follow others’ paths and do not follow their own, though they be Robber Zhi or Boyi, are equally excessive and perverse.

I am ashamed before the Dao and its *power*, and so above, I dare not practice the conduct of benevolence and righteousness, and below, I dare not engage in excessive and perverse actions.

*Binding one’s nature* means fixing one’s attention. *Zeng* refers to Zengzi, whose given name was Shen. *Shi* refers to Ziyu, whose given name was Qiu. Comparing Yu’er, Music Master Kuang, and Li Zhu to Zengzi and Master Shi is another instance of belittling the great and humbling the lofty. *Good* means excellence. Though they may be so, they are not what I consider excellent. Excellence in one’s *power*, following the natural tendencies of one’s nature and fate, is simply aligning with spontaneity.

Within these few lines—such as “what I call *keen* is not hearing *that* but hearing *oneself* alone,” and “what I call *clear-sighted* is not seeing *that* but seeing *oneself* alone”—lies the entire essence of the great canon. How could such words be casually uttered? Such expressions are uniquely profound and unmatched.

This word *that* cannot be lightly used. It is what Chan Buddhists call “a mad dog chasing a clod,” or “an illusory flower bearing an illusory fruit.” *Attaining one’s own attainment* and *following one’s own path* mean seeing and awakening to oneself. Generally, it is a matter of distinguishing between one’s original mind and external things. If one loses one’s original mind and chases after externals, all becomes excessive and perverse.

*Hearing oneself* and *seeing oneself*—if this were in my book—would be like the *Analects* saying “silently record it,” or the *Book of Changes* saying “silently complete it, without words yet trusted,” or Mencius saying “manifested in the four limbs, without words yet understood.” In the *Chunqiu Zhuan* preface by Master Yi Chuan, it says “leisurely immersion, silent recognition, and heart’s understanding”—all express this idea, though in plainer terms.

Huang Hui criticized Lu Xiangshan’s learning, saying that Jiangxi scholars all raised their brows and rolled their eyes, claiming enlightenment, which he vehemently condemned and refuted. Thus, in the *Collected Explanations of the Analects*, he glossed *record* (*zhi*) as “silently remembering it.” Mencius’ “without words yet understood” he also interpreted as “not needing others’ words to understand,” refusing to speak of sudden awakening. This was due to his cautionary stance, not the original intent of the *Mengzi* or *Analects*. Yet if we consider Master Yi Chuan’s words “silent recognition and heart’s understanding,” how could *zhi* mean merely “remembering”?

Still, for those who study the Dao, if during their practice they constantly harbor a mind waiting for enlightenment, it is even more impermissible. As the saying goes, “clinging to delusion while awaiting awakening is like being separated by Mount Sumeru.” Sudden and gradual awakening each have their own mechanism; one cannot say there is gradual but no sudden, nor must everyone attain it through sudden awakening.

Zhonggong’s *holding reverence* is gradual, while Yanzi’s *overcoming the self and returning to ritual* is sudden. Otherwise, why would it say, “In one day, overcome the self and return to ritual, and all under heaven will turn toward *ren*?” What is *ren*? To attain it in a single day—what is this if not sudden awakening?

Observe these lines: first, it raises the point that “overcoming the self and returning to ritual is *ren*,” then says, “In one day, overcome the self and return to ritual, and all under heaven will turn toward *ren*.” It further says, “*Ren* is from oneself—does it come from others?” The rising and falling cadence of the phrasing is just like Chan Buddhist dialogues. Only through careful reflection can one taste its flavor.

Once Yanzi grasped it in the words, he asked, “May I inquire about its details?” This is like the Chan saying, “How does one preserve and apply it?” The *Four Negations* and *Four Abstentions* are the means to *fully realize the mind, know one’s nature, and know Heaven*. What follows—*preserving the mind, nourishing one’s nature, serving Heaven, cultivating the self, and awaiting fate*—are the subsequent tasks. The statement “*Ren* is from oneself” is like the Chan saying, “In this matter, no one else can exert effort for you.”

Our late teacher once said, “Buddhist texts best verify our own; verification makes them easier to understand.”

Above, I dare not practice the conduct of benevolence and righteousness—this is *doing good without approaching fame*. Below, I dare not engage in excessive and perverse actions—this is *doing evil without approaching punishment*. *Dao and its power* mean spontaneity. I fear falling short of the Dao and its *power*, so though I do not engage in acts that approach punishment, I also do not engage in acts that approach fame. Approaching fame is not spontaneity. Thus, I say, “I am ashamed before the Dao and its *power*, and so above, I dare not practice the conduct of benevolence and righteousness, and below, I dare not engage in excessive and perverse actions.”

Observing Zhuangzi’s words here, how could he not be *rectifying the mind and cultivating the self*? His mockery of Yao, Shun, Confucius, Zengzi, Master Shi, and Boyi was never meant literally; it was merely the flourish of his brush.

Liu Shuping of Tangdong once wrote an essay titled *Zhuangzi and Lisao: Different Tunes from the Same Workshop*, saying, “Zhuang Zhou was a hero of pent-up indignation.” Master Lexuan greatly admired this phrase. It seems Zhuangzi, too, was indignant at a corrupt world before writing this book. His vision was lofty, his brush extraordinary—hence his excesses.

Sima Qian said of him: “He was skilled at weaving words and separating phrases, pointing to things and matching emotions, using them to strip away the Confucians and Mohists. Even the most learned scholars of his time could not escape his critique.”

chunks.original_text: 其言洸洋上音汪，下音羊，自恣以适己，此数句真道着庄子。 外篇马蹄 马蹄可以践霜雪，毛可以御风寒，齕草饮水，翘足而陆，此马之真性也。 虽有义许宜反台路寝，无所用之。 及至伯乐曰：我善治马。 烧之剔之，刻之雒之，连之以羁絷，丁邑丁立二反编之以皂栈，马之死者十二三矣。 饥之渴之，驰之骤之，整之齐之，前有橛饰之患而后有鞭策之威，而马之死者已过半矣。 此段言外物能为身累之意。 翘足而陆者，凡马立时其蹄必有跂起者也，此是下句处。 义台路寝即是王者之宫室，羲者养也，居移气养移体之地，必当时有此二字。 烧剔，治马蹄也； 刻，削也，亦削其蹄也，雒之，笼络也； 羁，络其头也； 絷，绊其足也，今所谓前秋后秋； 也连，列之也。 皂栈，槽枥也，众马列於其间也，整齐排布行列也。 橛，御也； 饰，镳缨在颔下，故曰前者橛饰之患。
chunks.translated_text:
The words flow vast and resonant—above like the deep tones of the ocean, below like the bleating of sheep—unrestrained and self-indulgent, perfectly capturing Zhuangzi’s spirit. In the "Horse’s Hooves" chapter of the *Outer Chapters*:

A horse’s hooves can tread upon frost and snow; its coat can shield against wind and cold. It grazes on grass and drinks from streams, lifting its hooves to gallop across the land—this is the true nature of the horse. Even if provided with grand halls and towering chambers, they would be of no use to it.

Yet when Bo Le declared, “I excel at managing horses,” he burned their hooves, trimmed their hair, notched their flesh, and bound them with halters. He tethered them with reins and hobbles, arranging them in rows within the stable, and already two or three out of ten horses perished. He starved and parched them, drove them to exhaustion, forced them into order and uniformity. Before them lay the torment of bits and bridles, behind them the threat of whips and spurs—by then, more than half the horses had died.

This passage speaks to how external things can burden the body.

“Lifting its hooves to gallop” refers to how a horse, when standing, will often raise one hoof—this is the meaning of the phrase below.

“Grand halls and towering chambers” refer to the palaces of kings. The character *yi* (義) here means “to nourish,” as in the saying, “Dwelling transforms the *qi*; nourishment transforms the body”—this must have been the original meaning of these two characters.

“Burning and trimming” refers to treating the horse’s hooves; “notching” means cutting, also applied to the hooves. “Binding” means restraining with halters. *Ji* (羈) refers to the headstall, while *zhi* (絷) means hobbling the feet—what is now called the “front and rear fetters.” “Arranging” means lining them up in order. The “stable” is the feeding trough, where horses are aligned in rows. “Order and uniformity” describe their disciplined formation. *Jue* (橛) refers to the bit, while “ornaments” are the reins and tassels beneath the jaw—hence the phrase, “the torment of bits and bridles before them.”

chunks.original_text: 马制於人而不得自乐其乐，所以死者多矣，即元龟与其曳尾於泥中意同。 但其间下数个之字，与前言二三，后言过半，文字华密如美锦然，古今多少笔法，自此萌芽而出。 或曰外篇文粗，误矣。 陶者曰：我善治埴，圆者中规，方者中矩。 匠人曰：我善治木，曲者中钩，直者应绳。 夫埴木之性，岂欲中规矩钩绳哉。 然且世世称之曰，伯乐善治马，而陶匠善治埴木，此亦治天下者之过也。 陶，泥匠也； 匠，木作也。 泥之与木皆人造#2之而成器，亦犹马之被烧剔 刻雒，驰骤整#3荠也，岂不失土木之性。 人皆以伯乐陶匠#4为能，亦犹泰氏而下以治天下为能也。 即#5前篇七义非人情之意，此三数行之文乃意不过如此，但文字精好。 吾意善治天下者不然。 彼民有常性， 织而衣，耕而食，是谓同德。 一而不党，命曰天放。 故至德之世，其行填填，其视颠颠。 当是时也，山无蹊隧，泽无舟梁，万物群生，连属其乡，禽兽成群，草木遂长。 是故禽兽可系羁而游，鸟鹊之巢可攀援而窥。 夫至德之世，同与禽兽居，族与万物并，恶乎知君子小人哉。 同乎无知，其德不离； 同乎无欲，是谓素朴，素朴而民性得矣。 同德者，得之於天者同然也。 人之生也各业其生，或耕或织，皆是自然天机，故曰常性，常性者，即前篇所谓常然也。 党，偏也，倚也，纯一而无所偏倚，放肆自乐於自然之中，故曰一而不党，命曰天放。 命曰犹言谓之也。 齐物论之天行、天钧、天游与此天放，皆是庄子做此名字，以形容自然之乐。 至德之世，言上古也； 填填，满足之貌；
chunks.translated_text:
The horse is controlled by man and cannot delight in its own joy—this is why so many perish. This is akin to the great tortoise dragging its tail through the mud. Yet within these lines, the repeated use of *zhi* (之) and the phrasing of “two or three” before and “more than half” after create a texture as rich and dense as fine brocade. From this, countless brushwork techniques of past and present have sprouted.

Some say the “Outer Chapters” are crude in style—this is mistaken. The potter declares: “I excel at working clay; what is round aligns with the compass, what is square with the carpenter’s square.” The craftsman says: “I excel at working wood; what is curved fits the hook, what is straight follows the marking line.” Yet do clay and wood by nature desire to conform to compass, square, hook, and line? Still, generation after generation, people praise Bo Le for his skill in training horses and potters and carpenters for their mastery of clay and wood—this is the error of those who govern the world.

The potter works with clay; the craftsman with wood. Both clay and wood are shaped by human hands into vessels, just as horses endure burning, trimming, notching, and binding, forced to gallop in disciplined ranks—do they not lose the natural essence of earth and wood? People regard Bo Le and the potter-craftsman as capable, just as those from the time of Tai onward consider governing the world a skill.

Thus, the seven principles in the previous section run counter to human nature, and these few lines convey no deeper meaning—only the writing is refined. Yet in my view, one who truly governs the world well does not act thus. The people possess an inherent nature: they weave to clothe themselves and till to feed themselves—this is called shared virtue. Unified yet impartial, this is called “Heaven’s release.”

In the age of perfect virtue, their movements are unhurried, their gazes serene. At that time, mountains had no paths or tunnels, marshes no boats or bridges. All things flourished in their kind, bound to their native lands. Birds and beasts gathered in herds, grasses and trees grew unchecked. Thus, one could lead beasts by halters and wander freely, or climb to peer into the nests of crows and magpies.

In the age of perfect virtue, humans dwelled alongside birds and beasts, mingled with the myriad things—how could one distinguish noble from base? Alike in ignorance, their virtue remained unbroken; alike in desirelessness, this was called “pristine simplicity.” In pristine simplicity, the people’s nature was preserved.

Those of shared virtue receive it alike from Heaven. As humans live, each pursues their livelihood—some till, some weave—all according to the natural mechanism of Heaven. This is called “inherent nature,” the “constant thusness” spoken of earlier. *Dang* (党) means bias or partiality; pure and undivided, without favor or leaning, they roamed freely in the joy of nature—hence “unified yet impartial,” called “Heaven’s release.” *Ming yue* (命曰) means “is called.”

The “Heaven’s course,” “Heaven’s balance,” and “Heaven’s wandering” in the *Qi Wu Lun* are all names coined by Zhuangzi to depict the joy of nature. The “age of perfect virtue” refers to high antiquity. *Tian tian* (填填) describes a state of contentment.

chunks.original_text: 颠颠，直视之貌，形容其人朴拙无心之意，又就其卧徐徐，其觉于于应帝王中，翻出此语。 山无蹊隧，路未通也； 泽无舟梁，水路未通也。 人各随其乡而居，自为连属一乡之中，自有长幼上下相连属也。 禽兽群居，深山去人尚远，无害之者； 草木各遂其生长，未有斧斤之祸也。 羁系禽兽而游，攀引鹊巢而窥，人与物相忘也。 东坡杂说，有少时所居书室，鸟雀巢於低枝，桐花凤四五日一至，颇与此处相似，见诗集二十八卷异鹊诗注。 以此观之，上古之时必是如此。 禽兽可与同居，万物可与同聚，又安有君子小人之分。 族，聚也； 并，同也。 无知，不识不知也； 无欲，纯乎天理也。 举世皆然故，曰同乎无欲。 不离，浑全也。 素朴，纯质也。 当此之时，各得其自然之乐，故曰素朴而民性得矣。 其德不离，是谓素朴，两句相因，而下句只用素朴二字接过，古文法也。 今人之文更无此等法度。 及至圣人毙躠上步结反，下悉结反为仁，踶跂为义，而天下始疑矣。 澶漫为乐，摘僻为礼，而天下始分矣。 故纯朴不残，孰为牺樽； 白玉不毁，孰为珪璋； 道德不废，安取仁义； 性情不离，安用礼乐； 五色不乱，孰为文采； 五声不乱，孰为六律。 夫残朴以为器，工匠之罪也。 毁道德以为仁义，圣人之过也。 前言及至伯乐，此言及至圣人，以下段应上段也。 蹩躠，勉强而行之貌，踶跂，行立不安之貌。 澶漫即汗漫也，流荡之意。 摘僻，用手足之貌，僻合作擗，向音躠是也。 此又是自屈折礼乐徇俞仁义中翻出，言虽不经，其文亦奇。 始分者，言其心迹始分矣，分则不纯一矣，如此分字皆是下得好处。 樽，刻木而为之，故曰纯朴不残，孰为牺樽，玉，不琢不成器，故曰白玉不毁，孰为珪璋。 道德，自然也，庄子以仁义为外，故曰道德不废，安取七义。 性情，固有也，庄子以礼乐为强世，故曰性情不离，安用礼乐。 若孟子曰节文斯二者，乐斯二者，圣贤之言也。 此书礼乐仁义字义不同，并以为外物矣。 文采乱五色，六律乱五声，皆是用人力非自然之喻。 工匠之罪，圣人之过两句，此上文结语也。 夫马陆居则食草饮水，喜则交颈相靡，怒则分背相踶，马知已此矣。 夫加之以衡扼，齐之以月题，而马知介倪、闉扼、鸷曼、诡衔、窃辔。 故马之知而能至盗者，伯乐之罪也。 夫赫胥氏之时，民居不知所为，行不知所之，含哺而熙，鼓腹而游，民能已此矣。 及至圣人屈折礼乐，以匡天下之形，县跂仁义，以慰天下之心，而民乃始踶跂好知，争归於利不可止也。 此亦圣人之过也。 此一段又是把前头许多说话翻做数行，中间添得几句，愈是奇特。 喜则交颈相靡，怒则分背相踶，分明是一个画马图也。 相靡，相摩擦也，看他交颈分背字下得如何。 衡扼，车上之物，扼，辀也。 月题，今所谓额镜也。 介倪，介独也，独立而睥睨，怒之状也。 闉扼，曲颈而扼拒也，不受衔络之意。 鸷，猛也，曼，突也，不受羁勒而相抵突之状。 诡，设计也，窃，潜地也，诡计以入衔，潜窃以加辔，皆是悍騺不受调服，故衔辔之时，如此费计较也。 与人抗敌者曰盗，马之知至於抗敌人，伯乐使之也。 若无衡扼衔辔之事，则马自马，人自人，岂见其介倪闉扼之态哉。
chunks.translated_text:
"Dian dian" (颠颠) describes a fixed, unwavering gaze, portraying a person’s artless simplicity and absence of guile. This phrase is later echoed in *Ying Di Wang* (应帝王), where it depicts one who lies at ease and awakens unhurriedly.

Mountains had no paths or tunnels—routes were yet unopened. Marshes had no boats or bridges—waterways were yet uncrossed. People dwelled where they were born, forming natural bonds within their villages, with elders and juniors, superiors and inferiors linked in order. Beasts roamed in herds, deep in mountains far from human harm. Plants grew freely, untouched by axes. Men wandered with tethered creatures, climbed to peer into magpie nests—human and thing forgot one another.

Su Dongpo’s *Miscellaneous Notes* records his childhood home, where birds nested on low branches, and phoenixes visited the parasol trees every four or five days—a scene much like this, as noted in his *Collected Poems* (Volume 28, *Poem on the Strange Magpie*). From this, we see that high antiquity must have been thus: beasts could dwell alongside men, all things could gather together—where then was the division between noble and base?

*Zu* (族) means "gather"; *bing* (并), "together." *Wu zhi* (无知) means "unaware, unknowing"; *wu yu* (无欲), "pure in Heaven’s principle." The whole world was thus, hence "aligned in desirelessness." *Bu li* (不离) means "undivided, whole." *Su pu* (素朴) means "pure essence." In that time, each found joy in nature’s spontaneity—thus "in pure essence, the people’s nature was preserved."

That their virtue remained undivided is called "pure essence." These two phrases are interlinked, with the latter condensing the idea into "pure essence"—a technique of ancient prose. Modern writing lacks such artistry.

Yet when the sage strained and stumbled in pursuit of *ren* (仁, benevolence), stretched and strained for *yi* (义, righteousness), the world first grew doubtful. When boundless indulgence became "joy," and contorted postures became "ritual," the world first divided. Thus, if pure simplicity remained uncarved, who would fashion sacrificial vessels? If white jade remained uncut, who would shape ceremonial tablets? If the Dao and virtue remained intact, why seek benevolence and righteousness? If nature and feeling remained undisturbed, why impose ritual and music? If the five colors were not disordered, who would create patterned designs? If the five tones were not confused, who would devise the six pitch-pipes?

To carve simplicity into implements is the craftsman’s crime. To fracture the Dao and virtue into benevolence and righteousness is the sage’s error. Earlier, the text spoke of Bo Le; here, it speaks of the sage—this section responds to the prior one.

*Bie sa* (蹩躠) describes forced, halting movement; *di qi* (踶跂), restless standing or walking. *Chan man* (澶漫) means "boundless, drifting." *Zhai pi* (摘僻) depicts the use of hands and feet—*pi* (僻) is here pronounced like *sa* (躠). This passage unfolds from the contortions of ritual and music, the subservience to benevolence and righteousness—though the phrasing is unconventional, its style is striking. "First divided" means hearts and traces first diverged; once divided, purity was lost. Such uses of "divided" are particularly well-placed.

Vessels are carved from wood—hence, "if pure simplicity remained uncarved, who would fashion sacrificial vessels?" Jade must be cut to be shaped—hence, "if white jade remained uncut, who would shape ceremonial tablets?" The Dao and virtue are natural—Zhuangzi treats benevolence and righteousness as external, thus "if the Dao and virtue remained intact, why seek benevolence and righteousness?" Nature and feeling are innate—Zhuangzi sees ritual and music as forced upon the world, thus "if nature and feeling remained undisturbed, why impose ritual and music?" Mencius spoke of "ordering and adorning these two," of "delighting in these two"—such are the words of sages and worthies. In this text, the meanings of "ritual," "music," "benevolence," and "righteousness" differ, all deemed external things.

Patterned designs disorder the five colors; the six pitch-pipes confuse the five tones—both are metaphors for human artifice overriding nature. "The craftsman’s crime, the sage’s error"—these are the concluding lines of the preceding passage.

Horses, when left to themselves, graze on grass and drink water. When pleased, they nuzzle necks together; when angered, they turn backs and kick—this is all the horse knows. Yet when yokes and crossbars are fitted, when forehead plates are strapped on, horses learn to glare defiantly, twist their necks in resistance, rear fiercely, evade the bit, and steal the reins. Thus, the horse’s cunning and capacity for theft arise from Bo Le’s doing.

In the age of the赫胥氏, people dwelled without purpose, wandered without destination, played with food in their mouths, and roamed with bellies full—this was all they knew. But when the sage bent and twisted ritual and music to shape the world’s form, dangled benevolence and righteousness to soothe the world’s heart, the people first began to strain and strive for knowledge, to vie for profit without cease. This, too, is the sage’s error.

This passage condenses the earlier discourse into a few lines, adding several phrases—its strangeness only deepens. "When pleased, they nuzzle necks together; when angered, they turn backs and kick"—it is as vivid as a painted horse. *Xiang mi* (相靡) means "to rub against one another"; note how "nuzzle necks" and "turn backs" are rendered. *Heng e* (衡扼) refers to chariot fittings; *e* (扼) is the shaft. *Yue ti* (月题) is what we now call a forehead mirror. *Jie ni* (介倪) means "aloof, defiant"—standing alone, glaring in anger. *Yin e* (闉扼) means "to curve the neck and resist," refusing the bit and bridle. *Zhi* (鸷) means "fierce"; *man* (曼), "to charge"—the posture of resisting restraint and clashing headlong. *Gui* (诡) means "to scheme"; *qie* (窃), "to steal"—devising tricks to take the bit, stealthily applying the reins, all signs of a stubborn, untamed horse. Thus, when the bit and reins are applied, such cunning is required.

To "steal" is to oppose one’s master—when a horse’s cunning reaches the point of opposing man, it is Bo Le’s doing. Without yokes, crossbars, bits, or reins, horses would remain horses, men would remain men—where would one see their defiant, resistant postures?

When the people can cease from this, it means that the people’s conduct is limited to such behavior. *Kuang* (匡) means "to correct"—using ritual and music to rectify human form, employing benevolence and righteousness to console human hearts—all of which arise only after the sages have acted; in high antiquity, none of this existed. *Xianqi* (县跂) means "to raise high and lift up"; *diqi* (踶跂) means "to be ill at ease." The love of knowledge and contention over profit resemble a horse’s scheming to take the bit and stealthily applying the reins.

The Inner and Outer Chapters resemble the *Zuo Tradition* and *Discourses of the States*, all from a single hand—having completed the *Zuo Tradition*, the *Discourses of the States* were then composed, though their style differs from the *Zuo Tradition*. This chapter of the *Zhuangzi* is one such instance of expansive, luxuriant prose, and for this reason some have doubted it was written by Zhuangzi, but this is not the case.

*Southern Florescence True Scripture, Proper Meaning*, Scroll Eleven, concluded.
