chunks.original_text: 杂篇盗跖 孔子与柳下季为友，柳下季之弟名曰盗跖。 盗跖从卒九千人，横行天下，侵暴诸侯。 穴室枢户，驱人牛马，取人妇女。 贪得忘亲，不顾父母兄弟，不祭先祖。 所过之邑，大国守城，小国入保，万民苦之。 孔子谓柳下季曰：夫为人父者必能诏其子，为人兄者必能教其弟。 若父不能诏其子，兄不能教其弟，则无贵父子兄弟之亲矣。 今先生世之才士也，弟为盗跖，为天下害而弗能教也，丘窃为先生羞之。 丘请为先生往说之。 柳下季日：先生言为人父者必能诏其子，为人兄者必能教其弟。 若子不听父之诏，弟不受兄之教，虽今先生之辩，将奈之何哉。 且跖之为人也，心如涌泉，意如飘风，强足以距敌，辩足以饰非。 顺其心则喜，逆其心则怒，易辱人以言。 先生必无往。 孔子不听，颜回为驭，子贡为右，往见盗跖。 盗跖乃方休卒徒太山之阳，脍人肝而餔之。 孔子下车而前见谒者曰：鲁人孔丘闻将军高义，敬再拜谒者。 谒者入，通盗跖。 闻之大怒，目如明星，发上指冠，曰：此夫鲁国之巧伪人孔丘非邪。 为我告之。 尔作言造语，妄称文武，冠枝木之冠，带死牛之胁，多辞谬说，不耕而食，不织而衣，摇唇鼓舌，擅生是非，以迷天下之主。 使天下学士不反其本，妄作孝悌，而徽幸於封侯富贵者也。 子之罪大极重，疾走归。 不然，我将以子肝益昼餔之膳。 孔子复通曰：丘得幸於季，愿望履幕下。 谒者复通，盗跖曰：使来前。 孔子趋而进，避席反走，再拜盗跖。 盗跖大怒，两展其足，案剑瞋目，声如乳虎，曰：丘来前。 若所言顺吾意则生，逆吾心则死。 孔子曰：丘闻之，凡天下有三德。 生而长大，美好无双，少长贵贱见而皆说之，此上德也； 知维天地，能辩诸物，此中德也； 勇悍果敢，聚众率兵，此下德也。 凡人有此一德者，足以南面称孤矣。 今将军兼此三者，身长八尺二寸，面目有光，唇如激丹，齿如齐贝，音中黄锺，而名曰盗跖。 丘窃为将军耻不取焉。 将军有意听臣，臣请南使吴越，北使齐鲁，东使宋卫，西使晋楚。 使为将军造大城数百里，立数十万户之邑，尊将军为诸侯。 与天下更始，罢兵休卒，收养昆弟，共祭先祖，此圣人才士之行而天下之愿也。 盗跖大怒曰：丘，来前。 夫可规以利而可谏以言者，皆愚陋常民之谓耳。 今长大美好，人见而悦之者，此吾父母之遗德也。 丘虽不吾誉，吾独不自知邪。 且吾闻之好面誉人者，亦好背而毁之，今丘告我以大城众民，是欲规我以利而恒民畜我也，安可长久也。 城之大者莫大乎天下矣。 尧舜有天下，子孙无置锥之地； 汤武立为天子，而后世绝灭。 非以其利大故邪。 且吾闻之，古者禽兽多而人民少，於是民皆巢居以避之，昼拾橡栗，暮栖木上，故命之曰有巢氏之民。 古者民不知衣服，夏多积薪，冬则炀之，故命之曰知生之民。 神农之世，卧则居居，起则于于，民知其母不知其父，与麋鹿共处。 耕而食，织而衣，无有相害之心。 此至德之隆也。 然而黄帝不能致德，与蚩尤战於涿鹿之野，流血百里。 尧舜作，立群臣，汤放其主，武王杀纣。 自是之后，以强凌弱，以众暴寡，汤武以来皆乱人之徒也。 今子修文武之道，掌天下之辩以教后世，缝衣浅带，矫言伪行以迷惑天下之主而欲求富贵焉。
chunks.translated_text:
**Miscellaneous Chapters: Robber Zhi**

Confucius was a friend of Liuxia Ji, whose younger brother was named Robber Zhi. Robber Zhi commanded nine thousand followers, rampaging across the world and oppressing the feudal lords. He broke into chambers and forced open doors, driving off people’s oxen and horses, and seizing their wives and daughters. Greedy and forgetful of kinship, he paid no heed to parents or brothers and did not offer sacrifices to his ancestors. Wherever he passed, great states fortified their cities, small states took refuge in their strongholds, and the common people suffered greatly.

Confucius said to Liuxia Ji: "As a father, one must instruct one’s son; as an elder brother, one must teach one’s younger brother. If a father cannot instruct his son, or an elder brother cannot teach his younger brother, then the bond of father and son, elder and younger brother, is of no worth. Now, sir, you are a man of talent in this generation, yet your younger brother is Robber Zhi, a scourge upon the world, and you cannot teach him. I am secretly ashamed for you. Allow me to go and reason with him."

Liuxia Ji replied: "You say that as a father one must instruct one’s son, and as an elder brother one must teach one’s younger brother. But if a son does not heed his father’s instruction, or a younger brother does not accept his elder brother’s teaching, what can even your eloquence do? Moreover, Zhi’s nature is such that his mind surges like a spring, his intentions gust like the wind. He is strong enough to resist enemies, and his eloquence suffices to gloss over wrongs. He is pleased when his heart is followed, enraged when it is opposed, and easily provoked by words. You must not go."

Confucius did not listen. With Yan Hui driving his carriage and Zigong as his attendant, he went to see Robber Zhi. Robber Zhi was then resting his troops on the southern slopes of Mount Tai, mincing human livers to eat. Confucius alighted from his carriage and approached the messenger, saying: "I, Kong Qiu of Lu, have heard of the general’s lofty virtue and respectfully bow twice to the messenger."

The messenger entered and announced Confucius to Robber Zhi, who flew into a rage. His eyes blazed like stars, his hair bristled to lift his cap, and he said: "Is this not that crafty and deceitful Kong Qiu of Lu? Tell him this: You fabricate words and concoct phrases, falsely invoking Wen and Wu. You wear a cap of twigs and gird yourself with the flanks of dead oxen. You spout a torrent of specious arguments, eating without plowing, clothing yourself without weaving. You flap your lips and wag your tongue, stirring up right and wrong to delude the rulers of the world, causing scholars everywhere to abandon their roots and falsely perform filial piety and brotherly love in hopes of attaining enfeoffment and wealth. Your crimes are grave and heavy. Flee at once, or I shall add your liver to my midday meal."

Confucius sent word again: "I am fortunate to be acquainted with Ji and wish to gaze upon the hem of your robe." The messenger relayed this, and Robber Zhi said: "Let him come forward." Confucius hastened forward, stepped back from his mat, and bowed twice to Robber Zhi.

Robber Zhi was enraged. He stretched out his legs, grasped his sword, glared with bulging eyes, and roared like a nursing tiger: "Come forward, Qiu. If your words please me, you shall live; if they oppose me, you shall die."

Confucius said: "I have heard that there are three virtues under heaven. To be born and grow tall, surpassingly handsome, so that young and old, noble and base all delight in seeing you—this is the highest virtue. To comprehend the bounds of heaven and earth and distinguish all things—this is the middle virtue. To be brave, resolute, and daring, gathering multitudes and leading troops—this is the lowest virtue. Whoever possesses even one of these virtues is fit to face south and call himself a lord. Now, general, you combine all three: your body stands eight feet and two inches tall, your face and eyes radiant, your lips bright as cinnabar, your teeth even as clamshells, your voice attuned to the Yellow Bell. Yet you are called Robber Zhi. I am secretly ashamed for you that you do not claim a nobler name. If you are willing to heed me, I shall go south to Wu and Yue, north to Qi and Lu, east to Song and Wei, and west to Jin and Chu. I shall have a great city of several hundred *li* built for you, establish a settlement of several hundred thousand households, and honor you as a feudal lord. Together with the world, you may begin anew, disband your troops, rest your soldiers, care for your brothers, and jointly sacrifice to your ancestors. This is the conduct of a sage and a man of talent, and the wish of all under heaven."

Robber Zhi flew into a rage and said: "Come forward, Qiu. Those who can be guided by profit or admonished by words are but the foolish and vulgar common folk. As for being tall and handsome, delighting all who see you—this is the legacy of my parents. Even if you do not praise me, do I not know it myself? Moreover, I have heard that those who flatter others to their faces also slander them behind their backs. Now you tell me of great cities and multitudes of people, seeking to guide me with profit and treat me as a herded beast. How can this last long? The greatest of cities is none other than the world itself. Yao and Shun possessed the world, yet their descendants had not even a place to plant an awl. Tang and Wu became Sons of Heaven, yet their posterity perished. Was this not because their profit was too great?

Furthermore, I have heard that in ancient times, beasts were many and people few. Thus, people dwelled in nests to avoid them, gathering acorns by day and roosting in trees by night. Hence, they were called the People of the Nest-Builder. In ancient times, people did not know clothing. In summer, they amassed firewood; in winter, they warmed themselves by it. Hence, they were called the People Who Knew Life. In the age of Shennong, they lay at ease and rose without care. People knew their mothers but not their fathers and lived among elk and deer. They plowed to eat and wove to clothe themselves, harboring no thought of harming one another. This was the height of perfect virtue. Yet the Yellow Emperor could not sustain this virtue. He fought Chiyou on the plains of Zhuolu, and blood flowed for a hundred *li*. Yao and Shun arose and established hosts of ministers. Tang exiled his lord, and King Wu killed Zhou. Ever since, the strong have oppressed the weak, and the many have bullied the few. From Tang and Wu onward, all have been men of disorder.

Now you cultivate the Way of Wen and Wu, grasp the world’s eloquence to instruct later generations, wear embroidered robes and sashes, utter false and deceptive words to delude the rulers of the world, and seek wealth and honor."

chunks.original_text: 盗莫大於子，天下何故不谓子为盗丘，而乃谓我为盗跖。 子以甘辞说子路而使从之，使子路去其危冠，解其长剑，而受教於子。 天下皆曰孔丘能止暴禁非。 其卒之也，子路欲杀卫君而事不成，身值於卫东门之上，是子教之不至也。 子自谓才士圣人邪。 则再逐於鲁，削迹於卫，穷於齐，围於陈蔡，不容身於天下。 子教子路菹此患，上无以为身，下无以为人，子之道岂足贵邪。 世之所高，莫若黄帝，黄帝尚不能全德而战涿鹿之野，流血百里。 尧不慈，舜不孝，禹徧枯，汤放其主，武王伐纣，文王拘羑里。 此六子者，世之所高也，孰论之，皆以利惑其真而强反其情性#l，其行乃甚可羞也。 世之所谓贤士伯夷叔齐，伯夷叔斋辞孤竹之君而饿死於首阳之山，骨肉不葬。 鲍焦饰行非世，抱木而死。 申徒狄谏而不听，负石自投於河，为鱼鳖所食。 介子推至忠也，自割其股以食文公，文公后背之，子推怒而去，抱木而燔死。 尾生与女子期於梁下，女子不来，水至不去，抱梁柱而死。 此四子者，无异於磔犬流豕，操瓢而乞者，皆离名轻死，不念本养寿命者也。 世之所谓忠臣者，莫若王子比干、伍子胥。 子胥沉江，比干剖心，此二子者，世#2谓忠臣也，然卒为天下笑。 自上观之，至于子胥比干，皆不足贵也。 丘之所以说我者，若告我以鬼事则我不能知也，若告我以人事者，不过此矣，皆吾所闻知也。 今吾告子以人之情。 目欲视色，耳欲听声，口欲察味，志气欲盈人。 上寿百岁，中寿八十，下寿六十。 除病瘦丧死忧患，其中开口而笑者，一月之中不过四五日而已矣。 天与地无穷，人死者有时，操有时之具而托於无穷之间，忽然无异麒骥之驰过隙也。 不能悦其志意，养其寿命者，皆非通道者也。 丘之所言，皆吾之所弃也。 亟去走归，无复言之。 子之道狂狂伋伋，诈巧虚伪事也，非可以全真也。 奚足论哉。 孔子再拜趋走，出门上车，执辔三失，目芒然无见，色若死灰，据轼低头不能出气。 归到鲁东门外，适遇柳下季。 柳下季曰：今者阙然，数日不见。 车马有行色，得微往见跖邪。 孔子仰天而叹曰：然。 柳下季曰：跖得无逆汝意若前乎。 孔子曰； 然。

No thief is greater than you, yet why does the world not call you "Robber Qiu" and instead call me "Robber Zhi"? You beguiled Zilu with honeyed words to make him follow you, causing him to remove his warrior’s cap, lay aside his long sword, and receive your teachings. The world all says that Confucius can halt violence and forbid wrongdoing. Yet in the end, Zilu sought to kill the lord of Wei, failed in the attempt, and was impaled at the eastern gate of Wei—this was the result of your incomplete instruction.

Do you truly consider yourself a man of talent and a sage? You were twice driven from Lu, your traces erased in Wei, impoverished in Qi, besieged between Chen and Cai, and found no refuge anywhere under heaven. You taught Zilu to bring about this disaster—above, he had no way to preserve himself; below, he had no way to serve others. Is your Way truly worthy of esteem?

Of those the world exalts, none surpasses the Yellow Emperor, yet even he could not preserve his virtue and fought on the plains of Zhuolu, where blood flowed for a hundred *li*. Yao was not compassionate, Shun was not filial, Yu exhausted himself, Tang exiled his lord, King Wu attacked Zhou, and King Wen was imprisoned at Youli. These six men, whom the world reveres—when closely examined, all were deluded by profit and forced their true natures into false paths. Their conduct is truly shameful.

As for the world’s so-called worthy men, Boyi and Shuqi: they renounced the lord of Gubu and starved to death on Mount Shouyang, their flesh and bones left unburied. Bao Jiao adorned his conduct to condemn the age and died embracing a tree. Shentu Di remonstrated but was not heeded; he carried a stone and drowned himself in the river, where fish and turtles fed on him. Jie Zitui was utterly loyal, cutting flesh from his thigh to feed Duke Wen, yet later the duke betrayed him. Enraged, Zitui departed and burned to death in a tree. Weisheng made a tryst with a woman beneath a bridge; when she did not come and the waters rose, he refused to leave and drowned clutching the pillar. These four men differ not from dismembered dogs or drifting swine, or beggars clutching gourd ladles—they all pursued fame and scorned death, heedless of preserving their lives and nurturing their longevity.

As for the world’s so-called loyal ministers, none surpass Prince Bigan and Wu Zixu. Zixu was drowned in the river, Bigan had his heart carved out—these two, whom the world calls loyal ministers, yet in the end became objects of ridicule. From the highest perspective, even Zixu and Bigan are not worthy of esteem.

As for what you, Qiu, have tried to persuade me with: if you spoke to me of ghostly matters, I would not understand them; if you spoke of human affairs, it would be no more than this—all things I have already heard. Now let me tell you of human nature: the eyes desire to see beauty, the ears to hear sound, the mouth to savor taste, and the will to be fulfilled. The longest-lived reach a hundred years, the average eighty, the shortest sixty. Subtracting illness, emaciation, mourning, death, and sorrow, the days one opens one’s mouth to laugh in a month number no more than four or five. Heaven and earth are without end, yet human death comes at its appointed time. Clutching this finite vessel and entrusting it to the boundless, it vanishes in an instant, no different from a swift steed galloping past a crack in the wall. Those who cannot delight their will and nurture their lives are not masters of the Way.

All that you, Qiu, have said are things I reject. Hurry, leave, and return home—speak no more of it. Your Way is frantic and deceitful, a craft of falsehood and pretense, incapable of preserving the true. What is there to discuss?

Confucius bowed twice, hastened away, exited the gate, and mounted his carriage. Three times he fumbled the reins, his eyes blank and sightless, his complexion ashen, his head bowed against the crossbar, unable to catch his breath. Returning to the eastern gate of Lu, he encountered Liuxia Ji. Liuxia Ji said, "You have been absent for days. Your carriage and horses bear the marks of travel—did you by chance go to see Zhi?"

Confucius looked up to the heavens and sighed, "Yes."

Liuxia Ji said, "Did Zhi perhaps offend you as before?"

Confucius replied, "Yes."

chunks.original_text: 丘所谓无病而自灸也。 疾走料虎头，编虎须，几不免虎口哉。 入保者，闭门自守也。 心如涌泉，言其气方旺也。 意如飘风，虚骄轻扬之意也。 妄称文武，言妄称文王武王之道以自名。 枝木，削木枝之皮以为冠。 牛胁，牛皮也。 得幸於季，言与下季得相亲也。 望履慔下，言一见於慔下而望其履也，此再通谒之辞。 知维天地，知可以包罗天地，天地不能出其知之外也。 能辩诸物，才能可以辩名诸物也，谓其无不知也。 其卒之也，要其终也。 禹偏枯，言其胼胝也。 孰论之，详论之也。 磔犬流豕，言其身之自杀如杀犬豕也。 操瓢而乞，有求於人也。 离，丽也，泥着於名也，故曰离名。 不念本，不知其本真之性。 伋伋即汲汲也。 执辔三失，言辔屡落也，车马有行色，言其似有所往而方归也。 微，无也，得无往见跖乎。 若前乎者，若我前日之所言也。 子张问於满苟得曰：盍不为行。 无行则不信，不信则不任，不任则不利，故观之名，计之利，而义真是也。 若弃名利，反之於心，则夫士之为行，不可一日不为乎。 满苟得曰：无耻者富，多信者显。 夫名利之大者，几在无耻而信。 故观之名，计之利，而信真是也。 若弃名利，反之於心，则夫士之为行抱其天乎。 子张曰：昔者桀纣贵为天子，富有天下，今谓臧聚曰，汝行如桀纣，则有怍色。 有不服之心者，小人所贱也。 仲尼墨翟穷为匹夫，今谓宰相曰，子行如仲尼墨翟，则变容易色。 称不足者，士诚贵也。 故势为天子未必贵也，穷为匹夫未必贱也。 贵贱之分在行之美恶。 满苟得曰：小盗者拘，大盗者为诸侯，诸侯之门，义士存焉。 昔者桓公小白杀兄入嫂，而管仲为臣； 田成子常杀君窃国，而孔子受币。

Qiu, what you speak of is like needlessly cauterizing oneself when free of illness. You rush to measure the tiger’s head and braid its whiskers—how nearly did you escape its jaws? To "enter the fortress" means to shut the gates and guard oneself. "The heart like a gushing spring" describes qi in its full vigor. "The intent like a whirling wind" conveys the sense of hollow arrogance and frivolous pride. "Falsely invoking Wen and Wu" means to claim falsely the Way of Kings Wen and Wu as one’s own. "Branch-wood" refers to stripping bark from tree branches to fashion a cap. "Ox-flank" is oxhide. "Found favor with Ji" means to have grown close to Liuxia Ji. "Gazing at his sandals in deference" describes how, upon a single audience with Liuxia Ji, one would long for even the sight of his footwear—this is the language of repeated pleas for an audience. "Knowledge encompasses heaven and earth" means that one’s knowledge can embrace heaven and earth, leaving nothing beyond its scope. "Able to distinguish all things" means that one’s talent can discern the names of all things—implying omniscience. "In the end" refers to the final outcome. "Yu’s partial paralysis" alludes to his calloused hands and feet. "Who would debate it in detail?" means to examine it thoroughly. "Dismembering dogs and butchering swine" describes how one’s own death resembles the slaughter of dogs and pigs. "Holding a gourd to beg" signifies seeking from others. "Detached" means clinging—being mired in fame, hence "detached from fame." "Not contemplating the root" means failing to recognize one’s original, true nature. "Frantic" is synonymous with restless. "Three times he fumbled the reins" means the reins repeatedly slipped from his grasp. "His carriage and horses bore the marks of travel" suggests the appearance of one who had set out and was only now returning. "By chance" means "perhaps"—"Did you by chance go to see Zhi?" "As before" refers to what had been said previously. "As I said before..."

Zizhang asked Mang Goude, "Why not cultivate conduct?" Mang Goude replied, "Without conduct, there is no trust; without trust, no appointment; without appointment, no profit. Thus, when one observes fame and calculates advantage, righteousness is indeed the truth. If one abandons fame and profit and turns inward to the heart, then the scholar’s conduct cannot be neglected for a single day." Mang Goude said, "The shameless grow rich, and the deceitful gain prominence. The greatest fame and profit lie in shamelessness and deceit. Thus, when one observes fame and calculates advantage, trust is indeed the truth. If one abandons fame and profit and turns inward to the heart, then the scholar’s conduct embraces the heavens." Zizhang said, "In ancient times, Jie and Zhou were exalted as Sons of Heaven, possessing all under heaven. Yet if one were to tell Zang Ju, ‘Your conduct resembles Jie and Zhou,’ he would flush with shame. Such disdain marks the baseness of petty men. Confucius and Mo Di lived in poverty as commoners, yet if one were to tell a prime minister, ‘Your conduct resembles Confucius and Mo Di,’ his expression would change, and his color shift. Such praise is deemed insufficient—for the scholar, true nobility lies therein. Thus, to hold the power of the Son of Heaven does not necessarily confer nobility, nor does poverty as a commoner necessarily mean baseness. The distinction between noble and base rests in the goodness or evil of one’s conduct." Mang Goude said, "Petty thieves are imprisoned, while great thieves become lords. At the gates of lords, righteous scholars reside. In former times, Duke Huan of Qi, Xiaobai, killed his brother and took his sister-in-law, yet Guan Zhong served as his minister. Tian Chengzi murdered his lord and usurped the state, yet Confucius accepted his gifts."

chunks.original_text: 论则贱之，行则下之，则是言行之情悖战於胸中也。 不亦拂乎。 故书曰，孰恶孰美，成者为首，不成者为尾。 子张曰，子不为行，即将疏戚无伦，贵贱无义，长幼无序，五纪六位将何以为别乎。 满苟得曰：尧杀长子，舜流母弟，疏戚有伦乎。 汤伐桀，武王杀纣，贵贱有义乎。 王季为适，周公杀兄，长幼有序乎。 儒者伪辞，墨者兼爱，五纪六位将有别乎。 且子正为名，我正为利，名利之实不顺於理，不监於道，吾日与子讼於无约，曰：小人殉财，君子殉名，其所以变其情，易其性，则异矣。 乃至於弃其所为而殉其所不为，则一也。 故曰：无为小人，反殉而天； 无为君子，从天之理。 若枉若直，相为#3天极。 面观四方，与时消息。 若是若非，执而圆机。 独成而意，与道徘徊。 无转而行，无成而义，将失而所为。 无赴而富，无殉而成，将弃而天。 比干剖心，子胥抉眼，忠之祸也。 直躬证父，尾生溺死，信之患也。 鲍子立乾，申子不自理，廉之害也。 孔子不见母，匡子不见父，义之失也。 此上世之所传、下世之所语以为士者，正其言必其行，故服其殃离其患也。 盍不为行者，言何不修其德行也。 观之名，计之利，而义真是者，言欲求名利惟修义为是也。 人若弃名利则反逆其心，无以自乐必欲求之，非行义不可。 此学干禄之意也。 多信者显，言多为可信之言以求荣显。 此言假信之名以自利者。 子张言以义求利，满苟得则曰今之求名利者诈而已矣。 若谓弃名利而反逆其心，必欲得之则纵吾心之所欲，以为苟得自满之计，犹为天真而无矫揉，故曰抱其天也。 小盗者拘，大盗者为诸侯，即前胠箧篇之论。 言行之情，悖战於胸中，谓其行不顾言，言不顾行也。 成者为首，不成者为尾，即前所谓得其时者为义之徒，失其时为篡夫。 此意盖以仁义之行皆为诈伪而非天真也。 五纪，五常也； 六位，三纲也，君臣父子夫妇也。 子正为名者，谓汝以仁义之名求得，我则但为利而已，不假矫伪之名也，为名为利皆非真实道理，故曰名利之实，不顺於理不监於道。 无约，无拘束而听其自然也。 曰满苟得，曰无约，此又寓意於其名者。 如前篇知无为之类。 弃其所为者，舍其所当为而不为，谓不能存生保性也。 徇其所不为者，谓为利为名乃其所不当为者也。 循天理自然则无君子小人之名矣，故曰，无为小人，反循而天； 无为君子，从天之理。 言亦不为君子，亦不为小人，则可以徇从汝天理之自然矣。 而，汝也。 无曲无直，相而视之，皆自然至极之理，故曰若枉若直，相而天极。 东西南北各有其方，而春夏秋冬属焉，消息往来皆一气也，故曰面观四方，与时消息。 执圆机则无是非，故曰若是若非，执而圆机。 信意而行，独得於我，则从容体道矣，故曰独成而意，与道徘徊。 转，背也。 背道而行，自名以义以求成功，则失其所谓本真者矣，故曰无转而行，无成而义，将失而所为。 而，汝也。 趋赴於富而求殉其成功，则将失其自然之天矣，故曰无赴而富，无殉而成，将弃而天。 凡曰无者，言莫如此也，禁止之意也。 正其言，谓以忠信康义之言为实也。 必其行者，谓必为忠信康义之行也。 服，被也，离，丽也。 言必遭其殃害也。
chunks.translated_text:
To condemn in speech yet defer in conduct—this is the contradiction of words and deeds warring within the breast. Is this not perverse?

Thus the Book says: "Who is vile? Who is noble? The successful become the head, the failed the tail." Zizhang said, "If you do not act, kinship and affection will lack order, noble and base will lack righteousness, elder and younger will lack sequence—how then shall the Five Constants and Six Positions be distinguished?" Mang Goude replied: "Yao killed his eldest son, Shun exiled his younger brother—where is the order in kinship? Tang punished Jie, King Wu slew Zhou—where is the righteousness in noble and base? King Ji was the rightful heir, yet the Duke of Zhou killed his elder brother—where is the sequence in elder and younger? The Confucians preach hypocritical words, the Mohists advocate universal love—how can the Five Constants and Six Positions be distinguished? Moreover, you rectify for the sake of reputation, I rectify for the sake of profit. The substance of reputation and profit does not accord with principle, nor does it reflect the Dao. Daily I dispute with you before Wu Yue, saying: 'The petty man dies for wealth, the gentleman dies for reputation.' Though their motives for altering their nature differ, when they abandon what they should do to die for what they should not, they are the same. Thus it is said: 'Do not be a petty man, and in turning back, follow Heaven. Do not be a gentleman, and follow Heaven’s principle.' Whether crooked or straight, they form the ultimate pattern of Heaven. Observe the four directions, and move with the seasons. Whether right or wrong, grasp the round mechanism. Alone in your intent, wander with the Dao. Do not turn against the Way in action, do not seek success in righteousness—you will lose what you strive for. Do not rush toward wealth, do not die for success—you will abandon your Heaven. Bi Gan was disemboweled, Wu Zixu had his eyes gouged out—such are the calamities of loyalty. Zhigong testified against his father, Weisheng drowned—such are the disasters of trustworthiness. Master Bao stood rigid, Shen Buhai did not defend himself—such are the harms of integrity. Confucius did not see his mother, Kuangzi did not see his father—such are the failures of righteousness. These are the tales handed down from high antiquity, the lessons repeated in later ages to instruct scholars: rectify your words and align your conduct, yet they still suffer misfortune and encounter disaster.

Why not act? Why not cultivate virtue and conduct? To observe reputation and calculate profit, only righteousness is truly right. If a man abandons reputation and profit, he reverses his heart’s desires and finds no joy—he must seek them, and only through righteous conduct can he do so. This is the intent of those who study to obtain office. The trustworthy become eminent—this means using trustworthy words to seek glory. Such words feign trustworthiness for self-interest. Zizhang speaks of seeking profit through righteousness, while Mang Goude says that those who seek reputation and profit today do so through deceit alone.

If one claims to abandon reputation and profit yet reverses his heart’s desires, insisting on obtaining them, then following the heart’s desires in a self-satisfied, opportunistic scheme is still to embrace one’s natural Heaven, free from artifice. Thus it is said: "Hold fast to your Heaven." Petty thieves are imprisoned, great thieves become lords—this is the argument from the *Opening the Trunk* chapter. The contradiction of words and deeds warring within the breast means that actions disregard words, and words disregard actions. "The successful become the head, the failed the tail"—this is what was previously called "those who seize the moment are righteous followers, those who miss it are usurpers." The underlying meaning is that acts of benevolence and righteousness are all deceitful and artificial, not natural Heaven.

The Five Constants are the five virtues; the Six Positions are the Three Bonds—ruler and minister, father and son, husband and wife. "You rectify for the sake of reputation" means you seek to obtain through the name of benevolence and righteousness, while I seek only profit, without feigning such names. Both reputation and profit are not true principles, thus it is said: "The substance of reputation and profit does not accord with principle, nor does it reflect the Dao." Wu Yue means unrestrained, following nature. Mang Goude and Wu Yue are names with implied meanings, like "Knowing Non-Action" in the previous chapter.

"Abandoning what one should do" means forsaking what one ought to do, failing to preserve life and protect one’s nature. "Dying for what one should not do" refers to pursuing profit and reputation, which are not what one should do. Following Heaven’s natural principle eliminates the distinction between gentleman and petty man, thus it is said: "Do not be a petty man, and in turning back, follow Heaven. Do not be a gentleman, and follow Heaven’s principle." This means neither being a gentleman nor a petty man, so one can follow the natural principle of Heaven.

Whether crooked or straight, when viewed in relation to one another, they are all the ultimate principle of Heaven. Thus it is said: "Whether crooked or straight, they form the ultimate pattern of Heaven." The four directions each have their place, and the seasons of spring, summer, autumn, and winter belong to them—ebb and flow are all of a single qi. Thus it is said: "Observe the four directions, and move with the seasons." Grasping the round mechanism eliminates right and wrong, thus it is said: "Whether right or wrong, grasp the round mechanism." Acting on true intent alone, one attains the Dao, thus it is said: "Alone in your intent, wander with the Dao."

"Turning" means going against. Acting against the Dao, self-righteously seeking success, one loses what is truly natural. Thus it is said: "Do not turn against the Way in action, do not seek success in righteousness—you will lose what you strive for." Rushing toward wealth and dying for success will cause one to lose one’s natural Heaven. Thus it is said: "Do not rush toward wealth, do not die for success—you will abandon your Heaven." "Do not" means "do not act thus," an expression of prohibition.

"Rectifying one’s words" means taking loyal, trustworthy, virtuous, and righteous words as true. "Aligning one’s conduct" means acting with loyalty, trustworthiness, virtue, and righteousness. "Suffer" means to endure; "encounter" means to adhere. Thus one inevitably meets with misfortune and disaster. Why not act? Why not cultivate virtue and conduct? Observing reputation and calculating profit, only righteousness is truly right. If a man abandons reputation and profit, he reverses his heart’s desires and finds no joy—he must seek them, and only through righteous conduct can he do so. This is the intent of those who study to obtain office. The trustworthy become eminent—this means using trustworthy words to seek glory. Such words feign trustworthiness for self-interest. chunks.original_text: 子张欲行义以求富责，因干禄之语而借其名也。 满苟得则以苟得而满其欲为自然之道，故设为问答之辞。 意谓矫饰以求利达，不如直情之为愈。 盖矫孟子天爵、人爵之说也。 无足问於知和曰：人卒未有不兴名就利者，彼富则人归之，归则下之，下则贵之。 夫见下贵者，所以长生安体乐意之道也。 今子独无意焉。 知不足邪。 意知而力不能行邪。 故推正不忘邪。 知和曰：今夫此人，以为与己同时而生，同乡而处者，以为夫绝俗过世之士焉。 是专无主正，所以览古今之时，是非之分也。 与俗化世，去至重，弃至尊，以为其所为也。 此其所以论长生安体乐意之道，不亦远乎。 惨怛之疾，恬愉之安，不监於体； 怵惕之恐，欣惧之喜，不监於心。 知为为而不知所以为，是以贵为天子，富有天下，而不免於患也。 推正不忘者，言汝之无意於富贵，岂其智不足邪。 意，度也。 度汝亦知此而力有不及邪。 故推正理以遏求富贵之心而不能忘邪。 此人，富贵之人也。 言此等富贵之人皆与我同生斯世，同处此乡，岂是绝俗过世之士，言其非有甚高而不可及也。 其意盖谓此亦眼前人耳，我岂不知之。 此人其心全无所主，全失其．性命之正，但知趋时以求己分之益，而为流俗所化，言其所为皆俗人也。 是非之分者，言以他人为非，以己为是，自求其身之益也。 古今，久近也。 前一时如何，今一时如何，览察其时之向背，以自求利也。 至重至尊者，天理之自然也。 皆弃而去之，独为其所谓求富贵之事，此岂长生安身养心之道也。 求富贵之人，其身其心或安或否，或悲或喜，迷而不觉，不能自见，故曰不监於体，不监於心。 为为者，为其所为，乃人为也。 所以为者，天理也。 知有人为而不知有天理，虽为天子犹不免於损身之患害，况其下者乎。 无足曰：夫富之於人，无所不利。 穷美究势，至人之所不得逮，贤#4人之所不能及，侠人之勇力而以为威强，秉人之知谋以为明察，因人之德以为贤良，非享国而严若君父。 且夫声色滋味权势之於人心，不待学而乐之，体不待象而安之，夫欲恶避就固不待师，此人之性也。 天下虽非我，孰能辞之。 知和曰：知者之为，故动以百姓，不违其度，是以足而不争，无以为故不求。 不足故求之，争四处而不自以为贪； 有余故辞之，弃天下而不自以为廉。 廉贪之实，非以迫外也，反监之度。 势为天子而不以贵骄人，富有天下而不以财戏人，计其患，虑其反，以为害於性，故辞而不受也，非以要名誉也。 尧舜为帝而雍，非仁天下也，不以美害生也； 善卷许由得帝而不受，非虚辞让也，不以事害己。 此皆就其利，辞其害，而天下称贤焉，则可以有之，彼非以兴名誉也。 此又不言贵，只言富。 穷美者，可以尽求其所好也； 究势者，可以尽权势之事也。 虽至人贤人亦有不及焉，言其力量之可以自用也。 使人因人、秉人，皆言其富可以使人也，即十万通神之意。 欲，欲富也； 恶，恶贫也。 避贫而就富，不待教而后能，故曰不待师。 此出於天性之自然也。 天下之人虽皆以为非，而我安能辞避之，此设为贪者之言。 无足，贪而不知足也，故名以无足、满苟得之类也。 动以百姓者，言智者之所为，每以百姓之同得於天者为主，故不敢自违於法度。
chunks.translated_text:
Zizhang sought to practice righteousness to attain wealth and recognition, borrowing the language of seeking office to lend it a name. Those who are content with mere acquisition treat such opportunism as the natural Way, thus framing their arguments in question-and-answer form. Their intent is to claim that feigning virtue to gain advantage is inferior to following one’s true nature. This distorts Mencius’ distinction between the Heavenly office and the human office.

Wu Zu asked Zhi He: “No man is without the impulse to pursue fame and profit. The wealthy attract followers; followers submit to them; submission leads to reverence. To be revered and submitted to—this is the Way to long life, bodily ease, and joy of mind. Yet you alone show no interest. Is your wisdom insufficient? Or do you understand but lack the strength to act? Why do you persist in upholding principle without letting go?”

Zhi He replied: “These men you speak of—born in the same era, dwelling in the same land—believe themselves to be transcendent sages beyond the common world. Yet they lack any guiding principle, drifting with the times to judge right and wrong. They conform to worldly customs, abandoning what is most weighty and most noble, all for the sake of their pursuits. How can such conduct be the Way to long life, bodily ease, and joy of mind? Grief and sorrow, contentment and joy—these are not reflected in their bodies. Fear and dread, delight and apprehension—these are not mirrored in their hearts. They know how to act but not *why* they act. Thus, though they may be honored as Son of Heaven and possess all under Heaven, they cannot escape suffering.

‘Persisting in upholding principle without letting go’ means: Do you truly lack the wisdom to desire wealth and honor? Or do you *know* this path but lack the power to follow it? Thus, I press the right principle to curb the craving for wealth and status, yet you cannot forget it. These men—these wealthy and honored men—live in the same world and the same land as I do. They are not sages who transcend the age; they are no higher than anyone else. My point is that they are ordinary men, and I am no less aware of this than you. Their hearts have no fixed anchor, no grasp of the true nature of life and destiny. They merely chase the trends of the moment to secure their own advantage, swept along by the tide of custom. Their judgments of right and wrong are self-serving, weighing past and present to seek personal gain. What is most weighty and most noble—the natural principle of Heaven—they cast aside, all for the sake of their pursuit of wealth and status. How can this be the Way to long life, bodily ease, and peace of mind?

Those who seek wealth and status may experience bodily comfort or distress, joy or sorrow, yet they remain blind to it all, unable to perceive themselves. Thus it is said: ‘not reflected in their bodies, not reflected in their hearts.’ They know *how* to act—through human effort—but not *why* they act—the principle of Heaven. Even the Son of Heaven, knowing only human effort and not Heaven’s principle, cannot escape harm to his person. How much less can those beneath him?

Wu Zu said: “Wealth brings every advantage to man. It exhausts beauty and exhausts power, reaching what even the most accomplished cannot attain, surpassing what the worthiest cannot match. It harnesses others’ strength to amplify its might, wields others’ wisdom to sharpen its discernment, and appropriates others’ virtue to adorn its goodness. Though not a ruler, it commands awe like a sovereign. Moreover, the allure of sensual pleasures, fine flavors, and power over men’s hearts is innate—no learning is needed to delight in them, no model is required to find them agreeable. Desires and aversions, attraction and avoidance—these are not taught; they are man’s nature. Though all the world may oppose me, who can renounce them?”

Zhi He replied: “The actions of the wise are always for the sake of the people, never transgressing the proper measure. Thus, they have enough and do not contend; having no ulterior motive, they do not seek. Those who lack, seek; they vie for every opportunity yet do not consider themselves greedy. Those who have enough, decline; they renounce all under Heaven yet do not consider themselves noble. True nobility or greed is not imposed from without—it is a reflection of one’s own measure.

Though possessing the power of the Son of Heaven, they do not use their rank to domineer over others. Though owning all under Heaven, they do not flaunt their wealth to toy with men. They weigh the consequences, consider the repercussions, and recognize the harm to their nature. Thus, they decline and do not accept—not to seek fame. Yao and Shun ruled as emperors yet remained at ease, not out of benevolence toward the world, but to avoid allowing beauty to harm their lives. Shan Juan and Xu You declined the throne, not out of empty modesty, but to avoid allowing affairs to harm themselves. All of them pursued what benefited them and declined what harmed them. Though the world calls them worthy, they did not act to cultivate reputation.

Here, Wu Zu speaks not of honor but only of wealth. ‘Exhausting beauty’ means indulging every desire; ‘exhausting power’ means exercising every prerogative. Even the most accomplished and worthy cannot match this—it speaks to the sheer force at one’s disposal. ‘Harnessing others’ and ‘wielding others’ both describe how wealth can command men, embodying the idea of ‘moving even the gods.’ Desire for wealth and aversion to poverty, fleeing poverty and pursuing wealth—these require no instruction, for they are not learned from a teacher. They arise from the spontaneity of human nature. Though all the world may condemn it, how can I renounce it?” This is the argument of the greedy.

Wu Zu—whose name means ‘Never Enough’—and those like ‘Content with Mere Acquisition’ are insatiable. The actions of the wise are always guided by what the people share from Heaven, never daring to transgress the proper measure.

chunks.original_text: 百姓所同得，有物有则者也，度即则也。 足而不争，德足於己而无所争也。 无以为故不求为，不在人而在天，人力无所与，故曰无以为。 知人力之无所与，则不求矣。 使其在我有所不足，则穷极四方而争求之亦不以为贪，此求德也，求在内者也。 德足而有余则身外之物皆辞之，虽辞天下亦不为康。 此食康二者之实非以为人也，非务外也，而皆反求诸天理之法度而监之，故曰反监之度。 以财戏人，鼓舞天下也。 虑其反，反身而虑之也。 雍，黎民於变时雍也。 不以美害生者，言其无为而为，不以美名而害其身，有天下而不与也。 可以有之，言天下之贤名可以自有而无愧也。 其为道为德出於中心之诚，非求以兴名誉也。 此又把尧舜与许由皆作好说。 无足曰：必持其名，苦体绝甘，约养以持生，则下久病长#5阨而不死者也。 知和曰：平为福，有余为害者，物莫不然，而财其甚者也。 今富人耳营锺鼓管钥之声，口赚於刍豢醪醴之味，以感其意，遗忘其业，可谓乱矣。 侅溺於冯气，若负重行而上也，可谓苦矣。 贪财而取慰，贪权而取竭，静居则溺，体泽则冯，可谓疾矣。 为欲富就利，故蒲若堵耳而不知避，且冯而不舍，可谓辱矣。 财积而无用，服膺而不舍，满心戚醮，求益而不止，可谓忧矣。 内射疑劫请之贼，外则畏寇盗之害，内周楼疏，外不敢独行，可谓畏矣。 此六者，天下之至害也，皆遗忘而不知察。 及其患至，求尽性竭财单以反一日之无故而不可得也。 故观之名则不见，求之利则不得，缭意绝体而争此，不亦惑乎。 必持其名者，言必欲求名而不求富贵之利，则徒然自苦其身，虽存如大病然。 绝甘，去美味也。 约养，俭以自奉也。 父病长阮而不死，即易所谓贞疾常不死也。 平为福，有余为害，物莫不然，财其甚。 此篇文字枝叶太粗，比之让王渔父又不及，但如此一句亦好语也，岂可泯没。 嗛，塞满其口也。 猿猴之颔曰嗛。 感其意者，动其意也，言役其心也。 遗忘其业，失其所当为也。 冯气，怒其气而不得通也。 侅，溺，不自在也，若人行负重物而登高然。 取慰，取足也。 取竭，用尽也。 今谚云有势莫尽用是也。 静居则溺，言不耐闲而自没溺於嗜欲也。 体泽则冯者，其身充肥悦泽则冯满有骄涨之意也。 满若堵者，言积财而高於堵，所谓阿堵物是也。 不知避，不知足，趋求而未已也。 冯，恃也。 恃此以为夸而不能舍，服膺念念不忘也。 念念不忘，但见憔憔戚戚之意满於胸中，故曰满心戚醮。 不自得如此，犹求益而不止。 剎请，劫取也。
chunks.translated_text:
The people’s shared endowment from Heaven consists of tangible things and their inherent principles—measure is principle. To be content and not contend means one’s virtue suffices for oneself, leaving nothing to dispute. To act without purpose is not to seek action; this lies not in man but in Heaven, for human effort plays no part—hence “to act without purpose.” Recognizing that human effort plays no part, one ceases to seek. If what lies within oneself is insufficient, one may exhaust the four quarters in pursuit without being deemed greedy—this is the pursuit of virtue, the search for what lies within. When virtue suffices and overflows, one renounces all external things; even if one were to renounce the world, it would not be for comfort.

These two—seeking sustenance and comfort—are not pursued for others, nor do they involve external striving; rather, they both return to the principles and measures of Heaven’s pattern and reflect upon them—hence “returning to reflect upon the measure.” To dazzle others with wealth is to stir the world. To consider the reverse is to turn inward and reflect. *Yong* means the people at peace in times of change. Not allowing beauty to harm life means acting without contrivance, not letting a fine reputation harm oneself, and possessing the world without clinging to it. One *can* possess it, for the worthy name of the world can be rightfully claimed without shame. Such conduct in the Dao and virtue arises from the sincerity of the heart, not from seeking to establish fame.

Here again, Yao, Shun, and Xu You are all treated as fond of persuasion. Wu Zu says: “One who clings to reputation, hardens the body, rejects sweetness, and restricts nourishment to preserve life is like one long afflicted by chronic illness yet does not die.” Zhi He says: “Balance brings fortune; excess brings harm—nothing is otherwise, and wealth is the most extreme case. Now the rich man’s ears are filled with the sounds of bells, drums, pipes, and flutes; his mouth savors the flavors of fine meats and wines, stirring his mind and causing him to neglect his affairs—this may be called disorder. Overwhelmed by pent-up *qi*, he labors like one bearing a heavy load uphill—this may be called suffering. Coveting wealth, he exhausts himself; grasping for power, he depletes himself. In quietude, he drowns; in abundance, he swells—this may be called sickness. Driven by the desire for wealth and profit, he rushes forward like one with ears blocked, unable to avoid danger, pressing on relentlessly—this may be called disgrace. Wealth accumulates yet goes unused; he clings to it without release, his heart filled with sorrow and distress, ever seeking more without cease—this may be called anxiety. Within, he fears the threats of extortion and robbery; without, he dreads bandits and thieves. His inner chambers are fortified, and he dares not walk alone—this may be called fear. These six are the greatest harms in the world, yet they are forgotten and left unexamined. When calamity strikes, one seeks to exhaust one’s nature and deplete one’s wealth to return to a single day of carefree ease—but it cannot be obtained.

Thus, when one gazes upon reputation, it is not seen; when one seeks profit, it is not gained. Yet one strains the mind and exhausts the body in contention for these—is this not delusion? ‘Clinging to reputation’ means insisting on seeking fame while forsaking the benefits of wealth and honor, thereby needlessly tormenting oneself—though alive, one is like one gravely ill. ‘Rejecting sweetness’ means forgoing fine flavors. ‘Restricting nourishment’ means frugality in self-care. ‘Long afflicted by chronic illness yet does not die’ echoes the *Yijing*’s ‘steadfast in illness, ever undying.’ Balance brings fortune; excess brings harm—nothing is otherwise, and wealth is the most extreme case.

Though this passage’s branches and leaves are somewhat coarse, falling short of the *Rang Wang* and *Yu Fu*, even a single line here is well-phrased—how could it be erased? *Qian* means to stuff the mouth full. The monkey’s cheek is called *qian*. ‘Stirring his mind’ means agitating his thoughts, implying enslavement of the heart. ‘Neglecting his affairs’ means forsaking what he ought to do. *Feng qi* means angering the *qi* so that it cannot flow. *Hai* means drowning, being ill at ease, like one carrying a heavy load uphill. ‘Seeking sufficiency’ means seeking fulfillment. ‘Seeking depletion’ means exhausting all. As the common saying goes, ‘Do not use all your power.’ ‘In quietude, he drowns’ means being unable to endure idleness and sinking into desires. ‘In abundance, he swells’ means that when the body is plump and sleek, it becomes full and arrogant. ‘High as a wall’ means wealth piled high like a wall—what is called ‘that thing by the bed.’ ‘Unable to avoid’ means insatiable, ever pursuing without cease. *Feng* means reliance. Relying on this for boasting, he cannot let go. ‘Clinging without release’ means constant remembrance, never forgotten. ‘Constant remembrance’ means only seeing sorrow and distress filling the heart—hence ‘the heart filled with sorrow and distress.’ So afflicted, he still seeks more without cease. *Cha qing* means extortion and robbery.”

chunks.original_text: 藏於屋内者，恐有劫盗，故为楼疏周环其室； 运而出外，恐有大盗，必盛其徒旅而不敢独行。 疏，窗也，楼墙上之楼也。 六者，曰乱、曰苦、曰疾、曰辱、曰忧、曰畏是也。 遗忘而不察者，言皆失检点而不自觉也。 单，独也。 但也，故事也。 反，复也。 及其病患已成，虽欲求全其生，去其财，但求一日复如贫居无事之初而不可得也。 尽性，全生也。 竭，去也。 反愿，去富而就贫也。 及至於此，则名亦何在，利亦何在。 缭意绝体，缠缚其身心也。 争利之时，徒缠缚其身心，反以成此祸患，非愚乎。 东坡谓让王以下四篇，非庄子所作，此见极高。 四篇之中盗跖尤甚，而太史公庄子传但谓作渔父、盗跖、胠箧以诋讥孔子之徒，略不疑其文字精粗异同。 何也。 岂子长之意。

Those who hoard within their houses, fearing robbers, construct lofts and lattice windows all around their chambers. When transporting goods abroad, fearing great bandits, they must assemble a retinue of followers and dare not travel alone. *Shu* means windows; *lou* refers to the upper stories of walls.

These six are called chaos, suffering, illness, disgrace, sorrow, and fear. "Neglected and unexamined" means losing all self-restraint without awareness. *Dan* means alone. *Dan* also signifies "merely," as in "mere affairs." *Fan* means to return. Once illness and misfortune have taken form, though one may seek to preserve life and relinquish wealth, merely longing for a single day’s return to the carefree poverty of former times is no longer possible.

"Exhausting one’s nature" means fully preserving life. *Jie* means to remove. "Reversed desire" means abandoning wealth to embrace poverty. By the time one reaches this point, where then is fame? Where then is profit? "Entangled thoughts and severed body" describes the binding of one’s body and mind. In the pursuit of profit, one merely ensnares body and mind, only to bring about such calamity—is this not folly?

Su Dongpo observed that the four chapters following *Rang Wang* were not the work of Zhuangzi, a judgment of great insight. Among these four, *Dao Zhi* is the most extreme, yet Sima Qian’s *Biography of Zhuangzi* merely states that he composed *Yu Fu*, *Dao Zhi*, and *Qu Qie* to slander and ridicule Confucius’s disciples, without the slightest doubt regarding the differences in refinement or consistency of the texts. Why is this? What was Zichang’s intent?

**Miscellaneous Chapters: "Discourse on Swords"**
Formerly, King Wen of Zhao delighted in swords. Swordsmen thronged his gates as retainers, numbering over three thousand. Day and night, they clashed before him, with over a hundred dying or wounded each year. His obsession knew no end, and after three years of this, the state declined, and the feudal lords plotted against him. The crown prince, Kui, grew anxious and offered a reward to his attendants: "Whoever can persuade the king to abandon his fondness for swordsmen shall receive six thousand gold pieces." His attendants replied, "Zhuangzi would be capable of this."

The crown prince then sent envoys bearing a thousand gold pieces to present to Zhuangzi, but Zhuangzi declined and accompanied the messengers back. Meeting the crown prince, he said, "What instruction does the prince have for Zhou, that he offers Zhou a thousand gold pieces?" The crown prince replied, "I have heard that you, Master, are enlightened and sagely. I humbly present this thousand gold as a gift for your attendants. If you refuse, how dare I speak further?"

Zhuangzi said, "I have heard that the prince wishes to employ Zhou to end the king’s obsession. If I were to persuade the king but contradict his will, or fail to please the prince, I would face execution. How then could I accept the gold? But if I persuade the king and satisfy the prince, what in Zhao could I not obtain?"

The crown prince said, "Indeed. What my king sees are only swordsmen."

Zhuangzi replied, "Very well. Zhou is skilled in the sword."

The crown prince said, "Yet the swordsmen my king favors all have unkempt hair, bristling sideburns, drooping caps, tassels of coarse silk, short-backed robes, glaring eyes, and speak in harsh tones. The king delights in them. If you, Master, appear before him in Confucian garb, the matter will surely go awry."

Zhuangzi said, "Permit me to prepare sword attire." After three days of preparing his sword attire, he appeared before the crown prince, who then presented him to the king. The king, gripping his unsheathed blade, awaited him.

Zhuangzi entered the palace gates without haste and did not bow upon seeing the king. The king said, "What would you teach me, that the crown prince has gone before you?"

Zhuangzi replied, "I have heard that Your Majesty delights in swords, so I have come to present my swordsmanship."

The king asked, "What can your sword do to restrain or control?"

Zhuangzi said, "My sword can strike down one man every ten paces and traverse a thousand *li* without hindrance."

The king, greatly pleased, exclaimed, "You would be invincible in the world!"

Zhuangzi said, "For the swordsman, one displays emptiness, entices with advantage, strikes after the opponent moves, and arrives before the opponent. I wish to demonstrate this."

The king said, "Rest now, Master."

chunks.original_text: 就舍待命，令设戏请夫子。 王乃校剑士七日，死伤者六十余人，得五六人，使奉剑於殿下，乃召庄子。 王曰：今日试使士敦剑。 庄子曰：望之久矣。 王曰：夫子所御杖，长短何如。 曰：臣之所奉皆可。 然臣有三剑，唯王所用，请先言而后试。 王曰：愿闻三剑。 曰：有天子剑，有诸侯剑，有庶人剑。 王曰：天子之剑何如。 曰：天子之剑，以燕溪石城为锋，齐岱为锷，晋魏为脊，周宋为镡，韩魏为铗。 包以四夷，裹以四时，绕以渤海，带以常山。 制以五行，论以刑德，开以阴阳，持以春夏，行以秋冬。 此剑直之无前，举之无上，案之无下，运之无旁。 上决浮云，下绝地纪。 此剑一用，匡诸侯，天下服矣。 此天子之剑也。 文王芒然自失，曰：诸侯之剑何如。 曰：诸侯之剑，以知勇士为锋，以清廉士为锷，以贤良士为脊，以忠圣士为镡，以豪杰士为铗。 此剑直之亦无前，举之亦无上，案之亦无下，运之亦无旁。 上法圆天，以顺三光，下法方地，以顺四时，中知民意，以安四乡。 此剑一用，如雷霆之震也，四封之内无不宾服而听从君命者矣。 此诸侯之剑也。 王曰：庶人之剑何如。 曰：庶人之剑，蓬头突鬓垂冠，曼胡之缨，短后之衣，瞋目而语难。 相击於前、上斩颈领，下决肝肺。 此庶人之剑无异於斗鸡，一日一命已绝矣，无所用於国事。 今大王有天子之位而好庶人之剑，臣窃为大王薄之。 王乃牵而上殿，宰人上食，王三环之。 庄子曰：大王安坐定气，剑事已毕奏矣。 於是文王不出宫三月，剑士皆服毙其处也。 喜剑者，喜剑斗之戏也。 夹门，拥门也。 以剑术之士而客於王之门者，三千余人。 以币从者，言以此为从者之奉也，犹今人言犒从也。 蓬头突发，露其发与鬓也。 垂冠，不高其冠，如今包巾也。 缨，绕於项下者也。 曼胡，粗鲁也。 短后，不襜也。 语难者，欲斗之时以语相诘难也。 示以虚开，以利与其进也。 后发而先至，鸷鸟将击必匿之势也。 设戏，设剑戏也。 敦剑者，敦断也，以剑相击也。 御杖，御，用也，杖，执也。 锋，剑首也。 锷，刃也。 镡，剑口也。 铗，剑把也。 裹以四时，言用之有时也。 制以五行，顺五行之理也。 日为德，月为刑，日月阴阳，春夏秋冬，皆顺造化自然之意。 直之举之，案之运之，上决下绝，皆形容其所用广大之意。 芒然自失者，闻其所言之大，觉其所好之浅，故自失也。 上法天，下法地，中和民意，即天时地利人和也。 四乡，四方也。 牵而上殿者，挽之而上也。 三环者，不坐而行，环所食之地三匝也。 此自愧之意也。 服与伏同，王既不用此戏，剑士皆退伏自毙於其所居之处也。 南华真经口义卷之三十竟 #1情性：明本作『性情』。 #2世：原作『母』据明本改。 #3为：原作『而』，据明本改。 #4贤：明本作『圣』。 #5长：原作『民』，据明本改。 #6之：原作『一』，据明本改。 南华真经口义卷之三十一 鬳斋林希逸

He was lodged in the guest quarters to await the king’s command. The king then ordered a sword exhibition to be arranged and invited the Master. Over seven days, the king assembled swordsmen, of whom over sixty were killed or wounded, leaving only five or six. These were made to present their swords at the palace steps, and then Zhuangzi was summoned.

The king said, “Today, let us have the warriors test their swords in contest.”

Zhuangzi replied, “I have long awaited this.”

The king asked, “What length of weapon does the Master wield?”

Zhuangzi said, “Any length I am given will suffice. Yet I possess three swords, and whichever the king chooses to employ, I shall first describe and then demonstrate.”

The king said, “I would hear of the three swords.”

Zhuangzi said, “There is the Sword of the Son of Heaven, the Sword of the Feudal Lords, and the Sword of the Common Folk.”

The king asked, “What is the Sword of the Son of Heaven like?”

Zhuangzi said, “The Sword of the Son of Heaven has its blade forged from Yanxi and Shicheng, its edge from Mount Tai of Qi, its spine from Jin and Wei, its guard from Zhou and Song, and its hilt from Han and Wei. It is bound by the Four Barbarians, wrapped in the Four Seasons, encircled by the Bohai Sea, and girded by Mount Chang. Its governance follows the Five Phases, its judgments balance punishment and virtue, its opening aligns with yin and yang, its grasp is held in spring and summer, and its execution proceeds in autumn and winter. This sword, when thrust, knows no forward obstacle; when raised, knows no height above; when pressed, knows no depth below; when swung, knows no side beside. Above, it cleaves the floating clouds; below, it severs the earth’s foundations. When this sword is once employed, it rectifies the feudal lords, and all under heaven submits. Such is the Sword of the Son of Heaven.”

King Wen, dazed and self-abashed, asked, “And what of the Sword of the Feudal Lords?”

Zhuangzi said, “The Sword of the Feudal Lords has its blade in the wisdom and courage of knights, its edge in the purity and integrity of scholars, its spine in the worthiness and goodness of gentlemen, its guard in the loyalty and sagacity of ministers, and its hilt in the heroism and valor of warriors. This sword, when thrust, likewise knows no forward obstacle; when raised, no height above; when pressed, no depth below; when swung, no side beside. Above, it models the round heavens, following the Three Luminaries; below, it models the square earth, aligning with the Four Seasons; within, it discerns the people’s will, bringing peace to the four quarters. When this sword is once employed, it strikes like the thunder’s shock, and within the four borders, none fail to submit and heed their lord’s command. Such is the Sword of the Feudal Lords.”

The king asked, “And what of the Sword of the Common Folk?”

Zhuangzi said, “The Sword of the Common Folk is wielded by those with disheveled hair and unkempt topknots, their caps askew, their tassels coarse and rough, their robes short and trailing. They glare fiercely and speak in challenge. They clash before one another, striking above at necks and throats, below at livers and lungs. This sword of the common folk differs not from cockfighting—one life is lost in a day, and it serves no purpose in the affairs of state. Now, though Your Majesty holds the position of the Son of Heaven, you delight in the sword of the common folk. I humbly deem this unworthy of Your Majesty.”

Thereupon, the king led Zhuangzi up to the hall. The royal steward presented the feast, and the king circled the table thrice. Zhuangzi said, “May Your Majesty sit composed and settle your qi. The matter of the sword has now been presented in full.”

From that day, King Wen did not leave the palace for three months, and the swordsmen all prostrated themselves and perished where they stood. Those who delighted in the sword were fond of such swordplay as sport. To "flank the gates" means to crowd the gates. Over three thousand swordsmen, treating their swordsmanship as a profession, were retained as guests at the king’s gates. "With gifts as followers" refers to those who received such offerings as their stipend, akin to what is now called "rewarding followers." "Disheveled hair and unkempt topknots" describes their hair and sideburns left exposed. "Caps askew" means their headgear was not properly raised, like a wrapped kerchief today. "Tassels" are what hang beneath the neck. "Coarse and rough" describes their uncouth manner. "Short and trailing robes" means their garments were not hemmed. "Speaking in challenge" refers to their verbal provocations when seeking combat. "Displaying emptiness and enticing with advantage" means luring the opponent forward with an opening. "Striking after the opponent moves yet arriving first" describes the raptor’s crouch before it strikes. "Arranging the exhibition" means setting up the swordplay display. "Testing swords" refers to the decisive clash of blades. "Wielding the weapon" means to use and grasp it. "Blade" refers to the sword’s tip. "Edge" is the cutting part. "Guard" is the sword’s mouth. "Hilt" is the sword’s handle. "Wrapped in the Four Seasons" signifies its use is timely. "Governed by the Five Phases" means it follows the principles of the Five Phases. The sun represents virtue, the moon punishment; the sun and moon embody yin and yang, and spring, summer, autumn, and winter all accord with the natural order of creation. "Thrusting, raising, pressing, and swinging" all describe the sword’s vast and boundless application. "Dazed and self-abashed" means that upon hearing such grand discourse, the king realized the shallowness of his own preferences and thus felt abashed. chunks.original_text: 杂篇渔父 孔子游乎缁帷之林，休坐乎杏坛之上。 弟子读书，孔子弦歌鼓琴，奏曲未半，有渔父者下舡而来，鬓眉交白，被发揄袂。 行原以上，距陆而止，左手据膝，右手持颐以听。 曲终而招子贡子路，二人俱对，客指孔子曰：彼何为者也。 子路对曰：鲁之君子也。 客问其族。 子路对曰：族孔氏。 客曰：孔氏者何治也。 子路未应，子贡对曰：孔氏者，性服忠信，身行仁义，饰礼乐，选人伦，上以忠於世主，下以化於齐民，将以利天下，此孔氏之所治也。 又问曰：有土之君与。 子贡曰：非也。 侯王之佐与。 子贡曰：非也。 客乃笑而还，行言曰：仁则仁矣，恐不兔其身。 苦心劳形以危其真，呜呼远哉，其分於道也。 子贡还报孔子，孔子推琴而起曰：其圣人与。 乃下求之，至於泽畔。 方将杖挐而引其船，顾见孔子还乡而立。 孔子反走，再拜而进。 客曰：子将何求。 孔子曰：曩者先生有绪言而去，丘不肖未知。 所谓窃待於下风，幸闻咳唾之音，以卒相丘也。 客曰：嘻，甚矣，子之好学也。 孔子再拜而起曰：丘少而修学以至於今，六十九岁矣。 无所得闻至教，敢不虚心。 客曰：同类相从，同声相应，固天之理也。 吾请释吾之所有，而经子之所以。 子之所以者，人事也。 天子、诸侯、大夫、庶人，此四者，自正治之美也。 四者离位而乱莫大焉。 官治其职，人忧其事，乃无所陵。 故田荒室露，衣食不足，征赋不属，妻妾不和，长少无序，庶人之忧也。 能不胜任，官事不治，行不清白，群下荒怠，功美不有，爵禄不持，大夫之忧也。 廷无忠臣，国家昏乱，工技不巧，贡职不美，春秋后伦，不顺天子，诸侯之忧也。 阴阳不和，寒暑不时，以伤庶物，诸侯暴乱，擅相攘伐，以残民人，礼乐不节，财用穷匮，人伦不饰，百姓淫乱，天子有司之忧也。 今子既上无君侯有司之势，而下无大臣职事之官，而擅饰礼乐，选人伦，以化齐民，不泰多事乎。 且人有八疵，事有四患，不可不察也。 非其事而事之谓之总； 莫之顾而进之谓之佞； 希意导言谓之谄； 不择是非而言谓之谀； 好言人之恶谓之谗； 析交离亲谓之贼； 称誉诈伪以败恶人谓之慝； 不择善否，两容颜适，偷拔其所欲，谓之险。 此八疵者，外以乱人，内以伤身，君子不友，明君不臣。 所谓四患者，好经大事，变更易常，以挂功名，谓之叨； 专知擅事，侵人自用，谓之贪； 见过不更，闻谏愈甚，谓之狠； 人同於己则可，不同於己，虽善不善，谓之矜。 此四患也。 能去八疵，无行四患，而始可教已。 缁帷，林名也。 愉袂，扬袂也。 选人伦者，柬选其理以教人也。 行言者，不告子贡子路而去，行且言也。 远哉其分於道者，言其离於道远也。 挐，船篙也。 反走，退行数步而后进也。 绪言，微言也，谓其略言而未尽也。 卒相某者，言终以教助某也。 同类相从，同声相应者，言此理人人同得之也。 释吾之所有者，言释去吾所有之道也。 经子之所以者，条陈世人之所宜知也。 释，放下不说也。 经，条陈也。 四者自正，各任其职也； 四者离位，相侵其事也。 一官各治其一职，人人各忧其所事。 忧，思也。 诗曰职思其忧是也。 乃无所陵，乃不相陵夺也。 征赋不属，不属，不继也。
chunks.translated_text:
**Miscellaneous Chapters: The Fisherman**

Confucius wandered in the Ziwei Forest and rested, sitting upon the Apricot Platform. His disciples read their books while Confucius strummed his zither and sang, playing a melody not yet halfway through when a fisherman descended from his boat and approached. His temples and brows were mingled with white, his hair unbound, and his sleeves swaying as he walked. Ascending from the marshland, he stopped at the shore, his left hand resting on his knee, his right hand supporting his chin, listening. When the song ended, he beckoned to Zilu and Zigong. Both responded, and the stranger pointed at Confucius, asking, “What is that man doing?”

Zilu replied, “He is a gentleman of Lu.”

The stranger asked about his clan.

Zilu answered, “His clan is Kong.”

“And what does the Kong clan govern?”

Zilu did not respond, but Zigong answered, “The Kong clan cultivates loyalty and trust in nature, embodies benevolence and righteousness in conduct, refines ritual and music, and selects the principles of human relations. Above, they serve the rulers of the age with loyalty; below, they transform the common people, seeking to benefit the world. This is what the Kong clan governs.”

The stranger then asked, “Is he a lord with lands?”

Zigong said, “No.”

“Is he an advisor to kings and princes?”

Zigong said, “No.”

The stranger laughed and turned away, walking off as he spoke: “Benevolent, indeed, he is—but I fear he will not escape harm to himself. His heart labors and his form toils, endangering his true nature. Alas, how far he is from the Dao!”

Zigong returned and reported this to Confucius. Confucius pushed aside his zither and rose, saying, “Is he a sage?” He then descended to seek him, reaching the marsh’s edge. The fisherman was just then poising his pole to draw his boat when he turned and saw Confucius standing with his face toward home. Confucius retreated a few steps, then advanced and bowed twice.

The stranger said, “What do you seek?”

Confucius replied, “Earlier, sir, you left with words unfinished. I, unworthy as I am, did not understand. I have secretly waited here, hoping to hear even the sound of your cough or sigh, that I might receive your instruction to the end.”

The stranger said, “Ah! How earnest is your love of learning!”

Confucius bowed twice and rose, saying, “From my youth I have cultivated learning until now, at sixty-nine years of age. Yet I have never heard the ultimate teaching. How dare I not be humble in heart?”

The stranger said, “Like attracts like, and like sounds resonate—this is the principle of heaven. Let me set aside what I possess and explain to you what you should know. What you should know concerns human affairs. The Son of Heaven, the feudal lords, the great officers, and the common people—these four ranks are the perfection of proper governance. If these four abandon their positions, no greater disorder can arise. When officials govern their duties and people attend to their tasks, none encroach upon another. Thus, fields lie fallow and homes stand exposed, clothing and food are insufficient, taxes and levies are unmet, wives and concubines are discordant, and elders and juniors lack order—these are the worries of the common people. Inability to fulfill one’s role, official duties left undone, conduct that is not pure, subordinates who are negligent, achievements unrecognized, ranks and emoluments unstable—these are the worries of the great officers. The court lacks loyal ministers, the state is benighted and disordered, craftsmen lack skill, tribute is unworthy, seasonal rites are delayed or out of order, and the Son of Heaven is not obeyed—these are the worries of the feudal lords. Yin and yang are not in harmony, cold and heat arrive untimely, harming all things; feudal lords act with violence and disorder, seizing and attacking one another, ravaging the people; ritual and music lack moderation, resources are exhausted, human relations are unrefined, and the hundred clans are licentious—these are the worries of the Son of Heaven’s ministers.

Now, you possess neither the authority of a lord or minister above nor the office of a great officer below, yet you presume to refine ritual and music, select the principles of human relations, and transform the common people. Is this not overreaching?

Moreover, people have eight flaws, and affairs have four perils—these cannot be left unexamined.

To meddle in affairs that are not one’s own is called *zong* (meddlesomeness);
To advance where none heed you is called *ning* (obsequiousness);
To guide speech by anticipating others’ wishes is called *chan* (flattery);
To speak without discerning right or wrong is called *yu* (sycophancy);
To delight in speaking of others’ faults is called *chan* (slander);
To sever friendships and divide kin is called *zei* (treachery);
To praise falsely and deceive, leading others to ruin, is called *te* (depravity);
To fail to distinguish good from bad, accommodating both sides, stealthily seizing what one desires, is called *xian* (perfidy).

These eight flaws externally confuse others and internally harm oneself. The noble person does not befriend such people, nor does the enlightened ruler employ them.

As for the four perils:
To love undertaking great affairs, altering and changing the constant, seeking to hang one’s name upon achievements, is called *tao* (presumptuousness);
To monopolize knowledge, arrogate affairs, encroach upon others, and act on one’s own, is called *tan* (greed);
To see one’s faults yet not change, and to hear admonition yet grow worse, is called *hen* (obduracy);
To approve of what accords with oneself and disapprove of what does not, even if it is good, is called *jin* (arrogance).

These are the four perils. Only when one has cast off the eight flaws and refrains from the four perils can one begin to be taught.

*Ziwei* is the name of the forest. *Yumei* means to swing one’s sleeves. *Selecting human relations* means choosing their principles to teach people. *Walking and speaking* means departing without telling Zigong and Zilu, speaking as he went. *How far he is from the Dao* means he is distant from the Dao. *Na* is a boat pole. *Retreating and walking* means stepping back a few paces before advancing. *Unfinished words* refers to brief remarks that were not exhaustive. *To the end assist so-and-so* means to ultimately teach and aid that person. *Like attracts like, like sounds resonate* means this principle is shared by all people. *Setting aside what I possess* means putting aside the Dao I possess. *Explaining what you should know* means systematically presenting what people ought to know. *Setting aside* means to let go and not speak of it. *Systematically presenting* means to arrange in order. The *four ranks being proper* means each fulfills its duty; the *four ranks abandoning their positions* means they encroach upon one another’s affairs. Each office governs its own duty, and each person attends to their own task. *Worry* means to think. The *Book of Songs* says, “In office, think of its worries.” *None encroach upon another* means none usurp or seize from one another. *Taxes and levies unmet* means they are not continuous.

chunks.original_text: 功美不有，无功也。 不持，不能持守也。 春秋后伦，朝觐失序也。 天子有司，天子之公卿也。 非其事而事之谓之总，非己事而强为之自兜揽也。 莫之顾而进之，不使之言而强进其言，逞口才也，佞，口才也。 析，离他人之交亲。 贼，害之也。 称誉诈伪者，誉其所不当誉，私为欺诈也。 败恶，犹毁辱也。 毁其所不当毁也。 毁誉出於私意，为奸而已矣。 匿，奸也。 以颜色投人之好曰颜适。 无善无恶皆欲其悦已，故曰两容。 揣人意之所欲而潜引拔之，长其恶也，此险人也。 八疵者，言八者皆大疵病。 君子不友者，君子不当与之友也。 明君不臣者，小人勿用，必乱邦也。 好经大事，喜经理国家大事也。 纷更变异，以易其常法，自欲高立功名，挂，高也。 叨，忝也。 专用其私智，独擅其事任，侵人之权而喜於自用，贪者也。 狠，狠戾而不受谏也。 他人虽有善，以其不同己亦以为不善，自矜夸也。 此四者，人之大息也。 能去此疵患，方可学道，故曰始可教已。 凡此皆子处人世所宜用者，故曰子之所以。 以者，用以自检点#l也。 孔子愀然而叹，再拜而起曰：丘再逐於鲁，削迹於卫，伐树於宋，围於陈蔡。 丘不知所失而离此四谤者，何也。 客凄然变容曰：甚矣，子之难悟也。 人有畏影恶迹而去之走者，举足愈数而迹愈多，走愈疾而影不离身，自以为尚迟，疾走不休，绝力而死。 不知处阴以休影，处静以息迹，愚亦甚矣。 子审仁义之间，察同异之际，观动静之变，适受与之度，理好恶之情，和喜怒之节，而几於不免矣。 谨修而身，慎守其真，还以物与人，则无所累矣。 今不修之身而求之人，不亦外乎。 不知所失者，言不知何过也。 四谤，鲁卫宋陈蔡四辱也。 处阴处静，道之喻也。 审仁义之间，辩说仁义不同之理也。 同异之际，是非之分也。 动静之变，随时之宜也。 受与之度，辞受之节也。 好恶之情，喜怒之节，讲明情性之理也。 渔父之意，谓夫子之为此，皆为人而非为己，所以不免於四谤。 若修其身而守其本真自然之道，而无物我之对，则无所累矣。 还以物与人者，言以外物还之於人而一归之自然，则物我不对立也。 今不求之於身，而汲汲於为人，是务外而不务内也。 孔子愀然曰：请问何谓真。 客曰：真者，精诚之至也。 不精不诚，不能动人。 故强哭者虽悲不哀，强怒者虽严不威，强亲者虽笑不和。 真悲无声而哀，真怒未发而威，真亲未笑而和，真在内者神动於外。 是所以贵真也。 其用於人理也，事亲则慈孝，事君则忠贞，饮酒则欢乐，处丧则悲哀。 忠贞以功为主，饮酒以乐为主，处丧以哀为主，事亲以适为主。 功成之美，无一其似乎矣； 事亲以适，不论所以矣； 饮酒以乐，不选其具矣； 处丧以哀，无问其礼矣。 礼者，世俗之所为也； 真者，所以受於天也，自然不可易也。 故圣人法天贵真，不拘於俗。 愚者反此，不能法天而恤於人，不知贵真，禄禄而受变於俗，故不足。 惜哉，子之早湛於人伪而晚闻大道也。 不精不诚，不能动人，即至诚感神之意也。 强哭强怒强亲，真悲真怒真亲，此六句甚精切。 真在内者，神动於外，言有诸中必形诸外。 神动者，精神感动於外也。 事亲以适者，适亲意也。

Not claiming credit for achievements is to have no merit. *Not holding fast* means being unable to maintain and guard. *Spring and Autumn out of order* means the sequence of court audiences is lost. *The Son of Heaven’s officials* refers to the Son of Heaven’s dukes and ministers. *Taking up what is not one’s affair* is called meddling—presuming to handle what is not one’s own business. *Advancing without being heeded* means forcing one’s words forward without being asked, flaunting one’s eloquence. *Flattery* is glib speech. *Sowing discord* means severing others’ close relationships. *Harming* means to injure. *False praise* means praising what should not be praised, a private act of deception. *Slandering* is like disgracing—destroying what should not be destroyed. When slander and praise arise from private motives, they are nothing but treachery. *Concealing* is deceit. *Adapting one’s countenance to others’ preferences* is called *facial compliance*. *Pleasing all without distinction* means courting favor with both good and bad alike, hence *two-faced*. *Probing others’ desires and subtly encouraging them* fosters their faults—such a person is treacherous. These *eight flaws* refer to eight grave moral diseases. *The noble person does not befriend them*—the noble person should not associate with such people. *The enlightened ruler does not employ them*—petty men must not be used, for they will surely throw the state into chaos.

*Delighting in great affairs* means taking pleasure in managing the state’s major matters. *Constantly altering and changing* means altering established laws to set up one’s own high reputation—*hanging* means elevating. *Presumptuous* means shameful. *Relying solely on private judgment*, monopolizing authority, encroaching on others’ power while delighting in self-assertion—this is greed. *Obstinate* means stubborn and refusing admonition. *Even when others have virtue*, if it differs from one’s own, one deems it unvirtuous—this is self-aggrandizement. These *four* are humanity’s great failings. Only by removing these flaws and perils can one begin to study the Dao, hence it is said, “Only then may one be taught.”

All these are what you should employ in navigating the world, hence it is said, “what you should use.” *Employing* means using them to examine oneself.

Confucius sighed deeply, bowed twice, and rose, saying: “I was twice exiled from Lu, my traces erased in Wei, my tree felled in Song, and I was besieged in Chen and Cai. I do not know what fault of mine brought these four slanders upon me—why was this?”

The guest’s expression turned somber as he replied: “How difficult it is for you to awaken! There was a man who feared his shadow and loathed his footprints, so he ran to escape them. The more he lifted his feet, the more footprints he made; the faster he ran, the more his shadow clung to him. Believing he was still too slow, he ran without rest until he collapsed and died. He did not know that by standing in the shade he could rest his shadow, and by remaining still he could cease his footprints—how utterly foolish!

You scrutinize the boundaries between benevolence and righteousness, examine the divisions of similarity and difference, observe the changes of movement and stillness, adjust the measures of giving and receiving, order the passions of like and dislike, and harmonize the moderation of joy and anger—yet you nearly could not avoid calamity. If you carefully cultivate yourself and guard your true nature, returning things to others, you will have no encumbrances. Now, instead of cultivating yourself, you seek from others—is this not misplaced?

*Not knowing what fault* means not knowing what error was committed. The *four slanders* refer to the four humiliations in Lu, Wei, Song, Chen, and Cai. *Standing in shade, remaining still*—this is a metaphor for the Dao. *Scrutinizing the boundaries between benevolence and righteousness* means debating the differing principles of benevolence and righteousness. *The divisions of similarity and difference* refer to the distinctions of right and wrong. *The changes of movement and stillness* mean adapting to the needs of the time. *The measures of giving and receiving* refer to the moderation of accepting and declining. *The passions of like and dislike, the moderation of joy and anger*—these clarify the principles of human nature.

The Fisherman’s meaning is that your actions, Master, are all for others rather than for yourself, which is why you could not escape the four slanders. If you cultivate yourself and guard your original, natural Dao, without opposition between self and others, you will have no encumbrances. *Returning things to others* means giving external things back to others and returning wholly to nature, so that self and others do not stand in opposition. Now, instead of seeking within yourself, you rush about serving others—this is attending to externals rather than internals.”

Confucius sighed deeply and said: “May I ask what is meant by *the true*?”

The guest replied: “The true is the utmost of sincerity. Without purity and sincerity, one cannot move others. Thus, forced weeping, though sorrowful, is not mournful; forced anger, though stern, lacks awe; forced affection, though smiling, is not harmonious. True sorrow is silent yet mournful; true anger, though unexpressed, is awe-inspiring; true affection, though not smiling, is harmonious. When the true resides within, the spirit moves without—this is why the true is prized.

Applied to human affairs: serving parents, it is filial devotion; serving a lord, it is loyalty; drinking wine, it is joy; mourning, it is grief. Loyalty is centered on accomplishment; drinking wine, on joy; mourning, on grief; serving parents, on suitability. When accomplishment is perfected, none resemble it; serving parents with suitability disregards the means; drinking wine with joy disregards the vessels; mourning with grief disregards the rites.

Rites are what the common customs establish; the true is what one receives from Heaven, natural and unalterable. Thus the sage models Heaven and prizes the true, not bound by custom. The foolish do the opposite: they cannot model Heaven but worry about people, not prizing the true, blindly following custom’s changes—hence they are inadequate. Alas! You were early immersed in human artifice and late to hear the great Dao.

Without purity and sincerity, one cannot move others—this is the meaning of utmost sincerity moving the spirits. *Forced weeping, forced anger, forced affection; true sorrow, true anger, true affection*—these six phrases are most precise. *When the true resides within, the spirit moves without*—what is within must manifest without. *The spirit moving* means the spirit is outwardly affected.

*Serving parents with suitability* means suiting the parents’ wishes.”

chunks.original_text: 功成之美，无一其迹者，成而不有，无一事而有其迹也。 不选其具者，不择其味也。 无问其礼，与其易也，宁戚也。 礼者，文饰於外，故曰世俗之为。 真者，天命自然之理也。 法天贵真而不拘於俗者，不以非世俗之所好为拘也。 恤於人者，忧不与人合也。 不知天爵之贵，故曰不知贵真。 以世俗之禄为禄，而甘为流俗所化，故曰禄禄而受变於俗。 如此之人，但见其不足，言常慊然也。 湛於人为，溺於务外之学也。 孔子又再拜而起曰：今者丘得遇也。 若天幸然，先生不羞而比之服役，而身教之，敢问舍#2所在，请因受业而卒学大道。 客曰：吾闻之可与往者，与之至於妙道； 不可与往者，不知其道，慎勿与之，身乃无咎。 子勉之，吾去子矣，吾去子矣。 乃刺船而去，延缘苇间。 颜渊还车，子路授绥，孔子不顾，待水波定不闻挐音而后敢乘。 子路旁车而问曰：由得为役久矣，未尝见夫子遇人如此其威也。 万乘之主，千乘之君，见夫子未尝不分庭伉礼，夫子犹有#3倨傲之容。 今渔父杖挐逆立而夫子曲要磬折，再拜而应，得无大甚乎。 门人皆怪夫子矣，渔父何以得此乎。 孔子伏轼而叹曰：甚矣，由之难化也。 湛於礼义有间矣，而朴鄙之心至今未去。 进，吾语汝。 夫遇长不敬，失礼也； 见贤不尊，不仁也。 彼非至人不能下人，下人不精不得其真，故长伤身。 惜哉，不仁之於人也。 祸莫大焉，而由独擅之。 且道者，万物之所由也。 庶物失之者死，得之者生。 为事逆之则败，顺之则成。 故道之所在，圣人尊之。 今渔父之於道可谓有矣，吾敢不敬乎。 比之服役，言比之弟子也。 舍所在，问其居也。 延缘苇间，以桡撑舟沿岸而去也。 此四字画笔也。 水波定，舟去远也。 如此其威者，言如此其敬畏之也。 逆立，对面立也。 拜而应者，手揖曰拜也。 湛於礼义有间者，言汝浸润於礼义之学亦有时矣。 彼非至人不能下人者，彼渔父若非至人岂能使人如此降下而尊敬之也。 下人不精不得其真者，推诚自届以求教於人，庶几可闻真实之诲也。 此一句乃为学之本。 故长伤身者，言不如此则无益於身而有损也。 万物之死生皆在一道之中，渔父有道者也，吾尊其道所以敬之。 自让王以下四篇，其文不类庄子所作。 让王篇中犹有一二段，渔父篇亦有好处，盗跖篇比之说剑又疏真矣。 锯盗跖篇今谓宰相曰，战国之时，未有称宰相者，此为后人私撰明甚。 前汉艺文志，庄子五十二篇，其篇数与今不同。 唐书只四十卷，即今行於世者，不知所谓五十二篇者，更有让王说剑之类乎。 抑犹有庄子所作而不传者乎。 杂篇列御寇 列御寇之齐，中道而反，遇伯昏瞀人。 伯昏瞀人曰：奚方而反。 曰：吾惊焉。 曰：恶乎惊。 曰：吾尝食於十浆而五浆先馈。 伯昏瞀人曰：若是则汝何为惊已。 曰：夫内诚不解，形谋成光，以外镇人心，使人轻乎贵老，而其所患。 夫浆人特为食羹之货，多余之嬴，其为利也薄，其为权也轻，而犹若是，而况於万乘之主乎。 身劳於国而知尽於事，彼将任我以事而效我以功，吾是以惊。 伯昏瞀人曰：善哉观乎。 汝处己，人将保汝矣。 无几何而往，则户外之屦满矣。 伯昏瞀人北面而立，敦杖蹙之乎颐，立有间，不言而出。

The beauty of accomplishment leaves no trace—it is achieved yet unpossessed, with no single act bearing its mark. *"Not selecting its instruments"* means not choosing its flavors. *"Without inquiring into its rites"*—between ease and sorrow, sorrow is preferable. Rites are mere adornments of externals, hence called the creations of worldly custom. The true is the principle of Heaven’s natural mandate. *"Modeling Heaven and prizing the true without being bound by custom"* means not being constrained by what worldly custom favors. *"Worrying about people"* means fretting over failing to conform to others. Not knowing the nobility of Heaven’s rank, one *"does not know to prize the true."* Taking worldly emoluments as one’s reward and willingly being transformed by vulgar custom—this is *"blindly following custom’s changes."* Such people are always seen as inadequate, their demeanor perpetually dissatisfied. *"Immersed in human artifice"* means drowning in learning that pursues externals.

Confucius bowed twice and rose, saying: *"Today I have been fortunate indeed. As if blessed by Heaven, you have not disdained to treat me as a servant, instructing me in person. Dare I ask where you dwell? I would follow and receive your teachings to complete my study of the great Dao."*

The stranger replied: *"I have heard that those who can be led may be guided to the subtle Dao; those who cannot be led do not understand the Way—beware of accompanying them, lest you bring harm upon yourself. Strive on, I leave you now, I leave you now."* With that, he poled his boat away, gliding along the reeds. Yan Yuan turned the carriage, and Zilu handed the reins, but Confucius did not look back, waiting until the water’s ripples stilled and the sound of the pole could no longer be heard before daring to board.

Zilu stepped beside the carriage and asked: *"I have long served you, yet never have I seen you meet someone with such reverence. Even rulers of ten thousand chariots or lords of a thousand, when they receive you, do not fail to observe proper courtesy, yet you still carry yourself with dignity. But today, this old fisherman stood with his staff facing you, and you bent at the waist, bowing deeply in response—was this not excessive? The disciples all find it strange. How has this fisherman earned such deference?"*

Confucius leaned on the crossbar and sighed: *"How difficult you are to transform, Zilu! You have been steeped in rites and righteousness for some time, yet your crude and rustic heart remains unchanged. Come closer, let me tell you: to meet an elder without respect is a breach of ritual; to meet a worthy without reverence is a lack of benevolence. If he were not a perfected person, he could not humble himself before others. Without utmost sincerity in humbling oneself, one cannot attain the true—thus one harms oneself for long. Alas, the lack of benevolence in a person! No greater misfortune exists, yet you alone cling to it. Moreover, the Dao is the path by which all things proceed. All beings that lose it die; those that attain it live. Acting against it brings failure; following it brings success. Thus, wherever the Dao resides, the sage honors it. This fisherman possesses the Dao—how could I not revere him? Comparing myself to a servant means treating him as a disciple. Asking where he dwells means inquiring about his abode. Gliding along the reeds describes poling the boat along the shore—a vivid four-character brushstroke. Waiting for the water’s ripples to still means the boat had gone far. 'Such reverence' refers to such awe and respect. 'Facing me' means standing directly opposite. Bowing in response means clasping hands in a bow. 'Steeped in rites and righteousness for some time' means you have long been immersed in the study of ritual and righteousness. 'If he were not a perfected person, he could not humble himself'—if this fisherman were not a perfected person, how could he elicit such deference and reverence? 'Without utmost sincerity in humbling oneself, one cannot attain the true'—only by wholeheartedly lowering oneself to seek instruction can one hope to hear true teachings. This is the foundation of learning. 'Thus one harms oneself for long' means that failing to do so brings no benefit to the self but only harm. The life and death of all things lie within the Dao, and the fisherman possesses it—thus I honor the Dao by revering him."*

From *"Yielding the Throne"* onward, the four chapters do not resemble Zhuangzi’s style. *"Yielding the Throne"* still contains one or two passages of merit, and *"The Old Fisherman"* also has its strengths, but *"Robber Zhi"* is even more distant from the truth than *"Discourse on Swords."* In *"Robber Zhi,"* the term *"prime minister"* is used, yet no such title existed in the Warring States period—this is clearly a later fabrication. The *Han Dynasty’s* *Art and Literature Annals* records fifty-two chapters of *Zhuangzi*, a number differing from the present text. The *Tang Dynasty* catalog lists only forty chapters, which are the ones now in circulation. It is unknown whether the fifty-two chapters included works like *"Yielding the Throne"* and *"Discourse on Swords,"* or if there were other chapters by Zhuangzi that have not survived.

When Lie Yukou was traveling to Qi, he turned back midway and encountered Bohun Maoren. Bohun Maoren asked: *"Why have you returned?"*

Lie Yukou replied: *"I was startled."*

*"What startled you?"*

*"I once drank at ten porridge stalls, and at five of them, they served me first."*

Bohun Maoren said: *"If that is so, why were you startled?"*

Lie Yukou replied: *"When inner sincerity is not dissolved, one’s demeanor shines with a radiant light, which externally pacifies others’ hearts, causing them to slight their elders and disregard their concerns. Those porridge-sellers merely peddle food and broth for profit—small gains from modest surpluses, their influence slight and their power light. Yet even they behaved thus—how much more so a ruler of ten thousand chariots? If I exhaust myself in service to the state and expend all my knowledge on affairs, he will entrust me with tasks and measure me by my achievements. That is why I was startled."*

Bohun Maoren said: *"A keen observation! If you conduct yourself thus, others will protect you."*

Not long after, when he went to visit, the shoes outside the door were piled high. Bohun Maoren stood facing north, leaning on his staff and pressing it against his chin. After standing for a while, he left without a word.

chunks.original_text: 宾者以告列子，列子提屦，跣而走，暨乎门，曰：先生既来，曾不发药乎。 曰：已矣。 吾固告汝曰人将保汝，果保汝矣。 非汝能使人保汝，而汝不能使人无保汝也，而焉用之，感豫出异也。 必且有感，摇而本性，又无谓也。 与汝游者又莫与告也，彼所小言，尽人毒也。 莫觉莫悟，何相孰也。 巧者劳而智者忧，无能者无所求，食而遨游，泛若不系之舟，虚而遨游者也。 奚方而反，言在何所而回也。 食於十浆而五浆先馈，其人敬己不待买而绩之。 和顺积中，英华发外，此圣门之言。 内诚不解，诚积於中而未化也。 解，化也。 谋，动也。 形谋，形容举动也。 成光者，有光仪也，即积中发外之意，而此以为有迹之学。 外镇人心者，镇服也。 言我未能无迹，故人得而见之，所以心服而敬我也。 赵州曰，老僧修行无力，为鬼神观破即此意也。 贵者老者，则人所敬我，今非老非贵，其人反轻彼而敬我，言敬己在於贵老之上也。 ，聚也，积也。 此等事积而久之必成患害，言名迹愈露则不能逃当世之患也。 多余之嬴，言其求利惟欲多，欲有余而已赢利也。 世之有力量者，则能轻重人。 卖浆，微者也，初无权力可以轻重人也，而能敬我如此，况为君者。 身方劳而智已竭，必将求我而用，使我效其成功，此所谓其所患也。 效，献也。 香人喜之，故曰善哉观乎。 言汝於此具一只眼也。 又曰汝止矣，谓不必出游矣，人将归向，守汝而为师矣。 处，止也。 已，助字也。 保，守也，归者，众而守其门也，此一保字便已有不足之意，盖瞀人之见又高一层也。 户外之屦满，从学者众也。 敦杖蹙之乎颐，坚立其杖而拄之於颐也。 蹙，拄也。 宾者，主宾客者也。 提屦而走，古人坐於席必脱屦而后入，急於善瞀人，故不及穿屦也。 发药者，言教诲开发而药石之。 已矣，休言之意。 我前此已言人将守汝矣，汝不能使人无保汝者，即所谓忘我易，使人忘我难也。 而焉用之者，言汝之所为何以至此者。 人之感动而悦豫於汝者，必汝不能自吃，使乖异出见乎其外而致然也，故曰感豫出异也。 汝既如此，非惟形见於外者不能自隐，必且感触摇动汝之本性，其於#4身尤无益也。 无谓即无益也。 又，尤之意也。
